name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Next point is the Commission statement - Initiatives taken in the framework of the ILO debate on the right to strike (2015/2553(RSP))

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, let me underline, in order to set the context, that the European Union and the International Labour Organisation (ILO) have a long record of good cooperation. Even more, the ILO is a key partner for our external policies.  The European Union promotes the ratification and implementation of ILO Conventions and relies on ILO supervision of labour standards, in particular core labour standards, and in the monitoring of trade association enlargement and development agreements. Therefore, having a well-functioning ILO standard supervisory system is important for us since its conclusions are crucial to assessing compliance with international labour standards. And here we have a problem, due to the fact that since 2012 the supervision of labour standards cannot be carried out properly.  Why not? Because employers’ and workers’ representatives at the ILO disagree on whether or not the right to strike is protected under ILO Fundamental Convention No 87, the Convention concerning Freedom of Association and Protection of the Right to Organise Convention. Secondly, employers’ and workers’ representatives also disagree on the capacity of the ILO supervisory bodies to decide on the scope of the right to strike, its limits and the conditions for its legitimate exercise. Beyond this there is, as well, a risk of endangering the tripartite relationships and weakening the ILO supervisory system.  As the Commissioner in charge of relations with the International Labour Organisation, I am deeply concerned about these developments and that is why I followed the discussion at the ILO very closely. I personally met the ILO Director-General, Mr Guy Ryder, last week who informed me of the most recent developments. However, as you know, the European Union is only an observer at the ILO. The Commission will therefore not intervene on the substance of the discussion. These matters fall within the competence of the Member States.  The recognition of the right to strike in ILO Convention No 87 is a delicate matter. At the last session of the ILO Governing Body, also thanks to European Union coordination in approximating their positions, the EU Member States were ready to support the option of asking the International Court of Justice for a clarification of the matter so that we can move forward and resolve this pending disagreement between employers’ and workers’ representatives. A tripartite meeting will take place in the ILO between 23 February and 25 February, the last week of this month, to discuss the issue.  The Commission is ready to support all players and provide information to feed into the discussion, notably by retrieving information on the situation regarding the right to strike in the European Union. Let me remind you that the right to strike is recognised as a fundamental right in the European Union. The Commission and the EU Delegation in Geneva will support EU Member States and will help them to coordinate their positions and speak with one voice.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, Commissioner, it is clear that the right to strike is a fundamental right, constituting our democratic systems. Although it is not the direct competence of the European Union, there are many texts - such as the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union or the European Social Charter - which prove the Union's commitment to social dialogue and this right.  Article 28, the Charter of Fundamental Rights guarantees employees the right to negotiate and enter into collective agreements at appropriate levels and to resort, in the event of conflicts of interest, to collective actions in defence of their interests, including strike action. In this regard, the reference is clearly the International Labour Organization (ILO), and in particular its Convention No. 87, as well as the interpretation of the committee of experts, which is recognized at the world level.  To address problems that could arise in this area, the ILO has set up a freedom of association committee and also the Committee on the Application of Standards, with experts. Over the past 60 years, these bodies have worked perfectly, in an ideal way. They have always been recognized by the three components of the International Labour Organization and have made it possible to find compromises for the benefit of the various parties.  Unfortunately, since 2012, we have had to see that the process is somewhat overt and that the social partners are no longer able to reach an agreement. The European Union has always had a clear and wanted position to promote social dialogue. The current blockage is therefore problematic, in that it calls into question social dialogue.  I therefore hope that the Commission will do its utmost to weigh its weight in order to enable the ILO to break this deadlock. If, however, this is not possible, the only way will be to seek an opinion before the International Court of Justice in The Hague. I thank you, Commissioner, for the work you are doing and, by the way, I would like to take this opportunity to invite you to renew initiatives to relaunch social dialogue at European level.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her One thing ahead: we, the European Socialist Group, will not allow the right to strike to be softened! Mrs Thyssen, we share your assessment that it is really important that you influence the Member States in Europe and that you raise your voice within the ILO, because the right to strike – and your colleagues and you have also said so – is a fundamental right in Europe. The Social Charter is part of the Lisbon Treaty. We have learned in Europe that successful economies are those with a strong social partnership. But a strong social partnership also means: social partners on an equal footing. And eye-level also means that we have strong trade unions. This includes the right to strike. In recent years, there have been repeated attacks on the right to strike in Europe. Within the framework of the Troika, the right to strike in the crisis countries was also restricted by conditions. Time and again I hear and read about trends in Europe that there are institutions, parties and employers' associations that want to reform and weaken this right to strike. This weakens the negotiating basis of the trade unions. For us it is clear: Defend the beginnings! The attack on a first fundamental right in Europe can have a domino effect and also restrict other rights. We expect you to work to resolve the dispute within the ILO in the interests of the workers and to defend our fundamental European rights!

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, my apologies for being late. I understand fully the concerns of some people with regard to the right to strike. I think it is very important to bring together the interests of both employers and employees while negotiating, and also to have respect for subsidiarity. Companies should have the possibility to input their employees all over Europe so companies are able to compete with other companies in the Single market.  We would like to give them new opportunities for growth and companies should be protected against unfair competition through bad employers who escape their responsibilities. At the same time we should protect vulnerable employees. But it should not become almost impossible for honest companies to set up activities all over Europe.  Viewing the great difference between different Member States, we cannot have a one-size-fits all pattern; that does not work. We hope the Commission is aware of this and will also pay attention to the different approaches necessary in a partial, targeted revision of the Posted Workers Directive. In the framework of the agenda for better regulation,  I trust the Commission will take into account scientifically based risk assessments and will also take into consideration the parliaments’ expressions of concern in the past. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – I want to ask you, dear colleague, in relation to what you have said, that some employees want to get rid of their responsibilities, if you do not think it is important for employers to have responsibility, if there should not be a balance between the responsibility that employees and employers have, and ultimately it is employers who have to induce a way of working and conduct, and practically there is a good understanding between the two parties, and there cannot be one without the other.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: blue-card answer. – I fully agree with your view. I think we need to find the balance between the interests of employers and employees. I think we need to focus on the interests of business, and I think that the framework that we have to look at has to consider how companies can perform in an equalised market. This is the responsibility of national governments: to be the watchdogs on how the rules are implemented at a national level.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. –  Madam President, I would like to express my concern at the continuing disagreement on the interpretation of Convention No 87, the ILO Convention on the Freedom of Association and Protection of the Right to Organise. It now appears that employer groups within the ILO no longer support the interpretation of the Committee of Experts on this particular convention. The jurisprudence of the ILO has stood for 60 years on this convention and has interpreted the right to strike as an intrinsic corollary to the right to organise. This right has been recognised internationally as a fundamental right of workers and their organisations. The freedom to associate, to organise, to bargain collectively, make it possible to ensure decent working conditions. Collective bargaining is a mechanism that helps to ensure beneficial outcomes for workers and productive solutions for employers. Collective bargaining can only be achieved by the freedom to organise, and one of those freedoms is the right to strike – as a last resort, to withdraw labour. Without that right it is like having really good legislation in place but no sanctions for non-compliance. Collective bargaining has no proper foundation without the right to strike. With regard to the current situation, as the Commissioner said, there will be a tripartite meeting at the end of February to try to resolve the current impasse. You, Commissioner, have outlined very clearly the current situation and the willingness of the Commission to support all players by supplying information from the EU, where the right to strike is fundamental. However, cases like Rüffert, Laval, etc. and the thorny issue of the posting of workers may have sown some of the seeds of this dissent, and we need to finally sort out that matter. But I am heartened to hear of your commitment to finding a resolution. At a global level it is crucial.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, the right to strike is the strongest weapon for workers to defend their interests vis-à-vis employers and is explicitly enshrined in Article 28 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. In reality, however, european elites, seeking the ever-increasing bankruptcy of the world of work for the benefit of capital, are in every way trying to undermine this right as well as many others. Their representatives constantly demand compliance with what is agreed when it comes to financial management, but forget what is agreed when it comes to the protection of fundamental rights, in particular economic and social rights. A final example is the Troika's insistence, in the last negotiation with the previous Greek government, to abolish in practice the right to strike in Greece. The Troika has demanded the establishment of a law allowing a strike only if an absolute majority of workers are concentrated, which is impossible, especially in tertiary national trade unions. The Greek people, with their vote two weeks ago, gave a resounding message-response and will soon be followed by other European peoples. Europe must remain true to the values of fundamental rights on which it is supposed to be based, otherwise it will be in danger of falling apart.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. –  Madam President, like others, my Group really regrets this development within the ILO where we are seeing a move to roll back an agreement that stood for many years, and jurisprudence that stands; it almost beggars belief that this is actually going on in the 21st century. The Conventions, particularly Nos 87 and 98, are, as people have said, about the balance of power within the workplace and they represent hard fought-for rights. That struggle, as we know, is still going on in some of our Member States, but certainly in many countries throughout the world, in sectors such as mining, brick-making and textiles. So any rollback of the definition of these rights that people have has profound implications for those who care about human rights, about decent work and about fair competition. So I think that the employers’ group needs to seriously consider what message it is sending elsewhere in the world through this action. For the European Union, the ILO core Conventions are part of GSP+, increasingly part of our trade agreements and therefore, for us, they represent a whole set of values and a way of working. We want to end exploitation, we want an end to unfair competition, undercutting through labour standards. So we have to support the right of organised labour and that includes the right to withdraw labour without being sacked, black-listed, beaten up or even worse, in many countries of the world.  So the ILO has a crucial role to play here and that social partnership has a crucial role to demonstrate the sort of standards, the sort of progress that can be made through negotiation and, where necessary, the right to strike.  So I really hope the EU employers are recognising they should be leading here, in demonstrating what good standards are. I also hope that our Member State governments are going to support the continuing recognition of this fundamental right, both within the Union and outside it.

name: Laura AGEA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have always believed that this was an assize in which citizens' rights were the priority, where citizens' demands and voice were the first objective on which to work. Unfortunately, however, especially in recent years, citizens' rights have been buried by much biggest interests, by financial interests, by great speculation, and all this very often generates protest, generates a sense of dissatisfaction.  Let us not forget that there are so many citizens and workers in Europe, those who are still left, who live below the poverty line, people who have lost their jobs, people who have lost their homes, people who live on the streets, people who have nothing to feed their children, children who stop going to school. Protest is the consequence.  Of course, an attempt is being made to put a remedy and a stop to the people who are protesting. So we saw what happened last year in Greece, when teachers were protesting and the then Prime Minister denied the right to strike on the grounds that there could obviously be social unrest and with this excuse he took away the right to strike. I saw it with my own eyes a few months ago, in Rome, when the Ast workers went to protest the steel works crisis and were loaded by the police, they were beaten. I saw guys I knew well to be beaten. That's what can happen.  The right to strike is a sacrosanct right that no one can take away from anyone, which workers must see protected. I would expect that in 2015 those rights that have been won over by others, that have bequeathed them to us, were not even an opportunity for arguments or comparisons. The rights, the inalienable rights, those that we have won, those that others before us and for us have won, must not be taken away from people in the slightest. If there is a protest, there is no action on the protest, the causes of the protest will be resolved. I expect this from Europe.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: In the European Union, despite talk of values, in practice union membership and strike action are considered by employers and the state to be a crime. They are punishable by dismissal and other punishments. In Greece, most strikes are declared illegal and there are thousands of workers who have been recruited or dismissed for strike action. The European Union has asked Greece to limit the right to strike and to legalise the lockout, which the European Union recognises as the right of employers. The debate on limiting the right to strike action is heating up in all EU institutions, as demanded by the International Labour Office. The Modi initiative to ban strikes when claiming demands against the European Union's strategy has been postponed but is alive. Two truths are revealed: First truth: In all the states of the Union, whether through austerity or relaxation, the anti-labour attack escalates with structural reforms centred on the competitiveness of capital. Popular reactions are expected, measures are being taken to suppress them. Second truth: One is their fear: the working class, the organized people. No savior saves him. Only his organization and his struggle for his own rights, for development for the benefit of himself, not capital. Alas, if in history the struggle of the workers took the permission of their exploiters! The right to strike was conquered by struggles by the workers themselves. They will be protected and exploited for their own case. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: "blue card" question. – Mr President, as respectful and sacred as the right to strike is, so is the right to work. How do you judge the phenomenon of minority groups in a particular political space banning entry to employee companies, often by force, and the result being that in the end these companies are closed down and everyone is left without a job?

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: "blue card" answer. We didn't expect anything else from the Nazis of Golden Dawn. They're instruments of capital. They have relationships with specific employers. They're funded to terrorize workers, to work as contractors, as slave traders, to put down-and-do workers in the service of their bosses. These are the Nazis. That's their role. He's always been like that, and that's why they have to be condemned and isolated from the workers themselves.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Congressman, I'd like to thank you for your support. I'm closing this round of comments. No more blue cards for the same question. Congressman, I'm not going to give you the floor. I won't give you the floor! The following post... (...) No one understands you without a microphone.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Madam President, I very much welcomed the Commission's statement made by the Commissioner. I very much welcome her statement, because I consider the right to strike, like my pre-spokesmen, to be a key right that belongs to the democratic rule of law, so it is good that we are dealing with this issue here in plenary, that the European Commission will negotiate with the International Labour Organisation on the state of play with this organisation and that we will try to unblock the situation of social dialogue that is blocked with this organisation today. I think that this is the right form to support the International Labour Organisation, which is to be the main gestor and protectionist of this collective labour law on the European continent. On the other hand, I want to emphasise here what has also been said, that the right to strike should be regulated at national level in various national legal regimes, that we should respect the principle of subsidiarity here, and i am therefore glad that I did not notice from the Commissioner's speech that there should be an effort at European level under Community law to regulate certain aspects of the right to strike in the future. I just want to remember the failed initiative of the Monti II Regulation of 2012, which, as you know, most countries blocked by raising the yellow card, back then it was 12 Member States, I was then a member of the national government in the Czech Republic and I remember the heated debate that was associated with it and basically across the political spectrum in the Czech Republic both the Senate and the government clearly stood by the opinion that the principle of subsidiarity is to be applied here.  So the position, the EU's active position in relation to the International Labour Organisation, yes, that is very important, let us promote such active international protection of the right to strike, but please respect the positions of individual Member States and their legal systems here.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Madam President, in June 2012 the International Organisation of Employers walked into the ILO conference with their corporate lawyers in a grossly unprecedented move. After decades of jurisprudence, they challenged the fact that the right to strike was part of the ILO Convention on the Freedom of Association, and social dialogue on the international level has been gridlocked ever since.  These employers want to take away the only tool workers have in order to stand up for themselves. After the catastrophe in Dhaka, Bangladesh, in 2013 thousands of workers swamped the streets to demand safer working conditions. Because of the right to strike they were able to stand up for safe working conditions and against fraudulent employers. Also in Europe, we have seen workers’ rights being weakened by the crisis: social dialogue is under pressure and unions are increasingly being set aside. This attack on the right to strike is a direct attack on fundamental social rights in the EU and abroad. Without the right to strike, collective bargaining is nothing more than collective begging. Dear Commissioner, I heard your support for the routes for bringing this case to the International Court of Justice, and I applaud your intentions. My question is what can you do in order to get more votes for these routes?

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: Madam President, the right to strike is seriously threatened around the world. Obstructing the right to strike and trade union action threatens the most basic democratic freedoms. Spain is one of the European countries where we have come back in this regard, with the criminalization of more than 300 trade unionists, with sentences of up to 64 years in prison and with a reform of the Penal Code and a gag law that involve drastic cuts in these fundamental rights. It is no coincidence that the Government that is most distinguished by dismantling the social state is also the one that most cuts the legitimate right of citizens to defend itself. Moreover, European precarisation of employment policies make it increasingly difficult for workers to organize and claim their rights. It is a priority to defend the right to strike and to support the convening of the Global Day of Action of 18 February, in defence of freedoms and the right to strike, against the undemocratic position of the Employers' Group of the International Labour Organization.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: Madam President, the right to strike is, of course, an important part of industrial relations and the last resort in defence of an individual. However, it must not be abused. It is hard enough getting trade unions to play fair in the UK. They are giving financial support to groups who blockade political offices, and stopping elected representatives from speaking to voters and appearing in public to discuss local and national issues. Of course, the last time the EU was involved in strikes, it was over the British jobs for British workers, the Posted Workers Directive being brought into light for allowing companies to hire workers that undercut the wages of the country they were posted to. So I would be very wary of sticking your noses in again to what is already a very sensitive subject in the UK. To be discussing here and calling for the unelected EU Commission to potentially meddle with the rights and the freedoms that it has taken centuries in the UK to develop is not something the British people voted for. Laws should be decided by our elected and accountable national governments, not imposed from bureaucrats from Brussels and Strasbourg.

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, let me express my concern about the attacks launched by the Spanish justice system against more than three hundred trade unionists for striking. Some are even prosecuted and criminally convicted. What is problematic in this case is the extremely restrictive interpretation of workers' rights, and this is even more true in times of economic crisis.  We can see that under pressure from some employers, the right to strike is being undermined, and not only in Spain. There is a growing current in Europe to restrict or even prohibit the right of protest and expression of workers.  Social democracy is being undermined once again. Could it be a barely hidden deal from the states to attract investors? Would workers' rights be a peril for the big market? However, the European Charter of Fundamental Rights, in Articles 12 and 28, refers to the right to strike and collective action. The European Parliament and the European Union must therefore forcefully reaffirm these fundamental rights so that they are respected by all Member States. I call on all parliamentarians to support the initiative of the International Trade Union Confederation to make 18 February 2015 a day of international mobilization in defence of workers' right to strike. The European Parliament could, for example, write a declaration to that effect.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Mr President, the Committee on Freedom of assembly of the ILO has proclaimed the right to strike as a human right. According to this Commission, this human right is always translated as the right to join trade unions in the workplace, to defend the professional interests of workers through collective bargaining. Unfortunately, the neoliberal mnemonic policies of harsh austerity imposed on the Member States through the Troika in the European Union have proven to break up industrial relations and trample on workers' rights. According to Eurofound, more and more European governments are unilaterally dismantling collective agreements. The European Union must change its course from these neoliberal policies of harsh austerity and memoranda. The European Commission must press the Member States to promote policies that ensure collective bargaining, labour rights and the right to strike. We, as the United Left, declare our solidarity in the struggle of workers to defend the inalienable right to strike.

name: Ole CHRISTENSEN
text: Madam President! Thank you to the Commissioner for the comments. It's actually a rather strange case that we're dealing with. One party, namely employers, no longer interprets the right to strike as the right for workers to defend their working conditions and their wages. It is, after all, a fundamental right and there must be a balance in the social dialogue! Otherwise, only the right of the strong will apply. Here it is important that workers can fight for their jobs, their working conditions and their wages. If I look at Denmark, it is the case that employers support the withdrawal of employers in the ILO from the interpretation of Convention 87, namely that it should be up to the Member States to assess whether this right should continue to exist. I don't think that's fair! We have a general right in the world that people can fight for their jobs; then it must be up to the Member States to decide how this should be done, but it must be a world right to be able to strike and fight for their working conditions. We must, of course, support other countries in the fact that it can also be done as a worker that the right to strike must and must be preserved as a central part of Convention 87.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for her work I am speaking explicitly in this debate as a member of the Committee on Trade. Commissioner, I agree with your considerations on trade agreements. This is because new global production and value chains are developing rapidly. This puts the living and working conditions of employees in different parts of the world in context, directly, in a wide range of economic and social conditions. We must therefore quickly establish the appropriate regulatory framework. The starting point for this remains the UN Charter of Human Rights, the ILO Conventions and Jurisprudence and the UN Social Pact. Article 8(d) guarantees the right to strike, ratified by 162 states, in accordance with international law. Trade and economic cooperation need legal protection. In this sentence, do not think of investors, but of workers and their trade unions! Exploitation means social dumping in competition. The right to strike is a legitimate means of combating it and must be defended internationally by the European Union. Otherwise, we are devaluing the obligation to respect ILO Convention 87 as a core standard in the sustainability chapters of EU trade agreements.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul Without the right to strike, it will be pointless to conduct trade union and collective bargaining, because there is no negotiation if one party has nothing at all to oppose. It will be like a football game where one team gets to run and play on their knees while the employers of the other team get to use their legs fully, with full force. Surely we know how such matches end.  It is more than 100 years since the labour movement began its struggle for decent conditions and decent wages. Even today, this fight must be fought. It is now a question of employers in Europe refusing to recognise the fundamental right to strike in accordance with the current ILO Convention.  I would like to thank Commissioner Thyssen for acting on this – you and the governments of the Member States must continue to do so. Either the EU becomes a place of hard conflict and slow development, or we put an end to employers' new war on the human right that trade union rights are fundamentally about.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: Madam President, I was saying that the right to strike represents a fundamental right. With the strike, workers become aware of their strength, they clearly understand where wealth is born and those who appropriate it. That is why the strike is systematically attacked by employers' associations, who fear it – and have reasons for it.  In a recurring way, expressions such as the fundamental right of every citizen to be disturbed, to preserve his health and well-being are introduced. They talk about the total costs of the strike for society. For them, workers are not citizens, they are not part of society. This aims to limit the strike by means of a menu of measures designed in practice to prevent workers from striking, to limit their impact until they become ineffective.  Of course, if it were up to some, we would still be in the time of slavery. However, for us, the future involves the social and political emancipation of workers. Any setback in this matter will always deserve our strongest opposition.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: Madam President, I welcome the efforts of colleagues who have secured the debate today. When the ILO is in crisis, it shows multilateralism is in crisis and widespread concerns over TTIP show that EU citizens do not want a global economy without fair social rules. Global free trade without effective labour rights, including the right to strike, effectively means more downward pressure on wages and unsustainable development for the many.  But the Commission also has a special responsibility to ensure that the ILO functions properly. The Commission has outsourced to the ILO the assessment of whether a country qualifies for trade preferences with respect to labour rights. The Commission chose to rely on the ILO’s Committee on the Application of Standards. We therefore have a duty to guarantee that this Committee can function properly and delivers effectively. The conflict within the ILO must be resolved urgently and it must be resolved, if necessary, by the ICJ.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: Madam President, I believe that the Commissioner is taking sufficient examples to better assess the level of non-compliance with labour standards in the European Union. I understand that the Commission is concerned and closely follows the debate in the ILO, but it would do much better to put pressure on the Member States and require them to comply with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. Debate in the ILO cannot be an excuse for inaction. Let us act in the international framework and do so in the European Union. I commend the Commissioner's efforts to try to get the European Union to speak with one voice before the ILO, but I hope it is not on the basis of the lowest common denominator, as so often happens: the least progressive common denominator minimum. We must stop democratic involution in many Member States of the European Union, for example in the Spanish State, where police forces have also been turned into prosecutors and judges as part of an offensive against political and trade union rights.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the right to strike is one of the fundamental rights of working people. There are three conditions which are closely linked and which must never be separated: the possibility for the worker/worker to organize himself and represent himself collectively, the possibility of negotiating their living conditions and the possibility of using the strike. Without organization there would be no collective bargaining and collective bargaining would be a mere deception if there were no possibility on the part of those who work to create actions to combat their interlocutor, in this case companies. It is a chain that must never be broken. And it's so natural that this happens in all parts of the world. All the developed states, but also the developing and growing countries, have this certainty for the people who work and it is so natural that the Charter of Rights of Europe, in Article 28, has not by chance put together the right to negotiate with the right to strike. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: It asks according to the procedure "blue card". – Mr Cofferati, I would like to ask you what measures should the European Union, the European Commission, take to punish or prevent certain Member States from limiting, restricting, or sometimes even eliminating, the right to strike in those countries?

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: answer to a "blue card" question. I believe that any national or supranational body, which cares about the value of work, the social value of work and the dignity of working people, should always guarantee the three fundamental rights that I have mentioned: that of organising, that of haggling and that of being able to use strike action as an instrument. If there are conditions or reasons for protecting, especially in the field of services, users who may also be adversely affected by the free exercise of a right, then it is then the organisations that determine the forms and methods of defending themselves.

name: Guillaume BALAS
text: Madam President, we are at the heart of the matter. We see it today, under pressure, in particular, from a part of the employers. Encouraged by the economic crisis, which creates an imbalance in its favour in the balance of power, since labour is very abundant while capital, of course, is scarcer, and exploiting this disproportion, it puts pressure on political bodies and states, which will restrict the right to strike, as seen, for example, in Spain or elsewhere. This means, therefore, that, symmetrically, policy intervention is necessary in the other direction, in order to support, of course, the demand of employee organisations within the ILO, which is certain, particularly in relation to the Court of Justice, and towards European states, which are now acting against these conventions. From this point of view, the European Commission has an absolutely major role to play, and we encourage it to do so.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the ILO has played a key role throughout history, also throughout the recognition of fundamental rights in the European Union. Thanks to the ILO, the right to strike has been incorporated into the European Social Charter. Thanks to the ILO, the right to strike is considered one of the fundamental rights of our social model. And when this is put at risk by the Employers' group in the ILO, the European Union cannot be neutral, no long as its own rules give it the role of observer. Because we are defending a social right, a fundamental right, in a context in which there is a great review, precisely, of this model and of workers' rights. We're not just talking about the ILO. We are also talking about the European Union itself, where many labour reforms, where many laws are trying to unprotect workers, taking away the right to strike and the protection of collective agreements, increasing flexibility at the expense of their safety. You cannot therefore be neutral in this debate, Commissioner. You have to defend not only the right to strike, but a social model that protects workers in our European Union, in our monetary region, in order, fundamentally, to move it elsewhere on the planet, as our constitutional principle says.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Indeed, the news is deeply worrying that the march to revoke the right of workers under international labour law to strike would, thus denying the ILO's settled case-law on the generally recognised right of workers to strike, destabilising the ILO's long-established dispute settlement system and would certainly weaken social dialogue, which would undermine both sides, but would suffer the most.  It is wrong that the content of the ILO Convention on Freedom of Association is not intended to be clarified, but merely to destabilise the supervisory mechanism that has existed so far. This situation cannot be tolerated when it comes to the right of workers to strike. This is a very important guarantee that working people are not exploited in the workplace and that their rights are not violated.  Commissioner, I call on you personally and the Commission to help resolve this situation in order to protect the rights of our citizens, our workers, and it is very important to help the Member States of the European Union to speak with one name in this situation.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Three years ago, the European Commission proposed a regulation on the exercise of the right to strike in the context of the freedom to provide services. The Commission's aim was to codify the case-law of the Court of Justice and to introduce legal clarity by confirming that the right to strike and the freedom to strike are of the same importance as the freedom to provide services. The regulation pointed to the fact that the right to strike is not an absolute right and should be regulated. The Regulation also sets out a new mechanism for the notification of conflicts involving employment relationships in cross-border situations.  However, the proposal for a regulation has been criticised not only by business but also by trade unions. In the end, the Commission withdrew the proposal for a Monti II regulation because of the yellow card procedure – let me just remind you: some member state parliaments have not accepted this regulation, considering that it is a member state."  Returning today to the Monti II proposal, we must remember that, like any activity, strikes should be based on the utmost responsibility.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Madam President, the strike is never done for pleasure. It is a fundamental right and the ultimate weapon of workers when their rights are seriously threatened and all other avenues have failed.  We would like to restrict the right to strike in Bangladesh, where people work in inhumane conditions for less than a dollar a day, we would like to restrict it in the Union where workers' rights have been acquired at the cost of high struggles.  At a time when the cynicism of some bosses, Lakshmi Mittal in mind - this is the one that comes to mind - is matched only by the contempt they show towards their workers by closing profitable businesses by pure financial calculation, where pension funds seek only double-digit profitability, necessarily by threatening the rights of workers when they own the business. , where widespread tax evasion orchestrated by big banks seems to be a rule, one would want to restrict workers' rights, the right to strike? It's despicable!  I welcome this initiative by the International Trade Union Confederation and thank you, Commissioner, for your vigilance and commitment to the defence of workers' rights, including, among them, the right to strike.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Madam President, we expect the Commission in this strained situation to try to balance what can be done between employers and workers, but what must be our minimum is indeed what has been reached. We have the right to strike in Europe, we have collective bargaining and to go below what we have reached today - regardless of globalisation, regardless of the problems in our textile industry, the steel industry, in other industries that are in serious crisis due to global conditions today - we still cannot allow ourselves to go beyond what we have reached.  That is why, even as a liberal, I want to stand firmly behind what workers' rights are and all that Europe has today as a role model for others in the world.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: Madam President, the group of employers has launched a continuous and deliberate attack on the right to strike, and this has been endorsed by the European Commission when it has urged Member States to implement structural reforms that have damaged social dialogue and collective bargaining, deregulating the right to work and thereby breaking balance relations in industrial relations , precisely against workers. Now the strike is criminalized. Spain is a clear example of this. There is a clear anti-union purpose in all this which, since my group, we will not consent to. Today, mrs Thyssen, it is not worth saying that positions will be coordinated: we must commit and express clearly the support for the day convened by the International Trade Union Confederation on 18 February, and also open a file to countries such as Spain for their attack on freedoms and anti-union practices.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: Madam President, the right to demonstrate has sometimes been confused here in this debate with the right to strike, and I would like to call on the Commissioner to take this big difference into mind.  The right to expression is a spontaneous right that often arises today with a mechanism that is that of social networks and that allows for quick contacts, but the right to strike has behind it an essential issue that is that of negotiation. And so we, when we are talking about a fundamental right, are talking about commitments that are made between workers and their employers, who want, through negotiation, in a first phase, to reach consensus. And it is only when this is not possible that the workers go on strike with their own injury. And it is this first question, self-harm, that is often also forgotten here. When we talk about the societal and economic damage that comes from a strike, we must never forget that workers use the right to strike to show that they are key parts in our society. Commissioner, our motto is: United in Diversity. This is also the motto of trade union associations.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: Madam President, first of all, I wanted to thank you for holding this debate at a time when the right to strike is being questioned, and not just in emerging countries. As has already been said, there are more than eighty open court cases in my country in court affecting more than 300 workers for exercising the right to freedom of association and the right to strike. In this sense, just a few days ago, a judge sentenced five colleagues of the Metal union in Asturias, MCA-UGT, to prison with more than two years in prison for performing these union information work in the face of a general strike. In the face of the disproportion of this judgment, more than thirty Members of this House have signed a letter of solidarity with these colleagues and the Government itself has acknowledged the serious problem it has with the implementation of the current legislation. However, he has done nothing; has made labour reform that further complicates the exercise of the right to strike. And I don't think this can go on like this. That is why I believe that the Commission should be interested in this issue, which affects the fundamental rights of workers and citizens in Europe.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: Madam President, Commissioner, companies today have in the European Union and free societies an inescapable social responsibility. Corporate social responsibility must be a requirement of modern states and modern societies. The freedom to strike is a fundamental freedom for workers. The right to strike makes companies stronger, more powerful, more competitive in the global market.  Therefore, instead of restricting the right to strike in the European Union in the Member States, it is necessary to seek to boost the right to strike in emerging powers, such as In China and other countries where this right is not respected. The European Commission, the European Union, must therefore defend the right to strike and punish, sanction Member States restricting that right, which limit that right.

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: Mr President, the strike reveals two facts: it is revealed that the theory of money has absolutely no value. If the worker with his work did not produce goods, he would not be interested in the employer the strike; He'd say, "I'll have the money produce goods." But he doesn't. This reveals that the worker alone produces goods and values, and money only exchanges values. For this reason, the European Union must not only declare the right to strike in Greece, where since 1916 the miners of Serifos have succeeded in establishing the right to strike, but also make it a condition for the participation of any state in the European Union. And if a European Union does not accept it.... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: In fact, this debate today shows that only workers can be subject to sanctions by the actors involved in the strike, such as workers, employers and the state that regulates them. I believe that in the regulation of the future, attention should also be paid to the fact that, especially here in the European Community, we may have the opportunity to do so, so that if the state is a transgression in the legislation, there should also be some kind of feedback or sanction. If employers create a situation where there is a strike, there should also be a penalty. The other, and here I would like to turn to the Commission. In my opinion, the TTIP treaty can only be concluded, it is only worth signing if we unify not only industry standards but also labour standards.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, today's subject is, I think, extremely important, perhaps more than we imagine. We must judge rationally and not passionately. The right to strike must exist. I don't think we need to question him anymore. It is, however, just as important, as Colleague Cofferati said, as is regulated before the strike. The strike must not please anyone, it must not please anyone, because the strike means loss on both sides. Employers cannot exist without employees, nor can employees have a job without an employer. That is why both sides need to understand that negotiation must be fair. Social responsibility must increase, but we must not encourage indiscipline. Employers need to understand that they do not work with robots, at the same time, they cannot ensure their competitiveness and productivity without satisfied and well-trained people. I have heard here often the word 'fight', I believe that there should not be the word 'fight', but there must be regulation, dialogue, and that is the responsibility of the governments of each country.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the right to strike is a fundamental right. That is the case in Article 28 of our Charter of Fundamental Rights. This is the case in Article 11 of the European Convention on Human Rights. And that is also the case – at least as we have always interpreted Convention 87 – in that Convention of the International Labour Organisation. Ladies and gentlemen, I have found that many of you share the Commission's concern. A double concern: 1) that the interpretation of Convention 87 is called into question, but 2) also more structurally, that if it remains blocked, it could jeopardise the monitoring system of the International Labour Organisation itself. You have yourself underlined in your interventions why this is not desired or desirable. We all know that the Member States are, first and foremost, members of the International Labour Organisation. The Commission is only present there as an observer. But, as I said in my introduction, the Commission will very actively support the Member States, help them in the discussions and, where necessary, make an effort to achieve a single position or to preserve the unity position that has been acquired. The importance of the meeting at the end of February should not be underestimated. It's an informal tripartite gathering. I hope that this will lead to a concensus. If that is not the case, we will look at how this should proceed, but the non-formal conclusion that is taken there will be passed on – you know the structure of the International Labour Organisation – to the Governing Board of the International Labour Organisation. A final decision will have to be taken there in March. You can count on the Commission, together with our delegation in Geneva and with the Member States, to do everything possible and to do everything possible to achieve a positive result. As you know, the Commission attaches great importance to social dialogue. Some of you have also pointed that out. We will promote it in all areas, both internationally and within our own European Union.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The debate is over.  Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Writing. – Unfortunately, across the world, not only in Europe, the balance between workers and employers has been tipped: employers are constantly increasing and workers are increasingly indert on working conditions. Strikes are one of the most effective tools for workers in this environment. Since the twentieth century, workers and their trade unions have had the right to strike in Europe, and ILO Convention No 87 on freedom of association and the right to organise, of which all EU member states, if not express verbis, have recognised this right. Since 2012, the employers' side within the ILO has challenged the right of workers to strike, an effort that has been quietly supported by governments in Asia, Africa and even some European governments. This is completely unacceptable. It is not for the governments of Europe and the European Commission to serve business blindly, but to ensure the conditions for social dialogue and to promote a balanced dialogue between the parties. "The best example" of behaviour most at odds with the real role of governments is my own country. In Hungary, since the amendment of the Strike Act 2010, the parties have had to agree on sufficient conditions as a precondition for strike action. In practice, this has made it impossible for Hungarian workers to exercise the right to strike. It is clear that the creation of dign worthable employment relationships cannot be possible without maintaining a balanced balance of power and dialogue, based on the right to strike.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Writing. The right to strike is a fundamental fundamental right. It is guaranteed in the European Union by the Charter of Fundamental Rights and must also be anchored internationally without restrictions. I call on the employers' side within the International Labour Organisation (ILO) to abandon their obstructionism. On the one hand, they doubt that the right to strike is guaranteed by ILO Convention No 87 on freedom of assembly. On the other hand, however, they prevent the ILO from appealing to the International Court of Justice in The Hague to resolve this issue. I call for this all the more because in recent years we have seen more and more cases in which workers are denied the right to strike. This has been the case in Greece in recent years. A strike by metalworkers has been banned in Turkey. This clearly shows that we urgently need clarification from the ICJ on this issue. We Social Democrats will not accept the restriction of fundamental freedoms of workers – neither in the EU nor in our neighbouring countries or anywhere else in the world. It is therefore particularly important to me that the European Union use its influence in all areas to enforce compliance with this right and the ILO core labour standards. This is particularly true in the case of free trade agreements such as TTIP.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Next point is the Commission Statement - European Youth Initiative (a amendment to the ESF Regulation) (2015/2554(RSP))

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, I will do my introduction in English and will give my answers as usual in Dutch. Allow me to present to you a proposal which the Commission adopted last Wednesday on youth employment. Since I came to office as the new Commissioner for Employment, Social Affairs, Skills and Labour Mobility, I have made the fight against youth unemployment my first priority. More than five million young people in Europe do not have a job at this moment. This is around one in five of young people in Europe. In some Member States we are facing youth unemployment rates of around 50%. Moreover, today 7.5 million people between 15 and 24 years old are not in employment, education or training and risk being socially and economically excluded, with all the dramatic consequences for themselves and for our society. This is unacceptable. This is why, in its Work Programme for 2015, the Commission committed to taking initiatives to promote integration and employability in the labour market, including measures to support Member States in getting young people into work. As you know, the Youth Employment Initiative was established following the urgent call from the European Council in February 2013 to address the unprecedented levels of youth unemployment in certain regions of the European Union most affected by this phenomenon. This budget line of EUR 3.2 billion, to be matched with funding from the European Social Fund, is dedicated to actions targeting individual young people who are neither in employment, education or training. Therefore, it contributes to the implementation of the Youth Employment Guarantee, in line with the Council’s recommendation of 22 April 2013. However, despite the provisions already in place to frontload this initiative, and an early eligibility date for expenditure – 1 September 2013 – progress has not yet lived up to expectations. The initial pre-financing amount of 1% – and 1.5% in the Member States in the programme – proved to be too low to roll out the initiative, particularly to those Member States that have significant budgetary constraints. This proposal aims, therefore, to tackle this deficiency by setting an adequate level of pre-financing for the Youth Employment Initiative. The increased financing proposed will amount to around EUR 1 billion – 30% of the specific allocation – instead of the current EUR 39 million. Based on the targets set by Member States in their operational programmes, we expect that, with this additional pre-financing, up to 650 000 young people will be able to rapidly receive support. I would like to underline again that the pre-financing proposal does not impact on the budgetary allocations for the Youth Employment Initiative in 2015, or the multiannual financial framework overall. Neither does it affect pre-financing payments from other funds or under operational programmes that are not relevant for the initiative. The urgency to adopt this proposal is justified by the figures. The longer we wait to act, the harder it becomes to help the young generation. I would like, therefore, to ask you to join me in the effort to make this proposal a reality for young people and to ensure that this additional funding can be converted as soon as possible into a concrete job, education or training offer for young people. (Applause)

name: Lara COMI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I am the first to thank you because I entered this Parliament at the age of twenty-six and therefore I define myself as a bit of the Erasmus generation but also of the precarious generation.  What you are doing and also the initiative of the Commission and President Junker, who has always paid particular attention to youth unemployment, also have the full support of the European People's Party. I am convinced that having more money and more funding is a very good instrument. The problem we see, particularly with regard to the Member States, is how this money is used, how all the extremely positive initiatives that Europe is taking towards the Member States are being taken on board. The Youth Guarantee Fund, which I consider to be an excellent experience, has also not been transposed and adopted in the best possible way by all the Member States; some have made copy-pastes of ads in temporary agencies. This is extremely wrong. We do not need to have a copy-paste, we young people need confidence, we need to be able to believe in this Europe too, and what you are giving is a great message of hope. What I am asking you very much, not least because Italy, my country, is particularly well known for not spending the money that the European Union gives well, is to be very careful about controlling this funding that we give directly to young people and indirectly to the States, because if they are not spent well they must no longer be given. They must be made to those who are efficient and to whom they are effective in this expenditure. I therefore congratulate you. It has all our support and our willingness, because I think that the future of Europe starts above all from young people and when we talk badly about Europe perhaps we need to know more about it.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner, thank you very much for your initiative. More than seven million unemployed young people in Europe are still a European disaster and we really need the Youth Guarantee to be implemented quickly. You, the Commission, took the right step in the right direction last week. 30% instead of 1% of the funds will be made available already this year. This means that 650 000 young people can get into work. This is a new perspective 650 000 times and 650 000 times a good start in life. We particularly welcome the political decision to put an end to the unsuccessful radical policy of cuts. Because we do not need further restrictions on the people who are already living at the limit, but we urgently need investment. A good example is Finland. There, the Youth Guarantee has brought 83.5% of young people out of unemployment into suitable work after three months. This must set an example for other states.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: for the ECR Group – It is excellent news that the Commission has decided to target young people. We know what amazing things our young people are capable of when they get the opportunity, but we also know how much they can suffer if young people are not given the chance to develop their job potential in a timely manner. The aim of the guarantee is to ensure that young people do not remain inactive for more than four months and receive a job, traineeship or continue to be educated. To this end, resources are now being released and the instruction is: rapid implementation. But do Member States have the capacity to make meaningful use of them? Unfortunately, the answer to this question is not unequivocal. I understand if the Commission needs to show that it is actionable and fast, but my concerns about the unreasonable use of accelerated payments remain. The programme is in danger of going down the easiest path: by nonsensical subsidisation of hastily created, unfortunately, many temporary jobs. The problem with unemployment does not start at the labour office, but much, much earlier. For example, when a child from a poor social background does not get into kindergarten, when the child gets to school, but for years he learns the old and untapped theory. When in college they have no idea about working with real business. And when, in the worst case scenario, graduates in the office end up working and meeting people there who don't know how to help them. Did you know, for example, that in Slovakia there are sometimes up to 700 unemployed per official?  Therefore, if today the Commission is proud of the speed of its work, I am rather afraid of dishonesty. I consider it not fair enough to deal with employment in the regions with the greatest problems in a hastily questionable implementation capacity. I find it equally questionable to add often clueless states with funds to subsidise jobs.  I understand the Commission's intention, but I am concerned about the result in reality. I will therefore pay particular attention, together with my colleagues, to setting up a control system. Youching money into a dysfunctional system without structural change would be disappointing for all of us.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: on the alde group. – Madam President, the €1 billion financial injection in the form of pre-financing for a project to support the young unemployed is an essential step for the new European Commission. Thanks for the courage belongs to the entire Commission and, in particular, to Commissioner Thyssen. Thank. You said, Commissioner, the later we approve this proposal, the worse. I agree and also add that the second necessary need is a change of mentality. The Czech philosopher Václav Belgrade said that work is not any activity, but only one that changes the world. In fact, if we are looking for a way to involve hundreds of thousands of unemployed young people in Europe in the workforce, we are looking for a way for these young people to change our world, our Europe. It's a journey from passivity to activity. Change must occur not only in the support system, but also, quite necessarily, in our attitude to work. Not all elite lawyers, proclaimed doctors, or world politicians can be. We need a great job in services as urgently as good craftsmen and skilled workers. The youth unemployment situation is alarming in some countries and threatens the economic stability of the whole of Europe. It is therefore high time to stop lowering the age limits of vulnerable groups and start motivating young people to self-sufficiency, economic independence from their parents or the state. Please do not look for difficult solutions, but let us show young people that working, doing business and educating themselves makes sense. That the world can change for the better anyone who does their job the best they can.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, Commissioner, the project you are presenting - increasing the pre-financing of the Youth Guarantee and providing an additional EUR 1 billion credit - is a positive gesture, and we will support it. However, I would like to reiterate that the International Labour Organization (ILO) estimates that there is a need for funding of $21 billion a year to meet a new project of training and stable employment for young people. On the other hand, let us be clear, the additional funds allocated are funds withdrawn from other social policies. Is it clear what the vast suffering of more than 7 million young people, deprived of work and activity, represents behind the coldness of the figures? If the European Union were to revive hope, it would decide to make early childhood and youth a great European cause by moving out of austerity choices, encouraging the transformation of all precarious jobs into stable jobs, initiating a project of self-reliance for young people, thus giving them the means to be emanscent, and by carrying out a bold project of professional social security in employment and training. There is always a lack of a leader in our speeches, namely, companies. Let us ask ourselves the question of corporate social responsibility, which make a profit and which not only do not hire, but also lay off. Access to work must be a fundamental right. We should make it live throughout the European Union.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, one year ago, around this time, I was sitting in an unemployment office discussing my own future with a nice, yet quite unmotivated, assistant in the unemployment agency. I was filling in forms, calculating how much money I had for my rent, food, train tickets and health insurance. I was thinking about my life, my dreams, what plans I had for my future, and I thought about my place in society: where do I belong? I have always been in a privileged position. I come from a country where youth unemployment is proportionately low. I come from a middle class, white family and I have a university degree. Still, the ultimate question that was always there in my mind was: what is my value for this society? Raised in an environment and an educational system where having a job is a synonym for being valuable, millions of young people probably ask themselves exactly the same question every day. Every day, young people are asking themselves what they have done wrong when people are telling them that they just need to try harder. People are telling them to try harder when trying harder is just not enough anymore. We need to make this very clear. This is not an individual problem of Paolo from Minorca or Kasia from Cracow. It is a systematic problem that was brought about by wrong political decisions in the past. Every day, especially in times of more and more alarming information leaking about tax fraud and tax avoidance, young people are asking themselves if we are doing enough to solve these problems, if we are willing to learn from LuxLeaks and Swiss Leaks and change a system that brings these problems every day. What we need is a fairer tax system and public investment to start this process. Strengthening the Youth Guarantee, as proposed by the Commission now, is only one step on a long and winding road to a solution, because eventually we will have to decide if we are standing side by side with the many million young people who are unemployed and desperate or if we support the interests of the few, yet powerful, people and companies hiding their wealth in tax havens and avoiding paying their share. When I was sitting in the unemployment office, one year ago, I took my decision. I would fight for the many who are often overheard and overlooked. Now I am in a position to speak to you, Mrs Thyssen, directly, and I want to say you, and to all your colleagues in the Commission, that this is only a first step. What we need now is, first, for you to push the Member States to really implement the Youth Guarantee in a way that will directly benefit young people, but secondly – and I think this is even more important – to push for policies that are going to take the European Union on a different path and that will really create employment so that young people have a future in Europe.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, what we are debating here is the European Youth Initiative, and we have calls for the EU to do this, that and the other to end the massive problems facing young people in finding a job. I suppose this is the same EU that has failed those young people. You only have to look at the employment figures for the Mediterranean eurozone members to realise that the EU and its initiatives have led to millions of young people being unable to find work, with Greece being the prime example with a 50% youth unemployment rate. We have seen billions of taxpayers’ money thrown at these countries and none of it has helped. How about Northern Europe? Well, of course, the elephant in the room there is immigration. While we have to compete with an open door to 450 million people to settle claim benefits and, crucially for this debate, compete for the same jobs, it will always be hard for young people to find work. At the last European committee meeting we were talking about new legislation on EURES, which is a website that hit the headlines in the UK a few years ago for advertising 800 000 UK jobs across Europe. That was nearly 50% of all the jobs listed. The new rules obviously will expand the number of UK jobs listed and advertised, but more importantly, the EU wants to include work experience and apprenticeship places advertised across Europe as well. How on earth are young British workers and those fresh-faced out of education, with little experience or skills, meant to find a job? The EU, whatever it does, makes things worse. I just hope that it will one day listen to the voters who say they want no more meddling and waste, and no more EU bureaucracy. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: blue card question. – The previous speaker very much criticised the European Union for not achieving anything in the fight against youth unemployment. After all, we are dealing with the Youth Guarantee, which is an initiative of the citizens. In fact, this is not the Commission's initiative in the first place, it has left the citizens, it has left the demarcation youths of Austria and Finland, and now the Commission has quite rightly reacted to this initiative. I would like to ask how you can criticise the European Union when, for once, there is an initiative on the table?

name: Jane COLLINS
text: blue-card answer. – I am going to go back to what I said about the elephant in the room. The elephant in the room is immigration. I am also going to go back again to what I said about the free movement of people and the immense pressure it puts on young people in our country, the UK, trying to compete for jobs. Also, other EU legislation and EU directives have failed. What makes you think this one is going to work? I do not.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I note that the European Commission is finally concerned about the social disaster that is lurking in European nations! More than 23% of young people under the age of 25 in France are currently unemployed. This social drama is the direct result of political choices which have had the effect of curbing the economic activity of many Member States: strong euro, ultraliberalism, lack of Community or even national preferences, lack of protection of vital economic sectors, continuation of a mad policy of total openness of borders. These many factors have had a very negative impact on employment. So, as a good arsonist, the Commission is now proposing to release EUR 1 billion under the Youth Employment Initiative. But this financial windfall will be just another blow in the water. Indeed, it is not enough to help young people find their first job or to train, it is first necessary to restore the conditions for a sustainable economic recovery, creating sustainable jobs. We must also stop the strengthening of the Eures network, which aims to support the one-way mobility of European workers. This European employment platform should not be a facilitator for the hiring of low-cost seconded workers, who compete directly - and in a totally unfair way - with employees in Member States such as France. Finally, the absolute principle of the free movement of people in the European internal market must be put to an end. The real fight against unemployment is at this price. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, you are talking about borders and the fact that they will cause problems for France. I come from Romania, of which France is the main trading partner. France exports billions of euros worth of products to Romania. France and Romania have economic exchanges and you also have Romanian doctors and students in France, Romanians who work very well in your country. Why do you want to close the borders? To find a solution to the problem of youth unemployment, we must work together. I think our partnership can be an example of that.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, I think the opposite is true. I think we need to restore a national or even community preference. Indeed, we can never be competitive if we have countries like Romania and France in this same European area. This is going to hurt France, and I'm here to defend my country. I am sorry for you, but that is the interest I have in my country.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, my first words are to thank you. After what we have just heard, I think we must thank you for identifying the real problem here, with the youth employment initiative, which is the problem of co-financing Member States. You have fully understood that it is in the states where the budget is most difficult to balance that we need the most to help young people enter the world of work. These are Greece and Spain, regions in great difficulty, for which the youth employment initiative was created. It is through this volunteerism that you have highlighted the difficulty and undertaken to respond effectively to it. There is an urgent need to integrate young people into employment. It is a very big problem and there is a great deal of confusion on the ground, as well as here in the debates. There is a great confusion between the Youth Guarantee, which is the policy of integrating young people into the world of work throughout Europe and for all young Europeans, and the youth employment initiative, which is strengthening the youth guarantee. I hear a lot about the $21 billion, the $6 billion, the $3 billion, etc. We need to target the youth employment initiative, aimed at those who are most in difficulty, in the most troubled areas, and you are doing it perfectly. Mobility is essential, because the living and working space of young people is the European space. No professional sector will be spared this European opening. In their profession, in their lives, young people need mobility. It is our first instrument to fight unemployment. Commissioner, you have asked us to help you. You can count on us, we will help you strengthen the pre-financing of youth employment. Help us, however, to eliminate the confusion that reigns in the minds, including those of ministers and heads of state and government: the youth guarantee is valid for all, while the youth employment initiative is a supplement for those who need it most. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Madam President, Mrs. Morin-Chartier, first of all I thank you for this explanation. However, since you come from France, given that your previous colleague Briois was just talking about mobility to the full (Interruption due to a technical problem.)  So I want to ask Mrs. Morin-Chartier about mobility. Since we swear to mobility as one of the main principles and foundations of the European Union, and especially when it comes to youth mobility, that is why I would like you to clarify, your colleague who comes from France Mr. Briois, who spoke before you, spoke the exact opposite of you.  I'm interested in what the attitude of the French delegation is, do you think that mobility is something that is bad, or do you think that youth mobility is what will help us implement this, not a guarantee for young people, but an employment initiative?

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank you for pointing out this mobility problem.  Mobility, for me, is the first lever, the first weapon we can give not only to young people, but also to all workers. The more mobility we have, the less unemployment there will be and the more we will reduce unemployment, because it is the adaptation of workers to changes in society. Geographical mobility is also a mobility of the mind, a professional mobility. So I am very angry with those who favour withdrawal, which leads to nothing. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: the blue card. – Honourable colleague, I would really like to ask whether there would be a better result in the recruitment of young people if we were to decentralise these opportunities, because, of course, individual countries are very centralised and have local authorities, regional authorities have very little opportunity to support, and each area wants to deal with these very complex problems. Thus, it was by decentralising and enabling not only participation, but also to contribute to the work of local and regional authorities to solve these problems, and to achieve a better effect.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, I'm sorry, I didn't have my helmet on. I have a connection problem and have not heard the question. (The President asks to repeat the question "blue card")

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: the blue card. – Thank you very much, I will repeat the question.
