As you think, there would be no greater effect if the opportunities for support for young people were more decentralised in Europe, because there are individual countries where they are highly centralised. Every local regional government wants to deal with these problems, but it has no chance, and it would contribute to both its own and local and regional governments, and we would have a much smaller problem.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, dear colleague, you are absolutely right. We need projects and, in my opinion, they need to be done as close as possible to the territory.  So I think that in a coordinated national organization, projects are projects of proximity and territory. There would be no point in the money if they were not with projects, and I think it is from the ground up that we can make those funds more effective — because I want to do that.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: Madam President, I salute the Commissioner for making the fight against youth unemployment her top priority, and we also welcome warmly her proposal fostering implementation of the funds available in this Youth Initiative. Of course we also urge the Council to adopt promptly these proposals coming from the Commission. However, we are only dealing with a kind of prepayment of EUR 1 billion, which was already available. If, Commissioner, you want to avoid a lost generation – if you want to open up a new future for young people in Europe – then we need to have a much larger wave of job creation: jobs of the future and quality jobs. That is why I believe that the critical factor – the deciding factor – will be the European Investment Plan. This plan should be used to create these jobs of the future for young people. That is why, Commissioner, I have a question for you, which is the following: how do you intend to use the European Investment Plan to pave the way for the jobs of the future, and particularly in those regions most hit?

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, young people are absolutely our future. In this context, reducing high unemployment is also an absolute priority for us. 'Growth and jobs' must therefore be more than a slogan. And the European Union can help facilitate this. But, ladies and gentlemen, the labour market is and remains, above all, a matter for the Member States. In Flanders, for example, we already have the Flemish youth guarantee, and with this the Flemish government wants to intervene structurally by providing intensive guidance tailored to young people looking for work. On the other hand, the Youth Work Initiative only supports projects and subsidising temporary jobs. That's not really sustainable. We think it is important to work structurally at the same time. Finally, I also call explicitly attention to a tailor-made language policy for young people with a migration background, as well as the specific needs of young people with disabilities. These two groups must also be given maximum job opportunities.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: Madam President, let me say first of all I fully support the Commissioner’s initiative to significantly increase the amount of pre-financing that is available to Member States to implement the Youth Employment Initiative (YEI). You saw that there was painfully slow progress and you reacted. Well done on that. As we are all aware, and as you mentioned, the youth unemployment rate is over 50% in Greece and Spain, and only three Member States – Austria, the Netherlands and Denmark – have rates below 10%. We know those figures, but every time we read them, they still shock us. My own country, Ireland, has an unemployment rate of 22%, and we have the safety valve of emigration. We will get an allocation of 68 million in Ireland for the YEI and a further 68 million under the Social Fund. I think it is important to say that this pre-financing – all of this money – is available to Member States and it can be used to support, not just the provision of traineeships and internships and apprenticeships, further education, training, etc., but also business set-up, support for entrepreneurs and targeted wage and recruitment subsidies. Last week I met the youth sections of the European Federation of Public Services Unions and the Irish Civil and Public Services Union. They emphasised to me the need to deal with demand as well as supply and pointed out that virtually no jobs are being created in the public service in Ireland. I know that the youth employment initiative cannot deal with this specifically, but it is crucial that money spent under the Youth Employment Initiative delivers real outcomes and real jobs. Not just training and up-skilling – yes, that’s important – but also a significant increase in employment.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: Madam President, the scarcity of European funds has been one of the main drivers of the implementation of the Youth Guarantee, which today is about remedying, if only partially. But uncertainty about its continuity and medium-term financing remains. But improvisation in funding is not the only problem that explains the failure of this young employment initiative. This initiative cannot be supported only on incentives for entrepreneurs; we see that it does not work, because it is being used as an element of precarization and deregulatory offensive against the world of work. 24% youth unemployment in the European Union, 55% in Spain. Young people without employment, with no possibility of emancipation and condemned to forced migration. Let's stop calling it mobility. There's nothing voluntary about it. If we do not harmonize taxes, labour standards, if we do not bet on public investment as a development tool, we only contribute to extending the social crisis and precariousness longer. This cannot be the alternative to misery imposed on our young people.

name: Karima DELLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this time the Member States will not be able to say that they did not know, that Europe is far from reality or that the European Commission is trying to get in their way. Indeed, what the European Commission has just said, in particular by facilitating funding to boost youth employment, is that we no longer have time to wait. That is the message that is being sent to us. It is true that it is unfortunate that we had to wait until the earthquake of the crisis and austerity policies that The Member States finally face reality: if we do not prepare the world for future generations, our very existence will be threatened. How many times in this Chamber have I repeated this figure of 7 million young people under the age of 25, without a job, internship or training? They are now called NEETs, as if they were a new class of population. No, it is simply a mirror of the failure of our economic and social policies and, as far as the Member States are concerned, I say 'be careful'. The Youth Employment Initiative - including the Youth Guarantee, this guarantee that allows them to offer employment, training, quality training and apprenticeships for all young people under the age of 25, within 4 months of losing their jobs or completing their studies - is a great tool and, with the proposal of the famous billion euros , the Commission must compel Member States to act. But making money available is only a first step. Its intelligent and efficient use is a second. The ball is now in the Member States' court, once again. You have to tell them: "You have the funding, you have the device. Now invest and show our young people that it is possible to make a life with dignity. Finally, make the ecological revolution, the energy revolution, to create new, sustainable jobs in which everyone can flourish, build their lives, start a family and look forward to a future more serenely." Your announcement will be a success if there is also a vision of the future, an economic horizon, because it does not only require national structures and administrations capable of absorbing these funds. This horizon - and I shout it loudly in this Chamber! Must be European and environmentally friendly... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker) (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mrs Delli, thank you for your emotional speech, but I am asking you here for the second time in this plenary whether you have ever studied what a dual system looks like in Austria or Germany, if you have ever wondered why unemployment there is so low. I don't think there's room for emotional gestures right now, but for us to act.

name: Karima DELLI
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, Mr MEP, how can we fail to react strongly to the catastrophe of an entire generation, which is almost my age and which today says and defines itself as lost: lost generation, precarious generation, generation on the margins of society? You're talking about devices, let's talk about them! You are talking about learning, what are the Member States waiting for to put the package into it? We do not need to learn in sectors that are now, unfortunately, closed, we must think about the future, therefore sustainable jobs, not relocated, but really in tune with the planet.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, while unemployment in Europe has risen, youth unemployment has exploded. In five years, the unemployment rate among young Europeans has increased from 15% to 25%. In Italy, youth unemployment is as high as 50%.  And yet, in the face of this social disaster, you are here to have the usual chatter and the young people who listen to us from home, from home because they do not have a job, will hear an hour of words, an hour of tired or ugly rhetoric. Do you want to understand that for the unemployed, the European Treaties, Europe 2020, the Youth Initiative are empty and useless words? Do you want to understand that there are too few funds if only in Italy there are 729,000 young people between the age of 15 and 24 out of work? Do you want to understand that using these funds is difficult because projects require pre-financing from the national budget and then repaid, and is it difficult to do so if Europe itself places budgetary constraints on Greece or Italy, for example, countries where unemployment is highest? The problem for europe's unemployed is Europe, this Europe: the single market, the euro, out-of-control immigration. There is therefore only one recipe for giving young people hope: putting Europeans back at the centre of social policies, protecting our businesses, immediately revising the suffocating parameters of the wrong European treaties, which should not even be applied in Italy because they run counter to the Italian Constitution. (The Speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: "blue card" question. I would like to ask Mrs Bizzotto whether, in view of the criticism she has levelled at the European Union's action, she agrees that, also as a result of her reflections, the right conclusion should be to strengthen economic integration, to have a full fiscal union and, therefore, I am thinking of strengthening the instruments of governance of the single currency within the eurozone, on which I believe there are contradictory positions on the part of her political group. , at least the Italian league, the Lega Nord.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: answer to a "blue card" question. Let us be very clear: we want a different Europe, a Europe that does not impose absurd rules and absurd directives, a Europe that does not kill our economy with European treaties that go nowhere. We want the citizens to be put at the heart of this Europe, not the financial lobbies, the banks and the interests of the few. If this Europe changes, it is our Europe. Otherwise, there is no point in continuing to remain in this Europe which kills the hopes of our young people and our citizens.

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: Mr President, first of all, I would like to congratulate the Commission and, in particular, the Commissioner, because from day one they ensured that youth employment would be one of their priorities and, to date, they are fulfilling it: congratulations, Commissioner! It is true that there has been a turning point in the European Union and that youth unemployment is slowly declining. The 2014 data are clear: youth unemployment has fallen by 1.7% through the European Union as a whole. And that equates to 464,000 young people under the age of twenty-five unemployed less than the previous year, of whom 82,000 are Spanish, or 17.67% of the European total. However, the current situation remains unacceptable. The Commissioner said so: more than five million young people remain unemployed. Many of them are Spanish. The European Union is not alone able to deal with this scourge with guarantees, but it must play a key role in helping national reforms and efforts be rewarded with stimulus that boosts growth and employment among young people, and that allows important employment-promoting measures to be taken in countries such as Spain , more opportunities can be provided for young people, as is the case with the proposal we are discussing today. Although the Youth Employment Initiative was launched as a shock plan, many Member States are struggling to implement the necessary measures, showing that initial pre-financing was not sufficient to be able to take swift and effective action, even more so when the budget is concentrated in the first two years and needs to be absorbed quickly and effectively. However, the Commission has been able to react, and this increase by almost EUR 1 billion is a good example of this. Now all that remains is to approve this proposal as soon as possible so that young people can start benefiting from now on.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: Mr President, first of all, I would like to welcome the measure: to increase pre-State funding. Increasing the security that States will have in the implementation of our fight against youth unemployment is a very good measure for the European Union, especially as the states with the most youth unemployment problems have the most funding problems with their budgets. But often one ends up thinking that our changes, which are taking place, are still slow, un agile, like a Titanic in the face of a huge iceberg from which we see only the tip, of which we see only the percentages in the form of unemployment, and we forget that behind there are huge social, institutional, economic and, also – we are seeing – electoral consequences. We are slow because the total budget we have to allocate to combat youth unemployment remains to be resolved; because even this spending is considered within the deficit targets, when we should be able to put it outside our deficit targets; because we have not yet increased targeting, the group of people that should be targeted by our fight against unemployment, and because we still forget, often, that youth unemployment is an effect of unemployment in general, which is usually double. And if we do not fight unemployment and deal with our crisis of deep demand, which has to do with our economic policies, we will not solve our youth unemployment problems. So let's turn, but with enough speed so that our helmet is not affected.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: To think that with one billion euros you will create hundreds of thousands of jobs is a pure illusion. You probably don't believe that yourself. The Commission has promised new beginnings, and yet you can only do the same thing all the time. You're still just putting more and more money into other and more programs. This is not working, but look at what a bad situation it is today. Politicians cannot create jobs. Politicians can only create the conditions for the creation of jobs. Therefore, the only solution is to reduce the regulatory burden. The European Union is the most regulated economic area in the world. Here's the problem. Not whether you give a billion or two or ten. We've got it all over. You need to improve the business environment, while also saving a lot of money that can remain an entrepreneur. They know what's best about it.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: Mr President, Commissioner, only four ideas. The first thing I want to highlight, so as not to lose the north, is that this is also called a policy of solidarity in a European context in the face of a huge European problem. And it is also worth noting so that people see that we are much more than a trade treaty or a relationship of international treaties. There will be no future for young people outside of a united Europe, despite what I have heard. Having said that, I would also like to remind you that we are dealing with policies that in some countries have to be inclusion policies; employment, but also inclusion. They cannot be just procurement promotion policies for businesses, which also sometimes distort the labour market. We have young people who haven't even finished basic education and we have to think about giving it back to them. Third, implementation is critical. This issue is so important that we must unfailingly make a professional assessment of results and success, and I think Europe needs to invest heavily in monitoring how these moneys are used. Finally, we welcome the acceleration of funding. This only shows that a lot of short-term money is needed, probably much more than has been given, probably on a much more ambitious budget to combat unemployment.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I too will say, of course, that I think it is good news that you have increased pre-financing to 30%. Those States that had difficulty in funding the first phase of the Youth Guarantee will surely appreciate it. But I have two issues which my group is currently concerned about in an important way. The first is that, beyond the fact that you can increase pre-financing, there is a clear problem of how the Youth Guarantee is being implemented, and we would like the European Commission to monitor, much more closely, how the Youth Guarantee develops in its content and practical application. In the case of Spain, one of the great beneficiaries of the measure, there are some autonomous communities that have not yet implemented the measure. We continue to devote much of the resources to bonuses, which contradicts the Youth Guarantee's own objectives and, in some cases, even make up unemployment lists, counting those young people who sign up for the Youth Guarantee as if they were no longer unemployed, and that process is not as automatic as some authorities applying the Youth Guarantee claim. Therefore, I would like to ask you for more control over the application, because that is what we are failing at, beyond the increase of pre-financing today. And second in every debate we must remember, there is not sufficient funding in the Youth Guarantee. The over-twenty-five years of age are still unable to access the programme, and the labor reforms we are carrying out are bearing the full weight of adjustment to the new generations. So it's no use patching like this if, then, in most labor reforms, the adjustment falls on the younger ones. And finally, a clarification which I would like you to make to me: in the multiannual financial framework approved by this Parliament, there were 2 billion margins that should be allocated, starting in 2016, to finance the Youth Guarantee was a political agreement of this Parliament. In the Juncker plan implementation programme we have now seen that these 2 billion will be used for the guarantees provided for the Juncker plan. I would like you to clarify whether that is the case and whether that money, now, will no longer be used to fund the initiative from 2016, because that would be very worrying and I certainly want you to clarify it for us.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the policies put in place by the European Union to promote and develop youth employment are symbols of failure. Thus, with an unemployment rate of 21.7% for all Member States, 7.5 million young people aged 15 to 25 are now unemployed and without training. In Spain and Greece, the youth unemployment rate even exceeds 50%.  The measures of the youth initiative will obviously not solve anything because, by ideological blindness, the European Union refuses to tackle the fundamental problems of mass immigration, which overwhelms Europe, and the continuous lowering of the Union's customs barriers.  Your globalist and ultraliberal ideology will defy the very idea of a border and the young people of Europe are the first victims. Your directive, known as seconded workers, approved by the elected representatives of the left and right here, has created a real social dumping, the least-spoken costs resulting in the least social. You have established legal but totally unfair competition in our national labour markets.  Only the restoration of borders, whether in the area of the movement of people or in the movement of goods and services, will enable Member States to carry out effective policies for youth employment.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, 'The Commission of the Last Chance', as President Juncker described in Parliament in October last year the task that awaited him. He was referring to the immense challenge of re-warming the citizens to the European project, against the threat of eurosceptic populists. Central to this is regaining trust. And trust, colleagues, – I don't have to tell you that – disappears with containers and comes back with wheelbarrows. This proposal is just one of those wheelbarrows, because the future of the Union is an abstract fact, but the immense youth unemployment is a tragedy that is taking place today and that must be addressed now. Now is our last chance to avoid losing an entire generation of young people, my generation, to the labour market and society. For me as a young Member of the European Parliament, the frightening figures of an average of 20% youth unemployment are anything but an abstract fact. Behind these figures are the faces of tens of thousands of my peers. Young people in Spain or Italy, but also in Brussels, Hainaut or Liège. I therefore welcome the Commission's proposal to make EUR 1 billion of early release to help young people find a place in employment, traineeship or training. The European Parliament must take its responsibility in this and approve the proposal as soon as possible. Timing is crucial in this matter. As a member of the Committee on Social Affairs and Employment, I would like to make a full statement. I also call on the Member States to use these resources without any means for concrete and effective initiatives to combat youth unemployment. But let's be clear: this extra pre-financing is, of course, only one element of the solution. It's just one wheelbarrow. We must continue to work towards a comprehensive strategy with better skills matching, encouraging entrepreneurship among young people, creating quality apprenticeships, investing in a flexible labour market and, of course, investing in sustainable jobs. Ladies and gentlemen, time is not just running out, the time is now!

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, following the communication on flexibility, this proposal to increase the pre-financing figure by EUR 1 billion to speed up the Youth Employment Initiative is certainly good news for European citizens, an opportunity for Europe to disarm those who want to bankrupt the European project. Parliament needs to find a common position quickly on the Commission's proposal and, above all, we need a firm commitment from the Member States. At least on this point, under the given conditions, Europe is playing its part and it is time for the Member States to do theirs more than they have done so far. Some countries, for example, have not made adequate use of the opportunities of the Youth Guarantee to bring inactive young people back into the labour market. I must point out, however, that the Commission's proposal does not set out any changes to the multiannual financial framework. I think we need to start discussing this. We therefore need to open a debate on the mid-term review and a real fiscal union and on the possibility for the Juncker Plan to support projects that can create jobs quickly and not just cash flow. We therefore need a new and incisive economic policy for investment and greater social justice, otherwise there will be no new jobs despite the Commission's efforts.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, again in the same play, viewers, we are once again discussing the crucial issue of unemployment among European youth. And what amount does the Commission now have? EUR 1 billion to pre-finance the much-publicized youth guarantee initiative. That is crumbs, considering that the European Union has allocated EUR 1 trillion to rescue the banks. Unemployment affecting young people in southern Europe is due to harsh austerity. In Greece youth unemployment reached 58% because, while Greece was given 215 billion euros in loans, these funds were not invested in the real economy but returned to the pockets of lenders. In order to beat unemployment in Europe, the European Union's production model must be changed. The policy of violent fiscal adjustment and the impoverishment of citizens must be abandoned. So we need funds, not crumbs, to create jobs for our youth. Because Europe can no longer afford to have 7 million unemployed young people.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: Mr President, youth unemployment in Europe is a scandal. While its magnitude varies from country to country, it remains generally at an unsustainable level. The economic crisis certainly amplifies it, but where it is rife, it calls into question the inadequacy of labour law, as well as the inefficiency of education systems. The countries where young people integrate most easily into the world of work are those that have favoured apprenticeships in business. In addition to mastering a know-how, the practice of a language other than theirs optimizes the strengths of young people to enter professional life. Unfortunately, too many young people are still away from mobility in the European Union, as if this adventure were forbidden to them. Let us raise the barriers urgently and financially support the movement. I call for the creation of a system for apprentices to recognize alternating training contracts outside their home countries. The aim is, of course, to encourage them to move outside the national framework, to open up to globalisation and its challenges. Colleagues, let us put an end to the rupture of equality that remains between higher education and apprenticeships in the right of young people to mobility in Europe. Finally, let us lay the foundation stone for what could become a European labour law by the establishment of an apprenticeship contract throughout the Union.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking In such a critical situation, where young people are currently in Europe, where on average one in five young people cannot find employment, and in some regions even every second, the European Commission's proposal to speed up the availability of funds for the Youth Employment Initiative is a very good decision and offers hope for rapid improvement. We all know that time in times of unemployment plays an extremely important role, as long-term unemployment has much greater difficulties in returning to work. Moreover, in many cases, through a lack of work and income, young people are approaching the poverty threshold overnight, the overshooing of which further exacerbates their situation and their opportunities for reinsuche.  By launching pre-funding in 2015, we are giving you the chance to intervene quickly in regions where more than 25% of young people are out of work, without any studies or training. All the more so because the lack of action in the Member States and regions where young people have been hardest hit by the crisis has often been the result of a lack of resources available.  Let us remember, however, that what the European Commission guarantees today is the availability of resources, not effectiveness in spending them. With each new multiannual financial perspective, we see a tightening of the requirements for the effectiveness of the management of European funds, which is a clear signal that not every euro spent is delivering the results it has delivered. The additional requirements for the use of the initiative's total budget of 6 billion and for reforms aimed at increasing young people's participation in the labour market are intended to ensure that the funds spent today produce long-term results and do not remain a one-off intervention without a future.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul Many measures of various kinds are needed to attack the extremely high unemployment rate among young people. That is why, of course, the Commission's proposal is a good one. So far, it has been too slow. It has been difficult to get a part of the European Youth Initiative because the Member States have been very cold, at least initially, but also because of other problems you have when setting up large projects.  Two reflections that I have after listening to the debate: would it not be good if we could try to involve the social partners – that is, trade unions and businesses – not only in their own pressing problems, but actually also to engage in the youth initiative and to take a greater role in giving young people a place and a meaning.  A second reflection is that it is also very important to think long-term when it comes to young and young people's labour markets. What we are seeing now is that jobs are emerging for both young and older people in some labour markets. In the United States, 10 million new jobs have been created. But what kind of job is that? We call it precarious jobs. These are texting jobs, they are zero-hours contracts, they are jobs that neither young people nor older people can ever make a living from. We must ensure that we do not end up in the American situation now, with regard to young people, but that we also have social thoughts and assessments about investment.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Mr. President, youth unemployment in some Member States is a serious socioeconomic problem. I believe that we will not solve it by simply allocating more budgetary resources, to youth initiatives, because in the member states where it manifests itself most, it is primarily about structural problems. We must insist on sweeping reforms that would allow young people to be edied in an entrepreneurial spirit and move towards achieving their projects with minimal benefits to the state and no administrative weights. Otherwise, we risk that quality ideas of European youth will never come to market, and their knowledge and enthusiasm remain untapped, which would be a huge loss for this Community. I also consider better linking the public education system to the private sector as I see no more effective way to respond to the fluctuating needs of the labour market.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: Mr President, I welcome this impetus to the youth employment plan and I hope that its implementation will have an immediate impact on the problem, which is, in the first place, a personal drama for many young Europeans. But it is also a problem for the future of our economy. We want to grow through knowledge and, paradoxically, the most prepared generation in history has more problems than ever before to access the labor market. Giving up this talent, as well as generating hopelessness and marginalization, drags our competitiveness. I also hope that the management of this programme will be done logically from the Member States. It is not to be acknowledged, Commissioner, that, as in Spain, the State manages 85% of the funds, and the regions, 15%, when it is established that proximity and knowledge are key to the success of this initiative. That is why I ask you, Commissioner, to monitor what States do with the funds, to implement regionalisation and to measure the results each of them achieves.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: Mr President, the Commission’s proposal of last week will surely prove to be beneficial, especially for Member States with high rates of youth unemployment, particularly as measures adopted so far have proven their limits. The main reason is that the Commission put the money at the disposal of the Member States but did not offer the proper means for them to use the money. Although the Youth Employment Initiative has been in place for more than a year, there are still Member States that have not yet – up to now – adopted the operational programmes that allow them to make full use of these funds. The late adoption of the European Social Fund Regulation and also of the MFF Regulation, as well as the delayed signing of the partnership agreements, also led to this situation.  Nevertheless, due to the condition imposed – to submit interim payment applications in which the European Union’s contribution from the Youth Employment Initiative is at least 50% of the additional pre-financing – some Member States might use the money for projects that do not really bring added value and might opt just to spend the money for purely statistical and mathematical reasons. The ʽhowʼ we spend the money is also important, not just the ʽifʼ we spend the money.  I would therefore like to draw attention to another issue which we will be facing next year. The entire financial envelope of the Youth Employment Initiative was frontloaded to 2014 and 2015, so next year we will have to use the global margin for commitments. But then again EUR 2 billion of this margin will be used to finance the guarantee for the European Fund for Strategic Investments and we do not know exactly how much money will be left afterwards.  So I think that greater challenges lie ahead of the Youth Employment Initiative in the future, particularly next year and the years between next year and 2020. Hopefully these shortcomings will be properly addressed, especially if the programme proves a real success through the recent measures.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Indeed, in this parliamentary term, we are constantly debating and looking for solutions to increase youth employment. Unfortunately, the results are so far that's really uneasy. Those 7.5 million young people who are neither in work nor in education are a real rebuke to us, politicians, of the need to look for concrete solutions, and that is why I certainly support the Commission's proposal to increase pre-financing to 30%, and if the Member States make wise use of this, then the situation in the Member States should certainly change, as so far not all countries have been able to implement the youth employment initiative due to the economic situation. , so this proposal is indeed very important. Training, appropriate and early vocational guidance, the quality of the science adapted to the labour market are essential and prerequisites for the emergence of jobs and for those young people to be recruited in those jobs. I therefore strongly urge the Council to support this Commission's proposal, while at the same time calling on the Member States to make the most of the advance aid provided by the European Union, because with this increased funding, we will certainly be able to bring back significantly more young people to the labour market.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I thank you for your intervention, and allow me to say that I am very much in agreement with your concerns and the measures you have put forward here. It is indeed unacceptable that more than 5 million young Europeans do not have a job. It is incomprehensible that no conditions, more and better conditions, are created to offer more than 7 million young people who cannot study and who are not part of vocational training programmes.  Europe has an obligation to act swiftly, urgently, to resolve this scourge of youth unemployment in the short term. We need social programmes, of course, but what young people expect, want and covet are job opportunities. Young people need to put their academic value into practice and they need to quickly gain skills to be able to enter an increasingly competitive professional world.  In Portugal, and despite the enormous challenges posed by the crisis, it is important – and going against what Mrs Lara Comi said... In my country, in Portugal, the Youth Guarantee has been applied in the best possible way. In Portugal, more than 180,000 young people have already achieved a professional opportunity and have made a huge effort to finish their studies.  But it's not enough, you have to do more. So, Commissioner, a generation ago, my generation, a generation of more ambitious young people who do not want to stick around: they want more and want no limits. Therefore, Commissioner, I congratulate you on bringing forward more than €1 billion in support for young employment, but I also challenge you to create an entrepreneurial ecosystem at European Union level that will enable hundreds of start-ups and thousands of jobs for our youth to be created. It is time, Commissioner, for the European Union to become a real start-up nation, so that all entrepreneurial actors are in constant contact and where new funding is available. I'll be done right now. We must, Commissioner, and I believe that we must not forget that the future of every country and the future of Europe belongs to each of us, belongs to young people.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking I agree with the Commissioner that proper funding and the proper use of opportunities in the Member States is crucial to the success of the Youth Guarantees programme. In this context, I would like to draw your attention to the problem repeatedly signalled to me by young people: these are traineeships and traineeships. Extremely important for gaining experience, acquiring practical skills and necessary in dual education. However, it is not possible to indicate on several occasions the place where the traineeship or traineeship took place. European mobility of trainees and apprentices is therefore crucial and the identification of a single centre, which would be a collection of information on possible places to train or traineeships. The quality of these traineeships and the proper social protection of both trainees and apprentices are also very important. And that is what should be enforced very strongly by the Member States. I will also mention the great importance of appropriate educational programmes, which should be created with the participation of labour market representatives.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Mr President, I would also like to thank the Commissioner for bringing this issue here. It's not new, of course, the numbers are alarming. When you find out at the beginning of working age that no one wants to hire you, it's a huge burden to start life, and it turns out that the state actually failed if it runs an education system that produces the unemployed. Therefore, if even in some Member States the unemployment rate is more than 50%, then we can talk about the failure of the system. If the system fails, then the causes of this failure need to be analyzed, no random measures will bring a long-term effect. Of course, the problem of youth unemployment cannot be pulled out of context, such as the quality of the education system, but also its targeting. I have completed an internship in Singapore and their education system is incredibly targeted at young people, its strengths and problems and I think that is just what we need to target our education system. We must admit that we are lagging behind in a number of criteria and in relation to the Asian education systems that have often outsmed us. I would like to wish you, Commissioner, that you can tackle the problem of youth unemployment from a certain perspective. As divided work in the Commission is a system, i.e. a horizontal perspective, I would like you to succeed in doing this too, because the system cannot be solved by this one proposal, and I think you are also aware of that.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Mr President, it is five to twelve for all those young people who are eager to show their talents in the labour market, but are not getting a chance now. In many Member States, youth unemployment rates are alarmingly high. Moreover, these countries are often systematically forced to make savings. So, to say the least, they don't have a penny to do to help their own young people into work. And the danger to a lost generation and the squandering of talents is thus lurking. By making EUR 1 billion available as a pre-payment to the Member States, the implementation of these plans to create new jobs can be started, and your initiative, Commissioner, is therefore a step in the right direction. But in order to develop the European knowledge-based economy with sustainable jobs, much more resources are needed. The investment plan will have a crucial role to play in this. In assessing projects, each Member State will have to take a good look at how many good, decent jobs they actually produce, including for young people and also for the medium term. Commissioner, your proposal is close, but it deserves all the support. That is why I hope that the Council will quickly agree to it, but I would also like to hear from you how you are going to ensure that further investment takes account of the jobs that young people so desperately need.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Commissioner, I welcome the proposal to pre-finance the programme to increase youth employment and, of course, I will also monitor the effectiveness of its use, because unemployment is a threat, a threat of exclusion, a frustration of young people, which we also sometimes see.  I can also confirm that existing programmes can also initiate the activities of entrepreneurs, especially in regions that have some economic or geographical disadvantage. And I could list specific young people who have subsequently found better jobs through internships. And, of course, these programmes cannot replace a stable sustainable environment, a competitive environment for our entrepreneurs, for the development of entrepreneurship in the Czech lands. But I think that is also in the hands of the European Parliament when we sometimes vote here on superfluous regulations.  Certainly, the role of education systems is also important, and where employers have not yet been involved, they should be given the opportunity to be involved in the preparation of training programmes and in subsequent practice. The Youth Initiative cannot be seen merely as a passive drawdown, but I see it as an investment in change and in long-term activities, and I thank you for this contribution to these programmes.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: Mr President, Commissioner, people tend to look at the youth unemployment crisis as a southern European problem, but if you look at the figures you will see it is a problem in all parts of the EU, including in my country – the UK – where over 760 000 young people are still desperately looking for work. If we are serious about tackling the terrible plight of these young people, we need to be much more ambitious, and whilst I applaud bringing forward money under the Youth Employment Initiative, I cannot help but think this is a mere drop in the ocean, a short-term boost without any long-term gain. Labour MEPs believe we need to see ambitious plans, in particular for the Youth Guarantee Scheme, which will boost and re-energise those young people who feel abandoned in the current job market. It is a shame the current UK Government has shown no interest in implementing the Youth Guarantee. However, Commissioner, I am sure you will be pleased to hear that my party – the Labour Party – is committed to a real jobs guarantee in the UK to get our youth unemployed into work.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: Mr President, during the negotiations of the past financial framework, one of the socialist group's main priorities was the Youth Employment Guarantee. The truth is that we did not get the Council to drop more than those EUR 6 billion that it wanted to put in for seven years, but at least we managed to concentrate that money in 2014 and 2015, because the priority is today and young people cannot wait until 2019 for us to implement these plans. But there's been a lot of trouble. There have been implementation problems, there have been delays in the approval of operational plans and, in addition, there have been funding problems. Therefore, we have lost an entire year and cannot afford 2015 to be another lost year, because we really need the Youth Guarantee to work. We now have this pre-financing ahead of us and we congratulate the European Commission, because that was one of the real problems. But now we have to make sure that the Youth Guarantee really gets going and reaches the young people who need it. Communication must be improved, because only two out of ten young people know that this European plan exists and the rest will never be able to ask to participate. And finally, we need to work on changing the financial framework. Because this advance in funding is going to create us a payment problem for 2015 and because in 2016 there is no money planned.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Mr President, I thank the Commissioner for the initiative she has just taken and the solution. We know that this is one of the difficulties posed by the Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative, and a solution was certainly needed.  But, as you have said, and we have all said it, young people have been the main victims of the economic crisis since 2008 and today the most vulnerable among them are those who do not have adequate education or qualifications: the NEETs, as we said earlier, those who are nowhere, who are left at the edge of the road. However, in the context of a context of austerity, an increasing number of measures are being taken to prevent Member States from taking structural actions for these young people, strong actions in education, training and investment in job creation. Commissioner, I am asking you one question. Are you prepared, in the context of the European semester, to ensure that you do not take away with one hand what you have given with the other, that is, not to withdraw the 6 billion that you are putting on the table today through the reform programmes, because these programmes remove the structuring actions aimed at these young people? Give us solutions in the context of the European semester in order to avoid the worst.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: The Commission's proposal to significantly increase initial pre-financing for the Youth Employment Initiative must undoubtedly be welcomed and supported as particularly timely and necessary. And in this regard, I would like to congratulate Commissioner Thyssen, who, in my opinion, deserves full recognition for her personal efforts in this regard. At the same time, however, we must be fully aware that this step is far from solving the issue. While there were 5 million and 600,000 under-25s out of work at the beginning of 2014, the current communication now speaks of seven million young Europeans who are out of work, without training or education. There is one more thing: the long-awaited mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy never took place. The Commission did not present its analysis, and my question to Commissioner Thyssen is this: Do you not consider it absolutely necessary to have such a review in order for the measures to be taken, really based on serious analysis, and not to be more PR action?

name: Elena GENTILE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, there is no doubt that this decision is the result of a new awareness of the difficulty of many Member States in initiating the planned actions necessary and indispensable for the promotion of new and more effective active labour policies. We will therefore certainly take up more quickly the objective of making young people payable the right to acquire new skills within training profiles that are increasingly geared to the needs of the business system, of that business system which has accepted the challenge of innovation and which today helps to give us a cautious picture of optimism linked to the first signs of recovery, at least in my country. But the challenge facing us is certainly much more ambitious and commits us to enhancing the human capital of young people. We ask them to promote together with us a new culture of enterprise and work that promotes growth in a new framework of social responsibility. Work, therefore, but quality work, and the quality of work, today as yesterday and certainly as tomorrow, declines above all in the field of workers' rights and dignity.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: Mr President, the word ʽapprenticeʼ comes from the Latin ‘to understand’, but I do not understand why the government of my country has allowed the number of apprenticeships in my own East of England constituency to fall by 6 000 in the last year, how four in ten firms that the government says are providing apprenticeships do not even realise they are doing so, and how almost all the previous growth in what our government calls ‘apprenticeships’ are people over 40, with 2 000 people over 60.  ‘The Apprentice’ has to mean more than the name of a TV show. British companies in the CBI this month found that the low level of skills is the greatest threat to UK competitiveness. In Britain, youth unemployment is rising again, with the UK behind both France and Germany and below the European average for young people not in employment, education or training.  I am proud to have worked to get European Youth Jobs Guarantee money for Thurrock in my constituency, yet, once again, the British Government’s delay in agreeing the programme means that while Parliament today is deciding to spend 30 times more on this fund, Britain has yet to get anything.  By simply rebranding what it means to be an apprentice, the government of my own country is simply branding itself as untrustworthy. Have I made myself understood?

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: Mr President, in Ireland last week we heard that youth unemployment is once again on the rise. Coupled with the mass emigration of over 160 000 youths since the crash, a lost generation of young people is being created. The European Union’s attempt to address these devastating levels of youth unemployment across Europe has been marred by a lack of ambition, funds and understanding. The EUR 6 billion allocated to the Youth Guarantee is a mere drop in the ocean.  If Europe’s leaders were less concerned with making themselves look good and more serious about getting young people into work, they would have created a properly funded scheme of at least EUR 21 billion, as recommended by the ILO. As it is, the scheme is simply once again paying lip service to our jobless youths. Yes, the Commission should frontload the EUR 1 billion but, without a well-funded system in place, young people are once again being offered overall an empty promise and not a guarantee of proper employment.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Mr. President, dear Mrs. Thyssen, thank you for these initiatives you're coming up with, since I'm sure you know the issues of youth and that you're really interested in this topic, but the numbers are really alarming. 5 million young people in the European Union are out of work, in some countries 50%. Unfortunately, my country Croatia also belongs to the very top of these percentages where a very large number of young people do not work.  Likewise, 7.5 million young people from the age of 15 -24 are outside any system, any education or apprenticeships, any kind of disfipulsion. It creates big social problems and that's why I don't like it when using the term lost generation. Unfortunately, it could become a lost generation unless we the elders all do something together. I believe that everything should be done to ensure that young people gain dignity, and dignity will be gained if they acquire the first position.  I think this is very important and I believe that this billion that you and Mr. Dombrovskis have set aside together, since you understand the problem, will significantly help member states to launch their operational programs and that really youth employment is no longer such a bile and urgent topic.

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: Mr President, there is one more thing I would like to draw attention to – a fine idea, as it is, and we must support it. I would also like to thank the Commissioner for taking it forward. But we must also be careful not to put young people in a training spiral. I have met numerous people of two degrees around thirty years of age who are in a constant training spiral. This leads to the idea that Mrs João Rodrigues addressed, namely that the investment programme and all EU measures must also contribute to improving competitiveness and creating jobs. After all, the European Union has been criticised many times for not moving forward with citizens' initiatives, but even good ideas are drowning in the Commission's bottomless bureaucracy, and there is some truth to that criticism. But this idea has really started with young people themselves, and it would be good if the Commissioner ever said this, that the idea was originally based on young people himself.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: Mr Presiding, Honourable Members, Honourable Commissioner, there is no doubt that youth unemployment is among the biggest problems of the Member States of the European Union. This is because youth unemployment is one of the main causes of internal migration within the European Union, large demographic disproportions and the depopulation of entire areas. This migration is causing huge demographic problems in a already severely demographically stricken Europe.  For example, there are such problems in my country Bulgaria. It is therefore prudent for the funds you provide to be channeled into the areas hardest hit by the demographic catastrophe and to focus on educating young people who can find their jobs and realisation where they were born and not be forced to migrate.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I congratulate you on this measure, and I congratulate the European Union on this measure, although it is a measure of an essentially palliative nature. The real solution to the problems of unemployment lies in economic policies of growth, not austerity.  Even so, I would like to draw your attention to a problem within this general problem of youth unemployment: it is the unemployment of young women. Young women are often forced to give up motherhood in order to have a job. Young women often have to choose between being mothers and having a job. And, therefore, policies that combat youth unemployment must also combat this iniquity, that young women may have a job and can also be a mother.  Finally, a word for effective scrutiny of how these moneys will be spent, because the recent past teaches us that they often disappear into corruption, in the purchase of political allegiances or in easy electoralism.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I come from a country, Galicia, in southern Europe, where the situation of young people does not differ from what has already been said here during this debate. More than a hundred thousand young people have had to leave, they emigrate to find work outside our country. Many thousands of young people are working in a situation of tremendous precariousness, which makes them poor workers, and many others have not yet had the opportunity to work.  In this context, we have also seen in our country that there are root causes of this situation, which are the neoliberal policies that have destroyed basic productive sectors such as fisheries, such as agriculture; that have destroyed a strategic sector in our economy as the naval sector; or that have destroyed and relocated production and businesses. In this context, we have also been affected by austerity policies and the Troika. That is why I ask you, Commissioner, to get to the bottom of the matter and review these policies. Other than that, the solution is not going to be real.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: Mr President, I have watched with interest this debate, and I see a lot of the Members of the British Labour Party here absolutely loving it – with big beaming smiles on their faces. And why wouldn’t they have? Because they can see, all through, infecting this room, the same thought process of ‘the answer to everything is big state, more taxes, more interference’. The same kind of thing that they ruined the UK with, they can now see the EU doing across the whole area – with every speech, a state growing larger and larger, and no real answers. Well, here is an answer: youth unemployment. It is a serious issue. What we need to be doing is to make sure we have sensible, controlled immigration into countries so that people can get a foot on the employment ladder. We also need to make sure that we do not constantly spend billions of pounds or euros on saddling future generations with debt that they will never pay off, just because people like the idea of the state controlling everything. It is time to throw away the ideas of the past.

name: Milan ZVER
text: I welcome the decision of Commissioner Thyssen, our former colleague, to release a billion euros already this year under the European Youth Initiative. These funds will be of great help, benefiting more than half a million young people in the 20 Member States of the European Union. My Slovenia is also among the countries that will receive these funds to promote youth employment, to create new jobs, to move faster from schooling to the labour market, to education and training. However, the European Commission must strictly monitor the use of money so that both mechanisms, the Youth Guarantee or the European Youth Initiative, achieve their purpose. If there is an increase, for example, the number of officials employed by the employment service, of course this will not be dedicated spending, we will do double damage with this. That is why I want the funds to be spent and purposefully and efficiently. Direct financial assistance will be an extremely welcome short-term measure. In the long term, however, the only way to solve the problem is by modernising the education system and by creating a healthy economic environment.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Listening to this debate today, a lot of Members– obviously including the experience of their own country – are in my ear, at least to whom you have stated that, since some governments do not really want this programme. So we see that, on the one hand, here in the European Parliament, in the European Commission, we have done a great much for the Youth Guarantee Programme, and somehow national implementation is faltering. In fact, some said he was being sabotaged by his government. Unfortunately, this is also the case in Hungary, and the government is not taking the necessary steps. In fact, I would ask how to make this programme more attractive, so that it is loved not only by the Union itself, but also by the Member States. I mean, what's happened so far, there's room for accountability, because a lot of countries, other than not loving it, are actually just using this program for some statistical cosmetics. I need real jobs, and that's why I'm asking.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: Mr President, Ladies and gentlemen, young unemployment is a worrying and frightening reality because of the figures it has and the consequences it has. In her initial speech, she said that 1 in 5 young Europeans are unemployed. That's about 5 million in Europe.  That is why I welcome the Commission's proposal to increase the pre-financing rate of the youth employment initiative in regions where youth unemployment exceeds 25 %, as is the case in Portugal, where the youth unemployment rate is 34.5 % and represents around 280,000 young people. On 4 February, the Commission reported that around €1 billion could be made available as early as this year to help young people who do not have a job, do not study or attend any training, the so-called NEETs, ranging from 15 to 29 years old.  Commissioner, I congratulate you on this initiative and I hope that the Commission will also set minimum standards to comply with the operational programmes to be adopted by the Member States with regard to the quality of traineeships, the dignity of wages and the stability of employment links. Commissioner, as you said, we can't waste any more time. It is urgent to rescue an entire generation at risk.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: Mr President, I believe that this programme does not respond to the reality of young people's problems. The measures that are proposed emphasize employability – again, employability – when the real problem we encounter is underemployment: most young people do not find a job that lives up to their qualifications. Not that they are not well qualified, quite the opposite: they have more qualifications than the jobs they find themselves with.  Our young people are being condemned to unemployment, precariousness and exile, because they cannot be called mobility. It cannot be called mobility: it is called emigration and exile. Austerity policies are destroying jobs; destroy quality in employment and destroy labour rights. It is intended to compete on the path of labour cost, rather than analyzing competitiveness from improving the capabilities of the production system. We need to improve the quality of employment and bet on innovation.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: Mr President, Commissioner, as the youngest member of this Parliament, I see in the youth guarantee much more than just a measure or just a programme. I see in it a real opportunity to change the lives of hundreds of thousands of young Europeans outside. At current pre-funding levels, we can reach no more than 22,000 young people. With the Commission's proposal, we can reach over 650,000. These are the 650,000 young Europeans who will stay here and create added value precisely in Europe. I heard colleagues say, "Not every young person can become a lawyer. Not every young person can become a doctor. Not every young person can become a star." Because the stars of this Union are not on the flag, but are among the young people out there.  That is why the Youth Guarantee must work in full sync with the European Social Fund so as to double the results. Member States must therefore take the fight against youth unemployment as a real priority. Moreover, this is also a chance for us to make the fight against youth unemployment a priority of words as a priority of deeds. It's up to us whether this becomes a reality. Thank you and I am admiring the Commission's intention to increase pre-financing.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. Thank you, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for this intense and fruitful debate. I can tell you that I share the care of the people. This is also the case for the other colleagues in the European Commission. The reality behind the figures mentioned here a few times is harrowing. Our budget is, of course, limited. We have to row with the belts we have and work with the budget that has been allocated to us. And you all know how we fought to get enough resources into the multiannh financial framework. With the resources we have, we do what we can. Especially when it comes to the youth unemployment initiative, we have made an extra effort. We have ensured that there is frontloading, so that the seven-year budget is pushed forward and that it can be used immediately. I think that's a very important thing. We have also ensured that projects eligible for funds from this fund, even those that had already started in the last quarter of 2013. We have as a rule that everything must be spent within five years, not within ten years, as is the general rule at the European Social Fund. We do not have a co-financing obligation for the Member States for this specific budget line, so that they can withdraw this money more easily. Now we are going to make sure that pre-funding increases and goes from 1 or 1.5% to 30%. So I think it will be very difficult to spend those resources even better. I therefore urge you to adopt this proposal quickly and, of course, I am making the same request to the Council. Now the question is: is that money well spent and where does it actually end up? This concern has been expressed here by several members of the European Parliament. Well, at the political level and in every bilateral contact I have had so far with ministers from the Governments of the Member States, I am raising this. Use the money, put it in, make it your work and also make sure that it is used properly, because if it is not used properly, we will act very quickly and very harshly and sanctions will be taken. My Directorate-General is doing the same and has since built up a reputation for being very efficient, always being willing to give guidance to Member States in building capacity, to give technical advice, but also to be strict, if necessary. We therefore do not hesitate to stop payments if there are reasons for doing so. I also assume that the social partners in the Member States do have a little more supervision, because according to the regulations, the social partners in the Member States are also involved in the drafting of the programme. So whoever is involved has a piece of ownership, feels called to follow what happens next. So I also count a little on the input of the social partners. As far as monitoring is concerned, the handling of the money itself, Member States have to report on the financial data three times a year. They are also required to present an annual implementation report and a first report on the Youth Employment Initiative will be published in April 2015. Towards the end of 2015, a full evaluation report will be published on the first year of the unemployment initiative, the way in which the money has been spent and the concerns expressed by the Member States. Coupled with the measure that is now before us, our initiative is to amend the ESF Regulation to allow for higher pre-financing; Member States must use the money effectively and within 12 months for the right purpose, and if they cannot prove it, they cannot prove it to the Commission, then the money will be recovered. So a lot of money is given upfront, more than we are used to, but it also makes extra sure that the money is used effectively for what it is intended for. I would also like to talk about the youth guarantee and the youth initiative. The Youth Employment Initiative, but also the Youth Guarantee – ultimately the great political objective and the great political commitment to which the Member States have committed – are closely followed in the context of the European semester. I can make it clear once again, or remind you that in the last semester exercise no fewer than 18 Member States of the Union received a country-specific recommendation on youth employment initiatives. We will continue to monitor this closely and we will also pay sufficient attention to this in the next semester exercise. But I am also very aware of colleagues – and several of you here in this House have pointed this out – that the problem will of course not be solved with this money, which is 3.2 billion, nor with the 3.2 billion extra from the ESF. With the pennies alone, we won't solve it. Solving youth unemployment is also a question of supply and demand in the labour market. So we also have to make sure that jobs are created. On the one hand, making sure that people are ready, that they have the right education, that if they are offered a job they can fill it, that they are sent to the jobs that are available, but of course there must be jobs. And that is why this Commission has been betting on a triangle from the outset. Budgetary responsibility, because we want to maintain or further strengthen financial stability. Structural reforms, including labour market reforms. And investment. We do not have to expect additional investment from governments, because they are tight in terms of finances, but there is a lot of dormant money in the private market, on the capital market, money that can be used for investment and that we need to get rid of. It is important to create attractive conditions for this. This is what we are trying to achieve, among other things, with our investment plan announced at the end of last year. That investment plan, the operation of which you have been explained here – there you had a question about Mrs Rodrigues, by the way – provides for investment in a number of key sectors, to ensure that Europe becomes competitive, but also in sectors necessary for the transition to a society, to an economy adapted to globalisation, which takes into account the digital dimension of society today. which contributes to competitive it and job creation. So I am counting on the jobs that will automatically arise by investing that money will also lead to new jobs. Europe, but especially the Member States and the regions, must then, if necessary, ensure that young people are ready to fill available jobs. Ladies and gentlemen, I think we all agree that we are talking about an immense problem here. It's not about a lost generation. We can't think about that. It's about addressing that issue and giving those young people hope, giving them prospects and giving them the opportunity, men and women, to start a life, to start a family, to make an investment, to do something in their lives. That's what we have to do. We have to make sure of that. And that's what it's all about. So for that reason I can only ask you again, help us to get this proposal through quickly. I know it's a drop in the ocean, but all the drops are helping and if everyone takes responsibility for the square metres on which they have powers, then we need to be able to tackle this problem and then we really need to be able to make sure that we give the young people perspective again. Thank you for your support.

name: Seán KELLY
text: Mr President, I just have a query regarding catch-the-eye. I was here for the last debate, I did not speak. I was here for the entirety of this debate and at the very outset – I could not do it any quicker – I bid for catch-the-eye. You were not presiding then. Most of the assistants around you were not presiding then. I want to know what criteria you used to select those you chose for catch-the-eye. One colleague said to me that I should try the lotto as I would have a better chance. I also want to understand why it is that when Members come in here and spend their time here and are told that they need to be here at the beginning to get called, they do not get called. It is not very pleasant. You seem to know some of those you were calling pretty well, which is all very fine, but I would like to know, since you were not here presiding at the beginning of this debate, what intelligence was brought to bear in choosing those you called to catch-the-eye. Secondly, as we do not have votes today, why did you not allow some more catch-the-eyes, and how many of those who bid did you not actually call to speak on this most important topic for all of us, and particularly those of us in countries like mine where there is very high youth unemployment?

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I would like to inform you that I have given a voice to those ladies and gentlemen from the various political groups who were at the top of my list, but I have not given a voice to many of the Ladies and Gentlemen I know, value and respect, but I have not given them a voice, so I would ask you not to suggest that I give a voice here to my friends. I am the 11th year in the European Parliament and I know a great many ladies and gentlemen, and I am very sorry that I was unable to give them all a voice today. I hope to be able to do so next time. Please accept my apology, if I could not give everyone a voice today, it really was not due to my bad will. The subject of this debate is very important for every Member State, including mine, Mr President.  Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. This week in Strasbourg, the European Commission proposed mobilising eur 1 billion in 2015 for the Youth Guarantee Initiative. We believe that this new aid, should it come true, can really help our young people. However, the Italian Government will have to monitor the programmes better and transparently from the various regions over the next few years. To date we know the total number of young people who have enrolled in the Youth Guarantee (more than 400,000 according to the latest official data), but we do not know how many have found a fixed-term or indefinite job. In the Committee on Culture and Education and through the Youth Intergroup we will continue to monitor the evolution of the initiative in general and the possible mobilisation of large resources for 2015.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. – After the first year of implementation of the European Youth Employment Initiative, the Commission has found that this is not occurring at the initially expected pace. This situation is particularly serious in Member States with more serious situations of youth unemployment. Spain, for example, which has the largest allocation of European funds for this programme, has taken more than a year to start launching this initiative. The Commission's proposal aims to increase the pre-financing rate of the initiative from 1% to 30%. Member States will therefore receive up to one third of the planned allocation during 2015, which could speed up its implementation. Despite reiterating our demands to ensure resources for this program in 2016 and to demand the increase in the budget for the period to the 21 billion requested by the ILO, as well as the coverage of young people up to the age of thirty, the Spanish Socialist Delegation wanted to agree with a measure that broadly considered it positive.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Commissioner Thyssen's proposal to mobilise EUR 1 billion to pre-finance 30% (up from 1.5% previously) of measures to promote youth employment under the Youth Employment Initiative is obviously positive. 5 million young people are now unemployed in the UNION, which is unacceptable. Of this billion, 13 million euros will be for youth employment in the provinces of Hainaut and Liège as well as in the Brussels region.  Having made the struggle for employment one of my priority fights in my commune of Farciennes and in the region of Charleroi, I can obviously only rejoice at this acceleration. Similarly, it is worth noting the contribution of ESF projects for the period 2014-2020 in terms of training, the fight against school drop-out, recognition of skills, etc. But these efforts must not be partially undone by the austerity measures advocated by the European Union, which de facto restrict the creation of these much-needed jobs. There is an urgent need to move away from socially destructive austerity in order to enable public and private investment to revive the economy and promote job creation.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – After the first year of implementation of the European Youth Employment Initiative, the Commission has found that this is not occurring at the initially expected pace. This situation is particularly serious in Member States with more serious situations of youth unemployment. Spain, for example, which has the largest allocation of European funds for this programme, has taken more than a year to start launching this initiative. The Commission's proposal aims to increase the pre-financing rate of the initiative from 1% to 30%. Member States will therefore receive up to one third of the planned allocation during 2015, which could speed up its implementation. Despite reiterating our demands to ensure resources for this program in 2016 and to demand the increase in the budget for the period to the 21 billion requested by the ILO, as well as the coverage of young people up to the age of thirty, the Spanish Socialist Delegation wanted to agree with a measure that broadly considered it positive.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. – In Europe we have very high levels of youth unemployment (23.5%) with huge disparities between Member States (germany at 7.8% in July 2014 and Spain at 53.8%). One in five young Europeans is out of work, yet there are around 2 million jobs available, largely due to the mismatch between acquired skills and necessary skills, the so-called 'skill mismatch'. One of the main weaknesses in the operation of the Youth Guarantee is the difficulty of Member States in pre-financing the start-up of activities planned at European level. This is particularly true for those States with greater budgetary constraints. In order to speed up and strengthen the implementation of projects in support of youth employment by the Member States, the Commission proposes the advance to 2015 of EUR 1 billion in terms of pre-financing, which I hope will be quickly supported by Parliament and the Council. In order to meet this challenge, we must invest, and invest well: in recent months, the communication on flexibility and the definition of the Fund for Strategic Investments bodes well. In this context, the proposal presented today by Commissioner Thyssen reinforces what we would like to see as the new course of European policies.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. – Today, in Europe, there are more than five million young people under the age of 25 without a job. If urgent support measures for young people are not put in place, there is a risk that the post-crisis generation will be a 'lost generation'. In order to combat youth unemployment, support initiatives financed by the cohesion package funds were needed. Their integration into the labour market has meant major investments in training programmes, encouraging "youth on the move" actions, qualification courses in new trades, specialisations in fields adapted to new technological trends.  It is worrying that the lack of work of young people can have serious consequences in the future with major financial implications. Firstly, their reintegration after a long period of rest entails numerous costs, on the other hand, the lack of activity is directly reflected in social contributions.  Given that in 2020, around 90% of trades will be directly linked to digital technology, adapting educational methods to technological developments is a necessity.  Supporting free youth initiative for start-up projects and supporting initial failures can restore the EU to the position of world player alongside the US and other competitors.

name: Lorenzo CESA
text: in writing. I would like to congratulate my friend, The Employment Commissioner Marianne Thyssen, on her initiative in favour of youth employment.
