With an additional billion euros, The Member States will have the necessary funding to launch immediately the measures to create jobs, traineeships and education and training programmes for young people in difficulty. As Commissioner Thyssen rightly pointed out, the problem of youth unemployment is one of the most serious in today's society and is likely to have serious socio-economic consequences, including for future society. The workforce is one of our most valuable resources, we absolutely must encourage it. We must work together, on the one hand the European Commission with the funds it makes available and, on the other, the governments of the Member States, with the appropriate projects and reforms in order to make the best use of them. One in five young people in Europe today is unemployed; according to the data that we have, in Italy, there are 729,000 children out of work and who do not follow any training. We can no longer accept this situation. As Members of the European Parliament we must be united in supporting this new Commission initiative and we call on the Council to do the same. Thank you.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I welcome Commissioner Marianne Thyssen's proposal to increase the amount of pre-financing for Member States in order to promote the employment of young people in 2015. This is a constructive and concrete proposal that will help to break the vicious circle. Member States with the highest levels of youth unemployment have the difficulty of providing the necessary payment for the implementation of the measures under the Youth Employment Initiative. Under this proposal, the EU will increase the pre-financing rate in its budget for 2015 from 1-1.5% to up to 30%. These changes will increase the effectiveness of the system. It will be easier to use the funds available for Member States facing budgetary constraints.

name: Damian DRĂGHICI
text: in writing. – The project to increase funds for young people is encouraging for those who do not have a job. Youth unemployment is alarming and poses a threat to economic stability in the EU. Projects are needed at the level of local and regional authorities to encourage youth entrepreneurship and vocational training. Financial resources should be allocated by region, with particular attention to the disadvantaged. We must not forget that youth unemployment is one of the main reasons for emigration.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. – Considering the difficulties that young people have in accessing the labour market, and the commitment of the EU to provide them with immediate support, I welcome the new change to the ESF regulation. This would allow quick mobilisation of resources for measures that have already proven effective in transforming the lives and career opportunities for disadvantaged young people. The European Youth Initiative is one of our means to increase the credibility, legitimacy and trust in the European institutions. This instrument raises awareness of the fact that Europe stands by the side of its young citizens to help them face the consequences of the current economic situation. For European support to make a real difference the Youth Unemployment Initiative must provide fast and substantial mobilisation of youth measures, well publicised by a broad communication campaign that reaches the greatest possible number of young people. I believe that supporting and monitoring cooperation with project partners is fundamental to help Member States to quickly implement the measures and to make sure that funds are spent where they are most needed and in the best way possible.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Thank you, Commissioner Thyssen, for this valuable initiative. I am pleased that the announcement to make the fight against youth unemployment a priority for this term of office has not remained just an empty declaration. The fact that extremely high levels of youth unemployment require rapid and decisive steps has already been said many times, including in this House. It is good that this time we are dealing with a concrete proposal which I am convinced of will make it very easy to implement the Youth Employment Initiative. The region from which I come – Lublin – is eligible for support under the initiative. In my discussions with local governments and potential project beneficiaries, the topic of the liquidity problem has often arised. The possibility of receiving a 30% upfront payment will certainly contribute to accelerating the implementation of projects at regional level by local authorities and smaller actors. I therefore hope that Parliament and the Council will quickly implement the proposed regulation.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. – The fight against youth unemployment should be a top priority. The draft that the European Commission has put forward is a good step but we need to see results. The unemployment figures in the European Union are still high. The reform has to start with the educational field that should help young people to integrate on the labour market. But this is not enough; lasting economic growth is needed. Mobility is essential and we must not forget that. Having more funds is very good, but we should know how to use them. We have to abandon austerity and invest in young people.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. – With regard to the Youth Guarantee initiative, I would like to draw attention to the fact that between 2008 and 2010, jobs changed in such a way that there was in practice only positive growth in terms of quality jobs in terms of long-term or full-time jobs, while for most of the new jobs it was more precarious status. It is important not only to pay attention to highly educated young people, but also to provide jobs and training opportunities for unsklined young people, but it is also difficult, since it is often an obstacle that they simply cannot obtain a diploma because they do not have a language test (the Hungarian Government also encourages this by special measures). The Hungarian government has already launched a large-scale programme to support young people in recent years. Just remember: unemployment was only 11% in 2002 (15-24), in 2010 it was 27%, and it can be said that, based on the work of recent years, this indicator has now fallen to around 20%, which is half as much as the Spanish or Greek indicators and better than the French, Belgian or Finnish indicators. But we can't stop here, we need to take further action.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. - The message to Member States from the outset of the establishment of the YEI is clear: a swift response and concrete measures aimed at integrating young people into the labour market are essential. The deadlines set for the implementation of this initiative differ from all other programmes.  The funds should be contracted by the end of 2015 and the activities carried out and the funds disbursed by the end of 2017, no later than 2018. With a view to speeding up Member States and insuduing them to act urgently, the Commission has enabled funding for young people's employment costs since September 2013. It is Now February 2015 and instead of the first payments to Member States according to payment requirements based on the activities carried out, the European Commission had to come up with a new incentive for faster implementation, which is an increased amount of advance payments to as much as 30%.  I welcome this decision by the European Commission, but we must all understand that the decision and debate in the European Parliament on the increased advance in 2015 is an indication that we have failed when it comes to young people. We need to accelerate and at least these measures for which the funds are there immediately, and which are intended exclusively for the employment of young people, we must realize as planned, immediately, not in 2023. It's too late for the young.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: writing – There are more than seven million unemployed young people in the European Union. The most vulnerable are those who do not have the necessary qualifications. The labour market better integrates young people who have the necessary qualifications or the necessary training. We want to provide funding for pre-financing to give young people a chance as early as this year. The YEI will complement the funding provided by the European Social Fund in Member States whose regions are struggling with youth unemployment above 25%. This initiative involved 20 EU countries. The good news is that in the European Parliament, the project is supported by the left, the right and the European liberals.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The European Commission suddenly seems to be discovering the extent of the social damage caused by youth unemployment in Europe. It is proposed that we add EUR 1 billion here to finance measures which will undoubtedly have more than limited effectiveness. And for good reason, since we do not tackle the bottom of the problem ... In fact, 7 million young Europeans are unemployed or without training, even though access to work is supposedly a fundamental right. 23% of under-25s are unemployed in France, 55% in Spain... This social scourge obviously has multiple causes, but all of them are bringing us back to the European Union, to Brussels. Euro, ultraliberalism, massive and uncontrolled immigration, free movement, total lack of Community and even less national priority, seconded workers, these are the economic, monetary and financial dogmas that have curbed economic activity and edug the job market in Europe, and in France in particular. Therefore, once again the Union behaves as an arsonist firefighter who tries to put out the fire that she herself lit with a half-empty sewing dice... States must recover their national sovereignty as soon as possible, so does the future of their youth!

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. The 30% increase in the pre-financing rate of the Youth Employment Initiative is very good news. I find the decision to prepare, alongside the Juncker Plan, which we all hope will really lead to an increase in employment, a substantial investment in a specific initiative for young people, very appropriate. I fear that, even with a possible increase in the number of jobs available, young people would still have enormous difficulties in accessing the labour market, for a number of reasons: from an inefficient link between supply and demand to insufficient vocational training to accompany the last stages of their educational career. This initiative could be a very important aid on both sides, both that of access to employment and that of vocational training and, I hope, could begin an overall (and permanent) improvement in the system of linking education and work. Now the Member States have the necessary resources to be able to really change a dramatic situation, it is their responsibility to make the best use of them.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – Increasing the funds dedicated to the youth guarantee by EUR 1 billion is a positive thing but, I think, insufficient for the 7 million unemployed European young people. The problem of youth unemployment is a systemic one generated by the current economic context, our inability to make progressive and rapid decisions but also by the lack of a long-term strategy. A coherent plan at European level is needed today more than ever because Europe is today the hope of these young people. We must supervise and support Member States in achieving policies and projects with real results in long-term job creation. I do not believe that closing borders is the solution, but precisely opening up, but also developing common social and environmental norms. 3 million Romanian citizens, for example, live in other European countries and contribute 2% of the GDP of Italy and Spain, treat English and French patients in hospitals or build houses in Germany. I support a European solution and propose that we adapt to the world of tomorrow by investing in the training of tomorrow's professionals. A sustainable direction is digital or sustainable development.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – Dear Mr President, combating youth unemployment is an important priority in my work. In Bulgaria, the proportion of young people between the ages of 18 and 24 who are not working or studying is 22% and significantly exceeds the EU average of 13%. In my country, the highest proportion of young people with whom the employment services cannot make contact has been recorded. The proportion of inactive young people is above 14% and is twice the EU average. Youth unemployment and early school leavers are also above the EU average. Among the main challenges of the Youth Guarantee in Bulgaria are the need to strengthen training and apprenticeship initiatives and to expand active employment policies in order to detect staff with an appropriate profile. That is why I am pushing for an increase in youth employment, with the scope of the Guarantee extended to all young people up to the age of 30, not to 25, as it is now.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The Commission decision to frontload the resources allocated to the Youth Employment Initiative in the first two years of the 2014-2020 period shows a genuine commitment to tackling the severe issues with youth employment that we are still facing. It also acknowledges the fact that timing is crucial and that bold decisions are needed in critical situations, which I welcome. Making EUR 1 billion, or one third of the whole YEI allocation, available in 2015 alone will ensure that projects in Member States roll out more quickly and thoroughly. And while the focus of the measures proposed by the Commission is on the financial aspect of youth policy, I am eager to emphasise the importance of how these funds are to be spent and what the overall strategy of reforms is. Subsidies and grants alone cannot fight youth unemployment. The EU needs to optimise the structural circumstances in the labour market by supporting thriving, job-creating businesses on the one hand, and encouraging skills-building on the other. If we truly aim to invest EU funds in projects with added value and long-term effects, we need to reward entrepreneurial spirit and strengthen the real drivers of the economy; to tackle the causes and not the effects of failure.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. - I welcome the European Commission's decision to make €1 billion from the YEI budget available as early as this year. This will increase up to 30 times the pre-financing that Member States receive to encourage youth employment. The constraints in the budget of the Member States and the lack of funds available at the initial stage of the programming period have caused delays and delays in implementation at the national and regional level.  Young people are a specific group in the labour market, characterised by a lack of work experience and practical skills, making them vulnerable to the market and threatening long-term unemployment, with young women at higher risk of long-term unemployment. Work experience is crucial for employers, but they are reluctant to provide it themselves, which leads to long-term unemployment in young people, because without work experience they cannot find a job, and at the same time have nowhere to acquire it. With this decision, the European Commission sends a clear signal that youth unemployment is their priority and that it wants to support member states' activities to return young people to work or in the education system, i.e. to include them in training programmes.  In Croatia, one in three young people is unemployed, so the funds from the Initiative should be used to increase stable and sustainable employment and self-employment among unemployed young people, as well as to increase competitiveness in the labour market.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. – There are many reasons why young people find themselves in such an unfavourable situation: the economic crisis, the inconsistency of the education system with the needs of the labour market, the insufficient social sensitivity of employers. After two years of adoption of the Employment Initiative, we cannot be satisfied with the results at Union level, primarily due to a lack of funds.  In particular, this applies to the member states hardest hit by the crisis, where the highest youth unemployment rates are also. But you can also see some positive changes. For example, in Croatia, some progress has been made in the past eight months, and youth unemployment between the ages of 15 and 25 has decreased by 8%. This proves that active employment policy measures are delivering results.  It is also pleased that this is recognised by the Commission, which improved the original proposal and significantly increased funding. However, Commission measures are not a permanent solution. We need to fundamentally change the problems. Everything that is possible should be done to prevent our most educated generation from becoming a lost generation.

name: Marek PLURA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent At the outset, I would like to thank the Representative of the European Commission for his participation in today's debate. I am extremely good that the Commission has made a proposal to speed up the payment of advances to the Member States. According to the proposal for regulation, the Commission has already adopted 28 of the 34 operational programmes introducing the initiative and has closed negotiations for a further 4. These figures show a strong determination by both the Member States and the European institutions to improve the situation of young people on the labour market. I hope that the EUR 1 billion launched this year will contribute to new investment and economic growth. According to the latest figures, more than 7 million young Europeans are not in work or education. Moreover, in the European Union we also have a problem with erless jobs. I hope that the implementation of the initiative will help to address the problem of non-adaptation of resources to the needs of labour markets.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: in writing. – Although discussions on the Youth Employment Initiative have clearly demonstrated divergences between Member States, I believe that addressing this issue at European level is welcome and should be encouraged. We all know that youth unemployment is rising on a daily basis. Market demands are sometimes ridiculous, requiring work experience from young people who have just come off the banks of educational institutions.  The problem of youth immigration - many, many of them with higher education - shows us the seriousness of the situation at European level. The problem that arises is a very serious one: in countries where they emigrate, they create competition in the local labour market, often leading to conflicts. The search for a job for young people has today become a cause for psychological struggle. The fight for a youth job has already become a cause for racism. The lack of jobs is causing a decline in the new generation. We must support any initiative of citizens or institutions, European or national, that creates jobs for young people.

name: Anne SANDER
text: In writing. I welcome the European Commission's proposal to speed up the release of the EUR 3.2 billion youth employment initiative in regions where more than one in four young people are unemployed. Commissioner, you can count on my support, in the Employment and Social Affairs Committee, to get this amendment voted on as soon as possible, because there is an urgent need. Indeed, if current pre-financing rates are not increased, only 20,000 young people will be able to take advantage of the opportunities offered by the initiative this year, while more than five million in Europe currently have no jobs or professional prospects. In addition to this assistance, which allows a young unemployed person to be offered a job, internship or training within four months, we also need a real policy for business, entrepreneurship and growth. The young people in my region, Alsace, who unfortunately will not benefit from the initiative, must be able to count on Europe to accompany their ambitions. Thank you.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. Mobilising a billion euros in funding for the Youth Employment Initiative could help up to 650,000 young Europeans to enter the labour market or re-enter the education system. I hope that this accelerated pre-financing will help to give a real boost to youth employment, which continues to be one of the key priorities on our European political agenda. It will be up to the Member States to ensure that these funds are made available to beneficiaries immediately as soon as the operational programmes are approved. However, we must not forget that this plan alone will not achieve the objectives we set ourselves in the fight against unemployment. I am convinced that it must be accompanied not only by complementary measures that can tackle the root causes of unemployment, but also by a more in-depth debate on European policies in this field. We must ensure that not only young people, but all unemployed people, have the opportunity to regain their right to work.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. – Youth unemployment does not affect all Member States in the same way. In Germany the youth unemployment rate was only 7 % in November 2014, but in Spain it was 54 %, in Greece 50 % and in Portugal 32 %. Without a job, young people cannot emancipate themselves and pursue their life projects, and economic development is compromised. The effects also make one feel about birth, which affects the future sustainability of the Social State. This initiative is perhaps a little late. Especially for countries such as Portugal, which, by virtue of the austerity measures imposed, have seen an accelerated degradation of employment and, as a result, in recent years, a young emigration unparalleled in its recent history. I come from the Azores, an OR where the regional government is a pioneer in adopting measures aimed at promoting youth employment. However, it has not been easy to combat the harmful effects on businesses and families of the austerity policies imposed by the Troika, which greatly affect the macroeconomic environment.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: skriftlig. – The current situation for young people in the labour market is not the most rosy, as it does not give them a promising perspective and a peaceful insight into the future. This is also illustrated by the eu-level youth unemployment rate, which stood at 23.6 per cent in 2013. Obviously, some Member States do not have the resources to deal effectively with this problem, as otherwise the situation would be improving. But it's not just unemployment that's a problem for young people. Many young people who are employed have a shable employment relationship that does not provide them with stability and sufficient guarantees to create normal living conditions. For this reason, they always decide to start a family later. They simply doubt the future. Therefore, the Youth Programme presented by the Commission is a step in the right direction. At the same time, it is necessary to verify whether the measures are also enforceable and in line with the real situation. For too long, we have been referring to young people as a major problem of the EU, and nothing noticeable happens. And if we do not act immediately, trust in the EU will continue to build up. It is justified to expect a programme of measures that will be financially concrete and realistic, timed and equipped with indicators to measure their effectiveness. Only in this way can we move from words and promises to actions

name: Sergei STANISHEV
text: in writing. – I welcome the Commissionʼs proposal to increase the pre-financing rate of projects financed through the Youth Employment Initiative (YEI) from around 1 % to 30 %. The fight against youth unemployment is one of the top priorities of the Socialist family. It was on our initiative that the European Union adopted the YEI and the Youth Guarantee Recommendation. We have been calling for a speedy implementation of the Youth Guarantee. Youth Guarantees have shown great success in tackling youth unemployment in countries where they have been implemented. This is why I call for the Youth Guarantee to be extended to everyone under the age of 30 and for a substantial increase in its budget.  Increasing the pre-financing rate to 30 % will facilitate easier access to the funding and will accelerate action on the ground. Over 7.5 million young people aged between 14 and 24 in the EU are neither in employment, education or training. That is why our political family will ensure that the increase in pre-financing is confirmed by Parliament and the Council and made available without delay.

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: in writing. – Dear Colleagues, The provision as early as this year of 1 billion euro youth employment initiative, whose total budget is €3.2 billion. euro unambiguously shows that one of our most pressing tasks is to return young people's hope and self-esteem to a successful realisation of the European labour market. Unemployment among young people under the age of 25 remains high - more than 5 million. 21.4% in the EU-28 as of December 2014. NEETs). Bulgaria is first in Europe on this indicator with 21.6% at an average RATE for the EU - 13%. I therefore welcome the COMMISSION's proposal in 2015 to increase many times (30 times) pre-financing for Member States from the Youth Employment Initiative. As a result, this year Bulgaria will receive EUR 16,556,624 out of a total of EUR 55.2 million. youth initiative for projects to reduce youth unemployment in addition to funding from the European Social Fund. The effective implementation of the Youth Employment Initiative depends on Member States' efforts to increase young people's activity and interest in the opportunities offered by the EU for employment, training, traineeships and entrepreneurship.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Written. – At a time when 7.5 million young people in the EU are out of work or not in education, strong measures to tackle this unacceptable youth unemployment are essential. The Communication from the European Commission to provide more pre-financing to make it easier for Member States to implement the EYI is therefore positive. Unfortunately, it is not about additional money, but about releasing already planned amounts more quickly. However, I believe that additional resources need to be invested in tackling youth unemployment.  Not only is the number of young people unemployed immense, research shows that young people who are unemployed at the start of their professional careers suffer disadvantages throughout their careers. The review of the MFK in 2016 should be used to provide additional resources. After all, without additional resources, the budget for the EYI has already dried up in 2016, while I fear that the youth unemployment problem will unfortunately not be solved.  An additional problem that the European Commission needs to address: Member States where youth unemployment is high are often also those that are forced to adopt a strict savings policy. It is difficult to save and at the same time invest in opportunities for young people.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. – Youth unemployment, which is around 50 % in some countries, is unacceptable. In Portugal, around 280,000 young people do not work, study or train. In the European Union, the average youth unemployment rate is around 23 %. Two years ago, the Commission launched the Youth Guarantee. However, two years after the adoption of the Youth Employment Initiative, the results are clearly unsatisfactory. The Commissioner for Employment has now announced an extra allocation for the pre-financing of €1 billion in youth employment promotion operations to directly support 700,000 young people. Of course, this reinforcement is welcome, although it comes late and is clearly insufficient. But more than this reinforcement, what we would like to see is, first of all, an assessment of the implementation of the programme so far, to understand what has gone wrong. Secondly, what we would like to see are effective policies to relaunch the economy, from which young people would benefit much more than this programme.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Writing. – According to the latest Eurostat data, my country, Greece, maintains a negative lead in unemployment at 25.7%, although it showed the largest decrease in the year level. At the same time, high youth unemployment kept it in second place in the EU, with 49.8%, after Spain with 54%. Despite a significant reduction in youth unemployment of 1.7%, across Europe the labour market situation is particularly difficult for our young people, regardless of their educational level. They often end up either unemployed or on limited employment contracts, reduced pay and a lower level of social protection, or are forced to accept precarious employment contracts or periods of unpaid work. However, the allocation of EUR 1 billion from this year for the Youth Employment Initiative will significantly increase the pre-financing received by the Member States to tackle unacceptable levels of youth unemployment and social exclusion. This will help our young people to integrate smoothly into the labour market by providing them with education and training. Our young people are the future of Europe. We must act today, immediately and in a coordinated way. If we do not, the costs will be disastrous for employment, productivity and ultimately social cohesion.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – The prolonged economic crisis and the spectre of stagnation and recession that threaten the euro area, but also the whole of the EU, are putting immense pressure on setting the priorities that the Union, as well as the Member States, must take into account. Many of the measures are urgent, but nothing can be more urgent than intervening through concrete measures in favour of the 7 million young Europeans who today do not have a job nor are they included in any form of education or education.  The proposal to increase the pre-financing of the Youth Employment Initiative by EUR 1 billion for 2015 is welcome and justified. I support the approval of this initiative in the EP and the awareness that the effectiveness of this measure also depends on action at European level, on implementation at Member State level and on a pro-active attitude of the young people themselves. It is our duty to draw their attention to the new possibilities, to inform them of the programmes that are intended for them and to mobilise them in their participation in these programmes.  It is disappointing that the debate in the EP was a new opportunity for Eurosceptics and populists to call for a limit on mobility in the EU, thus proposing false solutions to real problems.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. – Young people should be one of the priorities of the European Union and I therefore welcome Commissioner Thyssen's communiqué for the accelerated pre-financing of the Youth Employment Initiative. But we need to be aware that the Youth Guarantee is only part of the solution. Joint action is needed. Structural reforms should be continued by the European Union and the Member States. In this respect, Spain is an example to follow: after a very ambitious reform process, it is now at the forefront of the eurozone in terms of growth and job creation. The European Central Bank has once again demonstrated its commitment to maintaining price stability by presenting on 22 January a series of more ambitious unconventional measures than expected by financial markets, and for which I have no doubt that they will also contribute to growth and job creation. For its part, the European Commission continues to work on the European Strategic Investment Fund (EFSI) to stimulate the European economy, and it is time for us all to face as a team the great challenges facing the European Union; without a doubt, one of them is youth employment.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. – Increasing the pre-financing rate of the European Youth Initiative is positive. But we cannot confuse the advance of funds with the increase in funds. This programme, according to the ILO itself, should have 4 times the amount and this underfunding condition has not changed. The question is: what types of work are being created? It is your quarterly analysis of Employment and Social Situation that says that many of the new jobs created are part-time and/or temporary. Let's look at the example of Portugal. Excluding education, training or traineeships, which are obviously not jobs, this guarantee finances fixed-term contracts and also pays young people to travel to work interviews outside the country. What we need to know is how many fixed-term and stable employment contracts are being created.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission by Marita Ulvskog, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on promoting the financial participation of workers (O-000002/2015 - B8-0103/2015) (2014/2987 (RSP)).

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: author. - Mr President, I will speak my own language, Swedish. No, I will speak English. Parliament has previously called on the Commission to assess potential policy initiatives aimed at reducing the barriers to cross-border employee financial participation – so-called EFP schemes – and to provide information on, and raise awareness of, the issue, as many European employees and employers, in particular SMEs, currently lack access to information on the legal and fiscal frameworks for EFP schemes. A recent Commission study recommends a five-point plan to promote employee share ownership. However, the implementation of such policies entails significant challenges, and there are risks for the employees involved. On behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I would therefore like to ask the following. How does the Commission intend to promote employee financial participation in the light of Parliament’s resolution? What lessons have been learned from the recent pilot project? My second question: how does the Commission intend to ensure compliance with the principles set out in the 1992 Council recommendation – i.e. no substitution of wages, no discrimination and no conflict with participation in decision-making? My third question: how does the Commission intend to promote best practice for employee ownership schemes? Fourth question: how does the Commission plan to ensure employee participation and the inclusion of workers’ representatives in the planning and implementation of such schemes? Fifth question: does the Commission intend to develop models of strategic ownership as regards employees’ shares in ESO schemes so as to serve the long-term interests of companies and their employees? Sixth and last question: what measures should be taken to protect employees’ savings invested in a company, in the event of a crisis or of the company becoming insolvent, so as to avoid the double risk of employees losing their job, income and savings at the same time? A comprehensive involvement of employees and their representatives requires proper information concerning the underlying risks of joining a participation scheme and also raises questions related to taxation and labour law. How can the Commission ensure that workers are not being used, that all employees obtain equal access, and that they never have to face the risk of financial ruin should the company concerned run into insolvency?

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, I would like to thank Ms Ulvskog and Parliament for initiating this debate. I see employee financial participation as part of a broader narrative of sustainable entrepreneurship in Europe which I want us to support and to encourage. It is a complex issue with wider implications.  Recent research suggests that companies with employee shareholders tend to create more jobs, pay more taxes and relocate less than those without. Employees owning shares could also increase the proportion of long-term oriented shareholders and provide a solution to some business succession problems.  A number of recent Commission proposals have aimed to address the weaknesses in corporate governance identified during the financial and economic crisis. The proposal for a shareholders’ rights directive is part of this agenda. I am convinced that we will find a sound compromise. This being said, currently less than one third of companies in the EU offer financial participation to their employees. It may also be an internal market issue as the divergence in national, legal and fiscal rules for such schemes could create barriers to cross-border plans.  The Commission committed in its 2012 Action Plan on company law and corporate governance to investigating potential obstacles to transnational employee share ownership schemes and to taking appropriate action to promote employee share ownership throughout Europe. The pilot project launched in September 2013, which consisted of a comprehensive study, and the conference held in January 2014 helped the Commission in analysing the existing obstacles. The Commission intends to make the comprehensive information gathered in the study widely available to all interested parties. Given the diversity in national approaches to employee financial participation across the EU and the resulting cross-border problems, the Commission encourages the exchange of best practices, be it between Member States but also between companies and employees. When reflecting on the way forward the Commission will also take duly into account Parliament’s resolution from January 2014, as well as contributions from stakeholders. We will also be guided by the principles set out in the 1992 Council Recommendation on employee financial participation.  Let me also stress one important aspect: financial participation should not be a substitute for the main income. Instead it should play a complimentary role and be paid in addition to a fixed wage. Such schemes should in principle be open to all employees and treat them without any discrimination, unless some differentiation is justified given the employees’ different needs or interests.  The Commission takes note of Parliament’s resolution, in particular as regards consultation of workers or their representatives on such schemes before their introduction. Social partners taking part in negotiations at company level, according to national practices and traditions, should be involved. Employees belonging to trade unions should not be discriminated against.  The 1992 Council Recommendation also underlined the need to take into account national collective bargaining legislation or practices when choosing between the schemes available. Negotiations on such schemes should not replace the normal negotiations on wage setting and working conditions.  The potential risks of financial participation also need to be addressed. Employees participating in such schemes are exposed to the risk of losing both their job and their savings in the event of serious problems in their company. This is one of the most commonly seen drawbacks of employee financial participation. Reasonable risks when designing and running such schemes need to be avoided and employees should be provided with sufficient information about the details of the schemes and any risks involved.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, this is an issue that has been on the European agenda for some time. The first 'Pepper report' was presented in 1991, almost 25 years ago. I was seven years old at the time. So I won't say I've been through that knowingly, but I can look back on what's happened over the last 25 years. If one thing is certain, it is that here in Europe, and certainly in the European Parliament, we are fully convinced of the potential added value of financial participation for workers. Employees feel more involved in the company, are more connected to the long-term prospects of the company and they are more motivated to commit to that company. At the same time, this is also reflected in the better results that companies achieve as a result. And that, as the Commissioner himself rightly said, leads to more jobs, more jobs. So that's all good. At the same time, we have seen that over the last 25 years, systems of financial participation of workers have developed in different ways and at different rates in different Member States. Certainly when it comes to tax and social legislation, there are many differences in Europe, and with the increase of the internal market, with the increase of companies operating across borders, we are also seeing an increase in the number of cross-border obstacles. I therefore welcome the European Commission's plan, the five-point plan, in particular with a view to raising awareness and providing better information, because we all want more financial participation in a good framework with adequate protection for workers, but we have there as a Europe, as you rightly said, , not everything to say about it. I think we should fully support your approach. I've got three more questions. 1) How can we prevent financial participation from being put in place in some cases by existing participation structures? 2) Does the development of financial participation correspond to the increasingly flexible labour market? And how do you see, for example, the participation of employees on temporary contracts? 3) As far as SMEs, small and medium-sized enterprises are concerned, how can we ensure that small businesses can participate in such systems in a good way without too much bureaucracy and at no too much cost?

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Models of financial employee participation can be of lasting benefit to both companies and employees. This goes beyond the economic element: it is also about mutual appreciation, identification between companies and employees – this can also be strengthened by such models. It also serves a sustainable and long-term orientation of the company. In order to make these models better known across the EU, we need a stronger exchange of best practice examples. These examples include the sociedades laborales in Spain or the employee participation foundation of voestalpine AG, which is the only model in Europe with international voting rights bundling for individual share ownership. But in order to realize these benefits for both sides, clear ground rules are needed. This includes information and consultation of employee representatives, but also participation in decision-making bodies, early and comprehensive involvement of workers or their representatives in establishing such a model, the involvement of the social partners and a certain level of protection for workers from the double risk – on the one hand, losing capital in the context of participation and, on the other hand, the usual risk of losing their jobs. And, importantly, the European way of employee participation must not undermine national law. Commissioner, I would ask you to clarify how you intend to ensure that these basic rules are followed, especially in the case of cross-border models of financial employee participation. Only if, on the one hand, workers are fully involved and, on the other hand, they have to take as little risk as possible, will these models also be successful throughout Europe.

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, last year was the most successful year ever for employee ownership in the United Kingdom – a year which saw more people at work in the UK than ever before, and a year which saw 83% of new jobs being quality, full-time and permanent.  Employee-owned businesses have played a leading role in delivering the UK’s economic recovery. 2014 saw the number of employee-owned businesses rise by some 9%. Some 30% of employees in the UK hold shares in their company. Sadly, in many other European countries, ownership has actually declined. In the UK, our flagship is the John Lewis partnership with some 82 000 employees or partners. Companies range from the very small to the very large and represent a wide range of sectors. Overall, they contribute some GBP 30 billion to the UK economy. In my own region, we have employee-owned companies ranging from a veterinary practice in rural Herefordshire to a world-leading manufacturer of machinery protection systems in Kidderminster, from the largest independent chartered insurance brokers based in Birmingham, to a family-owned food distributor in Willenhall that has been trading for nearly 100 years.  The thing they have in common as employee-owned businesses is higher productivity, greater innovation and better profitability. Employee owners also think and act for the long term, sometimes in marked contrast to the short-termism that can prevail. I want to pay tribute to the Employee Ownership Association which champions this business model so effectively.  So what is the EU’s role in this? As always, it is to create the environment where businesses can thrive and grow, by addressing skills shortages and by removing barriers, but above all by reducing administrative burdens on business, especially micros, and making it easier for businesses to compete in the global market place.

name: Ulla TØRNÆS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, growth and job creation are very high on the agenda for all of us. We would all like to see jobs back in Europe. We had a very good discussion on youth unemployment prior to this discussion. I really think that we have an obligation to look into all possibilities for supporting growth and job creation.  In this perspective one perhaps minor, but important, thing could be employee financial participation (EFP). EFP can strengthen small and medium-sized enterprises, offering mechanisms for innovative financing, as workers may wish to invest in shares in the company by which they are employed. Despite these possible benefits, the focus on EFP varies from Member State to Member State. This is the reason why I am participating in this very important debate today, because when it comes to employee share ownership and employee financial participation, the Commission and Parliament – as was mentioned by my colleague from the EPP Group earlier on – have been doing a lot of talking. We have done studies and have collected information, data and knowledge. Now I think it is time to act. I would like to ask the Commissioner a very simple question. Are you planning to put forward a proposal for an action plan on this issue? At EU level in recent years we have taken a lot of initiatives regarding employee financial participation. We have adopted an opinion on employee financial participation, we have made several studies, we have adopted a resolution, we have completed a pilot project and so on. Now I think it is time to act. What concrete measures does the Commission intend to take to act on the promotion of employee share ownership? Which, if any, of the ideas in the pilot project promoting employee financial participation does the Commission actually intend to implement?

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, worker participation in corporate profits and the sharing of property can certainly, as we have seen and all of you have said, bring benefits, both financial and non-financial, both to workers and to businesses. Giving workers the opportunity to participate in the business activity and its management means making people more aware, more responsible and more involved throughout the work process and allows entrepreneurs greater efficiency and productivity. I am not saying this out of hear or theories, but because I have been a consultant in small and medium-sized enterprises for years and this was precisely the approach that we have always used, a win-win approach where both entrepreneurs and workers who have to be part of a single team and fight to achieve the same goals must win. I can proudly say that all the companies that have followed this approach, small and medium-sized Italian companies, in past years, have been companies that saw their profits and turnover increase and saw the living conditions of their workers improve. So this is the actually correct approach and the approach that we have to follow. We have done a lot of work on investment in training and these companies have always developed much more than other investments in training. So the time has really come to ask the Commission for a truly executive approach and concrete actions in this regard. We need to find rules that are precise, that are certainly able to protect the part of the employee, as they should be, but that finally give both companies and workers the opportunity to develop a new model of entrepreneurial management, really giving entrepreneurs the opportunity to play their part in a much more active way.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, the economic participation programmes for workers are generally moving in the right direction. It is, of course, a prerequisite for there to be a job. We must help to reduce high unemployment rates, a phenomenon particularly observed in the countries of the South. In this area we are all trying to give our best. However, on the subject we are discussing today, we must take into account some very serious issues, always with the aim of safeguarding workers' rights and protecting them from risks, as it is obvious that not every employee can have the knowledge of an investment adviser. Our aim is, in my opinion, to set some very basic rules. First of all, we must ensure that the participation of employees in the share capital of the company should under no circumstances be compulsory. Nor should the salary of workers or part of it be replaced with shares; employees, after being paid, can simply choose to buy shares in the company as a matter of priority. Finally, our proposal is that those who wish employees should be able to be represented as a shareholder as a whole, so that they can effectively exercise control over the management of the company. In any case, our priority is to protect workers' rights as well as to highlight the best prospect for workers.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done on this I am speaking here today not only as a Member of the European Parliament, but also as someone who spent many years in business, in small and medium-sized enterprises before moving into Parliament. I can already say that, in my view, employee participation makes a great deal of sense, in three respects: on the one hand, for employees, on the other, for employers, but also for companies. That is why it is good that we are dealing with this issue, even though I have been very surprised that this has been an issue for so many years and decades without any reasonable conclusion being reached. I would like to make two or three points as to why this is good for workers and for employers. It is clear to employees that it is a direct participation in companies and also in the success of companies, but it is also a stronger attachment of employees to their companies and thus a higher motivation. It is good for companies and employers because they can tie their most important capital, namely their employees, even more closely to their companies, and thus perhaps also improve their capital structure and, to a large extent, their creditworthiness. I would also say, however, that it is important to implement this instrument of employee participation only as a complementary element and by no means a mandatory element in Europe, for various reasons. I come from Germany. We have good structures in Germany, such as a company age group that is insolvency-proof and has been in place for a long time. With employee participation, we might have a double burden on many employees by having to pay into retirement provision once and perhaps also to employee participation. The second problem is that it is very easy to introduce public limited companies, but it could be very difficult in small and medium-sized enterprises. That is why I say that we must be careful not to require entrepreneurs to give up property rights without wanting to do so. To my conclusion, I would like to continue to work on this. But Let me be very clear: complementary and voluntary, but by no means compulsory.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, employee financial participation plans can become a very important instrument for increasing the level of social protection for European workers. These are intelligent schemes that seek to achieve positive situations, objectives and positive results for workers and companies, maximizing social utility. But this can only be done under certain conditions. Firstly, it is essential for the Commission to improve access to information on these plans, which will have a useful impact on the European economy in proportion to their dissemination. In this sense, the transnational aspect cannot be underestimated in order to activate a truly European system that overcomes potential situations of double taxation or forms of restriction on the exercise of the economic freedoms guaranteed by the Treaties. The resolution adopted by the European Parliament in January 2014 underlines how these instruments can constitute a kind of shock absorber that distributes investment risk among the main shareholders of the companies, while also ensuring that employees have an equity portfolio of savings. It remains crucial to ensure that, on the one hand, these instruments do not replace traditional welfare measures, which are essential for maintaining European social protection standards, which have already been seriously challenged by the short-sighted application of these doctrines that we have seen in recent years concerning the consolidation of national budgets. On the other hand, these instruments must be directed towards a truly sustainable model of economic management, investing in the highest level of consultation and participation of workers and trade unions at the various stages. Therefore, the objective of reducing social inequalities must be the priority at the heart of these instruments.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Mr. President, A colleague of Ulvski's has asked very high-quality questions. I will personally support any well-developed model based on voluntary grounds and strictly legally regulated employer-employee relationships. I believe that voluntary financial investment of workers in the company is a quality bond between employers and employees, because it creates a lasting relationship of financial interdependence. Workers would be motivated by such a regulated relationship through inclusion in the management process and financial rewards for good business, while employers would be more inclined to invest in the company longer term, primarily in the field of education and professional training. In addition to being based on voluntary basics, transparency and quality employee information, such a model should also be strictly legally defined.  I believe that the legal instability of certain Member States will be the main obstacle to the uniform application of this model at Union level. This is an additional reason why I think that the desire of this House to make decisions about the financial participation of employees at the company level is extremely positive. While the role of the state, first of all, should be to adopt an effective model, ensure the rule of law and protect the right of employers and employees to choose for themselves whether they want to apply this model in their company or not.  (Speaker agreed to answer the question "blue card" (Article 162(8) of the E.S. regulation)).

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr. President, Mrs. Tomašić, I assume you agree with me that privatization in the 1990s swept the Croatian economy and destroyed many companies. But I don't know if you agree with me that privatization has enabled small shareholders to become owners of those companies, for example Adris grupa from Rovinj, which have shown vitality and become exemplary, strong and good Croatian companies, thus bringing this financial interest of employees to the fullest.  I'm interested in your opinion on the subject.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr. Jakovcic, I think that privatization destroyed all post-communist countries, because the same people who were in power in communism, came to power again.  And as for adris group, it would take greater tightening, supervision and a little more management supervision and assistance and concession granting to workers.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: Mr President, already this morning we discussed the right to strike and the need to create new jobs to tackle youth unemployment. Our current discussion on the promotion of employee financial participation has some potential to help deal with both issues. As a worker and an employer, you are much more likely to recognise the rights and duties of all partners, and employee ownership schemes have some potential to create more and better jobs. However, for me one matter is paramount, and that is the potential that employee financial participation has to ensure a better share-out of the wealth that is being created by employment. The gap between workers and those with wealth continues to grow, and employee financial participation can help bridge that gap. Today we asked a number of questions of the Commission, and while we were told about an action plan and about risks, etc., I am still waiting to hear specific, concrete actions. Listening to all the colleagues, it is clear that employee financial participation varies significantly from one Member State to another, with a glowing report from the UK. I agree with Ms McIntyre in that we need the Commission to create, first of all, an environment that is conducive to the take-up of these schemes, and secondly, the flourishing of these companies. You, as Commissioner, have an opportunity to make a real difference here after years and years of talking. I look forward to hearing your proposals.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: Mr President, the financial participation of employees in their companies, whether individually or collectively, is obviously very desirable. Limiting absenteeism, encouraging the personal and collective involvement of professional teams or the transfer of business are signs of good health of a company, especially an SME. However, you want to reduce barriers to transnational employee financial participation schemes and, in your opinion, help to train companies through a virtual communication centre, a code of conduct, an online calculator of effective tax rates, etc. Of course, this is a real framework directive that is looming - you do not hide it - and, in the long run, another binding legislative proposal. Because, as always, in a totally schizophrenic strategy, under the guise of a good idea, you are putting in place schemes that aim at more Europe. Today, it is the reform of European corporate law and internal corporate governance, the same companies that you bring to your knees by too many regulations, too many diktats or too much competition. These companies, which are increasingly filing for bankruptcy or vegetating with structures that are both too large and too small to perform, are increasingly weakened. Wage savings can be a real opportunity, but only in the context of national prosperity, free from any monetary and economic constraints imposed by Brussels. We therefore refuse that by this project wage savings should also be crushed in the blatant failure of fifty years of European employment policy.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Dear Colleagues, It is regrettable that it took nearly 20 years for Europe itself to realise that full and almost completely uncontrolled market liberalisation had caused enormous social and economic damage in Europe, including in Central and Eastern Europe. Following the regime changes of 1989-90, a huge wave of privatisation took place in the eastern half of Europe, with nearly one million people losing their jobs in Hungary only. It seems that we need to learn again and again the lesson that market liberalisation should only be achieved between countries with nearly the same or similar economic strength. Otherwise, social differences will change greatly. I consider the programme of financial participation of workers to be useful, but I also consider it to be too late in historical measure. I welcome this form of protection for workers, but I also draw attention to the need to pay particular attention to the cost of living, in particular european energy prices, thereby improving Europe's competitiveness.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Mr. President! We are debating the participation of workers in companies here today, and we – at least most of them – agreed that this is definitely a very good idea. But we are also discussing how we protect workers when the company goes bust and the investment and the job are both lost. To ask such a question is typical of the EU and also typical of this House. Firstly, why are we discussing the issue here at EU level in the first place? Does this need to be regulated uniformly from Finland to Portugal? What happens if this is regulated differently? Will the euro collapse again, or the European Union? Secondly, when do we start to understand that the chance of winning is always a risk of loss? If you want to participate in the profit, you have to bear the loss, not just any third party. This is unfair, and it also applies to workers. But what is clear in this discussion is your human image. Their view of humanity in the EU seems to be that people, including the worker, cannot make a responsible decision. So he is immature, and he is not free. This is not my human image. Man is responsible for his actions. Man is mature, and man is free. Let us build on this our future! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: the blue card. – Dear colleague, I wanted to ask: in fact, there are quite different salaries in Europe, especially the minimum wage, and people in different areas are protected. I wanted to ask you how you think, although the general movement of capital in Europe is free, and the movement of people, and the movement of goods, but in order for people to live with dignity, or should not be talked about, that some kind of minimum compulsory income would be introduced in all the Countries of the European Union that companies should respect, and then people could participate in full and other financial instruments.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. The question concerned a Europe-wide minimum wage: we in the Alternative for Germany and I personally do not believe in this at all. This is, in principle, a decision between the employee and the employer or between the representative companies, between the employer representatives and the employee representatives, who have to regulate this. But we cannot make a single wage for europe as a whole. We can already see what happens when we make a single currency for the whole of Europe: then there are always those who cannot handle it flexibly.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the European Commission must make a determined commitment to industry and technological innovation, but without forgetting non-technological innovation, which allows us to move towards new management models in companies with a strategic vision for the future, with the participation of workers in decision-making in business management , in profits and even in capital, in order to achieve more competitiveness, more jobs and more social cohesion. The Basque Government is committed to these principles and has just launched the Innobideak Pertsonak strategy and allocated EUR 8.1 million in 2015 to advance these objectives. I would like to ask the Commissioner if she is aware of these projects and how she intends to implement and share the projects that already exist at the regional level to advance these objectives; if you plan to introduce this House with regulations in this legislature for debate; and I would like , of all not — to invite you to come to the Basque Country, if you do not already know it, so that you may know us and know how we do things.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking It is becoming increasingly clear that the Union has abandoned the idea of its founding fathers building a social market economy, where not only the costs of the crisis but also profits in times of prosperity are the share of all social groups. Today, the profits of companies – especially multinational corporations – are increasing and the real wages of employees are decreasing. Mechanisms for the financial participation of employees in the company's profits, or the institution of employee ownership of the company, are important ways of solving this problem – properly implemented can help to solve the problem of dramatically increasing social inequalities, while at the same time strengthening the links of employees with their workplace. The study, co-authored by expert professor Lowitzsch on behalf of the European Commission, states that after 30 years of research into examples of employee financial participation, companies that are partly or wholly owned by employees generate more revenue, are more productive, generate more jobs and pay more taxes than their competitors without this kind of financial participation. At the macroeconomic level, these companies achieve a higher level of productivity, which also makes them more competitive and growing. At the regional level, they make companies owned by employees remain tied to their place of origin, more resistant to external or foreign takeovers of property.  Nevertheless, we must bear in mind that there are also significant risks involved. Firstly, it is necessary to be very careful when implementing these mechanisms in small and micro enterprises, as they can affect the competitiveness of these companies. The second risk is more related to employee ownership in investment projects. The recent crisis has shown very clearly that in the event of a collapse of the economy, workers may lose not only their place of employment, but also the savings placed in the company's shares. In the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, we have come up with a question together with the European Commission, in which we stress that by promoting broadly understood financial participation of workers, we must also consider mechanisms to prevent them from losing their entire lives and ask how the Commission intends to promote a mechanism for employee financial participation and the exchange of best practices on the company's employee ownership, such as those in the UK, referred to by Anthea McIntyre.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Financial participation is one of the ways companies can encourage their employees to be more involved. At the same time, it is also one of the ways or instruments of ensuring the sustainable development of a company. Although this is a good opportunity for both employers and employees, the introduction of different schemes still raises very big questions in individual countries, and this process is going very slowly. I also worked very closely with the employers' association as a representative of the employers' association. And the key question was whether financial participation should be compulsory or optional. At the same time, some other important issues have been raised. There was not enough awareness that property not only brings positives and profits, but that property is also a liability. And, on the other hand, there was not enough understanding that, of course, profit participation cannot be a pay paycheck. And on the third page, there was not enough understanding that this method of cooperation must also have adequate tax treatment, otherwise it is not of interest to anyone. So, because the process is going very slowly, I support these issues addressed to the Commission, and I hope that we will no longer waste time and we will introduce this method of financial participation to all countries as soon as possible.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, this is a subject that fascinates me greatly. I come from a land that through this kind of popular shareholding has built its fortune. Of course, there is great concern and the six questions raised by the rapporteur are important, especially when a worker is there with his work and there with his savings. That is the great concern.  I believe, however, that we need very broad and very clear rules, which we can define as a framework, where communities have the capacity to transform the same enterprise into a community. It is very important that workers with the social partners and the company with the intermediate bodies build guarantees. They can be done together, and it is very important for unemployment that small businesses, which today more than yesterday need resources that they do not find in order to grow, in order to increase their employment, can do so without those laces and laces, as we say, that compromise higher costs without any institution being there more to disturb than to facilitate. We must regulate, regulate well, but the business community has the skills: workers and entrepreneurs. I believe that more needs to be done on employee profit participation in good performance. Entrepreneurs need to do more, because a business community has development and perspective, while a community that can't do business has neither development nor perspective.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: Mr President, the financial crisis has caused revenue stagnation in many Member States, and in some cases even a decrease in the share of value added created in companies that belongs to employees. Not coincidentally, recently, the British Prime Minister, speaking to businessmen, told them that the time had come to increase employees' incomes. I believe that stimulating employees to become shareholders in the companies in which they work is an effective way to increase revenue, as well as to motivate them in the results achieved by the company. I appreciate, however, that the best way to stimulate employees to become shareholders is the policy of each company in profit distribution, as well as the fiscal policy of each Member State, which must encourage this process. I believe that at European Union level we can only think about the extent to which certain regulations are needed in the area of supervision of companies in which employees become shareholders.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking While sharing the idea of financial participation of employees in property, it must be stated that decisions to introduce any such schemes should remain in the exclusive sphere of influencing the property of the owners of the undertaking. I am therefore looking with concern at the european Commission's proposals, which suggest the possibility of introducing a European regime for the financial participation of workers. Such proposals must be objectionable. Especially if they were to include micro, small and medium-sized family businesses. Actions to be voluntary should not be formalised. And certainly no bureaucratic and costly solutions should be created, such as promotion centres, expert groups, the adoption of new legislative standards. Such solutions are part of a culture of doing business, not legislation.  The domain of doing business is the ability to bear the risk of your own investments. If so, the priority in managing a business must be only knowledge and experience, that is, competence. These criteria cannot replace bureaucratic ideas for introducing non-market rules for interfering in decision-making and accountability. Their implementation would have to end in a disaster similar to the collapse of the communist economy based on companies managed by the proletariat.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: Mr President, Commissioner, next year we will celebrate the 125th anniversary of a text which reads as follows: "That paid work ... they are not shameful to man, but of great honor, as they give honest possibility of earning a living. That what is truly shameful and inhumane is abusing men as for profit and not estimating them in more than how much their nerves and muscles can give of themselves." There is a paradox that, according to an Oxfam report, in the same year of the celebration, in 2016, 1% of the world's population will hoard 50% of the world's wealth. What's going on? Because something's failing. In the recent report entitled 'Promoting ownership and participation of workers', the Commission recommends promoting the participation of workers in the shareholding of undertakings. And we agree if we in turn respect the idiosyncrasies of different business cultures in the various Member States. Several studies on this topic conclude that employee co-ownership of a company increases production and profitability, improves dedication and sense of belonging, creates more jobs, and makes more taxes paid. The significant variable is to combine ownership with a high degree of worker participation in work-related decisions. We wanted to point out to you and we are very interested in the response we must work to remove cross-border barriers within the European Union that limit this mechanism of financial participation of workers, as well as introducing aforementioned elements, such as the establishment of a common legal framework and the adoption of measures to protect, in a certain way and at first, as an incentive , the savings invested by workers in an undertaking, in the event of a crisis or insolvency of the company.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: I am very supportive of the participation of employees in the ownership structure. I have experience as a business owner. Even as mayor, who introduced ownership of the employees of the company to the utility company, which was a public limited company. With this ownership, we stimulate the key needs of today, that is, trust in the company. Trust in the company and long-term thinking of both employees and management. There is too much of a seeming conflict in our society between capital owners and employees. One and others want responsible behaviour, long-term orientation, and this employee participation allows for just that. It is also very important that countries introduce appropriate tax breaks that will support this participation and respond to the problems of today. It is also very important that these are the right answers, particularly for medium and small enterprises, which will be driving development in Europe.

name: Neena GILL
text: Mr President, I support and agree that the employee financial participation schemes have the potential to benefit both companies and their employees, not only by offering direct financial benefits to workers, but also because, when done right, such schemes can actually foster ownership and participation of employees in their companies – a concept which, as a Labour MEP, I am very supportive of. I am glad to see that, through this file, the UK government is finally making an attempt to promote responsible capitalism, an issue on which my party has been leading the political debate. However, my first concern will always be protecting the workers. I believe it is important that we do not run ahead of ourselves and that strong safeguards are put in place that deal with possible risks linked to these schemes. My question to the Commissioner is: what actions will be taken to inform and educate trade unions or other relevant organisations about these schemes, in order to empower them and to advise employees of the possible risks?

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the issue we are discussing is particularly important, especially after our debate on youth unemployment. Let me therefore make five points: firstly, the participation of workers in company decision-making contributes to strengthening economic democracy. Secondly, participation should be extended to participation in the economic benefits of the company, in my opinion mainly in participation in the distribution of profits. This not only strengthens social justice but also creates significant incentives to increase productivity and boost employment in business itself. But why don't we see this happening in Europe? Because the shareholders of the companies want the profits to be distributed exclusively to them. Take for example what happened to the profit distribution of CAC 40 companies here in France: 50 billion will be shared from profits. Fourthly, the matter must be dealt with at Member State level. Finally, there must be safeguards, i.e. this participation should not be compulsory, should not compensate for wages and should protect workers' rights.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, we who come from Slovenia or croatia know what self-management in companies means. This was a Yugoslav experiment that, of course, failed because it had no financial interest from employees embedded in the system. Namely, there was an interest of employees in the company, but there was no financial interest. So, after that, the privatization of the company took place and I know good examples in Slovenia, as my colleague Bogovič used to say, and which I mentioned, in which state-owned enterprises were privatised so that small shareholders and employees became owners of these companies. I don't know examples of where such companies have gone under - in fact, I know very profitable companies and I think these experiences are very interesting for what we're talking about today as well. That's why I wanted to warn you, esteemed commissioners, about these experiences and, of course, express my support for your intentions, because I think they are extremely good for workers and employees in companies.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: Mr President, is this initiative truly beneficial for workers or just, and in the times we are living in today, a way of trying to hold workers accountable for the management problems and financial problems created by those who have always profited from these companies but who now need to be saved? There are several experiences that we know that say that workers who became shareholders of companies ended up losing rights, such as the right to pension, since the pension of these workers was affected due to the insolvency of companies, but also lost their salary and even the job.
