In other words, they did not even receive the promised profits, and ended up unemployed as well. So the risks are enormous. States, public investment must be mobilised for economically important companies, and workers should not be forced to put their lives at risk. (The speaker agrees to answer a question under the "blue card" procedure in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – You and many of the people here have placed great emphasis on protecting the labour rights of those who owned the company. I therefore have a question for you, but also for the European Commission. If it is said that not all employees have the same financial knowledge as to the level of risk on the free market as to the management of a company, then, on the one hand, they should be allowed to share the same rights in the ownership of the company, under the same rights to manage the company, but also to differentiate the rights to protect their property vis-67 against other co-owners? On what basis would such "equality" (in quotation marks, because so de facto non-equality) arise?

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – We have no doubt that workers have all the conditions to manage companies, because they have proven several times in history that they can do so. It's not just managers. In fact, managers often manage them more disastrously. Now what it is about is ensuring that it is not the workers who are going to take the risks and probably situations that are no longer viable, because it was the managers themselves who put these companies in an unviable situation. It is not the workers who will have to pay for it, and therefore they will often present them with a situation that is apparently good, but is actually not feasible and will eventually disadvantage workers rather than benefit them.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: I, too, join those who, of course, welcome and support the proposals for the introduction of cooperation programmes and projects and, of course, the legal frameworks of workers at profit. Of course, this is also linked to the system of co-management and corporate governance. Here, of course, we collide with many issues, both rights and obligations, and I think that whatever this initiative will then take, it is necessary to be absolutely clear on these issues. In some countries, these attempts have been more successful, in some fewer cases, but I think the main problem that has arised in all of this is, in particular, the lack of clear definitions, on the one hand, of obligations on the part of employers and employees, and rights both in management itself and in making a profit. However, it is clear that this is also a question of the socio-economic system, which at the moment is not, in my opinion, very favourable to this form, but this is, of course, an issue for future courses.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the financial participation of employees is the wrong hypothesis with no future. There is no point in burdening the shoulders of a single person with the risk of losing a salary because his company closes and at the same time sees his savings destroyed. It is no coincidence that all the speakers have asked themselves how this contradiction should be resolved. No one has a proposal. The reason is simple: the role of the shareholder is inconceivable and incompatible with that of the worker. Therefore, only the cooperative solution can guarantee unity between these two functions. Any other solution is impractical.  Then, Commissioner, you have to agree with each other: on the one hand you want to encourage stable shareholding, on the other hand you want to promote labour mobility. In the case of employees becoming shareholders, this contradiction explodes. So we are looking for a composition between capital work in the traditional form, which is to assign roles and functions to the collective representation of both.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Membre de la Commission. - Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your contributions during the discussion. I would perhaps like to mention in my brief reflection one point of view that we have not discussed here, and that is the point of view of a consumer who is entitled to quality services. This greets visitors to the gallery.  Now, maybe what we're talking about here, I'm going to zoom in on a little practice. Even as a consumer myself, as a person who goes to the store, sometimes when I come across a saleswoman who is unhelpful, unwilling, slow, who lets me know that I'm harassing her, I wonder what she actually gets out of it to make the store prosper. And I'm thinking that it would be good if people in the service were motivated financially to leave me as a customer feeling that they respected me there, and that's why they served me well. So that's what we're talking about here today, ladies and gentlemen.  I would like to respond by saying that the Commission has as its great objective growth and employment, prosperity and stability of the business environment, as has been said here. At the same time, improving the conditions for doing business and not burdening you with additional bureaucratic burdens. These are all objectives and, at the same time, pitfalls that we must address in the Commission with clever and well-targeted legislative proposals. And that's among other activities I'm not going to mention here. In any case, today's debate showed me that we mostly understand the greater participation of employees in corporate governance and information and in codecision and increasing the ownership of companies as beneficial for business. That we don't actually see this in the first plan as a social aspect and a social improvement in the lives of employees, but it's just good and demonstrably good for the results of those companies. This is demonstrated by both the long-term debates and parliament's previous resolutions, and this is demonstrated by the study that the Commission is now working with, which we received on 28 October last year. This study proposes some specific measures that I will follow in preparing a possible legislative proposal, which, as you know, cannot come this year because it is not in this year's work plan. However, we will be considering a reflection on the draft legislation for 2016, which, however, and I can probably guarantee you today, will rather be a voluntary instrument. I do not think that we can come up with something from the position of the European Union that we will order someone to do, because there are indeed big differences between member states in the business culture, as has been said here, in the ability of employees to understand the investment activities of companies, and in some countries there is a need to increase their awareness. There's also an interesting passage about that in the study I had the opportunity to read. This means that it will be legislation of a softer nature, i.e. voluntary and rather a recommendation that will refer to examples of good practice.  Mrs Bilbao Barandic said here that she sees this as a recommendation for a good and successful corporate governance model. I see it very similarly because I also came from a business environment, I ran a company and I also worked in the private sphere for a long time. I think that in the search for a good model for corporate governance, we must always be treated and directed towards appropriately distributed responsibilities and risks. And these are all things that we have to deal with if we want to offer a good model to follow, one that can be used in all Member States despite the big differences.  We have a big task ahead of us, but I can only agree with those who have said that strengthening the motivation of employees by being financially involved is positive for the economy. I am not going to quote here from what the study recommends, but very briefly: it is, for example, the establishment of a virtual online hub, an online tool to inform about these good models, it is the establishment of an expert group, it is actually the creation of that action plan that some of you have been calling for here. I'm not saying at the moment that we're going to follow those recommendations to the point, but we're going to be very inspired by them and we're going to consider them very seriously. Thank you for the offer of the Basque model and project, I will be very happy to look into it. At the same time, thank you for the contributions of those of you who have called for improvements in cross-border business. You know that we have before us the preparation of the second phase of insolvency proceedings, the rules on insolvency proceedings for cross-border business, so thank you for these inspirations, too, and for giving me interesting ideas for the policy of improving consumer conditions, I spoke about this at the beginning.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate.  Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. – Next to the "whip" of wage and pension cuts and redundancies, the EU and its parties are using as a "carrot" traps of integrating workers into the interests of the company and the system that drains them, to disarm them and reconcile them with exploitation. The "participation" of workers finances capitalists through the forced reduction of the labour wage since part of it, with employer terrorism, is withheld as participation in a venture capital that does not share profits but only losses. In Denmark, companies can reduce wages by up to 7.5% and use what they withhold to boost their liquidity and capital adequacy. These are considered to be high investment risks and employees can only claim them in the event of profitability. The chapter promotes the "participation" of employees and the "self-management" of bankrupt enterprises, which were welcomed by the current (SYRIZA-ANEL) but also the previous (ND-PASOK) Greek government in the context of so-called "social entrepreneurship", and turns workers into micro-entrepreneurs of their misery, loading them with new debts. It is the other side of the so-called 'national unity', the one that puts workers under the flag of their exploiters, for the benefit of the latter. The solution for workers is not to participate in the companies of the exploiters but to put the companies and power in their hands, in the service of popular interests.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The next item is the report by Inés Ayala Sender, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on facilitating cross-border exchange of information on road safety related traffic offences (COM(2014)0476 – C8-0113/2014 – 2014/0218(COD)) (A8-0001/2015).

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, the truth is that I have to say that I am quite excited about the fact that we are finishing in this House today, I expect a long-term dossier, which has a long but finally venturous history. And, as Shakespeare said, everything's fine, if it ends well. In 2008, under the French Presidency, we were able to implement the first proposal, which precisely envolved this decision to end impunity, to reduce discrimination between offenders in the field of cross-border road safety. It is therefore an essentially European, cross-border dossier, which also aims to improve road safety, reduce road casualties and the injured. But it is true that, in 2008, we launched a comprehensive, bold procedure, which was actually based on information and the support of victims' family associations, important and European bodies such as the ETSC, or European associations of traffic authorities, such as Tispol. And we were therefore able to carry out that formula, that procedure, so that cross-border offenders would first be informed of their infringement, after returning home, and could be fined to end that impunity. But, as so often, the Commission and Parliament were not accompanied by the Council. The Council blocked, out of various fears, the procedure and we were not able, until 2011, to resume it. And here I must pay tribute to the Belgian Presidency which, with its creativity and its tenacity and courage, was able to resurrect this dossier with a true legal basis: the legal basis for police cooperation. But it was the way to be able to put on the rails a process and a procedure so important to end impunity in the field of trafficking. And it was the Belgian Presidency, together with the Hungarian, who again relaunched the procedure; on another legal basis it is true, although we were able to improve some aspects. We lost, for example, the presence of important Member States, such as Ireland, the United Kingdom or Denmark, but instead we could expand the list of assumptions and improved some of the proposals for such police cooperation. So by November 2013, we already had an instrument that should have been transposed by all Member States. And, at that time, shortly the after, in May 2014, the Court warned us of something that we had already been anticipating, but which we had not been able to ignore, which was that the initial legal basis, which had been provided for by the Commission and supported by Parliament, was the basis of road safety. This was obviously an obstacle, in the sense that the Member States were already implementing and successfully implementing the Information Exchange Directive, but the Court's decision had to be taken into question, as we have always done. I have to say that the Court was particularly clever in giving us the possibility of having a few months to put the text back on track. This was done by the Commission, to which I am very grateful, and again Parliament and I have to say that in this case we went and have been especially generous; and I look at it because I will then want to ask the Commissioner for something in return for parliament's generosity. Parliament did not want to reopen the whole dossier this time, to redo the Directive, which we did not like 100 percent, since the procedure is only an information procedure, but does not include the sanction.  That is why I ask you and ask you, Commissioner, to set in motion as soon as possible to make the evaluation report and, above all, to be courageous and to make us new proposals to close and complete the procedure. I think we owe it to the families of the victims of trafficking. We owe it to all European citizens who, through instruments like these, have to be able to believe that Europe really protects them, and protects them from something as important as the loss of life in traffic.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, I would like on behalf of the Commission to thank the Members of Parliament, and in particular the rapporteur, Ms Ayala Sender, for the quick examination of this proposal and the finalisation of the report within the deadline set by the Court. This is a perfect example of how good cooperation between our institutions can bring tangible results very quickly and efficiently.  The Commission is very grateful that we managed to address the issue on which the Court ruled last year, while staying true to the principles of the original directive. The new directive will now be implemented according to the transport legal basis in the Treaty and applied across all 28 Member States – and not only to the 25 as before, which excluded the United Kingdom, Ireland and Denmark. The adoption of this proposal will ensure legal continuity and will contribute to improving road safety, which is one of the essential objectives of European transport policy. Too many Europeans are still victims of reckless drivers who do not respect traffic rules. By making it possible to easily identify drivers from other Member States who commit traffic offences, the new directive is expected to have a positive impact on the behaviour of many motorists. EU citizens will realise now more than ever that road safety does not stop at national borders: it is a Europe-wide concern. As soon as one of the traffic offences listed in the directive is committed, the respective enforcement agent will be able to identify the owner of the car and ask him or her to justify him/herself. This puts an end to the anonymity of foreign drivers in a given Member State. I look forward to an interesting debate this afternoon.

name: Georges BACH
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner Bulc, I would like to thank commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to start by taking this opportunity to highlight the exemplary work between the Commission, the Council and Parliament. There is no doubt that road safety is an absolute priority for the European institutions. Only through joint and cross-border efforts will we be able to halve the number of road deaths by 2020. This measure is a further step towards greater road safety, in addition to better training, infrastructure measures and a better safety system inside and outside vehicles. It is very important that this directive must now apply in all 28 Member States, including the United Kingdom, Ireland and Denmark. At present, 20 countries have already transposed the provisions into national law. I am confident that the remaining Member States will make every effort to meet the transposition deadline. However, it is also important, as has already been mentioned, for all drivers to be equal. Whether local or foreign drivers, everyone will have to follow the rules in the future. Traffic offences such as excessive speed, alcohol at the wheel and so on are equally dangerous matters everywhere. Another important consequence of the new legal basis is the adaptation of data protection rules. Here we have paid particular attention to this exchange of information. The issue of road safety affects us all and requires sustained efforts, especially as the number of road casualties has unfortunately risen slightly in some countries over the past year. I am very confident, as does Mrs Ayala Sender, that the Commission will fulfil its commitment in November 2016 and present this progress report. Only in this way can we ensure that the European legislator fulfils its obligations and meets its challenges.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, Commissioner, rapporteur, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I think it is a step that is now moving in the right direction. We have now at least been able to answer the question of whether those who commit traffic offences abroad, which actually become conspicuous, can be prosecuted. I believe that, in the overall structure of the 28 Member States, this is not so easy to achieve. However, we must not forget that we must continue along this road. If we finally look at the results of the Vision Zero strategy, we see that, fortunately, the number of road deaths has continued to fall in recent years. This directive can only be part of the overall strategy. Why am I saying this? Of course, we now have a situation where, if you become conspicuous in an EU Member State, you can be contacted directly. But the question arises: what happens after that? I think that is what interests the citizens. At the moment, the end result is that enforcement – that is, that the fine is actually collected – is not the case. We therefore always proceed from the case where the person who committed the traffic offence ultimately refuses to pay the fine. In this case – and I am deliberately saying this because I know that you will have to carry out an evaluation in 2016 – these are precisely the points that must then be included in the European Commission's next legislative proposal. Because I believe that it is only really complete when the rowdy on the street knows that he is not going to get around to paying this fine. At the moment it is a good start. Thank you also to the rapporteur for the really hard work she has done. I am looking forward to the new legislative proposal, which will ultimately bring these matters to the fore.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, 25 000 citizens still die every year on Europe's roads. This amounts to the population of, for example, cities such as Emmeloord and Dalfsen in my country. And if we add in the citizens who are permanently injured by road accidents, you will come up with a number that compares to quite large cities in Europe. Those figures, Mr President, must and can be reduced. This can be done through better infrastructure, safe and intelligent cars and, above all, through better information and assistance. But even now because of this proposal to tackle traffic offences effectively and cross-border. It did not help, Mr President, what the European Commission has done, namely to initiate legal proceedings against the Council and this Parliament in order to defend its own right and influence. I didn't think that was a textbook example of addressing an urgent, societal problem. But I now hope that the re-adoption of this proposal will achieve the real objective of the directive, which is to promote road safety in Europe. Traffic offences can now be more easily enforced across borders, especially those that are most common and cause the most damage. And then it's about speeding, driving through red lights, and behind the wheel with alcohol or drugs. It is also important that road users know where they stand, and I therefore hope, Mr President, that Article 8 of the directive will not turn out to be a wash. Article 8 concerns the provision of information to road users. I think that is crucial, because it is also about enforcement. Fine, you have to. But it is also about good information so that everyone gets between the ears to drive responsibly on the road.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, Commissioner, the World Health Organization recalls in its studies that road accidents are the seventh leading cause of death in the world and that they will be fifth in 2030 if the most successful measures to date are not insisted on in order to reduce accidents. Campaigning to prevent speeding, encourage seat belt or helmet use, prevent drug or alcohol use, prevent distractions, and boost respect for road signs reduce the number of accidents and their severity. And the sanction of infringements relating to these issues, too. The Directive we are discussing today aims to improve cooperation and data exchange between Member States in order to improve road safety in Europe. The change in legal basis will also allow Denmark, the United Kingdom and Ireland to incorporate this Directive into their legislation. Its objective: to allow a smooth exchange between the competent authorities in the control of traffic of vehicle registration data throughout Europe and to identify and adequately punish all offenders, regardless of the Member State in which the basic safety rules, such as those cited at the outset, have been breached. I also hope that it will stimulate cooperation within the Member States where competences in this area are decentralised. The Directive should help to reduce accidents uniformly across Europe. Because Europe is the region of the world with the least deaths per million inhabitants due to traffic accidents. However, the distribution of victims and accidents has large differences between the different Member States. We must ensure that control of the most dangerous infringements is definitely possible throughout the European Union. In addition, we will encourage countries with the most accidents to take action on infrastructure, vehicle parks and other factors which are also paramount to avoiding a drama that in the Union involves the deaths of 55 people each million Europeans each year. That is why we also hope for the evaluation, and that the Commission will be able to present us with a new proposal in 2017, with a legal basis for transport which can improve the current Directive.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a truly unified and common European transport area requires a truly common and uniform set of rules of the game. This is precisely what the proposal for a directive before us is about, the creation of common rules of the game. This ensures that, within the Union, the applicability of the rules is the same for everyone and the deterrent that infringements have consequences exists, regardless of whether you are moving on your own or on a neighbour's property within the Union. This is therefore a question of fair and equal treatment of citizens before the law. I would like to thank both the Commission and the Council for their timely handling of the matter, and at the same time I hope parliament's approval of the proposal. This will enable us to ensure that a clear state of law is maintained and to continue the steps to create a single European transport culture. The directive covers all traffic offences with the highest number of road fatalities in Europe, including, most importantly, speeding, neglect to use a safety night and driving under alcohol or drugs. The Commission has previously estimated that effective implementation of the regulation can avoid between 350 and 400 road deaths per year. The illegal use of a mobile phone or other means of communication while driving, the so-called 'distracted driving', is also covered by monitoring and the exchange of information.  Improving road safety is a joint effort, and it requires all of us to do so.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. Mr President, First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Inés Ayala Sender, for all the work. We can say here that we can now close a chapter with this vote. It is said that this was a textbook example of cooperation. However, I do not think the whole process is exactly a prime example of cooperation. We have actually lost a great deal of time with all this and with the discussion on the legal basis. I am very sorry that the Council has actually been fighting for a very long time over the legal basis and has not been proved right in the end. I'm glad we can move on now. I am very pleased that the directive sets out provisions on data protection. But now it comes down to implementation. We still have eight countries to go for that implementation. More importantly, how do we deal with enforcement? Because we have not actually taken the necessary steps to do so. So in the review in 2016 we have to take another step; we will get there, because road safety is getting better in Europe, but I would not give it a beauty prize. In any case, we can now move on, on to 2016!

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: On the other: The EFDD Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Yes, the regulations need to be updated. As it is today, it works very badly on the roads. I see, not least in heavy commercial traffic, how cars from other countries easily escape the police's issued fines by simply throwing the note out the window. There is no system to raise this money, not that works at least.  It is important that we do something. There are several things in the report that I think are a good thing. Weight controls, for example, are great for drivers, because it is always the driver who sits with the responsibility the day you are stopped by the police. Traffic controls, proportionate to traffic, i also think are a good incentive. We also need to strengthen the heavy group of police who are in charge of the checks.  One thing that is very important in this, I think, is that the fine should be paid on the spot as far as possible. Otherwise, I think it's just too easy to get away from this. It is no problem for, for example, a haulage company engaged in commercial traffic to ensure that the driver, for example, has a credit card, a credit card, with him and can pay the fine. Otherwise, the legislation will have no impact on this. It's very important.  At the same time, I am also pleased that we can access the fake driving licences, which have become an increasing problem, where today you buy a driving licence over the internet and then get into a heavy truck and engage in professional traffic. This is not the optimal solution for me, but at least it is a step along the way that we can build on.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, like a sea snake, this directive is back in plenary. When it comes to persecuting motorists, the powerful who govern us have a lot on their minds. According to this text, repression against drivers is the only way to combat road violence. Why, for example, is there no provision to consult motorists' associations in the same way as other associations? With regard to the maintenance and renovation of the road network, of which many things could be said, this is never the time to talk about it, of course. It is expensive, whereas radars pay a lot. On the subject of the fight against criminals who use vehicles, often stolen, to commit their misdeeds, there is nothing. Do you think the Chechen drivers who killed a Niçoise woman on the Promenade des Anglais last month, driving two stolen cars, care about keeping their driver's license points? They had no permits or identity papers. Do you think that this directive will make it possible to better combat the practice of "go fast", which is becoming more and more widespread in the field of drug trafficking, including cross-border trafficking? Of course not. What we are asking for is a little flexibility for ordinary motorists, but zero tolerance for traffic criminals.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: Madam President, thank you very much. Firstly, thanks to the rapporteur of the S&D Group. Road safety in Europe is an important issue. As Mr Van Dalen said, 25 000 road deaths a year in Europe is a terrible number and we must reduce that as much as possible and as quickly as possible. That is why we, as an EPP Group, think it is a good thing that we can conclude this dossier here for the time being with a clear approach and a clear implementation. It is fair to say that, of course, we have all been screwed in on cross-border traffic offences. And then you always thought "we'll get away with that" but that'll be over now. Yes, we, as motorcyclists, have to swallow for a while, but road safety comes first, of course. The history of the proposal has been the least necessary. It has taken an unnecessarily long time with an unnecessary amount of legal seism between the institutions. A few more questions. First of all, it's now about eight traffic violations. It is indeed the most important eight. But what are we going to do with the other traffic violations? For example, the Netherlands, Germany and Belgium are currently exchanging more data on traffic violations. Now first the question of implementation, and then the question of enforcement. Mr Eickhout asked about it. Are the computer systems in different countries in order? We have adopted more measures here that later went wrong because of the computer systems. Finally, it is good that Denmark, the United Kingdom and Ireland are now also participating on the basis of equality.

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: Madam President, I welcome this measure very much and I welcome the support given by our Commissioner on this issue. Now make no mistake, this is a road safety measure. It is about deterrence and it is about good governance; it is not about burdensome or unfair regulation. All the offences considered are serious offences. In particular, speed we know is a primary factor in up to a third – if not more – of fatal collisions in the EU, and is an aggravating factor in most other collisions. So this is something that we really need to get a grip on. In my country, I know that this has not been universally welcomed and in many cases we have been urged to try to stay out of this. I am calling on the government today to change its view and to try and implement this more quickly than it has said it can. Just on the figures, there are some very extreme examples both ways of how this has worked out. On a London ring road, people going twice the speed limit in foreign-registered vehicles are not being caught; similarly if you look at the French figures, 500 000 people in UK-registered cars are getting away with speeding offences every single year. So this is something which works both ways. It works for the benefit of all across the EU and it also underlines the need to do more on road safety in general in order to meet our road safety targets, which we are going to be at a push to meet by 2020 – in particular, making sure that conditionality on road safety is a point on all major transport infrastructure projects in line with the Trans-European Network guidelines. EU funding should not go towards projects on urban mobility or on transport unless road safety is absolutely a top priority.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: the blue card. " There is no doubt that the exchange of information will reduce the number of infringements and that is our goal. I would like to ask whether the requirement for all parties to use vehicles that can be driven either from the left or from the right will not reduce road safety, as different infrastructure is created in individual countries.

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: blue-card answer. – This is a question that does get looked at in great detail in my country, and I am sure in others, to make sure that technically, when infrastructure and road measures are put into effect, the issues around left-hand/right-hand driving are taken properly into account and also, in particular, that drivers are warned effectively at border crossings. So that goes both ways, both in terms of the UK and on the continent.  It is an interesting point and it is something that all of us involved in transport work and road safety are very mindful of.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Freedom of movement within the European Union is one of the most important achievements of integration on our continent. However, the privileges of travelling on European roads should undoubtedly also entail responsibility for the offences committed. Member States should have the tools to effectively enforce the penalties imposed for traffic offences. To refrain from imposing a penalty on the basis of the technical inability to identify the address of the offender would be a clear violation of the principle of equality for all citizens of the European Union, but above all a disgrace nowadays.  In Poland, where the number of road accidents is one of the highest in Europe and where they very often result in the deaths of victims, the final harmonisation of these provisions is particularly welcome. In my country, accidents and road collisions caused by foreigners account for about 3% of all accidents and collisions on the roads, the vast majority of which are caused by citizens of the European Union. With the second most important fatality rate in the European Union, any such incident is extremely important and the possibility of effectively imposing a penalty on the offender plays an important preventive role.  It is also worth appreciating that the Countries of the Community – Denmark, the United Kingdom and Ireland, which until now have remained outside this system – have agreed to join it after a transitional period. This demonstrates a common conviction of the need to extend this system to the whole of the Union and of the positive results of the implementation of this directive in the Member States that have already transposed it into their legislation. I am therefore very pleased, and I would also like to point out, that it would be useful to extend this legislation afterwards, especially to neighbouring countries.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to commend the work of

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: Madam President, this piece of legislation exemplifies the flawed realities of the EU by creating overlapping legislation on something that just does not work. Years after the implementation of the Prüm Decision, the majority of Member States are still not able to exchange any of the three types of data deemed necessary for dealing with cross-border information exchange.  This demonstrates that this legislation simply is not plausible. UK police need the ammunition to be able to track and enforce drivers who ignore the law on our highways, but it is our own UK border control that needs to store data on the vehicle registration on entry, with the driver’s appropriate legal licence, not the EU’s. At least this way, anyone who leaves the UK can be stopped at our own border control and dealt with appropriately.  The need for EU expenditure to standardise cross-border technologies to implement this legislation is beyond belief. The language barriers between States that allow the system to operate effectively are unpractical and unsafe. The realities of this report pose more problems than solutions. Robert Goodwill, the British Road Minister, has stated that cross-border information exchanges on penalty points are inappropriate. It will be interesting to see if his party’s MEPs will agree that this is a matter better dealt with by individual Member States. It is certainly only the UKIP MEPs who wish to protect the UK interest, not like some other UK MEPs quoting mixed messages. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Matt CARTHY
text: blue-card question. –  Ms Seymour, your arguments would make sense were it not for the fact that your own country has a jurisdiction in Ireland which comprises, along the county that I come from, around 500 regional and local roads which it would be impossible to enforce any sort of border control over. Do you not, therefore, accept that there is a need to have some form of a system in place that allows drivers travelling into one or the other jurisdiction to live up to their responsibilities under road safety regulations?

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, there should certainly be a system in place, but it should be from within our own remit, not the EU’s.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Madam President! Safety on our roads is something that is very important to all of us. This is clear from every speech, despite all the political differences here in this House. So let us put that out of contention today in our debate. Austria is particularly affected because, as a transit country, it is particularly affected by east-west traffic. A cross-border sanction mechanism would therefore be very welcome here. I can tell you that in Austria, out of 4 million radar penalties, 2.5 million are caused by foreign drivers. The major problem that we have here – and this has already been pointed out by some colleagues – will be the implementation and enforcement of this directive, as you all know. Firstly, we know that some Member States have not yet transposed the previous directive – Italy and Greece have already been mentioned – and on the other hand, the question is whether all the Member States are really willing and can implement this directive efficiently. The problem of administration has already been raised in some Member States. In any case, the rules must apply to everyone. This means that the Member States must all implement this directive, otherwise it will end up: citizens of those states that have implemented the directive quickly and efficiently will also be the ones who will have to pay the most fines.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht KOCH
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. This report is of great importance for improving road safety, to which we have been overwhelmingly committed. Far too many people are still dying in accidents caused by crime on European roads, and far too many are seriously injured. We are all too familiar with road traffic offences, which are mainly responsible for fatal accidents. It is the significant speeding, drunken driving or driving under the influence of drugs, not wearing a seatbelt and driving over a red light. It is precisely these traffic offences that are at stake today. They must be punished, regardless of the Member State in which they are committed and in which Member State the vehicle with which these offences are committed is registered. Serious road traffic offences must simply not go unpunished in an internal market. An electronic data exchange network, which complies with the strict European data protection rules, will be created. This allows for reciprocal access to vehicle registration data – a prerequisite for facilitating or speeding up the investigation of an offence and enabling it to be punished. Now that the legal basis has been adapted in line with the ECJ ruling of May 2014, I am reassured. There are no more derogations; Denmark, the United Kingdom and Ireland may no longer refuse to apply the Directive. Road safety does not stop at national borders. Safe mobility for EU citizens has, in my view, become a fundamental right. We're still a long way from the goal - Vision Zero. Further steps must follow.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this proposal, as we know, takes up Directive 2011/82/EU, which was annulled by the Court of Justice of the European Union on the ground that it was adopted on the basis of an incorrect legal basis. Today's proposal is a new step towards European integration because it facilitates the cross-border exchange of information on road safety infringements, such as speeding or drink-driving, and puts an end to the anonymity of non-resident drivers. It also ensures that road traffic offences do not go unpunished and shows that all drivers in the European Union have the same rights and duties. Road safety can only be achieved if the rules are certain and are respected by everyone. In fact, the person who receives the road infringement notification is treated equally, because now all European citizens, regardless of the vehicle's number plate, are subject to the same legal consequence as the infringement. We must also bear in the view that each Member State is a destination for tourists from other Eu ropean Union countries and, consequently, the possibility of exchanging information with other States improves not only safety but also consumer rights. The era of impunity is therefore over, and yet I believe that a further step forward could be to allow not only the exchange of information but, indeed, the possibility of applying the sanction directly. A revision of the directive would therefore also be desirable in this respect. In conclusion, I think that there is now a change of legal basis, that is to say a formal aspect, but I also think that it is a fundamental aspect to make citizens aware of the safety of driving and therefore of the protection of the human person.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Madam President! Up to now – as has already been said – it has been possible to simply hit the strands in Europe and to commit a traffic offence while on holiday abroad without being punished for it. But it is not a cavalier offence to commit really serious traffic offences – that is a criminal offence! It can put other people at risk, and that is why it must not be at all. We have already ensured greater road safety in Europe by aligning vehicle inspection. Now it is only logical that we should also try to be able to prosecute traffic offenders across borders. It is true that we have a responsible exchange of data here, and it is also good that other Member States can also identify holders. Of course, we want to have free mobility in Europe in general – that is a principle, but this must be done to ensure fair rules of the game, which must be respected by everyone. That is why I think it is a good thing that we have this on the agenda again, in order to adapt it legally, so that it applies in all the Member States. We want free mobility, but we must no longer have mercy for serious traffic offenders. We simply need more safety on Europe's roads! We are, of course, happy to support the Commissioner in its implementation in our Member States.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Madam President, twenty times on the job, hand over your work. I can't resist quoting this maxim from the famous French poet Nicolas Boileau. Boileau: a whole program when talking about the repression of traffic offences, since this name could be translated, in English, by "drink water", in German by "trinken Sie Wasser", in Spanish by "bebe agua", and so on. In fact, it is the European Court of Justice that has you putting this directive back on the job: it was adopted on an erroneous legal basis. However, it retains the same motives. If it is a question of prosecuting the most serious offences, of course, it can only be agreed with, but I note that, among those offences, one has classified, for example, the failure to fasten a seat belt. This is certainly likely to jeopardize the safety of the driver, who is negligent but does not endanger the lives of others. There are many other serious offences that are not covered by this directive. Therefore, nothing changes with respect to the criticisms we were making four years ago on this issue. In Luxembourg, a signatory to the Treaty of Pmo, the directive has just been transposed into Luxembourg law, but we know that white-collar offenders can be reassured, even if the amount of their fraud is much higher than the fines that will be sought to recover from reckless motorists. In a nutshell, if it is a question of controlling serious offences, yes. If it is a question of making the machine work for motorists, we will not agree.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: Madam President, I think it is very important that we set a legal basis and ensure that there is no gap through which those who commit traffic offences in another jurisdiction can escape. For many years, drivers could act with impunity whilst driving on our roads relatively safe in the knowledge that they would not be prosecuted. That is all to change now and I welcome it.  This directive is above all about safety, and I welcome the cross-party support it has received going through the Committee on Transport and Tourism, of which I am a member. I want to commend the rapporteur Ms Ayala Sender, and indeed our shadow rapporteur, Georges Bach, on their work. According to an EEC impact assessment study, these new proposals will save between 350 and 400 road deaths per year. I do not think anybody can argue with that statistic in terms of the work we are doing here in ensuring that those lives are saved – not to mention the horrific injuries that we also have on our roads. This directive will save lives, but it will also bring Europe together in our common goal of saving lives on our roads and ensuring that we want to be one integrated Europe. We cannot have one law for domestic drivers and another for foreign drivers who choose to break the law. The eight traffic offences that have been covered are, I am sure, the most common. I know safety belts were mentioned and I would like to think that when we speak of safety belts we speak of ensuring that adults ensure that children are secure and have proper restraints in place. We have made considerable progress and I know, Madam Commissioner, it is one of your priorities to reduce deaths on our roads. In 1990, there were 76 000 deaths on European roads, and last year 26 000. That is considerable progress, but still a lot more needs to be done. I look forward to working with you, Madam Commissioner, over the next five years as you set out to improve road safety for all our citizens.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Madam President, Commissioner, first of all, let me thank our rapporteur, Inés Ayal Sender. I want to thank her not only for her urgent work and for the factual approach to adapting this important directive from the point of view of road safety, but also for her years of involvement, for the fair and consistent enforcement of traffic regulations on European roads.  The current proposal, which responds to the rulings of the European Court of Justice, will contribute to improving road safety, which is an integral part of EU policies. At the same time, it is one of the measures to make our commitment to halve the number of road accident victims by 2020. I therefore welcome the fact that the Directive covers the most common and serious traffic offences, namely speeding, not wearing seat belts, not stopping at red light, driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs, driving in the wrong lane, illegal use of a mobile phone or other communication device while driving and, for motorcyclists, driving without a safety helmet.  By approving the proposal, we will contribute to equal treatment of all drivers who commit traffic offences outside their country in all Member States. This will protect responsible drivers more from those who often feel impunity for committing traffic offences abroad. Thank you all again for the work you've done.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. The problem of impunity for foreign drivers has long been raised internationally, both by ministers and the media, and above all by ordinary citizens who are dissatisfied with this injustice. When we analyse the European Commission's data on european Union traffic offences and offences, this analysis shows that the proportion of non-residents committing crimes and offences is often higher than the proportion of citizens of a country, especially in the case of speeding.  Last year alone, more than 20 000 people died on the roads of the European Union. Unfortunately, we must remember that even the best preventive solutions in the field of road safety prove to be ineffective when there is a sense of impunity among road users. It happens that during a single journey, in one day the driver is able to break a dozen traffic regulations on the territory of several Member States, and its discovery depends precisely on the bilateral exchange of information between the selected services of the country concerned. I am pleased that this directive will enter into force, because I believe that it will ensure and simplify and speed up the mutual exchange of information and data on drivers between the Countries of the European Union, reduce the sense of impunity and increase the fair treatment of drivers regardless of their nationality.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Madam President, I certainly want to join this discussion and I would like to support this directive and thank Mrs. Sender's rapporteur. On the one hand we are fighting for demographic growth and we are talking about how we need to take measures for employment and everyone else, and at the same time it happens that 20,000 people are losing their lives on European roads.  I believe that this is inadmissible and will very soon become the past that one can be on vacation in one state, and then come home and go unpunished without identifying the perpetrator of the violation. I think this directive came at the right time and it's okay for the 28 systems to come together. I hope that the United Kingdom, Denmark and Ireland will also accept and that we will unify the systems.  In any case, this directive could, by some indicators by 2020, make 50% of people's victims less on our European roads and I think this should be supported in any case. However, it is seen here that cooperation between our authorities, the Commission and Parliament, is good cooperation, but cooperation between Member States will have to happen, which is what we strive for, not only in the field of protection in transport safety, but also in all other areas. That's what our basic European idea really is.  However, it is not just measures and sanctions that will help. Surely there need to be better roads, better infrastructure, better cars, and of course all these measures will make it possible and succeeding together to improve road safety. In any case, the borders of states are no longer obstacles and that's what you want to say. Thank you, Mrs. Bulc, for this proposal.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: The cross-border exchange of information on traffic infringements goes beyond mere police cooperation and is part of a much more important objective, namely road safety, which is a political priority of the European Parliament.  This proposal for a directive brings us one step closer to the target of a 50% reduction in the number of road deaths by 2020. The adoption of this initiative is a mission that we owe to those we represent and who face a daily fleet of outdated vehicles and undeveloped infrastructures, due to the drastic reduction in maintenance costs and the lack of funding for related improvement works.  In a European Union created on the freedom of citizens to move easily and safely within the territory of the Member States, cross-border exchange of information and cooperation between the authorities of those States are essential in discouraging the rules of traffic infringements by drivers.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the issue of road safety is particularly important because it is about protecting human life itself. It is therefore necessary to establish a new legal basis for the directive on the cross-border exchange of information on traffic offences. According to data studies in relation to car accidents and road traffic code violations, the proportion of non-residents involved was higher than that of residents. In particular, this concerns the exceeding of the speed limit. The large number of violations and violations of the Highway Traffic Code by foreign vehicles is due to the fact that the various local authorities do not know the address of the owner of the vehicle. Immediate measures, such as this directive, need therefore be taken to limit the impunity of unscrupulous drivers, who hide behind anonymity, so that we do not continue to mourn a hundred victims as a result of car accidents.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Madam President, I would like to express my support for this effort and thank the Rapporteur immediately at the outset. What I want to specifically mention, what others have not mentioned here, is the issue of relations with our candidate countries and potential candidates and with Switzerland.  I know you're in big business now to bring 28 countries together. However, I would like to stress in particular that I think it is very important to try to start talks with both Switzerland and Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, as these are definitely transit states. Here, I have nothing to brag about, but I was photographed twice in Lucerne driving at 90km/h instead of 80km/h and never getting a ticket. It's not to be commended, but it's true. So, I think it would be good to see how to include these countries, especially countries in the Balkans that are often as we know transit countries where many citizens of the European Union pass, from Bulgaria, Greece, Romania and of course I expect these countries to get involved as well.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: Madam President, this discussion stems from confusion about the legal basis of the Directive, a directive which was consensual and necessary. With this review we have tested as positive its update, with the introduction of new types of infringements, as well as greater guarantees in terms of data protection. Since this directive will end with a certain sense of impunity, it is no less certain that it will not work miracles. Road accidents have deeper causes, such as the ageing of the car fleet, the quality of the road network, as well as the fatigue of drivers.  In this sense, we see with great concern the model of public-private partnerships that dominates the construction of the road network in Europe, and particularly in Portugal. The result is paid roads, through expensive tolls that push a large part of the population to secondary roads, without quality, and with great damage to the safety of localities. This is just one example. Palliatives are necessary, but do not eliminate the need for background treatments.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Dear Commissioner, welcome to Parliament with the team. I, of course, join my colleagues and colleagues who support these Commission efforts to ensure greater security in the mobility itself, and I think that this directive is absolutely in the right direction. Greater mobility, of course, means nothing if this mobility is not safe. It is therefore necessary to provide all the appropriate mechanisms to ensure this security, and the exchange of information is already one major step forward, and I also join those who, of course, are concerned that this data management is adequate and, of course, safe. I would like to add one more thing, apart from, of course, the words on infrastructure that is needed to further strengthen this security, but it is also an area of punishment and punishment. The fact is that penalties can only be effective and effective when they achieve their purpose. However, penalties, especially in traffic offences, achieve their purpose only when they are indeed also enforced and removable. And I think that in this area, it is necessary to take an additional step to make this directive also enforceable in practice.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Parliament is today faced with the important responsibility of having to adopt the new directive on the cross-border exchange of information on road safety infringements, before 6 May 2015, in order to avoid creating a legal limbo that could undermine road safety in Europe. The directive has already shown its potential. Since its entry into force in November 2013, the number of infringements by foreign drivers, now aware that any infringement committed abroad can be notified to them thanks to this new mechanism, has in fact decreased. However, there is a need for legal certainty and it is therefore essential, all the more so when we consider that, despite the fact that the European Union is on track to achieve the target of a 50% reduction in road fatalities by 2020, the economic crisis has led to an increase in the number of road accident victims due to the ageing of the car fleet and radical cuts in infrastructure maintenance costs. Putting in place binding and non-discriminatory elements against impunity on Europe's roads must therefore be a priority for this Parliament, including by urging the European Commission and the Member States to cooperate through a strengthening of the exchange of information and the preparation of joint reports on road safety.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, I really welcome this debate. It shows me that we are together in this ambitious plan for road safety. I can only confirm that for all of us every traffic victim is one too many. Let me reply now to some of the concerns expressed during this debate. First of all, very briefly, personal data is processed very carefully and the Member States can only consult the other national database and use the data for the relevant procedures. So fundamental privacy rights are fully guaranteed. Now let me refer to your concern – which I share, of course; this is just the first step and the real work still lies ahead of us – and say that the Commission will now concentrate on implementation. It will prepare a report to Parliament and the Council assessing the application of the Directive and its contribution to road safety. That will happen by 2016.  This assessment will be an opportunity to look further, as some of you invited us to do. For instance, we will see if there is a need to develop common standards for automatic checking equipment, road safety guidelines, adding additional offences, harmonising traffic rules or even the criteria for a follow-up procedure in the case of non-payment of fines. We know that this is a serious issue.  But first we need to see what the current approach will bring. Perhaps it will show that this is a sufficient deterrent and people will change their driving behaviour. If not, I can assure you that the Commission will not hesitate to propose additional measures, as just outlined. Twenty-two Member States have transposed the Directive into national law. There are six more to go. We will work very closely with them to proceed with the necessary steps.  Finally, allow me just to thank you very much once again for the really good cooperation. I really look forward to working with you in the future on the issues that I have spoken about. I am, of course, looking forward to your support and a positive outcome in the vote tomorrow.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, thank you very much, Mrs Bulc, I did not expect less of your ability and your dedication and courage. Ladies and gentlemen, I also very much appreciate your kind comments and, above all, the great confluence in the need to deepen and complement this text, this Directive. It has been seven intense years of relentless cooperation between those of us who are engaged in road safety, tenacious and tireless people who know that, in road safety, if efforts are no longer made one day, it goes back very quickly. As some of you have said, there is already an uptick in casualties and injuries in some Member States. The reasons? The crisis has aged the fleet, the infrastructures – we also age – there are more vans, more urban victims, pedestrians, cyclists, bikers, but good... If, as we have done, we continue to insist on the goal not only of halving the victims by 2020, and of reducing the wounded as well, but on the goal of reaching even zero, we will surely win. Only with the implementation of this Directive do ETSC experts tell us that we will prevent 350 to 400 deaths per year on our roads. Can you imagine that? We're talking about the equivalent of an entire plane a year, plus the thousands of wounded. That alone is worth it. Don't these potential victims, their families, the traffic authorities, deserve it when they have to care for wounded and victims without being able to avoid the accident? If, as you tell us, Commissioner - and I thank you very much – the 2016 report is well accompanied by proposals to complete the current procedure, and if you were added to this, in addition to the revision of the Infrastructure Security Directive, plus the proposals you have just made to us, this legislature would, of course, mark a significant change in what matters most to us : that European citizens can continue to move on our roads feeling protected and safe. He's going after them.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: Madam Rapporteur, dear colleagues, let me also congratulate you on this debate. It is very important. Cooperation means more safety on the roads and let us not forget that means saving lives. So congratulations. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 11 February 2015 at 12.00. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Like a sea snake, this directive is back in plenary. When it comes to persecuting motorists, our leaders have a lot on their mind. According to this text, repression against drivers would be the only means of combating road violence. Why is there no plan to consult motorists' associations in the same way as other associations? The maintenance and renovation of the road network? This is never the time to talk about it. Of course, it is expensive when radars pay a lot. Fighting criminals who use vehicles, often stolen, to commit their misdeeds? Nonexistent! Do you think the Chechen drivers who killed a Niçoise woman on the Promenade des Anglais last month in two stolen cars care about keeping their driver's license points? They had no permits or identity papers... Do you think that this directive will better combat the practice of go fast, which is becoming more and more widespread in the field of drug trafficking, including cross-border trafficking? Of course not. We, the Members of the National Front, are asking for a little flexibility for ordinary motorists but a zero tolerance for criminals.

name: Karima DELLI
text: In writing. In this new directive, cooperation between Member States is strengthened, with a stronger obligation for recalcitrant countries, such as the United Kingdom, Ireland and Denmark. In addition, this new version takes into account the issue of personal data protection. This text is clearly a step forward and marks a return to the issue of road safety at the European level, after it has been put aside since last spring! As a reminder, 73 Europeans die every day on the roads in Europe and 250,000 are seriously injured each year. In France, there was an increase in road deaths in 2014, the first time in 12 years. To remedy this scourge, Europe has a key role to play. Cooperation in sanctions against all drivers who commit offences with impunity in Europe is a first step. This demonstrates a willingness to apply sanctions consistently. We regret that the Commission does not go any further by proposing a harmonisation of legislation, particularly on speed limits and alcohol consumption, which remain the leading causes of road accidents.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. – I very much welcome this report, and it seems that we are finally finally able to put an end to a process that has been going on since 2007. It is regrettable, however, that only the prospect of hard financial implications has sufficient incentives to comply with the prescribed speed limits and to continue following the law. I therefore urge the launch of a comprehensive campaign to encourage citizens to think responsibly and thus to prevent accidents, both in education and later through the media. It is a fact and a fact that in our Member States foreign persons cause a disproportionate number of road accidents compared to their number. The knowledge that it would be too difficult for the local police to recover a misdemeanor fine motivates quite a lot of drivers to push the accelerator more strongly. If all is true, this era is over, and police cooperation in this area will take it to a higher level between Member States. This is also hoped to contribute to our stated goal of reducing the number of road fatalities by 50% by 2020.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. – I fully support the report. I believe that the European Parliament is able to adopt a new directive by 6 May 2015 and to avoid the situation of legal uncertainty in almost all Member States that have already incorporated the provisions of the repealed directive into their national law. The directive brings concrete benefits by allowing, in particular, the same treatment of all European drivers, wherever their cars are registered. It makes it difficult for offenders to get away with, which contributes to building a safer Europe. It is regrettable that my country has been statistically 'leading' the roads for years. These are sad statistics, but on the other hand, our supervisory authorities have an interest in obtaining information about the abuses committed by our citizens abroad. This information opens up the possibility of restricting the right of driving to those who systematically commit tresses, thus threatening citizens of both their own country and other countries. The war on the roads must be curbed, and this directive is one of the means to do so.

name: Claudia SCHMIDT
text: Writing. – The cross-border exchange of information on road safety provides for a mandatory exchange of information between all EU countries on traffic offences such as turf, alcohol and drug use or mobile phone use at the wheel. No one should think that traffic rules are less serious when travelling abroad in the EU. Especially in view of environmental speed limits, public acceptance is already coming to an end. If other EU citizens are not prosecuted, the further I call for improved opposition possibilities for road users if they are served with a fine notice from another EU country will be exacerbated. In future, a watchful eye must be kept in mind to ensure that citizens are not run over by foreign legal systems and their rights are curtailed.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo (2015/2552 RSP)). I welcome the Vice-President of the Commission, Ms Mogherini.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs. – Madam President, let me thank you for this exchange of views today regarding the situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo.  As you know, the European Union has been a strong and consistent partner to the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) over the last 15 years. In 2006 it provided the bulk of financing for the organisation of the first democratic elections in the history of Congo and the DRC has been one of our top priorities in Africa over the past decades. This includes two military operations and a sustained effort to support security sector reform with two CSDP missions, as well as more traditional areas of cooperation such as health, roads and natural resources management. Today I think that many of you are especially concerned about the delays and uncertainties surrounding the electoral process, which includes the holding of local elections in 2015 and the legislative and presidential elections in 2016 at the latest. The recent debate over the passing of a new electoral law has led to violent popular protests calling for constitutional timelines to be respected, and to two casualties. During this difficult time we called on all political forces to seek a consensus to facilitate an appeasement of the situation, and we asked the government in particular to exercise constraint, to maintain an open political space and allow for the peaceful expression of opinion. The prerequisite of organising a general consensus before the legislative and presidential elections has now been dropped. This opens the door to organising the elections within the constitutional timeframe. This is a very positive step which I welcome and I know too that some of you expressed opinions on the same lines.  But respect for the constitution goes further than respecting timelines. Freedoms of speech and of the media, the right of peaceful assembly, respect for the rights of the opposition are all essential components of a democracy. These critical elements will be part of our dialogue with the Congolese Government, with the objective of reducing tensions in the political climate.  I am very much aware of, and I share, the concerns of this Parliament regarding the situation of Dr Denis Mukwege and the Panzi Hospital. Let me say too that I was honoured, personally, to sit in this very same room, listening to his inspiring and dramatic words last November on the occasion of the Sakharov Prize. I was also honoured to have on that occasion a very good meeting with him, looking for ways of cooperating on concrete projects. I wish to confirm to you that the European Union is following with great vigilance the situation concerning his physical security as a human rights defender.  I have also asked my representative in Kinshasa to enquire about the dispute between the Congolese administration and the Panzi Hospital. I strongly support an amicable agreement between the Panzi Hospital and the Congolese administration.  The holding of democratic elections leading to a peaceful transition of power will be key to longer-term stability in the DRC and in the wider region. Stability will also depend on other factors, in particular the neutralisation of all armed groups in Eastern Congo. There has been some significant progress in this respect thanks to the efforts of the Congolese army and MONUSCO.  Nevertheless, important challenges remain: for example regarding the ex-M23 movement. The governments of the DRC, Uganda and Rwanda should strengthen their collaboration to achieve a durable disarmament, demobilisation and reintegration of ex-combatants and their dependents.  The FDLR rebel group remains a major threat to long-term stability in the region. Linked with the Rwanda 1994 genocide ideology, this group has inflicted immense human suffering and has spoiled DRC–Rwanda relations. With the support of the United Nations, there is now a unique opportunity to address one of the root causes of conflicts in the Kivus. The FDLR movement has been given plenty of time by countries in the region to surrender peacefully. We discussed this in the Foreign Affairs Council in January and we adopted 28 Council conclusions where we stated that the time has now come for military operations. However we stress too that we invite MONUSCO and FARDC to ensure civilians are fully protected and that international humanitarian law is respected during the operations. Let me reiterate our support for the UN involvement in promoting peace and stability. This includes the sustained efforts of MONUSCO and troop-contributing countries as well as the personal efforts of the UN Special Envoy for the Great Lakes region.  Let me also stress that I know, and I share, your desire to curb the links between conflict and exploitation of natural resources in the Great Lakes region. As part of its comprehensive approach the European Union has started to address the situation. Together with the Commission, as you might very well know, my predecessor issued a Joint Communication on responsible sourcing of conflict minerals. And Parliament and the Council are currently examining right now the draft regulations that went together with this Communication. Finally, I would like to mention the European Union’s long-term commitment in the DRC to supporting the preservation of Congolese national parks. This includes Virunga Park, which is part of the UNESCO World Heritage Sites. The future of this park is threatened by permits being granted for oil exploration that could lead to oil exploitation in the future. Let me ensure you that we will continue to keep a close eye on national decisions that might impact on the sustainability of this park. To conclude, I would just like to share with you the information that I have mandated Mr Vervaeke, the EU Senior Coordinator for the Great Lakes region, to join a mission of special envoys that will go to Kinshasa in the coming weeks to assess the situation and obviously report back. I thank you for your attention and I look forward to the debate and listening to your speeches today.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. – Madam President, indeed, the problems in the Democratic Republic of congo are numerous. Madam High Representative, you have listed some problems, such as the problem of exploitation of minerals, illegal financing of armed groups, the problem of systematic rape of women – as evidenced here in this House by Dr. Mukwege, as of course is the problem of selective justice by which Dr. Mukwega's hospital was closed after he sent critical tones to the authorities. But the causes of all these problems can be found indeed in ineffifiable institutions, in undemocratic institutions, in the absence of the rule of law, in high rates of corruption. Protesters in Kinshasa rose mainly because an election law change was announced that would then order a census in the country before the next elections are called. And it was quite clear that this announced electoral reform was an attempt to perpetuaating incumbent President Kabila's authority.  That is why the affirmation and processes of democratization in the country are extremely important, and of course the refooulation and our policies of development cooperation so that they can potentiate the construction of inclusive democratic institutions. In this regard, I think that additional efforts are needed both from the aspect of development policy and the overall foreign policy of the European Union, and this should be one of the main messages from this debate.  Finally, I would also like to add that although we have today the authoritarian authority of President Kabila, before him his father, before that Mobutu, remains the same paradigm of corruption that is the very source of these problems. In fact, by building these inclusive institutions we have to face these causes and change that.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the presidential election in the Democratic Republic of Congo is of fundamental importance not only for the consolidation of democracy in that country but also for the balance and stability of the entire Great Lakes region. There is therefore no postponement of the electoral calendar. No use of false gimmicks that risk alienating millions of citizens from democracy. Good governance and the alternation of power is a constant that has been lacking for too long and in too many countries. We are outraged at the dozens of people who have been brutally murdered just for legitimately protesting against the amendment of the Constitution and the electoral law. We condemn the arrest of Vano Kiboko and other demonstrators and leading figures in the local opposition and call for his immediate release. We denounce the repeated violence against women and call for those responsible for such atrocities to be brought to justice. Madam President, recognising the legitimacy of the opponent in democratic competition is the only possible way to avoid violence and conflict. This is the great responsibility expected of the current Congolese leadership group, and this is what the European Union must demand, bearing in mind that no violation of human rights will ever be tolerated either by the international community or by the International Criminal Court in The Hague. In this context, we express our support for the MONUSCO mission for peace-building efforts throughout Congolese territory. Finally, Madam President, I would like to express my shame, as a European citizen, at the umpteenth tragedy that has cost the lives of 29 migrants off the coast of Lampedusa, a news that has gone unnoticed. Other human lives are added to the list of thousands of women, men and children, guilty of seeking a better life on European territory.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, Madam High Representative, I would first like to congratulate you on this extremely clear and precise summary which reflects your commitment to the DRC. The situation in the DRC is particularly worrying, even explosive, in more ways than one, which is not without consequences for the sub-region.  First, it is essential that credible presidential elections be held on time.
