The chairman of the DRC's independent national electoral commission, Mr.  Secondly, it is essential that the entire electoral process takes place in a calm climate, without orchestrated violence against opponents, against civil society, against potential candidates or against journalists. Freedom of the press, freedom of expression and freedom to demonstrate peacefully are fundamental rights guaranteed by the Constitution. Arbitrary arrests and intimidation cannot be tolerated, and that is what we are witnessing in the DRC today.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, I would like to stress here once again that every conflict we analyse or debate in this Parliament is always directly linked to the interests of transnational companies and Western powers in plundering the resources of these countries. In the case of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, the strategic importance it has for its enormous geographical dimension and for having much of the world's mineral reserves —diamonds, copper, gold, coltan — is not escaped by oil, water and land reserves. Anyway, a tremendously rich and tremendously impoverished country. I believe that, in order to resolve these conflicts, we must start talking seriously that multinationals have to leave and let the peoples themselves decide on their resources and their economies. It must also be reported that, in cases of conflict, women and girls usually always bear the brunt, and we have to pay special attention to them.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. Mr President, with a year to go until the elections, we see that Facebook is shutting down and that the repression is getting worse, that human rights activists are more at risk. I would like to stress that we will go another year until the elections, because I think it is important that we continue to promote that these elections should not be delayed and that two terms for Kabila are two terms. We must continue to emphasise this. We need to be very careful what is going to happen in Congo and protect the human rights defenders. But what we also need to do is really teeth our own law around conflict minerals. What lies ahead, Mrs Mogherini, is voluntary self-certification for a few European companies. What this House wanted is legislation that was binding on all products and would also lead to sustainable mining in conflict zones. Because how do you get the war out of a country? That is, among other things, by taking the money out of the conflict. My question to you, Mrs Mogherini, is: how do we make this legislation robust and effective?

name: James CARVER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, the DRC is a classic example for Western politicians of how it is unacceptable to use African nations as pawns on a diplomatic chessboard. Today’s problems in the DRC are a direct consequence of her abandonment after the Cold War on the back of Belgian King Leopold II’s earlier use of this beautiful mineral-rich country as his personal fiefdom.  As we all wish for a stable future here, the African-led UN force must now, more than ever before, face up to questions over their past conduct. Accordingly, I question whether a man facing over 121 allegations of breaches of human rights, General Bruno Mandevu, should still be a senior officer in a Congolese UN-joint military operation against the FDLR. Can someone under such scrutiny really be allowed to remain in a position of authority as we endeavour to enter a fresh chapter of hope in this troubled region?

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Madam President, Madam High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, despite my commitment to the Democratic Republic of Congo, I cannot be pleased that the situation of this partner country is on the agenda.  The decision of 25 January on the electoral law will not be enough to restore a climate of confidence for the rest of the electoral cycle.  The current situation includes four key elements. Firstly, the publication of a complete, consensual and, above all, detailed budget, already requested by the electoral monitoring mission I conducted last June. Eight months later, we are at the same point. The government and the CENI cannot continue to throw the ball back at each other. Secondly, the central element of any continuation of the electoral cycle in the DRC is dialogue between political parties. We need to encourage it, whether it is through working groups within ceNI or through new initiatives that create forums for cross-party discussion, to restore trust, to ensure the transition of power. The third key message is the implementation of the Addis Ababa framework agreement. The launch of military operations against the FDLR can only be decisive if real progress is made in the implementation of the framework agreement. Commitments must be kept by all stakeholders.  This debate is also an opportunity to recall Dr. Mukwege's Sakharov Prize. The Congolese authorities must fully support the activities of the Panzi hospital and refrain from obstructing its proper functioning. Finally, the protection of civilians must remain a priority, not only for Monusco, but especially for the armed forces of the DRC.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, I fully agree with what our colleague Louis Michel has said, both on the issue of press freedom and on the issue of human rights, and also on the electoral calendar. And I can only support the idea of an observatory, as he proposed. However, the European Union must remain coherent and has other instruments to carry out this policy, including the international trade instrument. You know that we are discussing today in the INTA committee the fight against so-called 'blood' minerals, that is, those that fuel conflicts in these regions. This measure must be binding. The Commission's proposal is timid and we are asking, as Mr Mukwege did when he came here to receive the Sakharov Prize and urged us to take binding measures in this area, that Parliament take its responsibilities. I therefore call on the whole Parliament to take responsibility and not just to say - at a time of human rights problems - that we do have to fight, and to use the tools at its disposal to combat human rights offences.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: Madam President, I too support Mr Michel's sensible proposals and also the words just spoken by our colleague. In November, European parliamentarians awarded the Sakharov Prize to Dr Mukwege today for making a living by recomposing the body and soul of sexually attacked women and girls as a weapon of war. Those who seek to destroy the state, to clear it, need to destroy communities and this is one of the most effective ways. At this headquarters, Dr. Mukwege asked us not to let the agreement signed in Addis Ababa die. The Framework Agreement for Peace, Security and Cooperation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo and the Region was signed less than two years ago, and today we fear the elections in 2016. After listening to Dr. Mukwege, impunity must be involved, for safety. Commissioner Mogherini, we need it to support the United Nations special envoy, to get involved and involve European society until we make progress in the region, an election acceptable in 2017 and, therefore, Commissioner, I support Mr Michel's proposals.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: Madam President, I am also one of the in-office to act urgently in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.  I just spoke, just two hours ago, to Denis Mukwege and he asked me to intervene this Parliament: he needs protection. Since 16 November, his situation has not stopped getting worse. Mukwege receives constant threats, phone intimidation, SMS and the security situation of your hospital and your person are at serious risk. Denis Mukwege's words still resonate here when he received the Sakharov Prize, resonating in our heads and consciences. It is time for this Parliament and the European Union to take strong action against the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. We cannot give the Sakharov Prize to Denis Mukwege and now abandon him in the face of an obvious lack of security for himself and for patients. Denis Mukwege has denounced in recent months the increase in rape of children under the age of five: that is what is happening. The Congolese Government has done absolutely nothing and Denis Mukwege is calling for an international investigation into this situation. Well: international research, direct commitment by the European authorities to the fight for peace and dignity in Congo, and a commitment to the personal security of Denis Mukwege, who came to ask us here, in person, and half of this Parliament ended up crying.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: Madam President, Madam High Representative, the repression of the Congolese Government last month caused at least forty-two of its citizens to die. It is a dramatic figure in itself, but it is a small part of the thousands of dead, of half a million displaced persons, of the two and a half million people in need of humanitarian aid and of the violations that occur in that country. That is the result, along with the persecution of opposition political leaders, along with the persecution of civil society in virtually all its strata. The European Union must commit to the African Union to incorporate all parties into a project to achieve peace, in a project to hold free elections, in accordance with a democratic electoral law. And finally, it must have a determined, firm, fair policy on the conflict of minerals: that they do not serve to finance the armed groups in the region. That is what I believe Parliament should ask the European Commission, the European Union as a whole, and that is what we are telling the High Representative in this debate.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: Madam President, the recent events in the Democratic Republic of Congo are unacceptable, and the rise in violence there must be condemned by all means.  The parliament has taken an important decision by enacting the electoral law. We expect the Democratic Republic of Congo to promptly set a date for the presidential elections in 2016. The humanitarian situation in Congo deteriorates every day, with a variety of threats to the safety of the population, such as conflicts over minerals, sexual violence used as a conflict weapon and tough repression by the government. The country seems to be falling step-by-step into chaos. I believe that the intimidation and arrest of political opponents and human rights defenders and the repression of civil society should be stopped by all means, and I expect the European Commission to take the necessary steps to stop this.  I am very concerned for the safety of our Sakharov Prize winner, Denis Mukwege, whose hospital was clearly targeted days after visiting this House. We expect as well that MONUSCO will take the necessary measures in order to fulfil its main task: the protection of civilians.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the latest developments in the Democratic Republic of Congo are causing serious concern in the international community as this region is in danger of being completely destabilised. This means, among other things, that the provisions of the Constitution must be observed for the holding of the presidential elections, which are scheduled at a very specific date. But Kabila's decision to extend his term in the presidential race has sparked a storm of opposition reactions, huge protests and bloody riots. Many activists have now fallen dead. But the existence of military groups and local conflicts in Congo have one material object: controlling the exploitation of Congo's rich natural resources. That is why democracy must be restored, fundamental rights protected and Congolese natural resources exploited in favour of the country's own people. This is the only way to protect women and children in the region.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, the Democratic Republic of congo is a particularly important African state for Europe. Not in that light in which I used to listen to one colleague say it was an ordinary country of King Leopold of Belgium - that's not the way we need to talk. We need to talk in a way that today in this democratic Congo we really want to achieve all those goals that the Congolese people have the right to achieve.  We have to have a consecutive policy. If we have given Mr. Mukwege a prestigious award, we must conduct consecutive further policies. Otherwise, we will lose the credibility of this Parliament and the European Union in the first place in Congo and elsewhere.  That is why I am applauding the High Commissioner and our policy of resolving this situation in the Congo through a democratic path, new elections and thus seeing really who has the trust of the Congolese people and I think that is the only correct solution.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: Mr President, I would like to speak on mining. Mrs Mogherini, you know, there is blood in this cell phone, there are rare minerals, some of which may come from the Democratic Republic of Congo. And we have a problem with that, because this trade enriches armed groups and creates money to finance their abuses. At the European level, we have a responsibility. We have a European regulation, on a voluntary basis, on the origin of minerals, whether it is tin, tantalum, tungsten or gold. First of all, it must be extended to other resources, such as oil, uranium, etc., and above all, it must become binding. How is it that in the United States the Dodd-Frank act is binding, whereas in our country, at European level, it happens on a voluntary basis? Secondly, it is not enough to limit this attempt at certification to importers, it must be done on the whole chain, and in particular on the final company. You have to ask her if she has an ethical charter for mobile phones. Because I think it's outrageous... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, quoting a writer from my own country, Flaiano, I would say that the situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo continues to be very serious but far from serious. Just think of the disgraceful decoy with which the current President wanted to try to postpone the elections. Unfortunately, in many former colonies in our Member States, the example of ten years of colonisation has led the ruling class to believe that democracy is a dictatorship of the majority, real or presumed, and not maximum protection of the rights of the opposition, and so President Kabila is trying to make the country his personal property, as the King of Belgium did in the past. It is time for us to be consistent and to say enough is enough and for our companies to give up forever the raw materials that are dirty with blood. A great man, our Sakharov Prize winner, Dr Mukwege, asked us to do so this year, and we must turn his words into our actions. Otherwise, the prize of which we have rightly awarded it will simply become the prize for our hypocrisy.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Mr President, I see that the debate on Congo is very passionate about this House, I see that there is a great deal of excitement. It seems to me that I am in the Mariuccia guesthouse that is in Italy, where there are practically pensioners who play cards and who make a few words while waiting for the evening to arrive to have dinner. Then I see the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and, of course, security, Mrs Mogherini, who is here. I would like to say a poetic phrase to you, Mr Representative: given the results you have had, not in the Congo, where I would like you to go and never go back, but in Ukraine, where Merkel went to talk to Putin about this problem together with Hollande, you count an emeritus, excuse me the fucking term. You count for nothing, I say nothing in this Europe! And to wake up this House, you sleep on your feet, Europe counts for nothing! It doesn't matter! Wake up a little! Wake up! Wake up! Wake up! Wake up! You're asleep! We need a Europe. (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr Buonanno, I would like to thank Mr Buonanno for his work on You have spoken for far too long. Their last comments remain hidden from the public because they could no longer be interpreted by the interpreters. (End of catch-the-eye process)

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vicepresidente della Commissione/Alto rappresentante dell'Unione per gli affari esteri e la politica di sicurezza. - Grazie Presidente. Vedo dalla lista degli interventi per questo pomeriggio, per uno dei punti di discussione successivi, cioè la situazione in Ucraina per l'appunto, che l'on. Buonanno non è iscritto a parlare. Lo invito, se forse vuole parlare della situazione in Ucraina, a venire in quest'Aula tra qualche ora e a discutere in quella sede. Io sarò qui, non so se lui ci sarà. Many of you mentioned things that I mentioned in my opening remarks and that I would like to underline. Thank you for joining our voices in this respect. I think this is a powerful message from this Parliament, and from the European institutions united, and I hope that this message gets to where it has to go.  Some of you mentioned the fact that this is not only important for the country itself, but it is also important for the region. I would also add that it is important for global security and stability, and that I will never ever accept the idea that one has to concentrate solely on crises and human rights violations and conflicts that are close to our borders, because also what happens in places that are apparently far away from us influences our security and our global stability. We have to deal with that, as it is not only our specific responsibility but also in our interest, and I think we should all understand that in this room.  Let me underline one point that was mentioned by many of you and something that Dr Mukwege reminded us of, which is the role of women in this. The victims are always women, girls – younger and younger every time, in every conflict – and children. Let me also mention the fact that there is a specific target. It is not by chance that it is always women who are the first victims or the first weapon in some conflicts. I can assure you that we are not only already working on this aspect in a specific way, in this particular case in the DRC, with support to the victims whether it be medical or legal, on the reform of the security system, and on the reform of the judiciary – because we also have to face that side of the attack against women – but we are going to work more and more on the first victims of conflict and violence who, everywhere in the world, are women and children. Let me also re-underline the need to be coherent. I thank those of you that raised this when you awarded the Sakharov Prize in this room only a few months ago. This implied that our support is not only to the person, but also to the work, mainly to the work of this person. I share these views, and I think that now today we need to guarantee protection to the person and to their work, and to collective work which is also a sign of hope for the country and for the region.  On Louis Michel’s proposal, let me say that I fully sympathise with this and I will make sure that once I go back to Brussels I will study it with our EU Special Representative for Human Rights, Stavros Lambrinidis, to see in what ways we can support it. Let me also say that I fully support the desire to curb the links between conflict and exploitation of natural resources. I know that the Council is examining the draft resolution that was presented with the communication by the Commission, and you have my personal commitment on that. I cannot guarantee that it will be enough, but I can guarantee that you have my personal commitment on it. Per finire fatemi usare l'italiano. Cécile Kyenge ha fatto bene a ricordare in quest'Aula oggi che la morte è tornata ieri nel Mediterraneo, e non soltanto ieri.  Colgo l'occasione del fatto che lei ha sollevato questo tema oggi qui per dire che ho appena informato la Commissione della mia intenzione di convocare una riunione straordinaria del gruppo di Commissari per l'azione esterna, insieme al Commissario Avramopoulos, per discutere di come rivedere le nostre politiche per l'immigrazione, per mettere insieme gli strumenti che abbiamo dal punto di vista interno, delle nostre politiche interne, e le nostre politiche esterne rispetto ai paesi di origine e di transito, e ho intenzione di mettere questo tema presto all'ordine del giorno del Consiglio "Affari esteri" dell'Unione europea. Credo che non possiamo aspettare altre tragedie in mare, dobbiamo prevenirle, e credo anche che l'Unione europea abbia, se ha la volontà politica, gli strumenti per prevenire queste tragedie in mare.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the lack of funding for UNRWA (2015/2563(RSP)). At the beginning of the debate, Vice-President Hahn speaks on her part.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, first of all I would like to thank you for giving us the opportunity to address this House today and to explain the European Union’s position as regards the funding of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East (UNRWA).  Let me underline that the European Union commends the important work of the Agency in delivering basic services to some five million Palestinian refugees across five fields of operation. I am particularly impressed by how the Agency has been performing under increasingly difficult circumstances, in particular in Gaza during and after the recent war, as well as in Syria with severe consequences in Lebanon and Jordan.  Allow me to recall that, along with its Member States, the European Union remains the largest and most predictable donor to the Agency. In combination with contributions from EU Member States, the overall contribution in 2014 accounted for 34% of the total support to UNRWA. Let me also stress that the European Union has always been very quick in paying the support allocated immediately after signature of the contract.  Since 2000 the European Union has provided over EUR 1.6 billion to the Agency. The aim of our support to the Agency’s regular budget is to sustain the delivery of essential public services to the refugees. Under the European Neighbourhood Instrument, the European Union has made a political commitment to make EUR 246 million available for UNRWA’s general fund for the period 2014-2016 through a joint multiannual framework. With an average allocation of EUR 82 million per year, this represents an increase of EUR 6 million compared to previous years. In view of the exceptional situation in Gaza, the European Union has acted swiftly and allocated an additional EUR 30 million to the Agency at the end of last year. This is in line with Parliament’s resolution of 18 September 2014 and with the EU’s pledge at the Cairo Conference on Gaza reconstruction in October 2014.  This additional allocation has allowed the Agency: firstly, to support children returning to school after the conflict and to provide basic food to over 800 000 refugees – EUR 7 million from the European Neighbourhood Instrument has been provided for that; secondly, to set up an emergency employment scheme, a job creation programme – EUR 5 million under the Instrument contributing to Stability and Peace; and, thirdly, to provide humanitarian assistance to help with emergency shelter – EUR 1 million by DG ECHO.  This EUR 13 million in additional funding from the European Union’s budget is a direct consequence of the Protective Edge Operation in Gaza, carried out in Gaza in July and August 2014. The Commission strongly regrets that the Agency has had to suspend its cash assistance programme in Gaza, which benefited tens of thousands of people by allowing them to repair their damaged and destroyed homes and provided rental subsidies for the homeless. In this regard, we hope that the EU funds planned in the pipeline will help palliate the financial situation of the general fund.  The European Union strongly calls on all donors to fulfil the pledges announced at the Cairo Conference on Gaza reconstruction in order to meet the immediate needs of the most vulnerable households in Gaza.  Finally, allow me to stress that the European Union also invites the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East to further increase its efforts to mobilise additional funds from non-traditional donors, including the Gulf countries, and to ensure the appropriate visibility of the European Union as by far the largest and most predictable donor.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Commissioner, this is not the first time the agency has faced such a situation. It is therefore important to ask the right questions, and above all to ensure that all actors take responsibility.  First, the agency should clearly identify the reasons why the promised funds were ultimately not mobilized. Beyond the budgetary constraints faced by many donors, what are the real roots of this situation? Second, it becomes necessary to diversify the sources of contributions. The Palestinian conflict goes beyond regional issues and requires a comprehensive response. It is necessary - and we agree with you - to involve more donors, including from emerging countries. The third point is that humanitarianism must not become hostage to the political situation. UNRWA not only provides material assistance, but also provides a guarantee of human development for years to come, guaranteeing access to educational services and microfinance. It should always be kept in mind.  This brings me to my fourth point. The Palestinian Authority must plan for the development of the Palestinian territories beyond the humanitarian emergency. We need a medium- and long-term action plan, which is not just about rebuilding what has been destroyed while waiting for the next crisis. With regard to the European Union, through your voices, Commissioner and High Representative, the European Union has begun to strengthen its contribution to conflict resolution and crisis prevention, taking a regional and comprehensive perspective. You have our support to continue in this direction. Finally, the international community needs to think more broadly about the solutions we bring to refugees. Leaving the conflicts unresolved - between Israel and Palestine, in Syria, perhaps soon in Libya - leads to an unprecedented increase in the number of refugees. UNRWA must remain one of a kind, and we must not again accept "temporary" conditions for the next 65 years.  (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for your contribution. I have just one little question: the occupation. Do you agree with me that this is the core of the conflict and that we cannot see a solution for either Israel or Palestine or all the refugees if we do not do something substantial about the occupation?

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, I have been very clear: humanitarians must not become hostages to the political situation. It is clear that today we have partners on both sides who must commit to finding a solution. The decision that will move the situation forward will not be unilateral. That is my position.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: on behalf of the S&D group – Mr President, Commissioner Hahn, distinguished colleagues, I will begin by reminding that UNRWA also aims to support a population in a dramatic situation, Palestinian refugees, throughout the Middle East. In the face of current crises and conflicts, UNRWA is a necessary, crucial instrument, both humanitarianally and politically and strategically.  Poor financing threatens the existence of this entity and its ability to achieve its purposes.  On 26 February, six months will be reached after the ceasefire, which ended fifty days of war in Gaza. At that time, 96,000 Palestinian refugee homes were destroyed or severely damaged by the conflict. Throughout this conflict, UNRWA has been a stabilising force, it has been a force of aid, even in dramatic conditions for the staff serving this noble cause and to whom we must convey our full value and respect.  However, in six months, UNRWA has received only a small portion of the promised funds to deal with the destruction. Not even partially rebuild the destroyed infrastructure. UNRWA was then forced to suspend the assistance programme in Gaza. Colleagues, in conclusion, the European Union, which wants to be a force of peace...  (the speaker has had the word withdrawn).

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: for the ECR Group. Mr President! It is, of course, against an incredibly tragic background that we are discussing the lack of cash flow to reduce refugees for Palestinian refugees. However, against the same background, we must also just have in mind that when the Court of Auditors last reviewed the way we spent the money in Palestine, it produced an incredibly critical report which fundamentally questioned the extent to which the money was spent properly.  That is why it is incredibly important for the ECR Group – when we discuss how the money is given to different organisations, including to UN organisations – that cash flows are managed, that fundamental European values are respected by those to which we give the money, and that, with the supporting measures we are taking for Palestine, we are helping to promote a peace process. , where both sides must bow to each other and where we do not give support to extremists on either side.

name: Fernando MAURA BARANDIARÁN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the examples provided by this debate expose, once again, that Europe has not been able to solve problems which concern us and affect us directly. We might ask ourselves, in the cases of Gaza and Syria, whether we have helped the parties achieve a political solution to the conflict; whether we have pushed Israel hard enough to provide minimal living conditions for its people as the occupying force in Gaza, or whether we have instead allowed them to do what they have deemed appropriate; if we have made progress in Syria, where today and after four years of conflict, the European Union still does not have a common project to help resolve the conflict. I could say that, when politics fails, charity fills its void, even if it alone is not political, but a means of covering up shame our shames with economic resources. Economic resources of our citizens, aimed at rebuilding a region focused on continued destruction and reconstruction every time Israelis and Palestinians come into conflict, rather than exerting, once and for all, real diplomatic pressure to help the creation of two states, the Israeli and the Palestinian with the recognition of the latter in an explicit way , which coexist in peace, security and prosperity. And all this, moreover, so that not even the Members of this house, of this European Parliament, can observe what is going on there. I can share with all of you that the Israeli Government has recently denied a group of MEPs from the ALDE Group among which I am visiting the Gaza Strip, to see first-hand, together with UNRWA, the use of these European funds. It is the sad realization, of course, that once again we do not do what we should and that we do not take ours seriously. (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, if the international community has not the political will to address the root causes of the conflict in Palestine – namely the occupation of Palestine, the blockade of Gaza, Israel’s ongoing violation of international and humanitarian law – if, indeed, the collective political will is not there to resolve this mess, then, at the very least, we should stop taking it out on the most vulnerable people in Gaza.  For months in this Chamber I have heard MEP after MEP defending human rights and international law. Fine words, yet some MEPs act as spectators too, or worse, defenders of unacceptable breaches of such international and humanitarian law. Ninety-six thousand Palestinian homes were destroyed or damaged during the last onslaught on Gaza. USD 720 million of assistance is needed. So far UNRWA has received 135 million, leaving a shortfall of USD 585 million . What happened to the USD 5.4 billion that was pledged in Cairo?  In the overpopulated, open prison of Gaza, people are sleeping among the rubble. Some children are dying of hypothermia as a result of inadequate winter shelter. There is one indisputable fact: when Palestinians are silent they are forgotten by many, but thankfully not by UNRWA, whose 12 500 staff work tirelessly on all our behalf. So let us give them the funding that they need to help the Palestinian refugees.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: verts/ALE Group. Mr President! I do not want to repeat what has been said last time, but just agree that we must all be aware that the situation in Gaza is worse than it has ever been, and at the same time that the refugees in Syria, the Palestinian refugees in Syria, are now under such pressure that they are forced to flee if they do not get real help now. It will be a burden on all of us. That is why, Madam President, make better promises to us about how the dramatic hole in the UNRDA's coffers can be closed so that they can continue the admirable work, because it is admirable, as almost everyone in here has indicated. In addition, we must also state that we will soon be able to hear that the EU's words matter. As recently as November last year, the Foreign Ministers assured us that they would take responsibility for keeping the desire for a two-state solution alive. And yet, when new settlements were again announced, it was just to the usual lament: "We're sorry!," "We're alarmed!," "We're distancing ourselves from...!," "We're shocked! They can just be allowed to continue. So something must now be done if the dream of a two-state solution is not to end up as a nightmare or simply disappear like a mirage. Let me conclude by simply demanding that the Palestinians do their own job. I am fully aware that Hamas is not helpful in this regard and that they should be criticised on sundays and together; but the Palestinians in Ramallah must also deliver. They are completely absent in Gaza and in the work of reconciliation, which has also therefore come to a complete standstill. If we are to succeed in coping with the tragedy in Gaza and the whole situation of having a real Palestinian state, the Palestinian authorities must come forward, including them, and live up to their commitments.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there are 96 000 homes of Palestinian refugee families damaged or destroyed, 90% of the inhabitants of the Strip are unemployed and without income, many people are still sleeping in the rubble and children have died of hypothermia, ladies and gentlemen. I would like the donors who have not fulfilled their commitments to UNRWA for Gaza, who have betrayed their word, those promises made very hastily to get some flashes and some wonderful souvenir photos in Cairo, to think about this. The Union must not only set a good example as the quickest payer, but must also demand that the other partners proceed without further delay and without apology to make the necessary contributions to enable the Agency to work. To those who raise the risk of misuse of funds, I would remind you that this means finding the best way to avoid it, not to cut it. You don't cut off a hand to prevent it from holding a rifle, it explains why you don't have to hold it. Otherwise we are more barbaric than those who would like to challenge it.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Mr President, an unrelenting war has been raging in the Near East region for 65 years. A war with countless dead and wounded, incalculable disasters and 5 million Palestinian refugees. The UN relief and work agency for Palestinian refugees provides relief and social services in key areas such as health and education. From a humanitarian and ethical point of view, the service is doing an important job of observing a policy of equal distances. We have every reason and obligation to strengthen it in every way. But if we do not combat the cause of refugee production, we will try in vain and bleed economically as a Union. The cause of the problem is the State of Israel and the cause of geopolitics. Israel is between Syria, Jordan, Lebanon, the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. Obviously geography is the de facto constant that determines civil-military movements and results. However, regardless of any purpose, the situation, especially in the Gaza Strip, is precarious and tragic. Israeli aggression is constantly creating new human casualties, new refugees, new infrastructure disasters, Despite all peace talks and efforts, Israel continues the same dead-end offensive policy. The solution is simple. Let us give the Palestinians what they deserve: a state.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Mr. President, according to the Brussels office of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees, which has been delivered to all MEPs, the European Union should soon deposit €82 million into the account of this UN agency. Likewise, last year ECHO paid an additional 5m euros for emergency aid in Gaza following armed conflicts in the area, which is otherwise in an extremely difficult humanitarian situation. Despite these donations, UNRWA, according to a report we received from the same Brussels office, is in a budget deficit of more than 71m euros. It should also be stressed that in addition to the situation in Gaza, about 470,000 Palestinians have refugee status in Syria, and as many as 95% need humanitarian assistance.  It is therefore important that we send a message of support from the European Parliament today to the competent authorities of the European Union, in particular ECHO, which is currently in talks with UNRWA over further financial assistance to this UN agency. The issue of Palestinian refugees is impossible to resolve without a political solution, and this Parliament has already spoken out about what it should look like. However, organizations like Hamas still do not recognize Israel's right to exist and our message today must also be to care about the security of the citizens of Israel.  Therefore, it should be concluded that, with humanitarian assistance to Gaza, it is necessary to increase the focus on our long-term development policies, on the process of building democratic and inclusive institutions. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question by raising the blue card on the basis of Article 162(8) of the Code of Health. Rules of procedure.)

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr. President, Mr. Stier, I share your concerns about the refugee situation and all that is happening between Israel and Palestine, but my question goes for whether you think and do you believe that the only correct solution is two independent states, namely Palestine and Israel, and that this is the only correct solution in the long run? I'm interested in your opinion on the subject.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr. Jakovcic, a solution that will follow the establishment of two countries is the only stable solution. The Palestinian people are entitled to their state, but Israel is also entitled to its survival as a state.  Once and as foreign policy adviser to the former Croatian Prime Minister, I organized the first visit of the Prime Minister of the Republic of Croatia to the Palestinian Authority and that was our message: support for the Palestinian people to establish their state, but also to have to recognize Israel's right to exist.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the European Union has been providing humanitarian aid to UNRWA for forty-two years. In itself it is a revealing fact: around half a century of an en masquered humanitarian crisis, in which human lives are lost every day of that half century. This crisis is the failure of the international community to reach a political exit to this conflict; it is also the result of the lack of a near horizon, credible, for a just solution in the area. Conflicts in the area, for example, Syria, have dramatically increased the number of refugees; therefore also the need for humanitarian aid. However, human resources have not grown, financial resources have not grown in the same dimension. We need, from the European Parliament, to call on the international community to respond to the extraordinary help that UNRWA is calling for for 2015. EUR 100 million is urgently needed to respond to this humanitarian crisis. We must respond from the European Union to ensure that our role in the area remains essential to promote a just, lasting peace, in accordance with a two-state solution, which is what we have long advocated.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: In the eyes of thousands of Palestinian refugees - especially those in Syria and Gaza - the aid that UNWRA can provide them with because of our solidarity and broadness, is the only difference between a miserable life and an even more uncertain future. Let us not forget: 90 percent of Palestinian refugees in Gaza and In Syria cannot survive without unwre assistance. When we respond to the call for support and provision of funds for the regular budget and emergency operations in Gaza and Syria, we must be aware that neither this humanitarian organisation nor its caregivants are responsible for the situation in which they find themselves time and time again.  It is the incompetence of the international community, including us in the European Union, that we are not doing enough to bring about peace and to resolve the basic, Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The problem will remain and will be more common with each new day and with every new conflict in the region that is at our door.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Mr President, first of all I would like to express our deep appreciation for the work of UNRWA and its people. Since 27 January UNRWA has been unable to provide assistance for repairs and accommodation in Gaza due to a non-inflow of the amounts promised by the participants in the Donors Conference in Cairo. Of the $5.4 million commitments, significant sums have not yet flowed. At the same time, the deficit in the UNRWA fund is EUR 71.7 million, while the European Union has promised EUR 82 million in aid. Commissioner, the European Union must honour its commitments and contribute directly to the promised amounts. As GUE/NGL we welcome today's debate, the subject of which we have highlighted. Six months after Israel's merciless bombings with thousands dead and wounded and 96,000 dilapidated houses, humanity must not forget Gaza. We demand the lifting of the blockade of Gaza, an end to settlement and occupation and recognition of the Palestinian state.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: Mr. President! The reason for today's debate is the current threat to the UNRWA reconstruction programme in the Gaza Strip. It is extremely worrying that support for reconstruction has had to be suspended, partly because of the lack of payments. After last year's Gaza war, thousands of families spend the winter in shelters. Time and again, people and children die from hypothermia.  The international community must ensure that the funds pledged at the donors' conference in Cairo actually arrive. To date, UNRWA has received only about a quarter of the promised funds. Long-term financing is equally important, especially in view of the current situation in the region. UNRWA is a pole of stability in the Middle East, not only in Palestine, but also in Lebanon, Jordan and Syria.  Of particular importance is UNRWA's school system, with more than half a million pupils. Often, these schools are the only place where children are taught democratic values and human rights.  The financial situation has deteriorated further as a cost to the war in Syria.

name: Javier NART
text: Mr President, Israel, as an occupying power, under the Fourth Geneva Convention, has an obligation to meet the needs of the occupied population and does not: we have to do it, fundamentally Europe. The cycle is: Israel destroys, we rebuild, and 30% industrial profit is carried away by Israeli industry. This is an obscenity that has to stop. When Europe is suffering cuts and European citizens are suffering economic problems, it cannot be that we continue to cover what Israel destroys. I will make you, Mr Hahn, a proposition: let us give UNRWA what it needs, withdrawing from Israel what it receives from the European Union under the agreements it signs with Europe. It cannot be that Europe continues to finance the business of 'destruction-reconstruction'. And secondly and lastly, it leaves me overwhelmed that the barbarity of the bombing of civilians, which is a war crime, you call it war. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Nart, I would like to thank Mr Nart for his work on this It would always be nice to stick to the facts. From the Gaza Strip, the Israelis were under sustained aggressive fire. Hamas continues to threaten the total extermination of the Jews. Confirmed by UNRWA, rockets were partially stored in schools. That is why I ask me, but rather to the High Representative: how is attention paid to the fact that money is now going out again, that these funds are actually being used for peaceful purposes? We also have to keep thinking about this again and again. Who was the aggressor, and who are the victims?

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr Gericke, I would like to thank Mr Gericke for his Unfortunately, this was not a question with a blue card to the speaker, but to the Commissioner. Nevertheless, I give Mr Nart the opportunity to respond.

name: Javier NART
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Gericke, there is a text which is not mine, it is the Fourth Geneva Convention, which I recommend to read. Article 56 and Article 59 require the occupying power to allow unrestricted access for humanitarian agencies to provide what is necessary, so that children do not die of hypothermia and people do not live in the trash, and so that eighty thousand homes do not remain destroyed.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: Mr President, Commissioner, it is appalling that a people, particularly the Palestinian people in Gaza, is suffering a five-fold penalty: a blockade, an occupation, the confinement of part of its population in refugee camps, war attacks and murderous attacks by the Israeli army, which has destroyed homes and infrastructure, killed or injured thousands of people - and now the international structure , the hand that somehow rescues them, UNRWA, is financially drained. We must not let this happen, but find ways to quickly close UNRWA's deficits. Those who have committed must pay their share. How can we find so much money for over-armament and war, and not find money for humanitarian aid, for the lives of innocent children? On the other hand, we have a responsibility to create the conditions for the protection of the Palestinian people and to act so that they have their land and their state.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: Mr President, UNRWA has called on the EU to make an extraordinary contribution and my Group says we should, to an organisation which is itself extraordinary. I share the concern of some of those in this Chamber that we are simply paying the price of the Gaza conflict, but with 8 000 families still waiting for the first instalment to repair their damaged homes it is they who have paid most of all. With 90% of Palestinian refugees in Gaza and in Syria reliant on UNRWA for their survival, there is an overwhelming humanitarian imperative for us to help.  I heard only yesterday that the UNWRA girls’ school in Ramallah is concerned for their future. And yes, of course we have to deal with the root causes, but let us accept that our own failure in being able to help do so means that we have an obligation to help. Since 2013, European Commission aid to UNRWA has already reduced from EUR 190 million to EUR 120 million. Today UNRWA has the highest deficit since it was first established in 1949. Let us make an extraordinary contribution to that extraordinary organisation.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: Mr President, it is clear that this debate has a lot to do with the negotiations we had over the past year for the 2015 budget, because no one misses that during these negotiations the European Parliament asked for EUR 300 million to support the peace process, for financial assistance, and also for participation in UNRWA funding. But unfortunately, in these negotiations Parliament had no allies, neither in the Commission nor in the Council, and that is why we cannot even match the amount of 300 million that we had insured for another year. And today UNRWA appeals to us because the situation is disperating. It's a matter of humanitarian aid. They are asking us for an additional effort to continue to care for the thousands of refugees currently in humanitarian emergency in Gaza and Syria. We are asked for an extraordinary effort to keep the housing program running and helping to repair and rebuild thousands of homes. I don't know what they think. I do not know what the Commission or the Council is going to propose. But what I do believe is that we can't look the other way. The European Union in which I believe, of course, cannot say no to this extra.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul It was a great and important event when we in the European Parliament decided by a large majority to support and push for the recognition of Palestine. But that's not enough, not yet. The Israeli blockade of Gaza has been going on for almost nine years. The dramatic effect of this is that the number of refugees referred to food aid from the UN relief agency has increased from 80 000 to over 860 000 today.  The economy and the ability to create and find jobs have been shattered and the majority of the population depends on humanitarian aid, while humanitarian aid has not kept pace with an increasing refugee population in one of the most unstable regions in the world. On the contrary: the UN Relief and Works Agency now has the smallest budget in ten years. The international community is currently failing to give the people of Gaza even a minimum of help. This risks the whole foundation of UNWRA's operations.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: We have had a crisis in the Middle East for decades. A decade ago, we were only talking about the Middle East crisis in Gaza, now we are talking about the crisis in Syria, we are talking about the crisis in north Africa. And I strongly support the European Union providing all the necessary resources for these unfortunate people. At the same time, I join in the appeals of those who speak of the need for a quality, long-term, stable political solution that will bring peace to this part of the world. For as events unfold, we can firmly believe that there will be more refugees, not least more refugees, who want to come to Europe, day by year, and these are our common problems. Efforts should also go in this direction so that everyone else who is co-responsible and in some way also feels responsible for this problem donates the funds they promised at the Cairo conference.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, 2014 was a particularly difficult year for Palestinian refugees who continue to suffer under occupation and continue to be robbed of their homes, their daily lives and, in many cases, their own lives. The last year of conflict has destroyed Gaza's economy, which has already been weakened by years of blockade. In such a desperate context, UNRWA has been forced to suspend its cash assistance programme and the consequences of this interruption could be dramatic. In fact, UNRWA is the only element of stability in an extremely precarious political and security context. I believe that the European Union must remind the international community of its responsibilities to ensure that the immediate humanitarian needs of this impoverished community are met. I am thinking in particular of the allocation of EUR 100 million in the first quarter of this year to enable families who have suffered minor damage to repair their homes and provide rent subsidies. This would prevent many families from returning to the collective centres, where as many as 12 000 Palestinian refugees are still housed.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: Mr President, I fear that the fact that we have this debate portrays a reality that the UNRWA spokesman in Jerusalem anticipated to us in the course of the mission to Palestine that a delegation from my GUE/NGL Group made last September: "Be you the voice of the Palestinian people," he asked us, 'because Gaza will be forgotten in six months'. Evidently, oblivion came much earlier. Otherever, UNRWA would not warn that it runs out of funds. As Martina Anderson has pointed out, it is a matter of political will and decision, that is, it is not possible to be neutral on this issue. It's not an option when we talk about a busy town. Nor is it an option to limit ourselves to a mere diagnosis of the situation by remembering the money that the European Union has allocated or committed, because that, among other things, only portrays our political incapacity, and Palestine and the Palestinian people deserve much more.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are talking about UNRWA, we are talking about the fact that the funds are insufficient and it seems clear to me that we all agree that sufficient funds should be provided and that those who made commitments in Cairo must keep them. However, the paradox of this debate, which then, of course, ends in the classic debate between Palestine and Israel, is that, as Mr Nart said, we first finance those who destroy and then go to finance to rebuild. It is a bit of an ambiguous attitude that we hold as the European Union. I would therefore say that we should look for a solution, in addition to guaranteeing funding to the Agency at the moment, that is political, and therefore guarantee the dual state, guarantee the Palestinians a peaceful future and go and prevent those who receive funding from us from then going to destroy or will always find ourselves in the same situation.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, allow me to close this debate by once again thanking this House for supporting the issue of Palestine refugees and also for today’s lively, interesting and engaging debate.  Let me stress that the Commission will continue to support the important work of the agency in the field. In this context, I am happy to confirm that the 2015 financing decision in relation to the contribution to the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees, which is worth EUR 82 million, was adopted by the European Commission today.  In addition, the EU’s Humanitarian Aid and Civil Protection department is currently finalising a EUR 5 million funding package for the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees for 2015, out of which EUR 4 million has been earmarked for the Agency’s Shelter Response in Gaza. This money will cover cash assistance for improving shelter conditions for the most vulnerable households and providing household items which were lost during last year’s hostilities.  Once again I would like to repeat what I said in my introduction: it is important to address the issue of additional funding, in particular from countries from the Gulf region and to channel their contributions via international organisations so that we can properly address the needs of refugees in the region.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Alyn SMITH
text: in writing. – I have seen UNRWA’s irreplaceable role in providing public services to millions of Palestinian refugees, including during many trips to Gaza. The fact is we need UNRWA now more than ever. There is a power vacuum in Gaza which could backfire if the humanitarian situation further deteriorates, following Israel’s deadly raids. UNRWA, we often forget, is also in charge of Syria’s 400 000 Palestinian refugees – protecting them in Homs, Hama, South Damascus in Yarmouk Camp, despite Syria’s almost continuous starving siege since 2012. We must also urge Jordan to let them in from Syria and not only elderly, children and women – or worse, deport them back to Syria as seen last year. UNRWA also has to deal with 50 000 Palestinian refugees fleeing Syria to Lebanon, on top of 300 000 already.  We Europeans already pay 57% of UNRWA funding but it is Israel who should be paying for the education of Palestine’s refugees, their healthcare and their housing, not Europe.  UNRWA has a USD 80 million deficit in 2015 and needs an extra USD 15 million from the EU to cover late 2015: I hope the Council and Parliament will set this as a top priority.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. In our view, UNRWA is being clearly prevented from carrying out its essential assistance and reconstruction work for the five million Palestinian refugees in the Middle East. The pressure is unsustainable in Palestine: the lack of UNRWA funds, the impediments that the Israeli government puts to the agency's reconstruction work in Gaza, the constant human rights violations of Israeli security forces and bodies, are generating waves of outrage and despair in Palestine. The EU must stop being a political dwarf, as Jacques Delors said, and boost his role as a leader in the area. And it can only do so by demanding that Israel, as responsible for the destruction of Gaza, assist reconstruction by providing financial means and removing the work of international organizations. It is also necessary to stop putting the oppressor and the oppressed at the same level, and that the EU helped to promote investigations against Israeli military and political leaders who allow and implement the systematic violation of human rights and the Geneva Convention. Finally, we demand that the existing partnership agreement be suspended. Only then can the EU start washing its face.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Ukraine (2015/2560(RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Mr President, we discussed Ukraine one month ago in this very same room, if I am not mistaken, and since then the situation which was already dramatic at that time has deteriorated further, as is very evident to all of us. In the last weeks, we have seen the shelling of residential areas in Mariupol, increasing attacks on civilians, and a clear escalation on the ground, in many different parts of eastern Ukraine.  What is at stake first of all, I would like to remind us all, are thousands of human lives, almost two million refugees and internally displaced people, the integrity and sovereignty of an independent state on European territory, and respect for basic principles of international law: the first basic principle being that you do not change borders by force.  What is also at stake, especially in these very same hours where we see the escalation constantly growing in a very dangerous way, is also – and mainly, I would say – our capacity to respond to these threats, not only in an effective way to protect international law, states and the lives of civilians, but also our capacity to restore and preserve peace in Europe.  In these weeks, we have worked constantly; not always in a visible way but always in a very united, coordinated way and one, I would say, that is starting to be effective. Just after the shelling in Mariupol we took a coordinated approach, first of all with Mr Juncker and with Mr Tusk, to make sure that all the EU institutions were reacting on the same lines and with one voice, and with the 28 different Member States starting with the Latvian Presidency.  We held an extraordinary Foreign Affairs Council meeting just a few days after the shelling of Mariupol, where we decided all together – here I understand I should sit on the other side of the room but you will forgive me – to increase our pressure on Russia and on the separatists, by extending the time framework of the existing list of individuals and entities to September, and by adding names. We also tasked the Commission and EEAS services to prepare additional options for our pressure.  But we have also decided all together, keeping our unity in difficult times – and this is the first thing we must always do, keep our unity in difficult times, because this is our main strength – we also agreed to increase our diplomatic and political efforts and our diplomatic and political activity.  In this respect we have worked, as we had also done in previous months, through two channels that have proved to be – I cannot say effective because we did not reach a result, but the most effective among those that we have tried: on the one side the Trilateral Contact Group of the OSCE, and on the other side the so-called Normandy format, to relaunch the direct contacts between Kiev and Moscow that had been interrupted for a while and to find effective ways finally to start implementing the Minsk Agreements.  Because at that time it was clear not only that implementation of the points of the Minsk Agreements was not ongoing, but also that there was a risk of completely losing any kind of reference to the only agreement that had been signed by the different parties.  In this last week, as you know, we have again had initiatives on different levels – the OSCE channel, the Normandy format channel and the constant direct contacts that I personally have had both with President Poroshenko and Foreign Minister Klimkin – and with Foreign Minister Lavrov in Munich some days ago – to support all these ongoing efforts.  Yesterday we had another Foreign Affairs Council meeting where we decided together to endorse these efforts and create a space for the negotiations that are going on at present in Minsk; to allow the possibility of a successful result in these negotiations tomorrow night in Minsk with the meeting of the Normandy format.  Tomorrow is a chance – not a certainty, but a chance – that cannot be missed for all the reasons that I stated at the beginning of my speech, for the people who are losing their lives, for the principles of international law, for the sovereignty of the state and for preserving and restoring peace in Europe.  A chance I would say, if this would not lead to a much broader discussion about our kind of world and our kind of order or disorder, to preserve some sort of global balance, global order in our times. This is what is really at stake. I do not say I hope, but I am working at this time to make sure that the whole European Union – not only some Member States, but the whole European Union – backing these efforts, supporting these efforts, as I say sometimes quietly but always constantly and united, gets a result of some kind.  There is another part of the story while we are talking about Ukraine. It is the fact that, in times of crisis and conflict on Ukraine’s territory, it is extremely hard and difficult to carry out reforms and the internal Ukrainian situation is from an economic and social point of view still increasingly difficult and worrying. We agreed already in December with Ukraine, during our first Association Council meeting, a list of priorities that are now trying to become concrete steps. On the government side, we see the full political will to pursue reforms. We also see and understand very well the difficulties of implementing, passing reforms in times of conflict.  I am talking about constitutional reforms, decentralisation, reform of the judiciary, electoral reforms, just to mention the political ones. But then we also have economic reforms, not only macroeconomic in their nature, but also reforms that need to change fundamentally the system in which the economy in Ukraine is working, starting first of all with tackling corruption.  This is all very much linked to the implementation of the Association Agreement, parts of which have already been provisionally applied since 1 November, as you know very well since you ratified this at the same time as the Parliament in Kiev back in September.  At this level, the European Union is giving support not only politically and technically, but also economically. You know that the Commission has just proposed an additional package, a third package, of EUR 1.8 billion, and I trust that this measure will find your support here in Parliament. We are also working through the Support Group for Ukraine to implement the measures that are foreseen by our Association Agreement. We deployed an advisory mission to assist in the implementation of the civilian security sector reform and a third sector on which our work and our assistance is concentrating is obviously facilitating the gas negotiations between Russia and Ukraine to ensure security of supply. I will stop here and listen very carefully, as I did last time, to your debate – our debate – and take stock of that. Let me say that probably the big opportunity we have today, from this European Parliament, is to launch a message and the message from my side would be to the parties, firstly, obviously, to Russia, but to all those that will meet tomorrow night in Minsk: that they should take this opportunity and finally come to agree on the implementation measures of the Minsk Agreement.  This is what it is all about and this is the only way in which we can start finding the way out of the crisis. I think that, here, today, we have the opportunity to send the message that, yesterday, the Ministers of the 28 Member States sent, united, very clearly: that this is a chance that must not be missed.

name: Jacek SARYUSZ-WOLSKI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, if tomorrow’s Minsk II last-chance talks fail to bring credible peace in the face of the naked war by Russia against Ukraine and the mountains of lies and broken promises, it will at last be time to move away from the logic of persuasion to the logic of deterrence. The EU has shown angelic patience and indulgence – and the word ‘angelic’ comes from the name Angela – but we have reached our limits. Quantitative and qualitative change in our action is needed because so far we have been doing too little, too late. Enhancing Ukrainian defence capabilities would create incentives for Russia to back down. On the contrary, the Russian military advantage over Ukraine openly invites Russia to continue the invasion, as we are witnessing. Ukraine has the right to defend itself. We have the responsibility to protect the victim against the aggressor in the name of our values. If we surrender our values, we ourselves will be in danger. The crisis in Ukraine is indeed about our own future and our own security. We may wish for there to be a diplomatic solution, but a military solution by Russia is taking place before our eyes. In order to achieve a political solution, leverage is needed to bring the aggressor to true – not Potemkin-village type – negotiations and to bring binding and executable results. The time has come to apply reverse logic, increase leverage through pressure, increase economic sanctions against Russia and close the gap in Russia’s military advantage – the gap between invader and victim – in order to achieve a peaceful solution in the end. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: blue-card question. – I would like to know whether you are aware of the latest threats coming from Russia and addressed to my country, Romania, that in the event that we continue to implement NATO decisions related to the infrastructure in Romania, the armament station now in Crimea could annihilate the Romanian naval forces. Are you aware of this, or not?

name: Jacek SARYUSZ-WOLSKI
text: blue-card answer. – Not yet aware, thank you, but not surprised.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Madam Vice-President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work and for the work she has What can this Parliament do today to resolve the conflict in Ukraine? Perhaps it really is only three clear messages. Firstly, tomorrow's meeting in Minsk to resolve the Ukraine crisis is probably, or perhaps, the last chance to resolve the conflict diplomatically. It must therefore be clear to all parties to the conflict that failure of the talks would inevitably lead to a further escalation of the conflict and thus to even more deaths, injuries and refugees. We expect the Russian leadership to make a serious effort and negotiate seriously for a political solution to the conflict and to make positive use of its influence over the separatists. Secondly, Ukraine can rely on our political and economic support. There will be no military solution to the conflict. The supply of weapons would not help to defuse the conflict, but would have the opposite effect. That is why we reject arms deliveries to Ukraine. Thirdly, our aim is and remains the integration of Russia into pan-European political, economic and security structures. We have an interest in a Russia that participates in solutions to international conflicts. We are in favour of talks between the EU and the Eurasian Economic Area that has just been set up. But without substantial progress, there can be no such talks.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, yesterday I listened to the Chair of the International Affairs Committee of the Russian Duma, Alexei Pushkov, explaining the need for a rapid peace solution for Ukraine. Unfortunately, his government is doing everything possible to prevent peace. Instead it is choosing to continue with its contemptible approach of inventing a false narrative with which to justify military aggression against Ukraine. Russia is providing heavy military equipment, financial assistance and combat troops to the so-called separatists, sparking a conflict in which over 5 000 people have now lost their lives – 263 civilians alone in the last six days and 1.5 million people displaced.  As we approach tomorrow’s Minsk deadline for a renewed attempt at a ceasefire, rebel troops are surrounding the important railway hub of Debaltseve and I have just heard of further criminal attacks today on civilian areas by the rebels in Kramatorsk in which at least seven civilians were killed. So sadly, even if a ceasefire can be agreed tomorrow – and I hope that I am wrong in what I am about to say – it is unlikely in my view to end the conflict. As recently noted by the British Foreign Secretary, Putin is behaving like a 1930s tyrant and such agreements are merely part of a dissembling approach to gradually legitimise territorial gains before embarking on another round of attacks. Ukraine is not an isolated area of foreign policy for Putin, but part of his wider dream to reconstitute a crony capitalist, authoritarian greater Russia and to challenge the post-Cold War settlement and legal order. Challenging NATO and the Western alliance is therefore part of his mission. Maintaining unity on EU sanctions against Russia is of importance and excluding Russia from the SWIFT system could be the next step.  Militarily, we must not allow Russian intimidation to prevent so-minded EU states from supplying the Ukrainian armed forces the means to defend themselves and to deter Russia’s ability to steal more territory from Ukraine. Sadly, in my view, the EU strategic partnership with Putin’s Russia, for now, is over.

name: Johannes Cornelis van BAALEN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. –  Mr President, we can speak out loud; we can speak harsh words; but it is now time to say ‘yes’ to Mrs Merkel and President Hollande. I think this is indeed the moment where Russia can prove if it is a peaceful nation or not. It is not necessary to draw the whole picture; the picture is quite clear. There was already a Minsk, and we need to have a Minsk II to implement Minsk I. But let us do it!  I will be very brief. If Putin does not want to take the olive branch he will be severely punished. That is the only way. Because any other way, we accept that Ukraine should be crippled. And Ukraine should not be crippled. What kind of sanctions? What kind of actions? For me and my group nothing is excluded, but we will debate it after Minsk II.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: , on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Madam Vice-President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work and for the work she has Yes! There is and must be no military solution in Ukraine, because the social contradictions of the country need a different policy to resolve them. The country does not need weapons, but social alternatives that break once and for all with the omnipotence of oligarchs and galloping corruption. Without this, neither social peace nor cooperative relations with all neighbours seem possible. The EU has responsibility for what has happened and is happening in Ukraine, as is the Russian Federation. It is therefore to be welcomed that tomorrow we will be back at the table in Minsk in order to work together to find a comprehensive solution to the conflict. It is clear to contradict those who self-servingly declare that the Minsk format and its results have failed. Yes! The agreement has not yet been implemented, but has been violated, but its central points must not be reduced, not even in Minsk 2: securing territorial integrity, starting a negotiated ceasefire and the military unbundling of the fighters, the binding search for a new, also institutional, balance between the east and the west of the country.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. It is quite clear to me that this move by Mrs Merkel and President Hollande was an important attempt to turn the tide. It is important that the two in Kiev consulted President Poroshenko, consulted with him before, for the first time in a long time, they got the main person responsible for this whole war in the East, namely President Putin, at the table. The whole of the European Union is looking at what is happening. I believe that two European Heads of State have not had and have not had so much support from citizens throughout the European Union for a long time, because it is about peace. That is what the European Union stands for. That is what Europeans would like to preserve in the EU. They want this peace to which we have become accustomed. However, you must also understand that, at the same time, the mood in Ukraine is very different. More and more people want to be able to return to a life without war. I am always fascinated by the fact that this people in Ukraine have not completely run out of air. They have thought so many times that there is now a turning point for the better, but every time a turn came for the worse. They, too, are now looking at what is happening in Minsk, but are far from as optimistic as we are, but rather are afraid that once again – as always in Minsk – there will be such a salami tactic, which will ultimately lead to a worsening of the situation in eastern Ukraine. I don't know. I hope, I have to say, a miracle. But I don't believe in a miracle, even if Angela is in the game. I very much agree with my colleague Mr van Baalen that if this attempt fails, we will have to re-talk about what we can do. There has been far too much hesitation and indecision in the European Union. The sanctions – I have to think of Mr Hahn, who represents Austria – Austria, others have repeatedly doubted that we, as soft power, have an alternative to military means. But we will have to discuss it again if Minsk fails. We will also have to discuss what this actually means, that we always say that Ukraine has a right to defend itself. If the idea of the Euromajdan falls, if the idea of freedom, the rule of law and justice – that is what it was all about – falls, then a piece of Europe actually falls. This unity must not only be there in this situation, but the unity towards Russia, which we will need for a long time to come. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: "blue card" question. I wanted to ask a question to those who spoke a moment ago. My question is this: if we have here our High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security, who represents the whole of Europe, why did Merkel and Hollande have to go and represent the whole of Europe? A moment ago our representative asked us that we should give a lot of money to Ukraine because it needs it and represents the whole of Europe. But then does Europe represent Merkel and Hollande or does Mogherini represent her? Because if Mogherini does not represent her, there is no point in her being a representative. I ask you what you think of what I'm saying.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I believe that this is another attempt to put an Italian discussion on a really big problem. And I do not know what the problem will be for citizens in Italy if Angela Merkel and Francois Hollande manage to negotiate a ceasefire at the same table in Minsk, with the Russians and the Ukrainians. I believe that you, I, that Mrs Mogherini can actually only applaud that. So: Give yourself your pettiness in this dispute!

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. –  Mr President, the word that best describes today’s debate is ‘enough’. Enough pretending that we do not understand what is really happening in Ukraine. Enough pretending that we do not understand who, and with whose arms, is killing thousands of Ukrainians, even today. Enough pretending that we do not understand that this war is Putin’s war against us all. Dear colleagues, today we must together say to our governments and our people: enough of lies, enough of hesitation, enough of weakness. Let us act!

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: The latest developments in Ukraine demonstrate in a way that can no longer be called into question the wrong policy implemented by the West in this regard. The country is gradually being destroyed.
