The civil war continues, thousands of innocent people lose their lives, while government forces in the battles against the separatists suffer heavy losses, lose territory, suffer defeats and have lost more than half their air power. Many soldiers also defect to the separatists. Instead of this situation bringing the West together and forcing countries to make an effort to defuse the situation, they are preparing to take new measures against Russia and, in cooperation with the US, want to give government forces weapons systems to continue fighting. This increases tension in the region and puts world peace at risk. We must realise that Ukraine is a vital area for Russia's defence, which will not, no matter how many measures are taken against it, accept its integration into the West. We must therefore find a way of working with Russia in order to defuse the situation and provide a political solution, not a military solution to the Ukraine crisis.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Mr President, last night we received Alexei Pushkov, chairman of the Committee on International Affairs of the Russian Duma, in the Committee on Foreign Affairs. He told us that Russia wants peace, and all the members agreed with him. We want peace too. Since last night's meeting, 2,000 Russian military personnel have begun maneuvers on the border with Ukraine. In Crimea, another 600 military personnel began similar exercises for a month. The Russian regime thus shows its military side. And as if to make things even clearer, Vladimir Putin has just given the Egyptian president a Kalashnikov as a gift. I repeat, as a gift: a Kalashnikov. Is peace still possible when Kalashnikovs become official gifts? Nothing more difficult, but not impossible. The EPP Group supports the position defended in recent days by the German Chancellor and the French President, because we must offer peace. And that requires negotiations and an immediate halt to Russian operations on Ukrainian territory. We need intelligence, not Kalashnikovs, for that.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: Mr President, I would say to the High Representative that everyone in this House agrees that tomorrow’s meeting is indeed the last chance for peace. The Minsk Agreement failed, but who is responsible for this failure? Is it Europe, as Putin claimed recently in an Egyptian newspaper? Is it Ukraine, which is paying up to EUR 7 million per day for a war imposed by Russia – a Ukraine which has lost its territory under Russian aggression? No, behind the escalation is Russia, and its support by all means for the separatists. I can only welcome the efforts of the High Representative and of Ms Merkel and Mr Hollande, and I hope they will remain united and in coordination with the United States. Faced with Russia and Putin who speak peace and practise war, we welcome the decision taken by NATO to deploy rapid reaction forces in Central and Eastern European countries. This is the only concrete measure we have taken recently to protect ourselves against Russian neo-imperialism.

name: Andrzej DUDA
text: Dear High Representative, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. I have very simple questions for you, looking also at the political issues in Europe – you would like to ask about the results of yesterday's Council meeting and what the negotiating mandate for tomorrow's meeting in Minsk looks like. I understand that you, as the Representative of the Union for International Affairs, will be at this meeting, because I would like the whole of the European Union to be represented there. If so, I would ask for clarification as to whether Chancellor Merkel and President Hollande have such a mandate from the whole of a united Europe to these negotiations and what is its concrete shape? This is the first thing.  I would like us to remember that Ukraine is not only the Donbass that is fighting all the time today, where hundreds, thousands of innocent civilians are killed by rockets and shot from Kalashnikovs, but also Crimea, which has been illegally seized by Russia. The question is, will the negotiations on Crimea also concern?  I would like to draw attention to one more thing. Ladies and again, Europe unfortunately shows all the time its powerlessness towards Vladimir Putin, who simply laughs and implements his imperial policy in Ukraine. The Russian tank cannot be stopped by europe pouring sand under its tracks, or by limiting its fuel supply so that it can drive more slowly. Fuel supplies should simply be cut off. This requires decisive action and strong sanctions, not a discussion that we will lose out on our economic interests and therefore let what it wants to happen in Ukraine, let Russia do what it wants. Finally, the latter makes – Putin disregards all agreements so far. He reads all agreements, agreements and international law in such a way that he only searches for what is convenient for him, pretending that there are no such provisions that oblige him to do anything. Finally, I call for firmness and call for solidarity between the European Union represented by our EU institutions.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: Mr President, to be able to stop the ongoing aggression of the Russian Federation against Ukraine we need to be united and strong. However, the reality might be different as, in recent efforts, the European Union was reduced to only two Member States. In order to sustain the EU’s Common Foreign and Security Policy the High Representative must be included. We need, and we will need, not just to achieve but to implement a peaceful settlement with the common voice of the 28.  Today is the 60th day on which Nadia Savchenko, a Ukrainian pilot, has been on hunger strike. To protest against the unlawful and inhuman action of the Russian authorities a number of Members of the European Parliament have joined her and are going on hunger strike for a day or two. Today Beatriz Becerra is on hunger strike. I call on other colleagues, as well as the High Representative, to join us in this symbolic action, demanding the immediate release of Nadia Savchenko.

name: Miloslav RANSDORF
text: Mr President, there are five types of crisis in Ukraine. First, a financial crisis. The danger of a technical default by the national bank has not been eliminated. The second crisis is an economic crisis because Ukraine’s GDP is only a third of what it was compared with 1992, and if we take into account the situation in a neighbouring state, Belarus, there it is 260%. A social crisis: on 28 January there was a protest meeting in Kiev and the miners cried ‘give us back Yanukovych, at least under Yanukovych we had the salaries’.  There is also an inequality crisis, because in Ukraine the 100 richest Ukrainians have a 38% share of the nation’s property. There is also a humanitarian crisis because the gangster regime in Kiev is organising a human organs business.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: However, Mr President, despite some gravel votes on that far left and the extreme right, it has to be said that the European Parliament strongly supports a unified european union line that will maintain sanctions as long as the war continues. And we have had suggestions that we can extend the sanctions to, for example, the Swift system if the situation escalates further, despite tomorrow's negotiations in Minsk. But, High Representative, I would like to draw your attention to the importance of strengthening the OSCE's special issue in Ukraine, because we know that it is this four hundred kilometres of open border from Russia to Ukraine that weapons are coming. What more can we do to give the OSCE enough resources, equipment and staff to do its job? And how do we get Russia to agree to control this border on the Ukrainian side as well?

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the winds of war blowing towards Europe should encourage us to remain united and not to divide us, they should curb the somewhat pavlovian reactions of our eastern European colleagues who, as soon as they hear about Russia, think that it is still the Cold War. The Cold War is over. Today, as the representative of the Duma rightly said yesterday, Europe should be concerned about ISIS, that is a threat! But the International Monetary Fund and the European Union are preparing to give billions of dollars to Ukraine. Well, but not even a euro to poor Greece that is on its knees, which your austerity policy has brought to its knees. So let's see what causes this crisis. Behind it is a stone coerced, which is perhaps NATO, and Russia had notified all western chancelleries that NATO's proximity to its borders would provoke reactions. This has not been taken into account. Strong geopolitics should guide Europe's choices, and it is incredible that the High Representative should leave this role to two nations that do not represent us all. The conclusions in Minsk will not solve the problem because, even if there is self-determination in Donbass, this will not be the solution to the problem. The problem is geopolitical and must be tackled clearly and not with the usual hypocrisy and weakness represented by the phantasmatical role of the European High Representative. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – You have said some terrible things here, Mr President, but you are another person from the same side of the Chamber who, among other things, says with great pretensions that the two heads of large European countries, not the representative of the European Commission, are going to negotiate. What is the effect? We have too weak European institutions because you on the right are notoriously weakening them. Do you not think that it would be in our common interest to strengthen the European institutions – the Commission and the European Parliament – so that we can be represented together?

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: answer to a "blue card" question. Thank you very much for pointing out the validity of my comment and allow me to reply that it is simply incredible that this European Union does not have a European foreign policy. This situation certifies the impotence and non-existence of European foreign policy. If we were not already Eurosceptics, we would have become eurosceptic today.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr. President! Mr Borghezio and Mr Ransdorf, far-right and radical left, always remain the same. We must see that the European Union and its Member States have given EUR 250 billion to Greece. I would ask you to take note of that. The European Union is united in a tremendous effort in the sanctions against the aggressor. Russia is an aggressor, a party to the conflict and has broken international law. We must take note of this clearly. It is important that Russia, as a party to the conflict, takes responsibility. We must see that sanctions are our instrument – not weapons, but sanctions, because we do not want war – to tell the aggressor that the costs are high, and that is where we can do so in case of need. We have to see that the government in Kiev – the thieves were the Yanukovych people, Mr Ransdorf – that the politicians in Ukraine, the government elected by the people for a pro-European course, are having difficulty in enforcing their reform process, because a war is being waged in their country by a foreign power and costing money. That is why you should not reverse things. The ability to compromise, which is being demanded by the Ukrainian Government in these hours in order to make a ceasefire possible, is a tremendous achievement. That is why it was consulted before Hollande and Merkel went to Moscow. Poroshenko will be at the negotiating table when the negotiations take place tomorrow. This is one way – and I would also like to say explicitly on behalf of the European People's Party that the European People's Party supports the Minsk mission and supports the way – to bring about a ceasefire, perhaps the last attempt to prevent the spread of war in order to bring about a peaceful solution in Europe while guaranteeing international law. That's the question. It is important, however, that the Minsk agreement, unlike the September agreement, includes the question of implementation, so that this does not become a new opportunity for Putin to gain time and thus further expand his territory of aggression. That is the policy. I am truly with my heart, with my thoughts and with my prayers that the mission in Minsk will succeed in order to achieve lasting peace in Europe. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Mr Brok, let us say that the peace plan fails, at which point you know we will see the separatists advancing within Ukrainian territory, supported by the so-called ‘green soldiers’ – Russian ‘green soldiers’ – and by new modern armaments. Should the international community, the European Union and the United States then provide the necessary military means to Ukraine to defend its territorial integrity and independence?

name: Elmar BROK
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. We now have a mission in Minsk that is successful. And I'm not going to answer hypothetical questions. It is now a question of securing peace. And there is already the possibility that European governments can supply arms, as the Council has decided. Only who ever did that is your government. There is a reason for this. We should try to secure peace and not talk now about what further consequences it will have if Minsk fails. We want to prevent this failure. That is the task of this hour and the next day. That is what we have to fight for. That seems to me to be the decisive approach. When I hear this cry from Mr Duda and others who do not want to give the European Union any institutional rights and are now claiming the rights of the European institutions, it is a measure of mendacity in an hour of Europe's need, when we are facing a war, that i am sick of listening to such arguments here from the right and the left.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Mr. President, I support the view that we in Europe must defend the principle of territorial integrity as a precondition for maintaining order, peace and security between countries. But how to defend this principle when it is directly threatened by war aggression, appetite for other people's territory.  On the one hand, the US administration argues that a decision to provide military assistance to Ukraine could prevent further Russian incursions into Ukrainian territory, and on the other hand a good deal of European policy strongly rejects arming Ukraine as a means to end the conflict. In my opinion, the common goal of the US and the European Union should be to further raise the cost of Russia's war against Ukraine, with a joint appearance being held in the future imposition of new or withdrawing current sanctions.  It should be recalled that Ukraine presided over the OSCE only a year ago, and is now engulfed in a conflict with a permanent member of the Security Council, with possible far-reaching consequences for the whole world. This only proves that the global security system of 1944 is ripe for full reform or at least for the likes of 1975.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today a court in Moscow has extended the arrest of Nadja Savchenko, a colleague of ours, a member of the Verchovna Rada, a member of the Council of Europe. Moscow could have made a nice gesture, a fine gesture of goodwill, on the eve of the ultimate long-awaited negotiations in Minsk by undoing her illegal detention, against international conventions, her abduction and her detention and letting her go home. Unfortunately, it has not happened and we can hope that at the negotiating table in Minsk there will be a little more understanding and a little more accommodating. Hope makes life. It is our moral duty to hope, but we have little reason to be optimistic, because in the meantime Russian-minded militias are going all out for a final military offensive. And today, the airport and residential districts of Kramatorsk were bombarded with rocket fire. Yesterday, Aleksey Pushkov of the Duma told the AFET Commission that Russia actually has a problem with those international rules that have been put in place so far and that it wants to rewrite those rules. At the same time, he said war is not a solution. That's an open door, of course. Diplomacy has to take over the weapons. And the proposals are on the table. President Poroshenko has previously formulated a proposal for far-reaching autonomy for Donbass, but only a ceasefire can succeed: disarmament, demilitarisation and departure of foreign Russian troops from Ukrainian territory.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: The cold and bloody war in Ukraine, with civilian casualties in Mariopol, but also in Donetsk, let us not forget this, rarely offers us the opportunity to say the words of consensus and praise for the political and diplomatic activity that should bring about the end of war and bloodshed. I will therefore use my minute today to pay tribute to German Chancellor Angela Merkel and Tom Hollande and their diplomacy. All of us, who care about peace more than heroic tightening and geostratetic advantages, would like us to lead the Minsk conference to a solution. The situation in Ukraine has slipped away from the leash and no one, not even the European Union and its Parliament, is without fault. Today, a sincere desire for peace and a political solution is certainly more important and closer to European interests than thinking about sending new weapons to an area where there is already too much of it today. (The speaker agreed to accept the question raised by raising the blue card (Rule 162(8)).

name: Marek JUREK
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Buddy! Do you not think that this escalation of hostilities in Ukraine in recent days is precisely the result of leaks that President Hollande and Mrs Merkel are proposing to freeze the conflict at the borders of conquest, that such a message is really an incentive for the aggressor to continue his aggression and a warning to the attacked that he will lose his national territory irretrievably?

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: blue-card answer. – I am pretty convinced that the German and French diplomacy, with Mrs Merkel and Mr Hollande, knows the significance of the negotiations and I have no reason to doubt it. They will protect the interests of Europe.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Mr. President! Mr Pushkov made it very clear yesterday at the meeting of the Foreign Affairs Committee that the current Russian leadership has no intention of complying with international law. Anyone who is confronted with such an aggressor must keep a clear strategic view. There is no military solution, say, at least none in favour of Ukraine. Others say there could be one – for Putin. Excuse me, that is precisely the problem. Only Moscow, not Ukraine, can win militarily. If we want Ukraine to succeed in this fight, we must focus on diplomacy – not just diplomacy, but also reforms in the country, energy independence, and the fight against corruption. We must strengthen and regroup the civilian forces and support this in solidarity through Europe. Only in this way do we have a chance that the aggressor will not win.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have had to change my speech and therefore, as it will be partly read, it is a few changes, because to hear you I am wondering.  Do you want the third world war by your speeches going to war, by a partisan, sectarian, double standard, propaganda, or do you want to face things, the truth, reality on both sides, avoiding accentuating conflicts? The people who elected you will vomit you if you reach this third world war!  What needs to be done, it must also be said, is to support the initiative of France and Germany. We must hope that the negotiations will lead to a halt to the fighting. We must take advantage of these negotiations to lay the foundations for and contribute to real peace and reconciliation in Ukraine, by regaining the sense of reason also in our chamber. Let us be a little serious, as are the heads of state who are responsible, and as are the nuclear powers in particular, because it is too easy when you are a small country to behave like a roquet. We must understand that our institutions must work for peace and reconciliation with Russia, not for hatred and war.  Our Parliament must recover if it is to maintain a minimum of credibility, but also of dignity and responsibility. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – A colleague talked about double standards, but when France was threatened in the 1940s and 1950s, when soviet tanks were said to be in Paris, you demanded western solidarity, unequivocalness. And even a politician who was critical of the United States, de Gaulle, at the time called for western unity and European unity. I have the impression that you are applying double standards – others when France's existence is under threat and others when the existence of our eastern neighbours is at stake. It is here that there is a double morality, not in the arguments of those who demand that European solidarity be realised.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have already had the opportunity to say this: in 1995, when I met Mr Kuchma, the United States had a plan to cut Ukraine in half. They acknowledge that they have spent $5 billion on that. They also acknowledge that sanctions were imposed on European states, which did not want them. Take the example of Mr Gorbachev, winner of the Nobel Peace Prize. Today, he supports Putin. Not in his domestic policy - he does not say it is an example of democracy - but he understands Russia's position. Let us try to understand this position, so as not to be partial and partial.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Mr. President, High Representative Mogherini, Mr. Vimont, I believe that the efforts of Chancellor Merkel and President Hollande are part of what you told us at the last meeting when we spoke here a month ago, of a holistic approach to European foreign policy in resolving the crisis in Ukraine. That is why it seems to me that today we must make it clear that we are really in for a peaceful solution, for the territorial integrity of Ukraine, including in the conflict against international law an annexed Crimea, that we give Ukraine the right to self-defense because it is also allowed by the Charter of the United Nations, and that we want restrictive measures towards Russia to continue. Because it is obvious that only by combining all these measures of our policy can we lead to the dissection of the situation, to respect the Minsk ceasefire, and I hope that tomorrow's meeting in Minsk, combined with the "Normandy format" will give one qualitative step forward. Because what we've seen over the past weeks, what we've seen in Mariupol, what we've seen in Donetsk, what we've seen in Debal'cev, what we saw today at crematorium, is a disaster. A catastrophe for Ukraine, a catastrophe for the Ukrainian people and a disaster for the European Union. In this regard, I also hold Russia to account. Russia is a global actor, a nuclear power. Where does Russia go with this kind of policy? It reminds me a little of that line: where there's a Russian, there's Russia. He can't do that. Other countries' borders, their ambitions, their orientation must be respected.  If Ukraine cannot go down the path chosen by its people, its rule in democratic elections, then this is not good, then all of Russia's neighbors are in trouble. And it is an additional responsibility of all of us, that here and through the mechanisms we have in implementing the Association Agreement, in support of The Supreme It works by Parliament to do European reforms in the years ahead, to bring it closer to the European project, that is our main task.  (The Speaker agreed to answer the question by raising the blue card on the basis of Article 162(8) of the Code of Health. Rules of procedure.)

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: blue-card question. – Sir, you said in your remarks that you wanted to see international law upheld. In that case, in your opinion, should Russia have a judge on the European Court for Human Rights?

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card.  - Mr. President, we saw a debate that took place in the Council of Europe just a few weeks ago. As you know, the Parliamentary Assembly has also adopted a Resolution, an important Resolution on rights, i.e. the denial of them for the Russian delegation, and we will leave the Procedures of the Council of Europe on how judges of the European Court of Human Rights are elected to our neighbouring organisation.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr. President, dear Mr. Plenković, I would like to ask you if what is happening in Ukraine reminds you of what was happening in the Balkans or in Croatia? And secondly, do you still think that a solution can be found in a way, as you once said, inspired by the peaceful reintegration of the Croatian Danube Region? Are you still standing on those words?

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr. President, thank you colleague Jakovcic, I have repeatedly warned over the past few months about the parallels between Ukraine as a victim in relation to Russia and Croatia as victims in relation to Serbia. However, they are not entirely the same circumstances.  There is no comparison between the Milosevic regime in Serbia and global actor Russia today. I think first of all now we have to do everything for a peaceful solution, and use our experience in the peaceful reintegration of the Croatian Danube region for peaceful reintegration and parts of the area of Lugansk and Donetsk, and crimea later into the constitutional-legal order of Ukraine.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: In agreement with President Plenković and High Representative Mogherini, I also believe that a peaceful settlement and a diplomatic settlement are the priority here. Even if I understand the tempers, because after many years of construction in Europe, Vladimir Putin simply kicked the door down on us. Nevertheless, I would like to ask everyone for composure and peace of mind, while at the same time telling The High Representative that I miss the European High Representative in the group photos. It is not a good message for European citizens that only the leaders of major powers are negotiating this conflict. All the more so because you are here a lot in Parliament, and you can represent what has been said here. But what I'd like to tell you about. This aggressor, Vladimir Putin, will enter the European Union next week, budapest, Hungary, as a guest of Viktor Orban – although I do not know if he will bring him a Kalashnikov or not. They will not negotiate ukraine, they will do business on a business as usual basis. I feel that this is not good for European unity, and I would like all the leaders of the Member States to use their influence at next week's European Council to use their influence to push back this particular voice, this unity-breaking voice.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Dogma or, as anyone prefers, the axiom in our discussions about the war in Ukraine was here in Parliament and in the Union in general the claim that there is no military solution to this problem – here Mr Bütikofer has formulated it again today. But it was the enchantment of reality, and the enchantment of reality never leads to effective politics. It is no wonder, then, that European policy is powerless and has not keeping up with developments. In fact, the conflict in Ukraine is being resolved militarily before our eyes. Whoever does not see it is under delusion. One side of the conflict – Russia – has relied on military means from the outset and has not hesitated to hand over arms to the separatists. Russia has never accepted our axiom and therefore immediately had an advantage in political disputes and diplomatic games.  Recent proposals to freeze the conflict would mean that this strategy has been successful and that the force has prevailed. They would mean that by using military means Russia could divide Ukraine, de facto mean the surrender of Ukraine, as well as the defeat of the West. And there are no guarantees that this will stop further Russian aggression and expansion, and perhaps even encourage it, and then colleague Schaffhauser will share Poland with Russia, not Ukraine. In this situation, the demand to arm Ukraine is not an expression of militarism, aggressiveness or rejection of the need to seek an agreement, but a path to peace. Only if we convince Russia that it cannot win this conflict militarily will it agree to a non-military solution to the conflict and give negotiations and peace a chance.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: Mr President, I will not talk about the peace negotiations as there has been a lot of talk about that already, so I am returning to the economic sanctions. Russia is very resistant to economic sanctions if resistance serves a higher political purpose. Russia will use every trick in its pocket to divide Europe to reach its goals. Creating divisions in Europe is what Russia has always done, and this can already be seen today if we look at the talks in Greece about getting funding from Russia. Ukraine needs a unified Europe. As it is the role of the High Representative to ensure this unity of Europe, and I would be grateful if she could reassure me on this front. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: blue-card question. – Thank you, Ms Kallas, for accepting a blue card. Would you agree with me that, for economic sanctions to have an impact on a country like Russia, with big resources, we would need a much longer time? Many people say that up to four or five months of sanctions are not going to work. Would you agree with me that, for the sanctions to bite, we simply need much more time and we have to be prepared for two or three years? What is your opinion on that?

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: blue-card answer. – I do agree that we have to wait more. We have to be ready for a longer period, because if we are impatient and say that the sanctions are not working after three months, then we have to think decisions through and properly, because we should be prepared for a longer time.

name: Peter ERIKSSON
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul This may well be a defining moment in the history of Europe. I think we're all seeing how time is running out. Then it is the wrong time to whine about who is going to negotiate and who will represent Europe, but this is the right time to stand stubbornly and patiently for peace and for the negotiation that is now actually being tried and to push Russia back to the negotiating table.  I also think that we should stand up for Ukraine in a concrete and clear way. The OSCE has not been able to do the job of guarding the border. I also think it is a very important question now for the Commissioner, regardless of what happens in Minsk tomorrow: what will the Commission do to ensure that we maintain the border between Russia and Ukraine? It cannot be just Russia that should stand up for it and be in control of it.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, I am speaking essentially to you because you seem to me to be filled with a spirit of peace, unlike a number of my parliamentary colleagues here. The world is moving dangerously towards a full-scale war. In eastern Ukraine, there are not 5,000 civilian deaths, but probably 50,000, according to German intelligence services quoted by the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung. Civilians in eastern Ukraine are trying to protect themselves from their own country's army, which massacres them, bombs them, destroys their homes, schools and hospitals with missiles. Meanwhile, in the hushed comfort of this Parliament, there is a party of war. This party of war, whose bellicose and caricatures we have supported for months, is the party of irresponsibility, that of Mrs Harms, mr Preda, Mr Saryusz-Wolski, Mr van Baalen. I say this before you, before the parliamentary representation, you will bear a heavy responsibility, both in the death of East Ukrainian civilians, but also if a war, if a major conflict breaks out. A heavy responsibility in history...

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: Honourable colleagues, honourable Mrs Mogherini, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Mogherini, for his excellent work. In 1992, when Milosevic attacked Serbia's neighbours, we Europeans hesitated to provide them with military assistance because we feared an escalation of the conflict. But because Milosevic was not stopped in time, this conflict turned into a bloody war that claimed more than a hundred thousand lives.  Europe and NATO are now hesitant to help strengthen Ukraine's defence capabilities. Again, our indecision actually contributes to aggression, as Putin's armed terrorists and Russian special forces soldiers continue to conquer Ukrainian land. Without such aggression, Ukraine will not be able to establish and strengthen democratic institutions, implement reforms and attract the investments that Ukraine so desperately needs for the development of Ukraine.  Ukraine needs our help now, not when it has lost even more territory and people. Thank you, Mr President.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the High Representative for taking a bold initiative and for keeping a strong institutional two-way bridge with this House. The situation in eastern Ukraine is steadily deteriorating. This means more violence, more human suffering and the landscape changing every single day – and for the worse. Most importantly, this means peace in Europe is drifting even further away. I feel extremely concerned about the rapid escalation of the conflict and about the attitude and actions of separatists and of Russia. But I also share the approach we have decided to take, aware of what is at stake in Ukraine today.  Only a strategy which creates a virtuous circle, based on necessity and proportionality between the undertakings of the EU and the situation on the ground, can lead to a sustainable solution to the conflict. Important diplomatic efforts are being undertaken. Peace always deserves the first chance. I thank the High Representative for having done all that is politically and humanly possible in the past few days to reach an agreement. Without forgetting one crucial precondition we managed to attain: our unity.

name: Marek JUREK
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking We all want peace, but that is why we should remember that the wars in the Donniecki Basin in eastern Ukraine may not have been there at all if we had reacted decisively, but politically. After the aggression in Crimea, the aggressor would hesitate to take further steps. The declarations at the moment that we will not hand over arms to Ukraine, or even more so the declarations that we will not accept Ukraine into the North Atlantic alliance made by Mrs Merkel and her colleagues, are completely irresponsible. Only the awareness that the continuation of aggression will be met with our decisive and political response can stop the aggressor. If we are unable to deliver such a message in these talks, unfortunately, let us be sure that Russian aggression will continue.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: Mr President, for several years now, some Western media have been trying to develop crude propaganda against Russia, based in particular on false rumours about the health of its president. Last October, the New York Post once again claimed that Vladimir Putin was suffering from terminal cancer. In recent days, fans of false information in the media have exhumed a report several years old, laid down by an obscure Pentagon official: "The Russian president would finally have the syndrome I wonder, for my part, about the mental health and ethics of our disinformation professionals who, war after war, continue to echo the worst American propaganda. Are these affabulators hoping to give a semblance of credibility to the statements of the former NATO Secretary General, Mr Rasmussen, who has just said that Mr Putin is preparing to attack a Baltic state?  While some indulge in this collective hysteria, blood continues to flow in Ukraine. Thus we learned on Sunday, in the German press, that this fratricidal war has already claimed more than 50,000 lives, ten times the figure officially put forward by Kiev. As for the refugees, they continue to flock massively to the alleged aggressor. Will you say that they have gone mad, too?

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the European High Representative, I would like to thank you for your support. Unfortunately, since the Ukraine decision a few weeks ago, the situation has not improved, but has deteriorated considerably in terms of the number of civilian casualties and the economic situation in the country. It is therefore important that the subject is back on the agenda. I am hopeful that Chancellor Angela Merkel and President François Hollande will make serious efforts to find a diplomatic solution to the Ukraine-Russia conflict and that the European Union supports a negotiated political solution and calls for peace as soon as possible. However, there is serious concern that the Russian leadership still does not recognise that they support the separatists with money and weapons, does not take political responsibility for the escalation of the situation. As a result, hundreds of people are dying and becoming earthly, many are dying senselessly. Therefore, many people agree that there is no military solution to the conflict and that it is equally harmful to the European Union, ukraine, Russia, but ukrainian citizens in particular feel the seriousness of the situation. They feel insecurity in their daily lives, they live in fear, poverty, and Russian propaganda only exacerbates this situation with scaremongering. It is therefore important that there is an immediate ceasefire. Withdraw heavy weapons from the region, ensure the safety of civilians and take into account the broad safeguarding of the rights of all nationality in the country, subject to international guarantees. That would be the main task.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: Mr President, tomorrow night’s summit provides a moment of great danger, but perhaps a unique moment of hope too that the repeated frustrations can be overcome and peace can succeed. Those of us in this Chamber must avoid the temptation simply to ramp up the anti-Russia rhetoric. If two EU leaders are prepared to fly to Moscow to avert what one of them called the prospect of total war in Europe, we have no less a duty to contribute to all, and any, hopes of a political solution. But if the talks fail tomorrow, we must not fail too. Talk of unwillingness to roll forward European sanctions can only undermine the strength of European unity to be able to create a change of attitude in Moscow. Indeed, the further list of names due to be published on Monday should appear because the progress we need to see can only be actual progress on the ground. Last night, Mr Pushkov from the Duma told our Parliament’s committee that Russia wanted a Kosovo solution for Ukraine – this from a country that opposed it for Kosovo itself – and he said Russia had no responsibility for insurgents who have crossed from its borders when European countries have precisely taken responsibility for foreign fighters in a different sphere who have crossed from ours. Russia has to be willing to change course for peace. We have to show them we remain open for them to do so.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: Commissioner, we all have a responsibility, the European Union and its countries are responsible, the European Parliament is responsible, you are responsible. When Russia annexed Abkhazia, Europe remained silent. When the Russian army killed 80,000 civilians in Chechnya, Europe remained silent. When the Russian army occupied South Ossetia in 2008, Europe raised a warning finger. When Russia occupied Crimea, Europe could only protest. If it were not for Europe's indifference, there would be no war in eastern Ukraine. Let us break the long chain of European silence, otherwise the Kremlin's aggression will continue and we will be responsible for it. Let us support Ukraine's fight by all means, political, economic and military, including the supply of weapons. Time is short and water rises. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: blue card question. – Mr. Ettina, I would like to support precisely this effort to do all that we have to do. I believe in democracy and I believe in diplomacy as well. And part of the diplomacy is also in supporting Mrs Savchenko's freedom, because she is a parliamentarian, she is a member of the Council of Europe, and I believe it is our responsibility to strengthen diplomacy, asserting what the institutions mean. Do you think we should include it in Minsk, Mr. Ettina?

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Yes, of course diplomatic solutions are the most important. Let's wait till tomorrow and tomorrow. If they fail now, there is no choice but to support Ukraine vigorously and clearly.

name: Marju LAURISTIN
text: Mr President, coming from a country on the border with Russia, I would say that all such countries really understand that what is at stake is not only Ukraine; it is really the future of the whole of Europe; it is security and peace in the whole of Europe. Putin is obviously testing the strength and unity of all of us and we have to show that we have that strength and unity. We all hope that tomorrow in Minsk there will be success. But we should also have a plan B, because we cannot be sure that success will be achieved.  And what is our plan B? What are our red lines? I suppose today is maybe not the time to voice this, but we have to think about it and we have to be ready to discuss it immediately after seeing what happens in Minsk. Because for sure Ukraine needs more humanitarian aid, and for sure Ukraine will need all our support for reforms. But also, Russia will not stop unless it knows that Europe is ready to impose sanctions which are not limited to blacklisting some names but also include an oil embargo, if needed, and other forms of economic boycott and, if needed, also to help Ukraine with ammunition.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: Mr. President! Europe's weakness is Putin's strength. Several people have said this, and that is the reality. Because we are so weak, Putin can do what he does. Everyone hopes that tomorrow in Minsk, perhaps, a result will come out. Diplomacy is our weapon, that is what we are using. But I also ask: what happens if Minsk is just another act in a big game and the aggression continues? What do we do then? Are we doing nothing? I don't think that's possible. It is unacceptable that Ukraine's sovereignty is being undermined, that the attempt to build a modern democratic country is being made impossible. This can never be accepted. Ergo we must help Ukraine at all levels, at all levels! These are political levels, these are economic levels. But we must also go further when it is necessary. I believe that, although there are sanctions, we must nevertheless remain in dialogue with Russia. 40 years of the CSCE process, the Helsinki process – a new mark-up for the peace order in Europe is needed.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Mr President, Madam Vice-President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her We are obviously at a crossroads. Either Russia seizes the opportunity tomorrow, or the war continues to spread. However, anyone who watched Angela Merkel's press conference with Barack Obama yesterday must say that Mrs Merkel seems to have succeeded in persuading the American President or convincing them that arms deliveries to Ukraine would not really help to end this conflict. Russia will not be impressed simply because the resistance of the Ukrainian military may be increasing. No, Russia must be made clear that it can only win with a peaceful solution. Otherwise, it will remain isolated. Above all, we must now support those who want to make a breakthrough in diplomacy. We must also remind Ukraine that it is doing its homework, fighting corruption, reforming the judiciary, redrafting the constitution and giving the regions more autonomy. Our great hope is that diplomacy will win tomorrow in Minsk. Otherwise, Europe will lose, and with it all of us! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Mr President, this is not a question, I wanted to underline the positive point of view of my college, and I hope that its analysis will prevail on the socialist side. This is at least an objective and positive analysis.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: It's not a question as such, so your answer is in tune with the question. We are now getting to the catch the eye procedure and, although we have exceeded the allotted time, we have 16 applicants. Because we can't give everyone the floor, we decided to give the floor to one for each political group. So I'm going to ask Mrs. Záborská to speak for a minute. (Interventions on request)

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: I see the war in Ukraine as a tragedy. I regret that on both sides there are Christians with a gun in their hand. History repeats itself. In 1939, a special group of Abwehr and SS officers dressed in Polish uniforms attacked a transmitter in Gliwice. So she gave Hitler an excuse to invade Poland. Today, unmarked Russian soldiers pass through the Ukrainian-Russian border, attacking the Ukrainian army and civilians alongside The New Russian separatists. The situation is very difficult, but peace must be negotiated and all possibilities used to do so. If Russia does not change its policy, both political and economic pressures can be intensified. However, Europe must speak with one voice in this situation. Some Member States are deliberately questioning Russia's decisive role in this armed conflict. This should not be tolerated by the EU, but if we allow war in Ukraine, we will admit war in the European Union.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: Mr President, it seems Russia is trying to make its case in Europe and it has to be denied this by all means. The deteriorating situation in Eastern Ukraine is extremely worrisome. We are witnessing the total lack of will by Russia to stop its military and financial backing of the separatists. I believe that the European Union should do all in its power to prevent a large-scale war and every European country should support the diplomatic initiative taken by Angela Merkel and François Hollande. I strongly support the position of the Council when it states that we must make all possible efforts to find a political solution to the Ukrainian crisis. We cannot afford and we cannot allow a large-scale war in Europe to take place again. At the same time, we hope that Russia will understand the gravity of this situation and the tremendously bad effect it could have on the future security and stability of Europe. In fact, the future stability of Europe is at stake.  I believe that if the peace plan ultimately fails, Ukraine should be supported by all means to defend its territorial integrity, sovereignty and independence. I might quote Margaret Thatcher and her TINA policy: There is no alternative.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: Mr President, honourable Members, Honourable Mrs Mogherini, between the political talks taking place tomorrow in Minsk (which are, of course, extremely important), I would like to draw your attention to a fact that remains aside from the news, namely the presence and problems of the huge minority groups that are in eastern Ukraine, right on the front of the fighting, between the cannons between the two warring groups.  The population in eastern Ukraine is not homogeneous. There are many national minorities there, including perhaps half a million Bulgarians and Gagauzi Bulgarians. These people are currently in a terrible humanitarian crisis.  I therefore call on you to activate humanitarian aid and humanitarian mission mechanisms; pay attention to the questions of forced mobilisation that is heard happening in these countries; pay attention to the power in Kiev that it must strictly respect all the rights and legitimate interests of national minorities in self-determination, in their own language, in their own association; pay attention to the president and the leadership of Ukraine, that this is an element of future peace decisions and negotiations.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Thank you, Chairman. Mr Mogherini, i would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mrs Mogherini, for his excellent Europe's soft power has collided with Russian weapons, and this is our new reality today. Tomorrow's Minsk meeting will hopefully achieve at least a new truce in eastern Ukraine, which I hope will not be violated again in a few weeks' time. But still so - in recent weeks, ukraine's control of territory has become increasingly scarce.  Today, the attacks have continued in Kramatorsk and Debaltseve. And a truce as such is certainly necessary, but it must not lead to a new frozen conflict zone, and that risk is very high there today. This is not the solution to europe's 21st-century security space.  Despite the fact that it is very difficult to find a solution to the whole conflict, given that this is a fundamental confrontation, whether or not Ukraine can decide its own future, all activities, including political action, sanctions, as well as the comprehensive and increasing assistance of Ukraine, must be continued. Thank you.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: Mrs Mogherini, I agree with you when you say that we really need a peace solution. But political peace solutions are not built on demonizing part of the conflict. On January 15, the unsuspecting Human Rights Watch repeated the accusation that Kiev forces target civilian areas indiscriminately and accused the Ukrainian Prime Minister of using cluster bombs and multiple rocket launchers. Why has the United States sent military instructors to Ukraine and why is Ukraine using NATO munitions in attacks on Gorlovka if its intention is to keep the peace? A political solution requires a different view of the conflict and not the imposition of one party on the other. One must ask for the withdrawal of aggressor forces from Donbass, the status of warring forces must be recognised to the parties to the conflict - which implies, yes, the recognition of the right of resistance to fascist and ultranationalist forces - and promote a direct dialogue between the parties to the conflict.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are at the end of yet another debate between the Guelphs and ghibellines in this House. So I take this opportunity to use them for a thank you with a little bitter irony. I would like to thank the governments of two founding countries, France and Germany, for the singular and unilateral initiative, however well-intentioned they may be, of the last few days. I would like to recall in particular the words of President Hollande, on 5 February 2013, in this House: Nous devons avoir la lucidité indispensable pour élaborer une stratégie afin de conduire une véritable politique extérieure commune, pour avoir une défense européenne. La France y est prête. Il est temps, là encore, d'en finir avec la dispersion des initiatives et de rassembler nos forces et nos moyens. L'Europe doit parler d'une voix et agir pour résoudre les conflits qui heurtent les consciences humaines. What a nice speech, one of the many that you hear here in these halls. It is a pity that it then resulted in a new version of an empty chair, and the chair was the most important one, that of the person who should and must, in my opinion, represent the European Union in these for a. Therefore, I express my support for his position and his work and I regret that France and Germany have behaved in this way and with a touch of irony I say to nominate them for the Eurosceptic Award 2015. With a little irony, with bitterness and with the hope that diplomacy and common sense will win over everyone in Minsk... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: Does Commissioner Mogherini agree that compliance with international law should be required not only from Russia, but also from Ukraine. E.g. the right to national self-determination – one of the fundamental human rights guaranteed by international law. Ukraine should be required to 1. upend and ensure the collective and individual human rights of indigenous national communities– be it the Russian community or the Hungarian community closest to my heart. 2. Transcarpathia is largely inhabited by Hungarians. In this area, it is now demonstrably, twice as many people are enlisted in the Ukrainian army than from other areas. What if it's not an infringement? Gross discrimination. 3. Conscription of a single Hungarian person would be a great thing, because it is also a violation of human dignity, and it also clashes with the prohibition of inhuman treatment. This is not a war of the Hungarians, Commissioner.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Mr President, I will start with one of the most frequently asked questions here, indeed one recently asked by one of my Italian colleagues. What kind of mandate is there for the initiative discussed here and which – here in this room as well as in the newspapers – is called the German-French initiative? I am sure that everybody sitting in this room has heard of something called the ‘Normandy format’. It was started some months ago and is something we refer to in our Council conclusions. To see what kind of European Union mandate there exists behind this initiative, you can look at all the Foreign Affairs Council conclusions over the last six or seven months – and I think also some European Council conclusions. Allow me to read to you parts – not all but a few sentences – of the last Foreign Affairs Council conclusions of 19 January 2015, before the initiative was taken. In those conclusions, all 28 Foreign Ministers, and I will come back again to unity, referred to the Berlin Joint Statement by the Foreign Ministers of France, Germany, Russia and Ukraine of 21 January, and we said: ‘All signatories of the Minsk agreements should convene as a matter of urgency within the framework of the trilateral contact group.’ This is something which is happening at the present time.  This is an OSCE, and not a European Union, exercise. However, I think it is not only our right, but our duty to recall the positive effort on the diplomatic side. Because I am saying that the present initiative is a European initiative, let me now read you a sentence that to me is the basis for our common work: ‘The European Union will actively support all diplomatic efforts conducive to creating a new political impetus […]. Full implementation of the Minsk agreements as the basis for a sustainable political solution to the conflict […] must remain the focus of such talks’.  To those who ask me about the kind of mandate for this initiative, I would say that it is exactly this. It is a normal Normandy format initiative, like many of the ones that we have had. Unfortunately it has not been as successful in the last months but I hope this one will bring some results. This is a decision taken by the 28 Foreign Ministers, by the Council. So I understand if, for internal political reasons and party politics, some groups and some Members of this Parliament take it as a way of attacking one or the other, but, believe me, this is a European initiative. It goes in the European direction and has to have all Europeans supporting it and not just applauding it. Some of you have rightly said that the important thing is that it gets results. If it gets results everybody should applaud it. I would say, not only applaud it but ‘actively support’ it. Let me say that I am very pleased to hear, especially on this side of the Chamber, a lot of support for ‘more Europe’. This does not happen often and I appreciate it very much. I also appreciate having so many supporters.  I know very well what my role is. At this particular moment, my role is to actively support those efforts by trying to get them to bring about a positive result. How? Firstly, by keeping our unity. Our unity makes the headlines only when we do not have it. But we all know very well that a crucial part of our response to this crisis is to keep our unity in political efforts and in diplomatic exercises, and when we exert pressure on Russia through sanctions.  In recent weeks we have had two Foreign Affairs Councils. In both of them, in very difficult political conditions, we all went into a room not being 100% certain that we would come out of that room completely united along the same lines and with some substantial result. This was done. It does not make the headlines and I am happy about that. I am happy if it does not make the headlines. I am less happy if it is underlined that we are not involved in negotiations or that we are not pursuing diplomatic efforts. Maybe when I am in a room with Mr Lavrov, Mr Poroshenko, Mr Klimkin, Mr Kerry or Mr Biden this can be considered a European effort. This is a European exercise, and do not play politics around it because this is serious. (Applause) Someone spoke of where we were. They correctly said, and I will reiterate the sentence: We are at Minsk II to implement Minsk I. We have to do all that we can to make it work and this is not the day to be thinking of what we do if this does not happen. We will have a day after; we will have one week after; we will have one month after. I agree with the Member on one month after, but one day after is probably not too late. If you want a diplomatic effort to succeed, you do not start planning Plan B before you get there. That is a basic rule, not only of diplomacy but of common sense. So what we have to do now is to insist on two things. Firstly, not to have a political and security environment that does not allow the meeting tomorrow to be successful. We have a collective responsibility. Obviously it is not primarily our responsibility but it is primarily the responsibility of those on the ground. Maybe I missed something today, but I think there is an awareness of the fact that, in any kind of negotiation, whenever we get closer to the moment when the parties have to meet, violence increases. This is what worries me most. So the first responsibility we have is to keep unity. Secondly, we must direct all our work, even parliamentary diplomacy, towards achieving a result that will facilitate a common European effort. Thirdly, we should try to make sure that the environment leading to tomorrow night’s meeting can allow a result. Fourthly, and in agreement with some of the last comments that were made, we must not only bring about a ceasefire but ensure the ceasefire can be implemented and monitored and that it is sustainable. This also means creating a framework for the ceasefire.  Now it is not for me to go into the details of what is being negotiated now. Obviously we are talking and exchanging information, but you do not necessarily issue a press release about that. I think we are all grown up enough to understand that very well. Maybe you are right that I should not assume this. Still I think that we are all very much aware of the fact that we have different steps to take and that we have a huge historical responsibility, not only a political one. Let me touch upon two things that were mentioned because I also think they were very important. Firstly, someone mentioned the need to reinforce the role of the OSCE and the monitors; I fully agree. I am very much involved in this network of diplomatic efforts. One of the people I talk to the most is Heidi Tagliavini who is doing an excellent job. I think in this sense that we are doing a lot already but if we come to a stage where monitoring is required we definitely will need to reinforce that instrument. Another point that was raised – and I will conclude on this – concerns Ms Savchenko. I am not sure whether or not you have already received my reply to your letter about that where I tried to list what we are trying to do. This is not easy. We are in contact with lawyers and our people in the delegation are trying to attend the trial, but it is not easy to get a guarantee in that environment. We are working on that and we are aware of that. Let me assure you that this case, and other cases of people illegally detained in Russia, are being closely followed by our service. Thank you very much for this discussion. For me at least, it was useful. I hope it was also useful to send out a clear message that not only are we united when it comes to the Council, the 28 Member States, but on this matter that we can also be increasingly united in Parliament.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. – Dear President, Senior Vice President. representative, colleagues, tomorrow is a particularly important day for both the Ukrainian people and Europe. It is a pity that on the eve of this important meeting, today, in Ukraine, blood is pouring again, military action is continuing, and people are dying. From tomorrow's meeting, we expect a very concrete result: to find an imperfect, but mutually satisfactory agreement, in order to end the use of force as soon as possible and to agree on the future of the occupied territories of Ukraine, so that this country can start slowly putting the station on its feet. Ukraine, in asking for new sanctions against Russia so far, shows its good will to the whole world that, despite the extremely tense and difficult situation, it is making every effort to achieve a peaceful solution. I am very keen to believe that other countries in the peace process will follow suit.

name: Ana GOMES
text: in writing. – The European Union must wage the war of aggression that Russia initiated with the illegal occupation of Crimea and continues in the Donbass in violation of the Budapest Protocol of 1994, which decommissioned the Russian-Ukrainian borders in exchange for the dismantling of the Ukrainian nuclear arsenal. And that also calls into question global safety, in actions tragically illustrated by the crash of the Malaysian Airlines plane last summer. In addition to the dead and wounded that are already being reported in Ukraine, more tragedies may occur as a result of Russian military flights and submarines crossing unidentified European space. The unassumed war that Russia has unleashed is not only against Ukraine's independence: it is against international law and global peace. Yes, whether we like it or not – and we do not want war – also against Europe. The Union cannot shiver. If the negotiating efforts of Chancellor Merkel and President Hollande do not achieve moscow's respect for the Minsk Agreement, the European Union will have to make the decision to support the ukrainian people's defence effort by all means.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. – Russia’s expanding its influence by direct aggression and hybrid warfare against its neighbours goes far beyond concrete military actions. It poses a direct threat both to Ukrainian and European long-term security. Russia’s sabre-rattling, Soviet-style propaganda of obvious lies and intolerance, financing extremist movements in Europe, has made it clear beyond any doubt that Mr Putin’s strategic aim is to reduce Ukraine to the status of a failed state, unable to make independent decisions like integrating itself into the European space of rule of law. Mr Putin sees the EU not as a strategic partner but as a strategic adversary, to be split and weakened. The USA and EU have to seriously consider aiding the Ukrainian army to defend itself. This would mean providing technological and specialist assistance to equip Ukraine with adequate know-how and ICT. In the short term, the EU has to considerably increase its humanitarian and development aid to Ukraine, providing also refuge and asylum as well as enabling students to continue their studies in the EU countries.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: Writing. – The cessation of the conflict in eastern Ukraine is one of the biggest challenges facing the Union so far in its neighbourhood policy. If its de-escalation does not occur any time soon, it may spiral out of control altogether. Further conventions can be disastrous in such a case. The solution will not be easy, but not impossible. The basis must be the preservation of territorial integrity and respect for Ukraine's sovereignty, together with efforts to avoid further frozen conflict. The initiative of Chancellor Merkel and President Hollande and their offer of negotiations with Russia are to be welcomed. I hope that further talks will lead to concrete solutions. I believe that sanctions against Russia must be maintained – together with the possibility of extending them – until a constructive approach is shown, which is essential for resolving the Ukrainian crisis. We must also call after the implementation of the Minsk agreements. Finally, I would like to stress that this crisis is also our crisis and unity within the Union is needed to resolve it.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Writing. – For more than a year now, in the Ukraine crisis, we have seen that European values such as freedom, democracy and human rights are by no means self-evident on our continent. To our chagrin, we have found that any attempt to resolve the conflict in Ukraine has so far been unsuccessful. The Minsk agreement has not been implemented and in recent weeks the conflict in eastern Ukraine has escalated. Russia is flouting Ukraine's territorial integrity and breaking international law. However, we must spare every effort to bring about a ceasefire in eastern Ukraine. We owe it to people. I therefore welcome the new initiative by France and Germany to make another attempt to bring about a diplomatic solution to the conflict. The main objective of the negotiations in Minsk must be a ceasefire in eastern Ukraine in order to stabilise the security situation in the region and create the conditions for a de-escalation of the conflict. In the further negotiations, it is crucial that the West continues to speak with one voice. This applies not only to the Member States of the European Union, but also to the alliance between the United States of America and us in Europe. It must continue as before.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. – In the arena of war where the people of Ukraine are blooded and at the negotiating tables of the imperialists, where they hypocritically talk about peace, the knives of acute competition for energy and their other interests are sharpened. It is the US, the EU and NATO that have launched the imperialist intervention in Ukraine as part of their competition with Russia. Now the US is sending weapons, NATO by decision of the defence ministers and with the agreement of the Greek government is tripling its army and multiplying its expeditionary corps and bases in neighbouring countries. The JRC calls on the people to be vigilant and condemns the unacceptable new extension of sanctions and the preparation and implementation of additional measures against Russia decided by EU leaders. This is a decision co-signed by the new SYRIZA-ANEL government in Greece, despite its original leondarisms, and which is pouring new oil on the fire, bringing new suffering to the peoples. The Communist Party denounces the anti-communist persecution industry against the Ukrainian KK, with the aim of banning its action, prosecuting its members and executives. The measures against him and the nationalist cries are a signal of danger to the Ukrainian people and are a signal that imperialist plans are intensifying in the region and that the anti-labour offensive against him is escalating.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: in writing. – The recent intensification of Russian and Russian backed violence in Eastern Ukraine aims at two targets: one military, another diplomatic. Militarily, it becomes increasingly clear that the Russian side is attempting, first, to "correct" the Debaltsevo "salient", thus improving the separatists' frontline position and, second, to conquest of the city of Mariupol, a big step forward towards establishing a land corridor between Russia and Crimea, otherwise very difficult to provide for after the illegal annexation. Diplomatically, even before the peace initiative of Chancellor Merkel and President Hollande, some analysts suggested that Moscow wanted to increase the level of violence in order to bring the western powers to the negotiating table. The problem is that, given the primacy of military action, in Moscow's eyes, diplomacy seems designed to buy time for the completion of the military objectives; hence, the lack of results during the meeting of the three leaders. The reverse is also true: a potential ceasefire in Minsk should be followed immediately by the initiation of the process of giving a political solution to the conflict. Otherwise, it will be another lost opportunity with even worse consequences.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: pisomne – The basis for a peaceful solution is the implementation of the Minsk Agreement, which guarantees the preservation of Ukrainian territorial integrity while satisfying the demands of the Russian-speaking people. However, a ceasefire is needed to meet it, which is not possible without stopping Russian military support for the separatists. The European Union must use all peaceful means to stop Russian aggression and violate international agreements.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. – I am fully aware of the seriousness of the situation in Ukraine and support all efforts for a peaceful solution, including EU sanctions against Russia. I also condemn the annexation of Crimea as a move that was contrary to international law. However, I fundamentally disagree with all the European Union's efforts so far to provide financial assistance to Ukraine. The reason for the poor economic situation in Ukraine is not the conflict with Russia, but the long-standing neglect of reforms and corruption in all ukrainian governments over the last 20 years. This situation cannot therefore be solved by the European Union's loans, but only by real reforms that will lead to greater competitiveness for Ukraine. This role should therefore continue to be played by the International Monetary Fund, which is certainly more successful than the European Union in rescuing troubled countries.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing – Recent events in Ukraine, such as the indiscriminate shelling of civilians in Mariupol, clearly illustrate the need to develop the CSDP to its full potential, in order to increase the Union’s capability to react adequately to the situation. Russia’s naval chief Admiral Vladimir Vysotsky once said that with Mistral warships Russia would have won the 2008 war against Georgia ‘in 40 minutes instead of 26 hours’. This assessment clearly indicates that Mistral ships would be a very effective platform in the Black Sea. As almost everyone has realised by now, it would be insane to support Russia’s expansionist polices in the region by delivering these warships to them at any point in time. As the attacks on both Georgia and Ukraine have shown, Russia’s expansionism is not a one-off isolated incident. Last month the Parliament condemned Russia’s aggressive expansionist policies in Ukraine, however, words alone cannot solve the crisis. An effective contribution from the Union to remedy the imbalance of power between Russia and Ukraine would be to acquire and man the Mistral ships, and send them as reinforcements to Ukraine.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the Review Conference of the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT) in 2015 (2015/2555(RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, let me first of all thank you for this debate. The upcoming NPT Review Conference, which will be held in New York from 27 April to 22 May, is something to which I attach a great deal of importance. It is the most important event on global non-proliferation and disarmament this year. I announced already during the hearing in this Parliament in October that I intended to put in a great deal of work on this and I can confirm that I intend to participate in the Review Conference, in the opening session, and to address the meeting.  I also believe that the role of Parliament in this is crucial. If I am not mistaken, it was the case in 2010 that Parliament adopted a resolution helping to shape the European Union position and I think that it will be extremely good – well, this is our first chance – to have a constant dialogue so that our position is somehow a common European position, taking in the view of Parliament too.  Let me thank you too for all those occasions where the EEAS has been invited to relevant committees on this topic. It is something I appreciate very much.  Now, coming to this year’s Review Conference, there is a mixed outlook, as you know very well. There are different views on the level of implementation of the 2010 Action Plan, and these views are probably quite difficult, or increasingly difficult, to reconcile. I think that, in this context, it is also important not to lose sight of a couple of issues that are regional issues but still relevant to the conference itself.  On one side, the ongoing negotiations with Iran that the European Union, as you know, is facilitating – I am personally facilitating – following a UN Security Council resolution and which could demonstrate that a peaceful solution to a serious issue is possible and mutually profitable for all.  Another element that is likely to influence the outcome of the Review Conference is the fact that the Conference on the Weapons of Mass Destruction-Free Zone in the Middle East, which was one of the key elements of the 2010 Action Plan, has not taken place yet. Here let me thank the facilitator of this for his efforts – his endless efforts – and I hope that all our support can lead to the conference being convened sooner rather than later. When it comes to the disarmament pillar of the NPT, there has been a growing debate, taking place mostly outside of NPT meetings, on the issue of the catastrophic humanitarian consequences of any use of nuclear weapons. A major international discussion on this subject was recently held in Vienna, organised by Austria. While some want to elaborate a legal ban on nuclear weapons, others advocate a building-block approach to disarmament with step-by-step nuclear reductions, taking into account the current security environment. It is an ongoing debate. As you know the European Union has different Member States, with different histories, different positions, and different sensibilities we would say.  But I was encouraged first of all by the fact that during the recent conference in London, the five NPT nuclear-weapon states reconfirmed their commitment to achieving a world without nuclear weapons, in accordance with the goals of the NPT, and made further contributions to developing the mutual confidence and transparency which is essential to making progress towards multilateral nuclear disarmament.  I think that the conference – even if, as I said, we are still in the process of shaping our formal position on that – should deliver a vision first of all on how to strengthen the Treaty as a whole. We are, as I said, currently preparing with our Member States the common position for the conference and I think that even if the Member States’ mix is complex – nuclear weapon states, NATO members, neutral states – I am confident that we will achieve a common position as we have done in the past.  I believe personally, but this is also the EU position, that the NPT is and has to remain the cornerstone of the global nuclear non-proliferation regime, as the essential foundation for the pursuit of nuclear disarmament. It is also an important element in the further development of nuclear energy applications for peaceful purposes. We, as you know, support the universalisation and the effective implementation of the NPT.  I believe that we will have to continue to promote a more comprehensive, balanced and substantive implementation of the Action Plan adopted at the 2010 NPT Review Conference, and this Action Plan has been our common roadmap to this Review Conference. However, I believe that we will also call on all NPT States Parties to live up to their commitments of 2010 and to do all that we can to ensure that the Conference delivers a common vision on how to implement these commitments.  I know that we do not have so much time but let me quickly go into some of the details of the European Union position, as it is shaping up with regard to the three NPT pillars, with the caveat that the common position is not official yet and is underdeveloped.  On disarmament, we have to reaffirm, I believe, that it is our commitment to pursue nuclear disarmament in accordance with Article 6 of the NPT and stress the need for concrete progress in this field, especially through an overall reduction in the global stockpile of nuclear weapons.  We will welcome the considerable reductions made so far, taking into account the special responsibility of the states that possess the largest arsenals, and we will welcome indications of progress reported by the United States and the Russian Federation in implementing the new START Treaty and strongly encourage them to seek further reductions in their nuclear arsenals, including strategic, non-strategic, deployed and non-deployed weapons, and in this atmosphere I guess this will be the most challenging exercise.  We will welcome and encourage the nuclear-weapons states’ conferences on the follow up of the 2010 NPT Review Conference, including confidence-building, transparency, verification activities and discussions on reporting. We will stay committed to Treaty-based nuclear disarmament and arms control and stress the need to renew multilateral efforts and revitalise multilateral negotiating bodies, in particular the Conference on Disarmament. The ongoing stalemate, including the persistent failure to agree on a programme of work remains, I think, not only troubling but also unacceptable.
