I think it is time to call for the immediate commencement and early conclusion of the negotiations, in the Conference on Disarmament, on a treaty banning the production of fissile materials for nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices. One point to which I attach particular importance and on which I have always been active personally is the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty (CTBT), which I believe is of crucial importance to nuclear disarmament and non-proliferation. I would continue, even personally, to work for its entry into force as a top priority (obviously not only by myself but by the European Union), continuing to promote this objective not only to diplomatic action but also to financial engagement. We have contributed substantially to the CTBT Organisation since 2006 and I take the opportunity to thank Parliament for its support for the CFSP financing provided to this end. As I said, I have been and I will stay personally engaged in the efforts made by the CTBT Organisation regarding the dialogue with the Annex 2 states whose ratifications are needed for the Treaty to enter into force. On non-proliferation, the European Union view: the international community continues to be faced with major proliferation challenges. This is very evident to us and must be addressed in a resolute way in order to maintain the credibility and the effectiveness of the NPT regime. I would stress the primary responsibility of the UN Security Council for maintenance of international peace and security, including the cases of non-compliance. I will not mention individual cases; if necessary, I could go back to some cases that Members might raise in their speeches. On the peaceful use of nuclear energy: the EU will reaffirm its support for the right of all parties to the Treaty to develop research, production and use of nuclear energy for peaceful purposes, without discrimination, and in conformity with the Treaty.  Let me at the very end – last but not least – mention nuclear security. I think that the Nuclear Security Summit process is crucial and stays crucial. I personally followed it when I was a Member of Parliament myself and a minister afterwards. I think it is key to reducing the threat of nuclear terrorism, something that is still very relevant, and to securing all vulnerable nuclear material in the coming years.  We are, and stay, committed to supporting the leading role played by the IAEA, including through financial support provided by the European Union to the Nuclear Security Fund. It has been substantial – EUR 40 million since 2004 – and for that I also have to express my gratitude to Parliament for having chosen to support that financial effort.  Thank you very much and I am looking forward to your ideas.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the High Representative, thank you very much for your statement. I believe that we have a very broad consensus on this issue here in this House. It is important that this conference is also contested by us Europeans with a common position. On this issue, too, the following applies: we are strong together. I hope that we will reach an agreement in the negotiations with Iran. So, we wholeheartedly support the efforts of Group 3 + 3. If we reach a deal with this country in this area, it will have a very positive overall impact on the non-proliferation process. I remain very concerned about a country like North Korea, which is a ban on nuclear tests. This country is not sticking to it. It's unpredictable. I believe it is very important that we remain in close contact with China in particular in order to keep this gentleman in check there in Pyongyang. I fear that we have seen a very bad example of Russia and Ukraine on one point – incentives. After all, the Budapest Convention of 1994 had as its central point that Ukraine should renounce its nuclear weapons and, in return, be guaranteed its borders by the great stake, the United States, Russia and the United Kingdom. The way Russia behaves in this case, of course, is not an incentive for a country to give up nuclear weapons. On the contrary, it also has the effect of some countries considering whether it might not be a better insurance to acquire nuclear weapons in the first place. That cannot be in our interest. For this reason too, we should hope that Russia will return to the path of peace in Europe.

name: Ana GOMES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Seventy years of the hiroshima and nagasaki disasters are marked and since we have the Non-Proliferation Treaty. Despite it almost doubled the number of states with nuclear arsenals outside the international monitoring regime. It is time to demand and strive for the NPT to lead to the total elimination of nuclear weapons in the world. The timing is urgent, and not just because of the Review Conference this year. Once again we are witnessing a geostrategic conflict in Europe, with war in Ukraine, caused dangerously by a nuclear power, Russia, in violation of a nuclear regulation treaty, the Budapest Protocol of 1994. But the resurgence of war and armed conflict and terrorism on European soil and in the nearest neighbourhood, the Middle East and North Africa, by state and non-state actors, cannot justify an arms race. On the contrary, the world must demonstrate that it has learned from the mistakes of the past. Nuclear weapons are not deterrents, on the contrary, proliferation leads to more proliferation. We must achieve the agreement of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty by Israel, India, Pakistan, and the re-entry of North Korea into the disarmament regime and control by the International Atomic Energy Agency.  So far we have failed to give npt effectiveness. The oldest nuclear states fail: the United States, France, the United Kingdom, Russia and China, which, while maintaining nuclear arsenals. They will have no moral authority to preach disarmament to other countries and fail those who, in recent decades, have entered the club of nuclear states refusing to join the NPT. They do not disclose the number of nuclear warheads, refuse international control and thus mutually fuel suspicion and mistrust. Cases from India, Pakistan, Israel and Iran. In order to ensure the strengthening of the NPT, it is also necessary, as the High Representative stressed, that the CTBT should finally enter into force. Madam High Representative, in addition to the common position for the next NPT review conference, we need the involvement of the NPT by those who have not yet done so to be part of the regular dialogues of the European Union with the countries concerned. It is vital that the Union uses its diplomatic capabilities as an actor in global security, development, trade, energy power, etc. to make the NPT a true binding global regime that eliminates nuclear arsenals and this also involves doing homework with the nuclear powers of the European Union, France and the United Kingdom.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, honourable Members, Honourable Commissioner, first of all, I would like to say that I am impressed by your endurance for another day in the Chamber, for which I congratulate you. Now on the subject.  The Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty is a one-of-a-kind international treaty aimed at preventing the proliferation of nuclear weapons and promoting the peaceful use of nuclear technology. But today, given the circumstances and threats from Islamic State and islamic extremism in general, we need to be very careful when talking about disarming nuclear arsenals. That is why I call on the participants in the upcoming Treaty Review Conference to concentrate their efforts on the risk of nuclear arsenals falling into unwanted hands, not just in ways to disarm them.  To acknowledge, yes, there is an opinion that these weapons of mass destruction are a threat to humanity, but they also constitute an essential element of the national security of many countries and are a guarantor of stability, security and peace in many regions. Today's conditions call for more emphasis on enhancing the security of nuclear weapons systems.  That is why I believe that the disarmament of nuclear arsenals must be achieved gradually and only through international treaties and cooperation in this field, while continuing to promote the peaceful use of nuclear technology, because my first belief is that cleaner, safer and cheaper energy than nuclear does not. There are many examples of this in Europe, such as the kozloduy headquarters.

name: Sabine LÖSING
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the I wonder why this Parliament is worthy of a debate today, and not a resolution on this truly vital issue. That would have been an important and necessary sign. The Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty was the consequence of the US atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. The threat of nuclear weapons is not and must never be a political or military means. But even two decades after the end of the Cold War, the earth is still contaminated by thousands of nuclear weapons. The civil war in Ukraine must not be the reason to jeopardise the Treaty. On the contrary! We need to discuss what role the EU should play, can and, yes, wants to play in particular. It is undeniable that there are hardliners on different sides. And yet last weekend, the five nuclear powers, China, Britain, Russia, the US, and France, issued a joint statement reaffirming their commitment to nuclear disarmament and diplomatic conflict resolution. However, it is not only here in this House that this does not seem to be of great interest. The press hardly reports on this either, although it is precisely at this time that such conferences can be a confidence-building measure and would lend credibility to the will for peace of all parties. What this world needs is to strengthen the voices of reason and a constant policy of détente. Nuclear weapons, after all, threaten everyone's lives.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I am pleased to hear that there is a commitment on the part of the Commissioner on this issue. I also thought I was hearing that the Commissioner would like to have broad cooperation with us in Parliament and would like to see a resolution on this matter. As Mrs Lösing has just mentioned, there does not appear to be a resolution here from Parliament this time, unlike previous NPT reviews.  I would therefore urge my colleagues here that we actually also support a joint resolution, the groups that have not yet done so. As Mr Gahler also said, we actually have a broad consensus. Why, then, are we afraid to express it and give the Commissioner the support we want to give her in this very important work? As we see it, the non-proliferation treaty is an extremely important issue, and it is important that we do not allow it to be watered down.  We had a hearing on this the other week in committee. As I understood it then, the conditions are not so good to get the agreement tightening. Rather, it seems today that the parties to the Non-Proliferation Treaty during the 2015 Review Conference will only conclude that they could not implement the action plan adopted in 2010. The same applies to the action plans adopted before then. So if we or the Member States are not looking to close down this agreement, we are at a crucial time right now.  This is at the same time as our security environment in the East and South has changed dramatically for the worse, thereby also increasing the risk that the weapons will actually be used. So if europe is not involved in driving, the risk is very high that we will soon be faced with nuclear anarchy in an increasingly unstable world.  I would therefore call on Commissioner Mogherini to do his utmost to achieve a strong and progressive common position for the review conference. It is important that the EU is a strong player for disarmament. I would also like to hear how the Commissioner sees the conditions for actually getting the agreement to be strengthened instead of watering down.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, since the signing of the Treaty on the non-proliferation of nuclear weapons a lot of work has been done by signatories to reduce, and ultimately abolish, nuclear arsenals, including the UK. The end of the Cold War did not bring relief from the threat posed by nuclear weapons and, in many ways, with their potential proliferation to more States and even terrorist organisations, the situation is worse. Recent events in Eastern Europe and the Middle East have shown just how quickly security can break down. I have no doubt there are some fanatics within this Chamber who would wish to see further centralisation of Member States’ security and defence. But in the perilous world we live in it is vital for British national security that the levels of nuclear disarmament and non-proliferation policy remain firmly in Member State hands.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: Mr President, High Representative, first of all the good side of the apple: lack of progress in nuclear arms control shows the need for a higher level of ambition in the upcoming 2015 Review Conference of the parties to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT). There is one very positive recent element which gives us an opportunity to restore confidence in the possibility of limiting sensitive nuclear activities: progress in the talks with Iran since the election of their new government. Fundamental disagreements on key issues seem to have been overcome. I believe we should translate progress in the talks with Iran into an agreement that establishes a comprehensive joint action plan enacting strong non-proliferation instruments for verification and as safeguards. Such a forward-looking and meaningful agreement, if translated into broad international norms, would be a great boost to the NPT talks. This is my opinion: it is absolutely necessary. More transparency and disarmament on the part of nuclear weapon states are a fundamental step forward in the European security strategy. Now the bad side of the apple: let me remind you, High Representative, of the Budapest Memorandum that already was mentioned here from 1994, that led to the fact that Ukraine gave up its nuclear weapons in exchange for security guarantees. That risks undermining the non-proliferation process, while the crisis in Ukraine shows disrespect for the security guarantees. Let me, personally, thank you for your patience and for your cooperation.

name: Marek JUREK
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Just as we must prevent the proliferation of nuclear weapons, so too must we respond to countries that threaten to use them. After all, we know that nuclear weapons were not only a tool of mass destruction, but also a tool of state terror. Since the beginning of this short century, Russia has assumed the use of nuclear weapons against a non-nuclear state in its war doctrine. I very much encourage you, Madam Vice-President, to say at the forthcoming conference that such a position is inadmissible. In practice, the Russian position means the threat of nuclear weapons against one of the members of the European Union. Obtaining a declaration that a nuclear state is inadmissible to use nuclear weapons against a state that does not have nuclear weapons would be a very important step towards making the world safer and, above all, towards greater security for the nations for which we are responsible. I invite you, Madam Vice-President, to come forward with this initiative at the conference that is coming.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ntp and ctbt are unfortunately perfectly unknown acronyms for too many millions of European citizens and acronyms who are snatching a bitter smile from those involved in international relations. The smile is really bitter when we think of the beautiful aspirations of these treaties which, in the vast majority of cases, are disregarded precisely by those States to which they are addressed as a matter of priority. I am addressing in particular the five who sit on the UN Security Council with the right of veto, not to mention India, Pakistan, North Korea and Israel. None of these states has ever removed the use of these weapons from their military doctrine, and it is therefore normal to see postponements, tactical positions, unjustified and unjustifiable absences. He knows this well who was present in Oslo in March 2013, in Nayarit in February 2014 and most lastly in Vienna. Our commitment to multilateral nuclear disarmament, as you said earlier, Madam High Representative, must be common and total towards our Member States and towards all other states that have similar arsenals, especially at a time like this when we know very well what kind of geopolitical confrontation is taking place on Ukrainian soil. We must have a legally binding instrument and, from this point of view, I welcome the possibility of a resolution by Parliament. A thought to close on nuclear testing and CTBT. They asked the people of the Marshall Islands who guinea pigs for nuclear hell what it means and how important it is to have a total ban on these types of experiments, and we support their claim for compensation from the United States.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Vice-President for a very strong statement on proliferation. Nuclear non-proliferation is no longer headline news. For many of my generation and those of younger years it seemed like a problem of the past, conjuring images of a Cold War thought long gone. But tensions between nuclear power states are now at their highest point for decades.  Most pressing is of course the situation in Ukraine, where a proxy war is being fought with Russian weapons and combatants. East and West are again locked in an icy conflict. Whilst our American allies consider weapon deliveries, the European Union must press on for de-escalation of conflicts and for non-proliferation of nuclear weapons. Current tensions call for renewed trust and perhaps indeed renewed inspections to ensure that current agreements are honoured. The EU must do all it can to ensure that the NPT framework does not evolve into another forum for conflict. I urge you therefore to state clearly, on behalf of the European Union, that current tensions with Russia and the West must not halt, slow or any way impede already agreed reduction targets for nuclear arms.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: The issue of nuclear weapons development is multifaceted, complex and depends on the general situation in the world. Therefore, in the real context of the forthcoming meeting on the revision of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, it is quite clear that there will be no easy solution. To date, we still have unresolved problems with Iran regarding the development of its nuclear programme, North Korea, whose actions are impossible to predict, is today the crisis in Ukraine and the occupation of some part of it. That is why today we are entering a new phase in which the confrontation between Russia and the West is exacerbating, making the issue of nuclear weapons of particular political importance. This treaty was one of the most significant agreements concluded during the Cold War, which has allowed the use of nuclear weapons for military purposes to date to be avoided. I therefore want to believe that, in negotiating a revision of the Treaty and in this extremely difficult period, political will and a common desire to ensure peace and stability in the world will be the basis for a new agreement.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam High Representative, in view of the 9th five-year review of the NPT, it is a pity that Parliament has decided this time not to table a resolution, interrupting a well-established practice until previous years. There were resolutions in both 2005 and 2010. In this way we are refusing to express our voice fully. At a time as uncertain as the one we are going through, I am thinking of the tense negotiations with Russia on Ukraine, but also at the crucial moment for a possible conclusion of the nuclear talks with Iran, the work of our High Representative would undoubtedly have benefited from formal political support from Parliament.  This time, in fact, it is not just a question of thinking in the long term, it is not a question in the background. Nuclear non-proliferation has an impact on some of the most sensitive scenarios for the Union's external action. That is why, in my opinion, we have missed an opportunity, but that does not exempt us from continuing our work and, why not, from imagining new ways out of the current stalemate. I am thinking in particular of the humanitarian initiative for nuclear disarmament, which at the Vienna Conference last December reached real momentum with the accession of 44 states, and which we should seriously consider as a possible option to relaunch the original ambition of the NPT.

name: Julie WARD
text: Mr President, I am working very closely with civil society and would therefore ask the relevant authorities to take into account the growing concern of these organisations and of the non-nuclear arms states regarding the threats to human life and to the planet posed by the very existence of nuclear weapons. Along with political representatives from more than 160 countries, I attended the Vienna conference hosted by the Austrian Government to discuss the humanitarian consequences of nuclear weapons. This was preceded by an equally significant civil society forum. The concerns of these organisations and the people they represent must be taken into account regarding non-proliferation and an eventual ban.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, I join those colleagues who have been talking here all along about how we need a resolution.  I think this European Parliament on this topic has, and this time, shown that it is thinking together and that we are aware of the dangers of nuclear weapons. Not only because we think some countries might be able to use it against democracy and against everything we stand for, but above all because the whole world would come into question. That is why I would like to stress that we need a resolution, especially when I have heard all those principles that Mrs Mogherini is talking about, which are disarmament, stock reduction, effective stock reduction.  Let's at least get something. Let's at least get a nuclear test ban. I think it's something we owe to this planet and at least that's how we end this Audit Conference.

name: João FERREIRA
text: Mr President, nuclear disarmament at international level is of vital importance. It is necessary to defend and strengthen the Non-Proliferation Treaty and its ratification by all States. In the current international context, the dangers are evident. In respect for the spirit and letter of the Treaty, disarmament and the end of the development, production and storage of new nuclear weapons are necessary.  The United States and NATO, maintaining overwhelming supremacy in conventional forces, do not dispense with their vast nuclear potential, insisting on the maintenance of nuclear weapons in Europe and Asia and making it impossible to create a nuclear-free zone in the Middle East. The rhetoric underlying The United States' nuclear doctrine, revised by Obama, is based on the duplicity of criteria and the instrumentalization of the Non-Proliferation Treaty and represents a perversion factor of its content and a threat factor to world peace.  Look at how Israel – which, unlike Iran, has nuclear weapons and has not signed the treaty – enjoys total impunity. Moreover, with the complicity of the European Union, as is once again in sight. And let me just add: it is regrettable, it has already been said, that the largest political groups, such as the EPP and the Socialists, have made it impossible for a resolution on the Non-Proliferation Treaty to be made possible in this Parliament.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are talking about the revision of the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, which will take place in New York in May 2015. It is sad to talk about nuclear weapons after seventy years. Because the truth is this: nuclear weapons are still seen as an important thing, something that cannot be done without it, so much so that in many non-Western states there is a race for know-how to understand how nuclear weapons can be equipd that can offend not that they can defend or that can guarantee safety. I still hear talk of ensuring our safety through nuclear weapons, but whose safety? I think that we have now reached the point where nuclear weapons should disappear from the very face of the earth, because they are only a threat to mankind, they are of no use at all. Unfortunately, we diplomatically, as a Union, have no power and therefore those who have them and those who want to do them will continue to do so, they are words and they will remain in the wind, unfortunately.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Mr President, I will start with a remark made by one of the last speakers, which was very clear and said it all: we have to protect the Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT), we have to strengthen it, we have to make sure that it achieves universal membership and application, and we have to respect it formally and substantively. This is the core of the European Union message to the NPT Review Conference. Someone else said, with a generational reference – and I very much share their view, and I guess some of the Members here will also share it – that it seems obvious to a large part of the European population that we should not even need to discuss these issues. However, I believe that we have a long way to go in the world. Obviously, we have a long way to go on the non-proliferation pillar, and the negotiations on the Iranian nuclear programme will, as I said, impact on the conference itself. I hope that we will see substantial developments by then, and I can assure you that I am playing my personal role, with all the dedication possible, to make those talks positive. This could be a historic opportunity because, while we are talking about disarmament, the non-proliferation pillar is just as important as disarmament. One reinforces the other in a sort of credibility cycle, which is why we have to work on the three pillars of the Treaty together. Just let me mention two things from the debate that I would like to underline. The issue of a resolution is obviously in your hands and not in mine. Still, I take this debate as an encouragement, and I would very much appreciate keeping this channel open, as you mentioned, through the committees here, with a view to the preparation for the conference – firstly because the European Parliament has a voice to raise, and also because it is important that we keep the channel open for communication on these issues with civil society organisations, public opinion movements and national parliaments. I believe that this is one of the things that affect our security and the security of our citizens very much. Sometimes there is an illusion that the NPT is about goodwill, good feelings or the good sentiments of some naive persons around the world: in fact, it is very much linked to our security and it is a security debate that we are having.  The last thing I would say is that it is precisely because of the security threat and the tensions around us that we need to work on this: on implementation, on all sorts of disarmament measures and on the steps that have been started in the last decade and the last few years. Someone mentioned the Obama doctrine, with the Prague speech, and the fact that it provided an impetus which was very relevant. We should not allow the tensions that we are facing in the world – not only in Europe but also elsewhere – to detract from the real purpose of our work on the NPT and the connected treaties, which is to increase our security, and not to relinquish it. I want you to be assured of my personal dedication to that, and I will obviously try to do my best to make sure that the European Union’s voices are not only united but also strong at the conference in New York.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Thank you High Representative Mogherini. I would also like to thank you for the long marathon that has engaged you this afternoon. There have been very civilised debates, but there have been some unpleasant words – and on behalf of the Bureau I express our solidarity with you – words which will in any case be evaluated by the Bureau. The debate is closed.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the report by Charles Goerens, on behalf of the Committee on Development, on the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly (2014/2154(INI)) (A8-0012/2015).

name: Charles GOERENS
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, let us start with some basic truths: if it did not exist, it would have to be invented. We are talking, of course, about the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly. It was within the framework of this parliamentary cooperation that it was possible to exchange, through the representatives of the peoples, on political issues of common interest. This dialogue has made the Assembly an essential instrument of democratisation. If this is the perception at the level of the 78 parliaments of the ACP and the European Parliament, public opinion, on the other hand, could be better informed. It had become accustomed to the Member State of the European Union presiding over the Council of the Union hosting the acp-EU annual meeting in its capital, or at another location chosen by the Presidency of the Union. In recent years, this habit has been lost. It is a pity because, by the same to the very end, we are depriving ourselves of making the work of this House better known to a public opinion which is overwhelmingly in favour of development policy. We want to see the future States that must assume the presidency of the Union return to a well-established tradition. As for the more political aspects of this original parliamentary cooperation, the wealth of contributions dealing with the most diverse issues, including governance, security issues and ACP-EU cooperation as a whole, should be retained, namely cooperation first at the regional level, and then, in particular, in the area of economic partnership agreements between these regions and the European Union. , without ignoring, of course, and I should have started with that, development cooperation itself. Mr President, although little is said about this, the ACP-EU dialogue on respect for fundamental values is becoming more and more important in our debates. Issues relating to non-discrimination in particular give rise, from time to time, to extremely lively debates. On the European Union side, we have very specific issues to solve - I am referring here to the budgeting of the European Development Fund, which is the instrument for financing ACP-EU relations. As long as the European Parliament does not have the prerogatives inherent in any parliament, especially in budgetary matters, we are rather embarrassed when we invite the ACP states to develop parliamentary democracy at home. Let us say, however, that the anomaly to which I have just referred should definitely be a thing of the past. If we could turn our backs on the past, we could more calmly address future debates and challenges.  Before concluding, I would like to focus on the challenge that will overshadow all others, namely the future of EU-ACP relations, which, it must be remembered, will expire in 2020. From my point of view, it is not too early to start thinking about the nature of our relationship in the future. If we do a countdown - and this in the event of a renewal in one form or another of the Cotonou agreement - it is important to devote it to it now. The European Parliament, and in particular its Committee on Development, would be well advised to endorse Commissioner Mimica's proposal to make an initiative report on post-Cotonou. In fact, we could have thought about it ourselves, since any parliamentary initiative would have to be initiated by parliamentarians themselves. Considering only the judicious nature of his appeal, it goes without saying that we cannot fail to address this reflection as soon as possible.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, the Joint Parliamentary Assembly is a unique forum for strengthening the European Union’s and ACP cooperation and connecting people in Europe and our partner countries through their directly elected representatives. I share the view expressed by the rapporteur, Mr Goerens, that we have successfully managed to extend our exchanges and work beyond purely technical and administrative matters. We have indeed been using our meetings more and more strategically to discuss issues of mutual concern.  Discussions that we had during the last Joint Parliamentary Assembly in Strasbourg on policy coherence for development, on Ebola, or on the post-2015 development agenda have been substantial. I expect the same level of engagement and input on post-Cotonou negotiations. Let me now move to the important recommendations made in this report to the Commission. On European Development Fund programming, I am happy that Parliament is now providing comments on EDF programming documents and I am confident that this new practice will improve the effectiveness and accountability of our development policy. On Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs), I share the view that trade should support and serve development objectives. This is a vision I will pursue, working closely with Trade Commissioner Malmström.  The development objective has been the core objective of the EPA process from its very beginning. It is translated into concrete provisions in the Economic Partnership Agreements, including a great deal of asymmetry in the commitment and obligations, in measures promoting regional integration and in a number of special measures and safeguards. These provisions allow our ACP partners to promote their industrial development and protect their infant industries, food security and natural resources.  The European Union also supports the related reform and adjustment process and helps ACP countries to develop their trade capacities, enhance their competitiveness and make themselves less vulnerable to risks.  EPAs also ensure long-term free access for all products to the EU market. This is unparalleled in any other trade arrangements and is a key for investors’ location and sourcing decisions. We have heard our developing partners say on many occasions that they want trade and investment even more than our development money.  But we have also heard some of the specific concerns about the concrete potential of EPAs to contribute positively to trade facilitation and policy coherence for development. We would be ready to work with our partners to assess the Economic Partnership Agreements’ functioning and implementation in order to maximise their trade and development potential. On policy coherence for development (PCD) I can only welcome the proposal that the Joint Parliamentary Assembly should appoint two standing co-rapporteurs on PCD because it is one of the Commission’s main priorities. As for Parliament’s call for an explicit reference in any future agreement to non-discrimination on the grounds of sexual orientation or gender identity, let me remind you that a second revision of the Cotonou Agreement has considerably expanded the list of topics for dialogue on specific political issues of mutual concern to include traditional grounds for non-discrimination, in line with provisions by which ACP countries are bound under international conventions. At the time the ACP States firmly opposed including LGBTI rights on this list. However, the new wording of Article 8(4), taken from the wording of Article 2 of the UN Declaration on the same subject, does not exclude the possibility of discussing LGBTI rights with ACP countries. The European Union has regularly engaged with ACP countries on human rights, including non-discrimination on LGBTI issues, and we are determined to do so in the future. Some Honourable Members have had direct experience of ACP reluctance to discuss this issue. I agree with you that we must find the best way to pursue dealing with this issue and I will continue working with you to this end. This will, together with other very important issues, be part of the forthcoming public consultation process on Cotonou or on the post-Cotonou Agreement, and I look forward to the opportunity of further engaging with Parliament and with the Joint Parliamentary Assembly.

name: Maurice PONGA
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, I am pleased that today we are discussing the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly. Indeed, this assembly is a unique forum for discussion between parliamentarians from the South and MEPs. It is therefore important to value his work. In the report of our colleague, Charles Goerens, we take stock of the activities of this assembly in 2012 and 2013. Several reports have been adopted on topics of common interest such as the rule of law, political stability, economic partnership agreements and health issues.  In addition to political resolutions, the ACP-EU APP has also strengthened its presence on the ground. Indeed, fact-finding missions have been sent to Mali, Liberia and Haiti to better understand local issues, and two joint election observation missions have been sent to Mali and Madagascar. These missions help to strengthen our understanding of the situation in ACP countries. They must be supported and continued in the years to come, I am convinced. I am pleased to see that this parliamentary assembly is increasingly present. I hope that in the future the ACP-EU APP will be able to position itself on issues of major importance such as the future of relations between the EU and the ACP countries after 2020, or the international discussions on the post-2015 development framework. I invite all colleagues to support this report.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D- - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in this world full of difficulties and conflicts of all kinds, the European Union must be able to exert a decisive influence through the dissemination of its founding values. We have to be aware of that, that is the whole point of the ACP-EU partnership. The work carried out in the framework of the Joint Parliamentary Assembly is an opportunity to strengthen the dialogue between the European Union and the ACP countries. The report presented to you demonstrates by the activities carried out and the proposals made all the benefits that can be derived from such a partnership. Therefore, the APP cannot be judged by its limited powers, but should be seen as a space for dialogue and reflection that contributes decisively to the definition and achievement of sustainable development goals on a global scale.  First of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Charles Goerens, for the excellent work done. The examination of the text in committee allowed us to enrich it and to have a balanced text today. Like the members of the Social Democrat group, I therefore call on colleagues to support it. To close my remarks, I invite all Members of the European Parliament, members of this House, to participate in APP sessions so that they can see the added value of such an institution.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, High Representative, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the way in which I would also like to thank Mr Goerens for the overall, quite balanced report. Apart from two or three points, where, too often, I feel that he is too often putting a typical European emphasis on the gender debate. It has already been mentioned. Do not get me wrong, I am not totally against it, but I still hear in my ear what many African colleagues said at the last ACP part-session in Strasbourg: people, we have bigger problems, understand this at last! I think we should understand this and not become alien to the world. Otherwise, however, as coordinator of the ECR Group, I share many of the points raised in the report on the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly. I would like us to be able to work even more flexibly and quickly. I have already proposed that, in addition to the three specialist committees and the election observation missions, the instrument of short-term task forces for current crises or issues should be created in order to be able to quickly show the parliamentary face of Europe on the ground. Speaking of face , allow me a little story: last December, the ACP meeting was planned in Vanuatu. Nearly 60 colleagues had signed up for it. Then came Ebola. There were only 15 of my 60 colleagues here in Parliament in Strasbourg. I think we need to show more interest in global issues, even though we still have 10 parliamentary elections here in the EU this year.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I believe that the ACP Assembly should also address issues of fiscal justice. Two of its main pillars are trade policy and development policy, but if there is no fiscal justice, development policy becomes mere charity. The Member States of the European Union sign bilateral treaties with these countries, which do include tax agreements, but they are perverse because, under the pretext of avoiding double taxation, they establish legal mechanisms that facilitate what is practically tax evasion in those countries, therefore diminishing their collection capacity. European transnationals, our companies, produce there at low cost and come here to tax, but they make use, there, of the infrastructures of those countries and, if a factory burns down, it is the firefighters who are going to put out the fire. And that's called being an exploiter. It is $160 billion that loses a year in tax evasion, which is much more than it received in official development aid. So I believe that the House is an excellent framework for introducing change and for this institution to cease to be so inconsistent in its development policies.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. Mr President, I would like to raise two points in this debate. Firstly, Europe. The European Commission is still making agreements with regions and ACP countries on development cooperation. These agreements are made in particular with ministries of economic affairs or ministries of finance or ministries of planning. In fact, the parliaments in those ACP countries are hardly involved. It should be our job to help our colleagues in the various African parliaments to really shape the control of these programmes. I believe that this will give the Joint Parliamentary Assembly added value. The second point is about the future. Frankly, I find it a little complicated for us to hold meetings with parliamentarians from Africa, the Caribbean and the South Pacific. We have a collection here that you really should call colonial. I would like to maintain the relationship with these different regions, but not in the form of ACP, when we are in need of renewal in 2020. It's a little weird to keep our view of the world where our colonies used to be. I would therefore like to invite ourselves and also the Commissioners to think towards 2020 on how we are going to approach regional approaches here, with us looking at countries in their regions, even though their neighbours are not ACP members.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are starting from the premise of the report by my colleague Charles Goerens, which is certainly a job that is well done, that we can support and that has already been voted on in the DEVE Committee. We support the report except for an amendment which we would like to retable in this House and which relates precisely to possible military intervention in the ACP countries. We will be asking for electronic voting because we are apostrophes for the fact that diplomatic and peaceful intervention is needed in those countries because the conflicts, which are often induced by western countries, give rise to a whole series of problems that we discussed at length at the last ACP meeting. I would like to move on to my second point, which is the importance of the ACP Joint Assembly. Ladies and gentlemen, we have already discussed this, it is important. However, in fact, when we held the last meeting here in Strasbourg at the beginning of December, we were fifteen people and I do not think there was all this interest on the part of the institutions. No member of the Council has even come forward, and I remember that this was not really taken well by the representatives of the African, Caribbean and Pacific parliaments. We have important objectives and the ACP Joint Assembly is certainly the place where we can discuss and we can find shared programmes. But we should also reach agreement among ourselves and see whether we think it is important or not. If it's just important to make a trip to the Caribbean, then we're a little hypocritical. So let us give due importance to the ACP Assembly which has existed for a long time.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Mr. President, here I am welcoming my colleague Goerens' report on the work of the Parliamentary Assembly of ACP countries and the European Union.  Indeed, this interparliamentary assembly offers one unique opportunity for a democratically comprehensive dialogue between MEPs and parliamentarians from ACP countries. And I agree with the rapporteur that this assembly can and must serve as a forum where difficult or controversial topics will sometimes be discussed in an honest and open way. One of these topics is the universality of human rights, the right to the dignity of every person, regardless of race, religion, nationality or sexual orientation. It is because of this last one that some MEPs, especially from Africa, believe that our European attitude is sometimes the basis for some new European cultural imperialism. Such a conclusion I think we all share here that she is guilty, but we must continue to work on dialogue with our colleagues from Africa. Of course, not emphasizing positions that are not universally accepted, sometimes even within the European Union, but that by insisting that human rights, precisely because they are based on natural law, apply to all people. Perhaps this one approach will help us reach one better understanding with colleagues from Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific, on controversial topics.  In the end, I would also join the criticism for not attending council representatives. Said colleague Goerens that if the AKP did not exist, it should be invented. It may need to be modernized or changed, but as long as it exists we must respect it.

name: Norbert NEUSER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to highlight two things about Charles Goerens, who is making a good report. He said: firstly, if there were no cooperation between the EU and the ACP, it would have to be invented. Secondly, it is not too early to start discussing now, to develop strategies for what will happen after 2020. 78 ACP countries and 28 EU countries have a strategic majority in the United Nations. I think we should be aware of this time and again. Compared to other countries that are now approaching development policy, such as the BRICS countries, we have the great advantage of having a common basis of confidence that we are meeting our ACP partners on the basis of our fundamental European values – human rights, freedom of expression, individual rights, sexual freedom. It is an incredible opportunity for us, which we, as Europeans, should continue to use. I think that we must also call on our Member States to be more active in this. In recent years, the Member States have clearly evaded their responsibilities. We, as a Parliament, and we in the Commission, should call on the Member States to be more active in the ACP area.

name: João FERREIRA
text: Mr President, we value the experience of the functioning of the Joint Parliamentary Assembly, which includes European parliamentarians and acp, Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific. It is regrettable that it has been devalued by the Council, several Member States and, to some extent, even by the European Parliament. This House has proved to be a very rich area of cooperation, mutual knowledge and exchange of experiences. A space where the contradictions that result from the unequal development of capitalism, the deep asymmetries that run through the world today, are well evident. A space where the contradictions between a development-friendly discourse by the European Union and concrete sectoral policies are evident, which systematically undermine and subvert declarations of good intentions. The contradictions of those who point the finger, in a paternalistic tone, and how often with unconfessed ambitions of neocolonial clipping, without looking at the misfortune that rages in their own home, without looking at the disastrous domestic results of the policies and options that he wants to impose on others.  It is against this background that we will hold the important debate on the future of post-2015 development policy.

name: Nathan GILL
text: Mr President, when we think of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific, or the ACP as we have been calling it here, we think, of course, of the sun. It has become increasingly apparent that the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, which supposedly started as a force of good, has become nothing more than a front for lavish holidays and massaging egos. Who funds these trips? Well, of course, it is us, the taxpayers. In 2011 a short excursion to sunny Togo by a group of 33 MEPs cost the beleaguered taxpayer, at a conservative estimate, GBP 435 000. In 2014, a 34-strong ACP-EU delegation went to the beautiful island of Tenerife and accumulated a bill of close to GBP 600 000, all courtesy of the humble taxpayer. The most laughable case of these fact-finding missions was when five delegation members went out to the tropical island of Fiji in 2012. It was supposedly a mission to learn about the political crisis in that small island nation. Reading the four-page report they compiled, it becomes apparent that it was nothing more than a holiday, with a conclusion that the most humble politics student could have googled. At a time when families can barely put food on the table, the political elite of the EU are taking lavish holidays on their behalf. It is time for Britain to leave the EU and start putting food back on the tables of the British people.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Lots of ACP countries are members of the Commonwealth. Do we have to understand that you are against the UK’s close cooperation with all these countries? Do we have to understand that you are against the visits of the British MEPs in these countries to achieve better cooperation and enhance trade, cooperation on democracy, on market economy, on tourism and so on and so forth? Do we have to understand that?

name: Nathan GILL
text: blue-card answer. – The only thing I am against is you lot taking holidays at my expense, and the taxpayer’s expenses. You do not need to go on a fact-finding mission to Fiji or the Tenerife, quite frankly. It is taking the mick.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Charles GOERENS
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, I wanted to ask the honourable colleague if he was aware of the right of every Member to also talk about the subject that is on the agenda.

name: Nathan GILL
text: blue-card answer. – … but not to take lavish holidays at the expense of the taxpayer. Full stop!

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking I support the very good report by Mr Goerens, because the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly is a very important platform for open, democratic and deep dialogue, partnership and constructive solutions in the policies of the European Union and acp governments to overcome the problems posed by the current local, regional and global challenges. The Assembly actively monitors political, economic and social developments in the ACP States in an effort to promote development goals and respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, including respect for fundamental social rights, democracy based on the rule of law and transparent and responsible governance, which are an integral part of sustainable development.  At the last session of the Strasbourg Assembly, I was co-rapporteur on the report on private sector development strategy, which was voted unanimously by both Houses and which, in the same vein, sets out ways of helping the private sector. The report stresses the importance of effective private-public cooperation. This dialogue between local and national authorities and the private sector also encourages private sector participation in the development policy development and implementation. This one example shows that cooperation between the ACP countries and the European Union is necessary and very important.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the post-Cotonou negotiations present us with an important historic moment, giving us the opportunity to re-establish our relationship with the countries of africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific. At stake in the coming years is the redefinition of ACP-EU relations and cooperation, which is therefore an opportunity for strong and active engagement on the part of the Member States. In this context, the contribution that the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly is able to make to the debate is crucial. The structure of this body offers in its uniqueness the opportunity to introduce the democratic paradigm in trade relations between countries, a model by its nature based on the centrality of the human person, first of all, and on collective well-being, overcoming a model based on balance of power while respecting human rights. This House also accompanies the countries in strengthening democracy. With this vote, Mr President, the European Parliament is giving a strong signal of sharing this relational model in full sharing the founding values of the Union.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: Mr President, I would first like to stress the support for the report and Mr Goerens for the magnificent work he has done. I would like to stress the uniqueness of this Joint Assembly and its important work in favour of the growth and rapprochement of the countries of the European Union and Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific, especially with regard to the political dimension and the development dimension. It is a joint body that aims to promote democratic processes through dialogue and through concertation, and above all issues of understanding of development. It is very important — I am part of (already my second parliamentary term) of this House — that the various meetings may be held under the rotating presidency of the Council, as was done when Spain chaired the Council, in the Canary Islands. One of the priority issues is undoubtedly the post-Cotonou process at the end of the legal framework: being able to sit down and reflect on what these future relationships will be, the actors in this relationship, the instruments, the global challenges, the joint or specific relationship and, therefore, it is important and very timely to put this resolution to the vote. There should also be some reference to migration and development. It is a complete and very important issue, and also the recognition – which has been increasing in these countries – of civil society.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, one of the most important conclusions in this report recognises the need for a better definition of the strategic priorities of the European Union's cooperation with the ACP countries.  In fact, we need clear priorities at a time of so many challenges: from poverty to climate change, from Ebola to refugees, from human rights to terrorism. But in this year of decisive conferences, one of the main priorities should be an inclusive debate on the future of development policies. The leadership of the European Union in this chapter must be inclusive leadership.  And what I ask the Commissioner is that, having been in the Joint Parliamentary Assembly, we would like to know whether he has taken into account the concerns of the ACP countries in the proposals that the Commission has put forward for the future of development finance, and how it assesses the participation of ACP countries in the discussion on the future of development at global level.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Mr. President! First of all, thank you again to Mr Goerens for the comprehensive but also honest report. 2015 is the European Year of Development. We should not forget that in all the debates we are having here. This year, we should particularly look at our relationship and our relationship with the african, Caribbean and Pacific countries. The European Parliament, together with the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, has a unique platform for this, which offers us the opportunity not only to appear here in plenary with debates and resolutions, but also to discuss the problems together with our colleagues from the ACP countries. And we should talk much more to each other, and not just to each other. How fragile democracy is in many of these countries is is currently shown to us by Nigeria, where the elections were postponed at short notice to the disappointment of the people there in the country. However, the ACP-EU Parliamentary Assembly will only be able to be effective if colleagues – as has already been mentioned – also take part in it here in Parliament. But the Council should also face up to its responsibilities and appear when it is on the agenda. We owe that to our colleagues from the ACP countries. Otherwise, we will not be taken seriously and there is doubt as to whether we are seriously addressing their problems. Presence is everything, and there is nothing to replace the contact.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Mr President, I am involved in supporting the report and above all to support the very existence of the ACP-EU Joint Assembly, which should in no way be regarded as a symbolic forum, let alone anecdotal or ornamental, but a genuine political forum based on mutual respect and, above all, on the equality of parliamentary representations of the ACP countries and the European Union , and which must become increasingly important politically. For this, some things must also be changed: to clearly propose that there be a dialogue with civil society and representatives of non-governmental organizations in order to better understand the situations and problems of the countries with which such important cooperation is established; secondly, to make a smart combination between the work of this Joint Assembly and the Economic and Social Committee of the European Union, which also has a specific monitoring committee on this dimension of ACP-EU regional policy. Finally, I wanted to refer to the importance of strengthening the work on immigration, the political dimension of the House, in order to prevent irregular migration flows and, above all, to combat trafficking in human beings, which is a very specific political dimension of this cooperation between the European Parliament and the ACP Assembly.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: Mr President, two brief ideas. A first to highlight the importance of the parliamentary dimension in the framework of ACP-European Union cooperation. The results obtained by parliamentary diplomacy, as well as the concept itself, have to be evidenced and also have to be valued. The truth is that many of the results achieved in the work of our House are not immediately or tangibly measurable or perceived by each and every one of our partner countries. It takes, of course, some time to bear fruit. That is why the parliamentary dimension of our cooperation should not, in our opinion, be diluted in future relations post-2020. And, as far as possible, it should even be strengthened. Already for its participation in the current debate on the future of ACP-European Union relations.  Another idea is to involve the increasing number of public administration actors at more decentralised levels – be they municipalities, regional governments or associations of municipalities – in an increasing connection to our parliamentary assembly. Contacts with the authorities are therefore important, but also with the living forces of civil society who can in some way contribute positively and proactively to the objectives set out in our cooperation. In conclusion, let me just highlight the undeniable role of the powers of proximity, in particular the municipalities, which, I believe, should become increasingly involved, in an informal but regular way, in our work of our Parliamentary Assembly, whether through specific meetings or through conferences, seminars or others, in order to enhance and take the message of our privileged cooperation further and further.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Mr President, I would like above all to congratulate Mr Goerens on his report and, in the spirit of what our Spanish colleague, Mr Lopez Aguilar, said earlier, I would also like to underline the exceptional nature of this joint Parliamentary Assembly. Basically, it is the only multilateral inter-parliamentary assembly created on the basis of an international agreement. As has been said, this Assembly is a forum for debate on key issues, such as development cooperation, but also democratisation and the political stabilization effort of the ACP countries. I remember, for example, the debates we had in Suriname in 2012 on extremely interesting cases, such as the situation in the DRC, Mali, Somalia. The importance of involving neighbours and regional organizations in the management of these crises was affirmed at the time. Then there is election observation. Here, I believe that we have already established cooperation for the elections in Mali and for the second round of the presidential elections in Madagascar. I was part of those delegations and I remember that we worked very well with our ACP colleagues. Finally, as rapporteur on the coherence of development policies, I support the very good idea of appointing two permanent co-reporters to the Assembly - that is said in paragraph 18. In this way, we will have excellent cooperation.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Madam President, dear colleagues! I have been a member of this House since 1999. I have had many debates with colleagues from the ACP countries, and it is very important that we have joint debates on an equal footing with colleagues from those countries and that we fight for common solutions. That is a point that is very close to my heart. That is why I would like to raise a critical point here. Over the years, I have watched how participation has evolved. While our ACP colleagues are, of course, taking part in a large number of participants, I note that on the European side, the presence is very much within the limits, to put it mildly. I find it unacceptable that at the last sitting we had here in Strasbourg, there were still 19 European colleagues to vote, although there could actually be 78. I believe that we must make a new commitment here. This commitment must be personally accepted by all parties involved. This starts with the co-president on the European side up to the latest delegate. That is what I expect from everyone! Only then can we also ensure that our colleagues on the ACP side show us the respect and confidence that are the prerequisites for this cooperation. Because we need to talk very soon about how we will reshape this when Cotonou 2020 is over. Then we will ask ourselves the question: will we continue this, or will we divide it up? These are very important debates, but for that to do so, there must be confidence among those involved. That is what I would like to promote.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Madam President, there are three elements. Firstly, the holding of the sessions of the Joint Parliamentary Assembly in the Member States of the Union which hold the rotating presidency of the Council. This not only has enormous added value but is also a symbolic part of our partnership with the ACP countries. The credibility of our commitment to this partnership will be clearly called into question if we continue in the disappointing direction that has been taken for the past two years. The second institutional element is that your participation in the last meeting of the APP, Commissioner, was particularly appreciated by its members. We can only hope that this commitment will continue.  Thirdly, on the basis of Mr Goerens' very good report, I fully support the idea of strengthening the dialogue on human rights and, likewise, the appointment of the two permanent co-reporters on the coherence of pro-development policies, these are excellent proposals.  Finally, I would like to recall the exceptional nature of this meeting. To support it is to highlight the strategic importance of our ACP-EU partnership.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have also asked to take part in this debate in order to affirm my pride in being part of the ACP Parliamentary Assembly, an extraordinary place for debate and discussion, dialogue but also for the encouragement of speeches by this Parliament, which has helped to shine a spotlight on major and extremely serious issues in recent months. I am thinking of Ebola, the violence in Congo, the massacres in Nigeria, the attacks by Boko Haram, the Islamic Fundamentalist offensive that is also spreading in Africa. Talking about neocolonialism is instrumental. Here we are debating, but we are also acting, sending observers and ing prejudices are being brought down. Of course, relationships are not easy. The heterogeneity of acp countries and regions requires careful reflection and a lot of diplomacy. We develop strategies, set goals, verify results. Our priorities must be to combat violence, to protect the human rights of women and minorities and to cooperate more and more intensively in development, as well as to increase good trade relations.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, we consider the functioning of the Joint Parliamentary Assembly between acp countries and the European Union to be important, because it is an important political forum, where representatives of the peoples of both sides discuss and cooperate on serious issues: firstly, foreign policy, such as the political crisis in Somalia or the situation in Mali; secondly, issues with a significant social impact, such as human resources in the health sector in the ACP countries or the social and environmental impact of coal mines or even price fluctuations. In addition, the Joint Assembly can and should continue its important initiatives on issues such as migration and the fight against AIDS and Ebola. We therefore support the action of the Joint Assembly, because it is a powerful institution for strengthening relations between Europe and the ACP countries.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: Madame la Présidente, permettez-moi tout d'abord de remercier notre rapporteur, Charles Goerens, pour ce très bon rapport. Madam President, the ACP-EU Joint Assembly has become a key player in ACP-EU relations and cooperation. It plays a fundamental role in achieving common understanding and agreement on issues of mutual concern. It brings more democracy to the dialogue between states, and I therefore deplore the declining participation in this conference by some EU Member States. EU Member States should be fully committed to this open, democratic and comprehensive dialogue. Cooperation between parties is vital if we are to achieve the objectives of the European Development Fund and ensure European policy coherence on political, economic and environmental issues. That is why I believe we need to strengthen this dialogue, especially with the aim of achieving a strong common position for the conference in Paris next November.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Madam President, the parliamentary assembly of the ACP countries and the European Union is a really great mechanism for dialogue. We all know very well which countries we work with within that assembly and then we know very well that dialogue simply has no alternative. That is why I want to support all those who spoke here in favor of this forum which definitely needs to treat security topics, economic development topics and all those topics that Mr. Gorentz and Mr. Mimica spoke about. I am convinced that this is a good path on which, our Commissioner Mimica, makes it seem that all those countries that are so important to us in our cooperation and often in a situation, when we talk about them in another way, not like today. I think it's a good path that Mr. Gorentz has set out in some way with his report and I believe it's a successful cooperation for the European Union.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: I support this report, but it must be said that the relationship between the European Union and the ACP countries has been having difficulties in recent times, and I say it as a member of this Assembly and a specialised academic in the field. The European Union, which was previously the most involved international actor in this area, has not acted uniformly and strongly enough. Lower involvement is also generated by Europe's lack of cohesion, in my opinion, especially since external action in these countries is dominated mainly by the old countries, members of the European Union, and the new countries are less involved. I think it is important to look at the expectations of the ACP countries, which expect Europe to hope for democracy, development, but also a proactive economic partnership. Unfortunately, we are not able to be as active as other states in this part of the world. I still believe that this United Parliamentary Assembly plays and can play an important role in this partnership. Europe must give direction to this Parliamentary Assembly and equip it with partners of structures that oversee and act coherently in achieving our objectives in these areas and in this partnership.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, I would like to thank the European Parliament and the rapporteur Mr Charles Goerens for this important debate. The Joint Parliamentary Assembly is indeed a unique and general forum for discussing key development and political issues, thus connecting people in Europe and in our partner countries through their directly elected representatives. I have no doubt that together we will find innovative ways to strengthen our cooperation with the ACP countries in coherence with the new challenges of our times. The forthcoming public consultation process on post-Cotonou would be an opportunity to thoroughly analyse the failure and success of the current agreement in terms of its effects on the sustainable, social and economic development of the ACP countries. It would also provide the necessary input and guidance for negotiations on the future EU-ACP post-2020 framework for development and economic cooperation. A European Parliament own-initiative report on post-Cotonou partnership, as suggested by Mr Goerens, would be a welcome contribution to this debate. I look forward to the Joint Parliamentary Assembly continuing to uphold the principles of democracy and good governance.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, at the end of this discussion, I would like to begin by thanking all the colleagues who have spoken on my report and on the EU-ACP relations in the parliamentary field. Secondly, I think I can see that there is agreement on several points that I think are quite politically important. I am thinking, in particular, of the appointment of two co-speakers on the work of our assembly. Furthermore, I believe that there is practically a consensus on all benches to start thinking now about the future of EU-ACP relations. It is not too early to begin: if we do a countdown, these negotiations still take several years, and that means we should start negotiating by 2018-2019 at the latest. This presupposes that we have first defined the European Parliament's broad guidelines in this area, of course in close collaboration with the Commission and the Council - I concede that it is more difficult with the Council, which is never present at our meetings, neither at the ACP-EU meetings, nor at the Committee on Development, where it is entitled to speak; it's a shame and it's a missed opportunity. Thirdly, the tightening of relations between the 78 ACP Member States and the 28 Member States of the European Union is - As Mr Neuser mentioned a few moments ago - a largely untapped opportunity. We have, he recalled, a strategic majority within the United Nations and in major conferences; 2015 is the year of major conferences, especially on the financing of official development assistance, it is an opportunity to seize.  We have also seen the extent to which the disagreement or lack of coordination between the 28 on the one hand and the 78 on the other, particularly in the trade negotiations, has virtually derailed the Doha development principle. That is why I invite you to look more closely at political mobilization.  Last but not least, let me also stress this point: I think I can also say on behalf of all my colleagues that this cooperation in the EU-ACP Assembly is a real undertaking in terms of the democratisation of all our countries first, and also of the relations that unite us.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, February 11, 2015, at 12:00 p.m.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the oral issue at the Commission on Zero Tolerance to Female Genital Mutilation in Iratxe Garcia Pérez, on behalf of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality (O-000003/2015 - B8-0104/2015) (2014/2988 (RSP)).

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: Author. - Madam President, Commissioner, female genital mutilation is internationally recognised as a violation of the human rights of women and girls. It reflects a deeply entrenched gender inequality and constitutes an extreme form of discrimination against women. It is always practiced on minors and is therefore also a violation of the rights of the child. It also violates the rights to health, safety and physical integrity. Some 140 million women worldwide are currently suffering the consequences of this practice. In December 2014, the United Nations General Assembly adopted a Resolution to intensify efforts to eliminate female genital mutilation. It calls on States to develop, support and implement strategies to prevent this practice, including training of medical staff, social workers and local and religious leaders, to ensure that they provide competent support and care services to women and girls at risk of mutilation. I will bring to this debate the words of Khadi Diallo, a member of the women's group's association for the Abolition of Sexual Mutilations: "I will never forget that day. I was twelve years old, and my sister was ten. Like every summer, we were at our paternal grandparents' house. One morning, early, we went to see my aunt, my father's sister, whom we always wanted to visit. I didn't suspect anything. My aunt took me to the bathroom and she and several women pounced on me, grabbed me, knocked me down and separated my legs. I was screaming. I didn't see the knife, but I felt like I was being cut. There was a lot of blood. I cried, but they said, "Don't cry. It's a disgrace when a woman cries. You're a woman now." Our mother came to see us. The first time he cried and kissed us. But there was nothing I could do. In Africa, the paternal family has the right to life and death over the child. They told us that a woman must be robust, suffered, reserved and not very talkative." This is a real testament, like that of millions of women around the world, also in Europe, who continue to be victims of injustice and inequality. In the countries of the Union where women victims of female genital mutilation live, this practice is most often carried out during a stay in the country of origin, although there are obvious indications that they also occur on the territory of the Union. A recent study by the European Institute for Gender Equality concluded that there are victims of mutilation in at least thirteen countries in the European Union. In November 2013, the European Commission published a Communication entitled 'Towards the elimination of female genital mutilation', which takes a cross-cutting approach to eliminating this practice. That is why we would like to take this debate to ask the Commission what action it has taken in this area and how it will help Member States to develop specific indicators, adopt and implement legislation, and how it will contribute to this policy in their external relations. We also want to know how your work on operational planning in the field of justice will be ensured is connected to existing commitments to end gender-based violence. There is another question which deserves our attention and which I would like to hear your answer to, which is: what concrete measures will the Commission take to ensure the protection of asylum seekers on grounds related to female genital mutilation, within the framework of the consolidated Directive on asylum seekers? As you can see, there are many issues that concern us about being able to end this practice with concrete actions that are within our competence. Eliminating female genital mutilation should be a priority on the international agenda. If the laws are not firmly enforced and are not very strict, the effort will be in vain. It is a practice that violates the most basic rights of girls and women, and has serious physical and psychological consequences. When a woman is informed about this, it is herself who protects her daughters and other girls in her community. Nor can we forget the work of cooperation between public institutions and organisations working in civil society, because it is essential to achieve the objective of ending in Europe a brutal practice of violence, which has no place in 21st-century Europe.
