Because if anyone intends to justify this practice under some excuses, let us say very high and very clear that respect for traditions and cultures has as its impassable limit respect for human rights.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, I want to thank Parliament, and particularly Ms García Pérez, for its efforts to eliminate female genital mutilation and its support for the work of the Commission and the European External Action Service outlined in the Communication entitled ʽTowards the elimination of female genital mutilationʼ and adopted on 25 November 2013.  The Commission strongly reaffirms its stance against all forms of violence against women, including female genital mutilation. This practice is a violation of human rights and of the rights of the child. It violates women’s and girls’ physical integrity, causing profound and life-long impacts on their health and their well-being, and can even led to death. Currently the Commission, together with the European External Action Service, is following up on the actions that we committed to in the Communication.  What are we doing on increasing knowledge? Estimates show that there may be as many as 125 million victims worldwide and 500 000 victims in the European Union alone. We have very little reliable information about how, by whom and where female genital mutilation is carried out. Therefore, improving knowledge is one of our main priorities. Together with the European Institute for Gender Equality, we will develop a common methodology and indicators to estimate the risk of female genital mutilation in all EU Member States. The European Institute studies will tell us more about the reasons behind female genital mutilation being continued or abandoned among migrants in the European Union. This will help us to create an effective strategy for ending the practice.  Now, what are we doing or what are we going to do on prevention? To bring about the social change necessary for families to abandon this tradition, legal action alone is not enough. This is why the Commission is supporting and will continue to support work at grassroots level, engaging communities that practise female genital mutilation both in the EU and abroad.  To this end, the Commission will very shortly open a call for proposals for EUR 4.5 million for transnational projects aiming to prevent, inform about and combat harmful practices in the European Union. The Commission is currently funding four national awareness-raising campaigns run by Member States that specifically target female genital mutilation. In our external actions we also support grassroots projects that aim at the abandonment of female genital mutilation. This includes projects with a specific component on justice or creating a protective environment for women’s rights. Thanks to the support of Parliament, a web-based platform will be developed for professionals who come into contact with girls at risk and victims of female genital mutilation. I would like to thank you for that here today. The Commission is working to include female genital mutilation in the development of a communication providing guidance for EU Member States on integrated child protection systems.  How are we protecting victims? The Victims’ Rights Directive should be transposed in November 2015. This Directive ensures victims of female genital mutilation easy access to well-functioning specialised support services and protects them against any threat of physical or emotional harm during criminal investigations and trial.  The Commission has organised several workshops with Member States on the implementation of the Directive. The most recent one took place last week on 6 February, the International Day of Zero Tolerance for Female Genital Mutilation. The Commission is also disseminating training materials on female genital mutilation for legal practitioners through its e-Justice platform.  Let me end with a few words regarding the external dimension of our work. Access to justice and the promotion of laws protecting all the rights of women, including the right not to suffer from traditional harmful practices, are priorities also encompassed in the EUʼs policy strategy in its external action for women. To promote gender equality we use political and human rights dialogues with partner governments where we bring up women’s empowerment, human rights and women’s health issues. Secondly, we also support advocacy and lobbying initiatives to improve national legislation and the development of suitable national policies on women’s rights. Thirdly we support capacity-building initiatives for government officials and advocacy and awareness-raising for all sectors of society.  Once a year a gender-specific training course is organised in the External Action Service. This training is targeted at staff from the External Action Service, the Commission and Parliament based in their headquarters, in EU delegations and in missions related to the Common Security and Defence Policy and in Member States. Since 2012, Amnesty International has been invited to present a session on ending female genital mutilation.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, on this International Day of Zero Tolerance to Female Genital Mutilation, the EPP Group is playing its part in the fight to eradicate these terrifying mutilations. This absolute scandal must stop. Every year, nearly 3 million women, girls and even very small girls, suffer these real tortures, female genital mutilation, perpetrated in the name of so-called social traditions, in the name of so-called religious or cultural reasons. And in the very territory of the Union, as we know, around 500,000 women and children also have to know about these absolutely unacceptable and intolerable practices. In the EPP Group, we welcomed, and still welcome, the european Commission's commitment and its action plan, presented in November 2013, but regretted that this action plan, which was stated and supposedly very ambitious, was not accompanied by a very precise timetable, which would have made it possible to judge achievements already undertaken and did not include concrete measures either. , precise and effective, to truly strengthen the fight against these female genital mutilations. We take note, Commissioner, of the extremely specific statements, the commitments and the list of future actions that you have outlined before us. They are going in the right direction, they are responding to the objective that this oral question was intended to achieve, which was to allow us to go further and to be able to really have a roadmap, a path marked by firm and precise commitments. We will not wait a year to come back and deal with this subject; we will ensure that these specific commitments are met.

name: Maria ARENA
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D- Madam President, I thank the Commissioner for her presentation on the catalogue of actions that can be taken by the European Commission. Of course, we can welcome this fairly comprehensive catalogue, which touches on both the issue of access to health, the protection of girls and women, the treatment of asylum seekers and the promotion of this action at the Commission level to combat mutilation.  At the same time, I share my colleague's view that we do not currently have a specific timetable. We have that catalogue on the table, but what about the precise timetable and the objective? As you said, it is difficult to collect data. So where is this data collection? It is difficult today to prove that Member States have put in place effective processes. How do you assess the effectiveness of these processes? We are talking today about the international protection of these girls who should not risk deportation to a country where FGM is practised. What about these evictions? We know that there are so-called safe countries, that is, countries that, in general, would not practice female circumcision, even though we know that it is practised in some of their regions. We are told, "Yes, but we do not send girls back to these areas." But you know that when you come from a northern area and you are sent to a southern area, that is not necessarily the best thing.  There is therefore a great deal of uncertainty about the action of the Member States in the fight against female circumcision, whereas you are giving us today this catalogue of good intentions of the Commission. I would have liked to know in concrete terms what the Council is proposing for its application.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, mainly ladies, good evening, gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The problem of female genital mutilation does not seem to be a European problem. The term gives the impression that it is a problem of African tribes and their rituals. That would be bad enough – but the problem has immigrant us. So we now also have this heinous crime against women and girls.  With respect to the crimes here in our country, I would like to say that anyone who wants to practice female genital mutilation as a religious practice or whatever does not belong to our cultural circle does not belong to us, and it cannot be integrated into us.  We will neither tolerate nor accept FGM. We do not mutilate people. No men, no women, no boys and no little girls and babies. End of announcement! And on the crimes in Africa, let me make one point: the girls and women there need help. Misereor puts the number of women and girls affected at 157 million. And two million are to be added every year. Many, long not enough, but many get help. And that will not taste good for many people in this House – I would say too many – because they are building and nurturing images of enemies here. But a very large part of this aid is provided by the development aid works of the Christian Church, the Evangelical Church and the Catholic Church: Caritas, the Diakonie, Misereor, Missio, the German Episcopal Conference, Church in Need. I think that has to be said. One often gets the impression here, especially in Parliament, that Christians are second-class people. Those who sometimes go to church on Sundays are very close to Christian fundamentalism, and those who go every Sunday are actually already a Christian Taliban. So let us be clear: these are Christian aid works whose work against female genital mutilation is infinitely valuable.

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I am delighted to hear what the Commissioner has to say about the implementation of this much-needed action plan to tackle this particularly horrific form of violence against women and girls that is FGM – female genital mutilation. We are all quoting the projected figures on victims in the EU and worldwide, but in fact we are not able to say exactly how many girls are cut every year because there is a lack of reliable data. What we can say is that vulnerable girls, often from already isolated sections of our communities, are at the most risk. What effort is there now to collect this data and how will we tackle this practice if we do not know the scale of the issue? The Commission’s recent communication commits to helping Member States raise awareness and provide training for relevant professionals, and that is very welcome. In the UK the first and only case of prosecution of a Dr Dharmasena for not attending to FGM shows knowledge amongst key professionals remains woefully low. He says he never received any training on FGM in either his undergraduate or postgraduate studies and was not aware of any hospital policy on FGM. We have to provide training for teachers, doctors, policemen and other key professionals now, so that they can recognise the warning signs and will know what to do when presented with the evidence. Training takes only a few days but it could help prevent vulnerable girls from being forced to live with the consequences of FGM for the rest of their lives. Awareness-raising among professionals is a great start but of course that is not enough to end this brutal practice. We must all work closely with the communities, to start to change attitudes and to talk about this issue, supporting the brave women who refuse to allow their daughters to be cut and arming the girls with information so that they can recognise the warning signs and resist.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Female genital mutilation is a terrible form of violence against women and girls. It is true that patriarchal violence takes different attention in different contexts, but it always aims – always – to suppress women, limit our living space, our sexuality, our place in public space.  All violence against women and girls is traditionally deeply rooted in our tradition. I am strongly opposed to the fact that fgm, i.e. female genital mutilation, is lifted out of the broader work against violence against women. In order to be effective, it must be integrated into the broader work of combating all forms of violence against women and girls. Then we create solidarity, feminist solidarity, for a joint work in which all women and girls can live a life free from violence.  Perhaps the most difficult thing is to see the systematic and structural patriarchal violence on which the majority culture in Europe is built, ranging from the witch-burning of the past to today's impunity for rapists. Even those women who are not affected are indirectly restricted, through fear and caution, a self-limitation that creeps into our everyday lives, into our lives.  Violence against women and girls is a violation of human rights. That is why it is a fundamental problem of democracy. That is why the Commission urgently needs to come back with a legislative proposal on how to combat all forms of violence against women, including genital mutilation. When's it coming?

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, thank you very much to the Commissioner for being with us; I would also like to congratulate the rapporteur, the author of the question, because I think it is very relevant. My presence here, although obviously a minority one, shows that, as has been said, this is not a problem that interests only women, but should be of interest to the whole of society. We are very pleased that this question is being asked because again we find ourselves with a huge distance between the Commission's words and the facts. The Communication of 25 November 2013 is, as has been said, a very good Communication, but we are not seeing the concrete steps to make it a reality: we miss that timetable. Female genital mutilation is a crime, a crime that must be prosecuted wherever it is committed. It is therefore important that the Commission requires the countries of the European Union not yet to apply the principle of universal justice to do so, and also to persecute those who take young women to non-EU countries to carry out mutilation there, so that they know that they will not go unpunished. And, in that sense, female genital mutilation is, above all, an act of violence against women. When is the Commission going to get to work to draft this effective and general directive against gender-based violence that we are asking of it? But this is not just a legal problem: only 41 cases of female genital mutilation have reached European courts, while 500,000 victims and 180,000 are at risk. Many of the women who suffer it assume it as an inevitable custom—they don't even know it's a crime—and many others cannot come to court because of the pressures of their environment. We must empower women to report, so that they know that all European institutions are at their side. We must work on educational and integration programmes because, as Unicef reports say, poverty and marginalization are the keys to continue this practice in Europe. We need powerful outreach campaigns, policies responsible for immigration integration, and humanitarian asylum policies. We need that holistic approach that this Parliament has already asked for, and now it reiterates.

name: Louise BOURS
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, there are tens of thousands of cases of FGM in the UK and not one person has been brought to justice. It is the failed policy of multiculturalism which has given rise to this abomination across the UK. In the UK elected officials and representatives have turned a blind eye to this practice in order not to offend minority communities and avoid being labelled as racist. Lack of integration within these communities and a political class too afraid to speak out are allowing this practice to continue. It is these people who have let down the thousands of young girls and women butchered in the name of a backward cultural custom. This evil practice must end. Politicians and the justice system must have the courage to act. Protecting children has to take priority over zealous and outdated political correctness. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)).

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: blue-card question. – I agree with you that more must be done to tackle FGM, including in Europe. But why then did your party, UKIP, refuse to vote in favour of the European parliamentary resolution of December 2013 which strongly condemns FGM? UKIP I think would do better to put their anti-EU ideology aside and realise that working together sometimes is the best way to change the world for the better.

name: Louise BOURS
text: blue-card answer. – Well actually I was not here when that was tabled; I am a new MEP. But the Liberal Democrats have a great big load of guilt to take on their shoulders with their failed policy on multiculturalism and political correctness. So I think actually that that question from you is an absolute disgrace.

name: Vicky MAEIJER
text: Mr President, it will happen to you: you are 15 years old and because of some sick ritual, without medical necessity your external genitals are removed. Involuntary, forced. An encroachment on femininity. Female genital mutilation is a terrible phenomenon that must be dealt with harshly by sovereign countries. There are more than 125 million victims worldwide, half a million in the EU. In many countries, genital mutilation is punishable. This is also the case in the Netherlands. Yet my country has almost 28 000 circumcised women. Eighty percent of these women come from Muslim countries, such as Somalia, Egypt and Eritrea. With our open borders, we are not only importing hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants, but also a terrible phenomenon such as genital mutilation. We are not helping these women through politically correct chatter and the hollow phrases of this Commission. Anyone who really wants to put an end to genital mutilation will not escape the mention of islam's role in these misogynistic and barbaric practices. Stop mass immigration and the Islamisation of our continent.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: Madam President, from the People's Party we condemn the most extreme violation of human rights involved in female genital mutilation. Every six minutes a girl is the victim of this atrocity; 28 countries continue to practice mutilation. It is by no circumstances religion or custom or tradition. It's not culture or honor: it's violence, it's a crime. Martin Luther King said it's always a good time to do the right thing. Somali model and activist Waris Dirie decided to break the code of silence and tell the world of her own experience, when she was mutilated—at just three years old—by one of the elderly of the Midgaan clan, who performed on her the worst female genital mutilation a woman can suffer: infibulation. She was appointed, from that moment on, a UN spokesperson for this issue. On the wedding night, the husband grabs a knife or knife and cuts, before forcing his wife by force. If a woman is not ablation, she does not marry and is expelled from the village and treated like a prostitute. Families firmly believe that a woman has to submit to ablation to be pure. You have to remove and close later, as proof of virginity. These women are the backbone of the African continent. As a result of these mutilations, women have many psychological and physical diseases throughout their lives. There is a proverb in Somalia that says the last camel in the line walks as fast as the first. What happens to any of us and us undoubtedly affects others. That is why, Members, today we are asking the Commission for more than just political will to end female genital mutilation. We call for prevention, we call for more effective repression by Member States, awareness raising but, above all, eradication at the global level.

name: Julie WARD
text: Madam President, I have been moved by my encounters with the European campaigners on female genital mutilation (FGM) who have shown that by working together, including and supporting women in communities affected by the practice, we can begin to effect change. Campaigns have a lifespan but issues do not go away, so we must continue to speak out, together with civil society, in order to raise public awareness and move closer to the next goal – zero tolerance. A powerful way to do this is to encourage and support affected communities in bearing witness to their experiences. Through the telling of the stories of those who have experienced FGM we break the taboo and stigma which surround the ritual. Through sharing the testimonies of others who have been involved, such as health professionals, lawyers and community workers – men as well as women – we show how this is an issue that must be tackled at home as well as abroad. Zero tolerance regarding FGM must come about through more tolerance of open discussion of the practice, changing the language we use so that victims become right-holders whose rights we must uphold.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: When waris dirie's book Desert Flower came into my hands years ago, I confess, I was shocked. I've never heard of female circumcision before. Her autobiographical narrative reinforced my dismay. It was no fiction, it was a harsh reality. And this reality persists to this day. Even today, hundreds of thousands of young but also older girls are subjected to this barbaric, unprecedented procedure in the world every year. And apart from a kind of ritual habit, there is no support in religion, nor is it a procedure approved from a health point of view. Contrary. Many girls bleed to death during the procedure, the rest are suffering every day for life. They struggle not only with inflammation, but also with indescribable pain when simply urinating or menstruating. However, scars remain not only on the body, but also on the soul. It is therefore our duty to condemn this ritual mutilation and to call on other African countries, following the example of Ethiopia or Côte d'Ivoire, to ban female circumcision by law, even with severe punishment for the perpetrators. Since, unfortunately, these practices are also emerging in Europe, we must do everything we can to ensure that such interventions do not occur in our countries and to punish not only those who carry it out, but also parents who allow their daughter to be maimed.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: Madam President, Mrs Jourová, female genital mutilation is a brutal, cruel and intolerable practice. It is a global crime against human rights, with which we show zero tolerance. We do not accept unworthy invocations of custom, tradition, culture, private life or religion. Like rape, ablation is one of the most effective tools of organized terrorism to turn women's bodies into a weapon of war, and it is not a distant phenomenon: half a million girls have already been mutilated in our European Union. Mrs Jourová, today I would like to ask you for specific measures here: a European database, an action plan with sufficient budget and a defined timetable for its implementation, as well as the ratification of the Istanbul Convention by the Union, and the Latvian Presidency to prioritise it on its political agenda. To paraphrase Dr. Mukwege, our 2014 Sakharov Prize, "when a woman is mutilated, wherever, it is my daughter, my mother, my sister who is being mutilated."

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: Madam President, it is true and we all agree that genital mutilation is considered one of the most brutal practices and a violation of the human rights of girls and women. But it must also be said that it represents the most extreme form of patriarchal domination over the female body and perpetuates gender inequality and discrimination against women. Therefore, genital mutilation must be recognised as a form of gender-based persecution, covered by the UN Convention on the Status of Refugees, and the recommendations on refugee women of the United Nations High Commissioner must be followed, although, Commissioner, this will hardly be possible as long as there are countries, such as Spain , who practice hot returns, while other countries look the other way. This practice is an issue of concern to every woman and every man who believes in equality, dignity and justice for every human being. And there are no excuses here.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, since there are more women, I am also pleased that we are talking about this issue. Let us talk a little bit about the numbers of this barbarity, because it is barbarism. Amnesty International tells us that around 3 million women a year undergo female genital mutilation – that is about 8 000 a day and we are talking about 500 000 in the European Union. Many mutilations take place directly within the territory of the Union. Circumcision, cleavage, cauterization, infibulation: we are talking about physical side effects but, above all, psychophysical, moral effects, women to whom their sexuality is taken away, to which the soul is subtracted, in a certain sense. We are talking about barbarism. I therefore agree with Commissioner Jourová when he says that we must act in a preventive way and that the action plan can probably be a good thing, but we must certainly work on the right of asylum of those who are fleeing or those who want to be repatriated to those countries.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: Madam President, how can we fail to approve zero tolerance against female genital mutilation, these barbaric practices that are contrary to our cultures and our European civilisation? These atrocities are said to affect 175 million women and girls worldwide, but 500,000 in Europe, which is outrageous. The European Union has encouraged mass immigration without demanding law-abiding and assimilation, and advocated the establishment of different cultures and traditions within our countries. You are now talking about ensuring protection for victims through asylum procedures. But the consequence of such a measure will be to encourage, in the countries of origin, these atrocious practices by creating a new path to immigration. Contrary to this asylum policy, Member States must sanction these mutilations. They have a repressive arsenal in this area and this is within their exclusive competence. European action would therefore have no added value on this point.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Madam President, I would like to point out that there is no cultural, traditional or religious excuse that can justify female genital mutilation. We must do everything we can to put an end to these crimes. So I would like to emphasize five things.  Firstly, with regard to the Commission's communication adopted in November 2013, we all agree that the extreme urgency is the adoption of a timetable and a specific deadline for the implementation of the actions listed. Secondly, I stress the key role that the European Institute for Gender Equality must play in helping Member States develop specific indicators on FGM. Thirdly, on the external side of the policy to eradicate female genital mutilation, I draw your attention to the importance of perfect coherence and coordination between you, Commissioner, high representative, special representative on human rights and commissioners for development, humanitarian aid and migration. Three key words: coordination, exchange of information and complementary actions to give shape to the union's overall approach.  Fourthly, I think it is important to start thinking about the consideration of genital mutilation in migration policy. On the one hand, with regard to asylum applications and on the other hand, because we must also pay attention to girls from communities from emigrants in Europe and to the risk of being sent to their country of origin to undergo such mutilation. Finally, we must not fall into the trap of medical excision, which would be more acceptable: medicalized or not, this is a violation of human rights. Awareness campaigns must take this trend into account and above all be careful not to substitute evil for another evil.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: Madam President, the point here is that it does not matter whether the justification for female genital mutilation is with culture, tradition, custom or religion. It's a felony. An estimated 500,000 women have been mutilated. In other words, 500,000 crimes have been committed in Europe. We have about 200, 000 at risk of it happening. What are the benefits of treaties and laws that do not guarantee the safety of women who are at risk of being cut and amputated on European territory?  There are still medieval customs and traditions in Europe. Female genital mutilation is one of them. We still have a barbaric Europe, an apathetic Europe in the face of the numbers it cannot confirm. The Commissioner said she couldn't confirm the data. But if it's 500 or 500,000 women who are mutilated, does that make the problem smaller?  A year from now, we'll all be outraged by these numbers, unconfirmed numbers, but the rusty blades will continue to cut women. And I'm done, Madam President. If the European Union does not take concrete action... (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker)

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for I listen attentively to this discussion and am outraged and disgusted, because for the ninth time we have celebrated the World Day of Zero Tolerance for Female Genital Mutilation – the ninth time. And what is the data? The data is that 140 million women worldwide are mutilated, that two million women suffer every year because 6 000 women a day are mutilated and half a million in the European Union, in Europe. It is appalling that nowadays, in the 21st century, such sadistic practices occur. I have listened to your speech and, unfortunately, I do not find specifics in it. We can talk, we can talk, and nothing comes of it. Women suffer. Who will reprimand them if we do not effectively reprimand their lives today? Commissioner, what will be the concrete steps? When will a road map be drawn up to eliminate this hideous practice?

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I believe that we should put our debate in the right context. The subject is not the Christian quality or not of Europe, the theme is not to deal with a tragedy like this by touching on real racist accents, as I have also heard this evening. The theme is whether we place women's freedom, women's self-determination, the issue of the inviolability of their bodies at the basis of our idea of Europe, if we feel the inescapable need to stop male violence against women, which is exercised in as many forms as there are patriarchal domination. We know that we can no longer wait, we can no longer wait for the European Union to accede to the Istanbul Convention and for a concrete commitment to be made which will also call for ratification by the Member States. There is a lack of statistical data. Eurostat, which provides statistics on everything, has no clear idea of the contours of the problem in Europe. I believe that on a day like today, when we mourn other victims in the Mediterranean, we really should ask ourselves the question of the law... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: Madam President, I was here a year ago commending the Commission communication on elimination of female genital mutilation. After one year, this barbaric practice still affects millions of girls around the world and in Europe. We are talking about child abuse. It is a crime and it should be treated as a crime. The time has come for the Member States to enforce the laws that criminalise FGM. Effective prosecution and conviction of the guilty parents and the cutters are essential for prevention. To eradicate FGM in Europe we need to eradicate impunity in Europe. We also have a responsibility in our external action to support information, awareness-raising, education on child rights and on the medical risks of this barbaric practice that causes psychological and physical damage to the girls. We need also to support the courageous women who dare to speak out and to stand up against long-standing tradition. For example, in Senegal, there is outstanding work by an NGO, Tostan, which is empowering local women to themselves eradicate FGM in their own community.  To be effective on the ground we need to show respect for culture, religion and tradition, but we can never ever accept that violence against children is justified by culture, tradition or religion. So, Commission, please bring action into your good recommendation, with concrete measures.

name: Jens NILSSON
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul Female genital mutilation, which is a multi-thousand-year-old custom, is a terrible practice that must stop – and it is zero tolerance that applies. While society is being modernised, this scrip remains for millions of women around the world, and talking about genital mutilation remains a major taboo, especially in areas where it is commonplace.  Witnesses – affected women – tell us that the problem is not just that bodily stitched together, but that at the same time it feels like someone is singing your mouth. A global fight against genital mutilation must therefore actively work to raise awareness of the risks of the procedure, but also through a pronounced feminist foreign policy that highlights women's oppression in all the ways in which they occur. The Social Democratic government in Sweden, led by Margot Wallström, has worked on the basis of a pronounced feminist foreign policy. This must continue and we must ensure that women throughout the world are supported.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: Madam President, we all agree here that FGM is one of the most barbaric forms of exerting control over a woman’s sexuality and therefore over her whole life. The question today is really what we can do about it here in Europe. I think that it is a marvellous thing that we are all gathered together talking about the way forward and it is time that we actually got on with it. Prosecution rates are far too low. We need to share best practice; we need to improve the enforcement of the law. We must have successful prosecutions to show the success of our policy. Catherine Bearder talked a little bit about the UK and the latest attempts at a prosecution – in fact the first attempt at prosecution, and this is despite GBP 1.4 million being allocated by the Prime Minister a year ago to provide information through the NHS. A doctor has been effectively acquitted for not having been told about FGM, so it is vitally important that we get on with that information campaign.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: Madam President, female genital mutilation is undoubtedly one of the most heinous forms of violence against women. It is a serious violation of their rights and children's rights as well, causing irreparable injuries to their physical, sexual and psychological health, and even causing death. This is the most brutal form of alienation of women in patriarchal systems, and it is a brutal alienation that also happens inanely.  But in addition to the improvement of criminal frameworks and their applicability of this, the fight against this obscurantism cannot be separated from the wider struggle for the protection and strengthening of women's sexual and reproductive rights, access to sex education, improvement of maternal and child health – matters in which there are now unacceptable regressions due to the European Union's so protected macroeconomic coordination , with all that it entails. We are talking about situations that occur in our countries and therefore these women too should be entitled to these rights.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it was 2006 when this Parliament, for the first time, raised the urgent need to address the issue of FGM from a European perspective, a perspective based on the awareness that, although this phenomenon is rooted in cultures other than our own, many of the women forced to live with the devastating consequences of these practices or even in the process of being subjected to these practices live within the Community borders. Commissioner, in November 2013, the institution that you represent here today listed a series of actions aimed at combating this barbaric phenomenon. However, the failure to set precise deadlines for their implementation makes it difficult to assess their real effectiveness and, therefore, the time has come to make a great effort. Member States' support for the application of national legislation prohibiting this practice must be combined with support for the real victims. We must also work to support the communities and professionals involved in this area. If in February we celebrated the International Day against FGM, if we want this anniversary to acquire concrete significance and if we really want to contribute to the eradication of this phenomenon, it is time for reflection time to leave room for action.

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: Madam President, I note that few of us have spoken this evening on the serious scourge of female genital mutilation. It's serious and it's a shame. Let us get out of the preconceived ideas: this subject must also concern men, when we attack a whole section of humanity. Let's focus on the words "female genital mutilation." What is it about? It means that women are mutilated, hurt, sometimes killed. These are continuous tortures. These mutilations reflect a deep-rooted inequality between men and women. As you said, this problem is not just an African problem, it also affects Europe. What should be done? From now on, we must raise awareness and, above all, promote a change in attitudes, encourage the ratification of the Istanbul Convention. We must also think about an asylum system that would take into account this serious scourge and the lack of condemnation in some countries. These women are not victims, they are fighters, as Dr. Mukwege said. The fight is with them that we must lead it.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: Madam President, a picture is worth a thousand words. And I'm speechless in front of this picture of a woman holding the knife with which she practices the crime of genital mutilation, because intentionally damaging a woman's sex organs is a crime. I am disgusted that many men who live culturally with this barbarity recognize that they like the way women who have been mutilated walk. How can anything caused by pain be exciting for anyone? This attitude of submission of the woman causes the girls to be sacrificed to find a husband and many parents support her. I transcribe the testimony of one of them: "I was nine years old. My parents told me to get in the car, we were going to a party. I was surprised my brothers didn't come. I only remember a woman with a knife and my father carrying me in his arms after torture." This ablation occurred in Spain in 1993, but most mutilations are carried out in countries of origin; For this reason, Spain has a protocol of health action in which parents undertake not to mutilate their daughters. I believe that these protocols should be adopted throughout the Union. We urgently need legal and financial instruments to protect victims. Beliefs have to be torn down and we have to do everything in our power to bury this knife that mutilates the body and soul of so many girls.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Female genital mutilation reflects the deep-rooted and often even the most violent form of discrimination against women in some regions of the world, and violates their right to health, safety, body integrity, and the right not to be tortured in the most cruel way. Millions of girls and women living in the world today have been subjected to this violent crime, and this is not just an external problem. And in Europe, there are about half a million women who have suffered genital mutilation, and only 41 criminal cases have been brought against this crime across Europe, according to the Institute for Gender Equality. We need to raise awareness and awareness of this form of violence against women in our societies.  What exactly does the European Union have to do? First of all, to apply effective criminal responsibility, to strengthen the network of preventive measures, from well-prepared medical professionals to social and educational staff. Commissioner, we look forward to taking concrete action and active work in this area.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Madam President, female genital mutilation has been subjected to about 140 million women and girls worldwide. We have also heard as many as 500,000 within the European Union. And often the motives for female genital mutilation are cultural in nature, but the right to culture must be limited if it is at the expense of other human rights, which in the case of female genital mutilation is indisputable. Female genital mutilation therefore constitutes an infringement of the right to freedom, security, dignity, the right of women and girls to health, the right to freedom from torture and in cases where mutilation is a consequence of death, of course, and the fundamental right to life. All these rights, especially the right to life, from which all other rights derive must be protected and preserved in order to truly lead the right fight against such harmful traditional customs that are implemented in certain countries.  Genital mutilation is now carried out in at least 28 countries in Africa, the Middle East, Asia - all of these are recipient countries of international development aid and therefore we must also use our development policy as a tool in the fight against female and girls' genital mutilation, as development policy should be used to combat all other violations of basic human rights. Therefore, from the point of view of a member of the Development Committee, I would like to ask the Commissioner to what extent she is cooperating with Commissioner Mimica on this issue.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, only a few days ago, on the UN World Day, the World Health Organisation released terrible numbers of barbaric and cruel practice. An estimated 135 million girls worldwide suffer from genital mutilation. In some Horn of Africa states, such as Somalia and Eritrea, but also in Egypt and Guinea, the phenomenon affects about 90% of the female population. However, the victims are also in our Europe, in my Italy, where up-to-date estimates tell us that at least 40 000 women are still subjected to the violent practice of FGM, which deprives them of sexual pleasure, makes them the object and not an individual, also attacking their lives. We must fight for strict legislation that prohibits these practices, provides for sanctions and adequate assistance for victims. We must promote a targeted information campaign aimed at those who justify a tribal practice with cultural and religious reasons. We support Amnesty International's appeal and also give courage to the women who save their girls.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. You have now heard more or less a message of the same, whether we are from right-wing or left-wing groups, from so many of us. We are committed to telling each other here as Members that FGM is inhumane, that FGM is a crime. And, that is the conclusion now, we all share with each other that the European Union should not only discuss in this context, but that it should act. Information campaigns have been mentioned. However, it is particularly important to me not only to mention, but to actively demand that FGM should be a reason for asylum. I think it has been repeated by many people, but take it with you that we, as Members of the European Parliament, are committed to this and, in some cases, say the same thing in a more or less in many voices.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Madam President, genital mutilation is usually a girl at a very early age represent a deliberately induced suffering whose consequences are very severe. The current extreme pain and shock of mutilation, infections and complications in wound healing, complications in pregnancy and childbirth and frequent cases of death are just some of the consequences of this brutal and inhumane act.  The practice of genital mutilation seriously offends the dignity and life of women around the world, and since they are mostly girls, it is also a gross violation of human and children's rights. I am concerned, because of flawed laws and sketchy enforcement measures, girls are being mutilated in our countries within the borders of the European Union or taken to their parents' home countries. Ways should be found so that girls, victims of genital mutilation, do not become victims for the second time when they are left without parental care after the prosecution of their parents.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: Madam President, I congratulate the European Commission on the action plan and the measures set out here today. It is almost unbelievable that in the 21st century there is still a need to talk about it. Collectively, we have to ask ourselves how we got here, how it is possible for such an aberrant practice to take place in our world and particularly in Europe. Even in my country, recent reports point to dozens of cases of female genital mutilation. They're old cases, but they exist. One case would be too much, but we are talking about tens of thousands across Europe.  In addition to all the instruments available to the International European Institutions and national institutions, I believe that the bet will also have to be made on education. Educational efforts that are made around the world must be contributed to the educational efforts that are being made around the world and especially to direct educational campaigns to communities where there is a greater risk of the practice happening.  From what has been announced today, I see that the Commission proposes to play a particularly active role in so that the Convention for the Prevention and Combating of Violence against Women recognised by the Istanbul Convention is implemented, regardless of the territory in which crime succeeds.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the report drawn up in 2013 by the European Institute for Gender Equality concludes that female genital mutilation, this modern barbarity, is a global phenomenon. The report finds that there are victims or potential victims in at least 13 European Union countries, including Germany, France and the United Kingdom. Female genital mutilation is a serious violation of human rights, and therefore the risk of being subjected to this practice should be a valid reason for granting asylum or humanitarian protection. Finally, the eradication of mutilation will require a series of actions focusing on data collection, prevention, protection of girls at risk, the prosecution of perpetrators and the provision of services for victims.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Mr President, dear friends, dear fellow combatants, I think we have heard a lot of horror stories here tonight. I just regret that there are so few people here. During our debate here tonight, 420 young girls around the world were circumcised, with a blunt knife, with a stone, bleeding to death. And we are only here with about 30 to talk about this. I especially regret the fact that there are so few men here. Because dear men, women also have the right to enjoy sex. That must be the battle. If you look at the inequality that we are in here in the chamber, we know that the battle is far from over, we know that we have to convince the men in this world to go to war. We in the ALDE Group will already be fighting. I've seen many associates here. Know that we will have a lot to do before we eliminate these atrocities.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Mutilation of the human body is condemnable. And while I have great respect for a person's religious feelings and beliefs, I must stress that it is not commanded by any of the world's religions or by Islam. I do not remember exactly how many times in the last ten years we have discussed this topic in the European Parliament. We organised conferences and adopted resolutions. However, this debate has shown that we have not come far. My opposition to female circumcision is very strong. I support all the instruments and policies that will make it possible to increase prevention, while penally affecting everyone who participates in this exercise. However, I do not agree that trying to put an end to this barbaric custom should become a pretext for pressuring for the swift ratification of the 2010 Istanbul Convention. This is entirely within the competence of the Member States and the Commission has no right to put any pressure on them in this regard.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Madam President, as a human being and a doctor, I am appalled by this practice. I am committed to effective and swift measures, to combat this particularly intimidated form of violation of women's rights. First of all I mean the effective criminalization of such activities, taking into account the principle of exteritoriality.  Half a million victims of genital mutilation live in the European Union as said, with only 41 cases of this kind recorded in courts in 11 Member States. This is truly embarrassing for European society. Also, we can't fight a problem we don't know. It is necessary to make a unique record of all aspects of genital mutilation and educate the staff engaged in this.  In particular, asylum applications for victims of mutilation and those in direct danger should be expedited. The strategy adopted by the European Commission is insufficient, as it does not set clear deadlines. Only an expensive list of good wishes remains, not in economic terms, as the Commission likes to point out, but in people's lives.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Mr. President, I absolutely support the adoption of a strict legislative framework that would end the application of this hassly practice on the territory of the Member States of the European Union. But I am aware in advance that we will also have a problem with the best possible legislation, and this problem is a practical application. It will require great determination from Member States, many of which are fighting this practice unsuccessfully on their territory for the time being. Stopping female genital mutilation in the European Union as a policy of public health importance must not be an isolated measure, but part of a broader policy of integrating minority groups into European societies. We must not forget that the problem of adapting the integration of these groups is the reason why they very often prefer the custom from the state of their origin in relation to the laws of their new homeland.  Member States here will finally have to draw the line and make it clear that despite the cultural and religious heterogeneity of modern Europe, no one is above the law.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: Madam President, this problem needs a multidisciplinary response in the field of education, health and social services. We need specific training for professionals and a lot of commitment, because we are faced with a barbaric, violent, inhumane practice that remains supported by the prejudices, lack of information and domination that women still suffer in too many countries. It is not an opinionable issue: it is an obligation that we all believe people have only rights that are inalienable. We advocate coordinated action that focuses on identifying risk, convincing families that they are able to turn a vacation in their home country into a return to the past for their daughters. We need to inform, convince and offer psychosanitary solutions to victims, because fortunately mutilation is now reversible. And this needs street action from the local level, but we need European support for global action. That is why, Commissioner, what support do you find in the College of Commissioners for your initiatives?

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the figures on the intolerable practices of female genital mutilation are still alarming both in third countries and in the Union. They are also partial data, which makes it even more difficult to perfect prevention strategies and targeted interventions to protect current and potential victims. The sanctioning reaction is almost non-existent, all too often due to the lack of reporting by the victims. For minors, there is also a risk of secondary victimisation in the event of removal from their parents as a result of conviction. The list of actions presented here today by the Commissioner to eradicate this phenomenon is certainly significant, but it must be transformed into concrete actions, appropriate legislation, awareness-raising campaigns and an acceleration of cultural progress inside and outside Europe, aimed at combating, but above all preventing, this and all other forms of violence against women and girls.

name: Mary HONEYBALL
text: Madam President, I am speaking in this debate as someone who represents a city where there are communities where female genital mutilation (FGM) takes place. It is absolutely appalling and barbaric and I totally agree with everything everyone has said about female genital mutilation, but just going out there and trying to enforce law does not work. There have been no successful prosecutions in the UK despite the fact that FGM has been a crime for some years. France has been a bit more successful. However, I think that what we need to do is really encourage the communities themselves to understand that this practice is wrong, and to understand those women, and they are mainly young women, who are willing to come forward. I think a lot more support is needed, and if the EU and the Commission come up with some plan for finance and support for those communities that would be really helpful.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Membre de la Commission. - Ladies and gentlemen, please believe that I am as outraged and shocked as you are by the fact that this practice persists in such huge numbers not only outside Europe, but also in Europe. I had only recently become acquainted with these figures, and I really did not know that this barbaric practice was so ingrained in our continent. I have looked at all the possible instruments that Europe has and the instruments that the Member States have, and I have to say that there is legislation on the part of the Member States that gives the possibility of prosecuting this practice when this particular method of mutilation is no longer directly mentioned in the Criminal Code, then there is always a criminal offence, which is a serious injury with lasting consequences, which is highly penalised in all criminal law-abiding European countries. , so I was really surprised at how little the legal possibility of prosecuting this barbaric crime is being used.  We're talking about zero tolerance for female circumcision. And yet, when we talk about zero tolerance of crime, it's as if we feel that it's self-evident. Zero tolerance for crime is something that's not being discussed. When we talk about zero tolerance for female genital mutilation, I have come up with arguments like – well, but it is a tradition – in the consultation on this matter. I mean, it's something that's been going on for centuries, and it can't just be eradicated. I will be the first to be in favor of preserving cultural traditions and the multit00 of cultures, but not for preserving a tradition that is in stark contrast to the law that has a place in the EU. So I say again, there are those instruments here, both the criminal law and the asylum directive that we are monitoring, which gives the Member States a direct obligation to deal with vulnerable groups of those who come to Europe to seek asylum, and specifically mentions the concern or attention directed at women and women who are at risk of this practice. So we have legislation in place. I think that the EU should – however it has been said here that we do not have the right to pressure the Member States – urge the Member States to make better use of the legal instruments that already exist and not to delay punishing this practice.  What we're missing is data. It also said here that we can't fight hard enough and convincingly enough with something that we don't really know how extensive it is and that we don't have mapped out. I could read here, and I do not want to delay, the statistics that we have from the Member States where this problem is very serious. I'm already surprised that we have the latest data from 2007 somewhere. This means that on the one hand we do not have fresh data, even this I do not understand why we are not trying to better map the problem and fresher data. And on the other hand, we have numbers that are probably just estimates, because, as I was warned, it's really hard to collect that data. So it is up to us to focus on this in cooperation with EIGE, and you know that I spoke here some time ago about the fact that we are working on a new strategy for gender equality and that an important chapter here will be a chapter on combating violence against women. And here we will also be dealing with the preparation or, in fact, the creation of an action plan that will bring about concrete steps that we will take. In my experience, however, the action plan will not be reliable enough if we do not have a reliable data base. So this is where we need to start, and like I said at the beginning, we're already working on it. I would end up at the moment, I think that this question or this problem will be repeated here periodically, because it is indeed a very serious problem, and I will be available not only here in plenary, but also in the meantime, to give information on how the Commission is acting. I understand all of you who are calling for concrete steps and concrete action.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. It is clearly inconceivable that such a debate on female genital mutilation could take place in our present society, since this barbaric practice should not even exist. Yet the figures are damning: 175 million women and girls worldwide suffer these atrocities and worse, 500,000 in Europe alone.  Beyond fine speeches and political incantations, it is clear that this problem deserves zero tolerance. Unfortunately, successive policies of the Union and the governments of the Member States have failed to contain this practice, since they refuse to face reality. The mass immigration wanted by Brussels, without any demand for any respect for the laws or assimilation, encourages the continuation of these practices on our soil because of different traditions, cultures or religions... And the sad fact is that in Europe, half a million women are subjected to genital mutilation and Member States must immediately sanction these acts, since they are the only ones competent in this area. Finally, only a genuine policy of assimilation (not integration) will allow all citizens to live in respect of the fundamental values of our civilization.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. – We urge the Commission to take concrete steps in order to eradicate the practice of Female Genital Mutilation (FGM) in the European Union. Around 120 million women and young girls in the world have been the victims of such horrible mutilations. It is time now that all women at risk of FGM in the EU should be protected, as it is recognised as a violation of human rights of girls and women. This practice brings no health benefits and only harms the human body, carrying long-term consequences and health risks. That is why asylum must be granted to those at risk from FGM and we must enact legislation prohibiting FGM. Preventive measures to stop violence against women and girls are also vital and we should promote and support action taken at the individual Member State level.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. – Female genital mutilation is now one of the most barbaric violations of human rights and gender equality. An estimated 140 million women and girls have been victims of female genital mutilation, mostly in Africa and the Middle East. But this is not just a problem of societies outside our Western world. Quite the contrary! This act of barbarism, which inflicts atrocious harm on women and young girls, has already made 500,000 victims in the EU alone, with victims, or potential victims, in at least 13 EU countries! It is urgent to attack it quickly and effectively, and both the Commission and the Member States must make every effort to eradicate it, both ex ante, in information and preventive measures to support potential victims and through dissuasive criminal frameworks, as well as at a later stage, in identifying cases, punishing offenders and monitoring victims. It is not in many cases to know how the Commission intends to link the protection of asylum seekers on the grounds of genital mutilation with the Asylum Procedures Directive.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. – Female genital mutilation is a violation of the human rights of women and girls, and constitutes an extreme form of discrimination and violence against women. It violates the rights to health, safety and physical integrity, unless subjected to torture and cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment, to enjoy sexuality itself, and even the right to life when the victim of ablation dies. Currently 140 million women and girls worldwide suffer the consequences of FGM (500 000 in the EU). The eradication of FGM should be a priority on the post-2015 development agenda and should be included in the EU's foreign and asylum policy. States, with the help of international institutions and civil society organizations, should develop, support and implement prevention and combat strategies that include the training of medical personnel, social workers and local and religious leaders. They must also adopt strict laws that are firmly enforced and provide for sanctions against the culprits. Tradition cannot be justified: respect for traditions and cultures has as its impassable limit respect for human rights.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. – Female genital mutilation is a violation of the human rights of women and girls, and constitutes an extreme form of discrimination and violence against women. It violates the rights to health, safety and physical integrity, unless subjected to torture and cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment, to enjoy sexuality itself, and even the right to life when the victim of ablation dies. Currently 140 million women and girls worldwide suffer the consequences of FGM (500 000 in the EU). The eradication of FGM should be a priority on the post-2015 development agenda and should be included in the EU's foreign and asylum policy. States, with the help of international institutions and civil society organizations, should develop, support and implement prevention and combat strategies that include the training of medical personnel, social workers and local and religious leaders. They must also adopt strict laws that are firmly enforced and provide for sanctions against the culprits. Tradition cannot be justified: respect for traditions and cultures has as its impassable limit respect for human rights.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Statistics show that there are 500 000 women and girls living in Europe who have experienced genital mutilation and 180 000 girls and women are at risk. Genital mutilation is a particularly cruel, deeply rooted form of violence against women and girls in certain traditions and religions. It violates fundamental human rights and the principle of equality between women and men in the most radical and brutal form. The opposition to female and female genital mutilation is also reflected in Article 38 of the Council of Europe Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence, which has already been ratified by eight EU countries and a further 14 Member States have signed it and are in the process of being ratified. They also include Poland, which on 6 February this year approved the law on the ratification of the Convention in the lower house of Parliament. The Convention prohibits the justification of violence by morality, tradition or religion (Article 42), which is still the case in the modern world: women are stoned and buried alive for alleged betrayals, raped with impunity, sold, enslaved. The end of violence against women is made possible by recognising and disseminating the principle of equality between women and men, as promoted by the Convention. Therefore, the EU should accede to this agreement as soon as possible, as a party, in order to encourage Member States to speed up work on its ratification.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. – Given that 3,000,000 girls and women are genitally mutilated every year – around 8,000 a day – the incidents of female genital mutilation must be condemned in the strongest possible terms. Female genital mutilation is a serious violation of women's human rights, causing serious health and psychological damage. In addition, FGM violates the right to health, safety and physical integrity and violates the right to freedom and torture. Circumcision can even lead to the death of the women concerned, as these usually take place in extremely unhygienic conditions. It is estimated that 150,000,000 women worldwide are currently suffering from the effects of FGM. The main distribution areas are mainly Africa, countries of Asia and the Middle East. In Egypt, Guinea or Somalia, for example, about 98% of women are affected by FGM. In many countries where female genital mutilation is commonplace, despite laws against FGM, there are few convictions and trials. Very rarely are legal action taken against violations of the law. Female genital mutilation, however, is no longer an exclusively "African phenomenon". There are about 5,000,000 African immigrantwomen registered in the EU countries, many of whom come from FGM-practicing countries. It is estimated that around 8,000 girls and women in Austria are at risk of FGM; approx.2,000 are already circumcised. FGM or consent to the intervention is a criminal offence in Austria under the Criminal Law Amendment Act 2001.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. – Female circumcision is a brutal violation of the human rights of millions of women and girls around the world. It is right that this problem is commemorated every year on 6 February by the International Day of Zero Tolerance against Female Genital Mutilation. However, it is not acceptable for the European fight against this crackdown, which entails health risks and incredible suffering, to continue to take the form of written resolutions. Who statistics showing partial or complete circumcision in some 500 000 women and girls living in Europe and more than 125 million worldwide also demonstrate the need to intervene actively. Female circumcision does not bring any health benefits. On the contrary, it causes protracted trouble and, in some cases, death. The idea that this procedure is performed on unsuspecting underage girls, who subsequently have to cope with health problems and psychological trauma, is absolutely shocking. Therefore, we cannot afford to accept this practice here, even in third countries. It is appropriate to crack down on the trend of its medication and the export of GIRLS from the EU to developing countries in order to do so. I insist that the Commission and individual Member States do more to combat female circumcision not only on their territory, but also in developing countries, especially this year, which is dedicated precisely to development aid and cooperation.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. – Female genital mutilation is a violation of the human rights of women and girls, and constitutes an extreme form of discrimination and violence against women. It violates the rights to health, safety and physical integrity, unless subjected to torture and cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment, to enjoy sexuality itself, and even the right to life when the victim of ablation dies. Currently 140 million women and girls worldwide suffer the consequences of FGM (500 000 in the EU). The eradication of FGM should be a priority on the post-2015 development agenda and should be included in the EU's foreign and asylum policy. States, with the help of international institutions and civil society organizations, should develop, support and implement prevention and combat strategies that include the training of medical personnel, social workers and local and religious leaders. They must also adopt strict laws that are firmly enforced and provide for sanctions against the culprits. Tradition cannot be justified: respect for traditions and cultures has as its impassable limit respect for human rights.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. On Tuesday, in debate at the plenary session, the European Parliament will present its recommendations to the Commission to stop excisions on European soil. An estimated 120,000 women were at risk for female genital mutilation in Europe in 2015. On the one hand, we call for the protection of asylum seekers who are victims of excision or from countries where their children could be circumcised. We also call for a real information campaign to be put in place for doctors to contact the authorities if they have sufficient presumptions of female circumcision, as is already the case when children are subjected to domestic violence. Nearly 60,000 female circumcisions in France and Great Britain, 30,000 in Italy or the Netherlands, more than 13,000 in Belgium: female circumcision has also become a European reality. According to European projections, 120,000 girls are expected to join the list of victims in the coming months on our soil. To explain this act in the name of custom or respect for cultural differences, as is all too often the case, is an aberration. It is a practice likened to violence against children that no state in Europe, nor in the world, can admit.
