name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Rapporteur. - (FI) Mr President, we are now dealing with eight reports on the accession of eight different countries to the Hague Convention on Child Abduction, which is fully entitled-called the Hague Convention on International Child Abduction. These countries are Albania, Andorra, Armenia, Gabon, Morocco, Russia, Seychelles and Singapore. To date, a total of 93 countries have acceded to the Convention, including all EU Member States. The entry into force of the Hague Child Abduction Convention between EU Member States and the new States Parties has been delayed. The progress of the case awaited a ruling by the Court of Justice of the EU on whether the acceptance of the accession of the new States Parties falls within the competence of the EU or the Member States. In October 2014, the court ruled. The adoption of the accession of a third State to the Hague Convention in question falls within the exclusive competence of the European Union. Child abduction is a violation of human rights. The UN Convention on the Rights of the Child guarantees that a child has the right, in principle, to live with his or her parents if he or she is good and safe to be with them. A child living separately from their parents has the right to meet and keep in regular contact with both parents. A meeting can only be prevented if it is against the best interests of the child.  What, then, are the legal means to find a solution to child abducting? The Hague Child Abduction Convention aims to implement these rights of the child. It contains the procedures for resolving cases of child abduction between States Parties.  Today, more and more couples come from different countries. More and more children therefore have roots in more than just one country. That's when problems can arise if couples divorce. Unfortunately, increasingly, this can lead to the child being abducted to the other parent's home country instead of the parents agreeing on custody of the child. The number of such international cases of child abduction has been steadily increasing. According to statistics, there are around 1 000 cases a year in the EU, if not more. The Hague Child Abduction Convention is therefore important because it provides legal and operational means of resolving cases of child abduction. The accession of new states to the Child Abduction Convention means that in future there will be permanent arrangements between EU Member States and these third countries to resolve cases of child abduction. The main principle of the Agreement is that the competent authorities of the States take immediate action to return the child to the State of residence. Only after the child is in his or her country of residence will the court go to court to deal with parental disputes, such as the question of custody. In this way, the Child Abduction Convention is also likely to prevent cross-border child abduction. But ratification alone will not solve child abductions. However, accession alone or formal ratification alone will not solve the issue. Each Contracting State shall define a central authority to coordinate the resolution of child abduction cases in the state concerned and to guide the implementation of the Agreement. The effective application of the Agreement requires the development of central authority activities and close cooperation between the authorities. But the EU can contribute to how cooperation on these issues starts. For its part, the Commission could examine whether there are development needs in the legislation or functioning and capacity of the new State which acceded to the agreement. The specific needs of each country must be taken into account, especially in the case of so-called developing countries. Finally, I would like to say that the entry into force of the Child Abduction Convention between the EU and the new States Parties requires that, after the European Parliament, the Council of Ministers approves the accession of the new states and that the Member States give their assent to this. I would ask you, ladies and gentlemen, to vote in favour of the reports tomorrow so that this agreement, which will improve children's rights in concrete terms, will also enter into force as soon as possible between the EU and these eight new States Parties.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, honourable Members, child abductions are another heart-breaking topic of today’s session here and I know that this matter is of special interest to many of you concerned by specific cases that desperate parents bring to your attention. Like you, I want justice to be served and, within the limits of my competences, children in the EU to be better protected.  The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an important international legal instrument. Its aim is to provide a system of cooperation between the central authorities and a rapid procedure for the return of an abducted child to the country of the child’s habitual residence. Altogether, 93 countries, as Ms Hautala has said here, are already parties to this Convention. All EU Member States have joined the Child Abduction Convention. The EU is not a party to the Convention but has incorporated its principles in binding European legislation, which is the Brussels II Regulation. It is in the EU’s interest to maintain a common legal framework with third states in order to solve international child abduction cases and guarantee legal certainty and speedy proceedings for EU citizens involved in these kinds of sensitive disputes. In December 2011, taking the view that the question of the international abduction of children fell within the exclusive external competence of the EU, the Commission adopted proposals for accession acceptance for eight third-country states. Contrary to the Commission’s and Parliament’s views, within the Council most of the representatives of the Member States considered the Council to be under no legal obligation to adopt those proposals. As a result, the Council did not adopt the proposals.  Last October the European Court of Justice confirmed that the exclusive competence of the European Union encompasses the acceptance of the accession of a third state to the 1980 Hague Convention. It is now time to finalise this process without further delay. The Council needs to take a decision on each of the proposals in unanimity. The negotiations are quite challenging but we are dealing with serious matters of child protection. We therefore have a duty to find a solution to this. I will use my contacts with Member States to advance this process as much as possible. I would like to thank the rapporteur Ms Hautala and the Committee on Legal Affairs (JURI) for their constant support for the Commission’s initiative. We share the same determination to protect children and resolve abduction cases quickly. I am convinced that a robust EU presence in the external field is of paramount important in this regard.

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Honourable Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. How many times do we hear that the best interests of the child are the highest law, that we must do everything we can to ensure that our youngest generation, that is, our future, really, has the best possible living and development conditions. The brutality of everyday events shows that we still need to make new efforts to protect these children. With all the greater discomfort, I inform you that the two-year period of work on these reports is not our pride. The competence dispute took so long. Fortunately, it has been overcome, and today we can say that the next eight countries will accede to the Hague Convention, which we are pleased about, because it is an extremely important instrument governing relations between the Member States of the European Union and third countries in view of such an important problem as the abdument of children.  But we must remember one more thing: that all kinds of rules should be extremely simple and clear – so that everyone understands them. Moreover, they should also be flexible – so as to adapt them to the child's situation, so that it is always the best interests of the child that we talk about so often that is indeed the highest command for us and comes first. Thank you very much for mentioning the Brussels II Regulation. I have a great request to you. We expect the Committee on Legal Remedies to come forward with a proposal to review the functioning of the Brussels II Regulation, because there are many problems that have not been solved and which are extremely important in terms of cross-border childcare and ensuring that each parent, as well as the child, has the opportunity to interact with each other.

name: Mary HONEYBALL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, of course we must do everything we possibly can to protect children, and I totally agree with the rapporteur that we should support her report and support the accession of these eight countries to the Hague Convention. However, I would just sound a note of warning because it is not quite as straightforward as that. We have some concerns over these eight countries, and the EU itself does not have any means of assessing how well these countries may do in the future. Some EU Member States have expressed concerns about that, including, I have to say, the UK. We have a real duty to look at this and to answer some of the questions raised, and we should continue to monitor what goes on. Children who have been abducted in cross-border situations should, of course, be given a higher standard of care and we must make sure that happens. We must also make sure that, wherever possible, they are reunited with their families. It is not acceptable for children who have already suffered a lot to go through further traumas and suffering, which could be avoided, when they are returned to their habitual country of residence. There is a lot here that needs to be thought about in terms of protecting children. That is why we must make sure that some of these eight countries, about which we have concerns, are monitored, that we keep in touch with what is going on, that reports are submitted to Parliament, and that the Commission really does follow up what is going on. It is very important we get this one right. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I agree that the Hague Convention is very necessary, that the protection of children's rights is paramount, but do you share my opinion – and I am meeting with this opinion and it is reported to me by voters in my homeland in Poland – that very often national courts rule callously on the basis of the Hague Convention to issue a child's father who does not know the language of the father's family?

name: Mary HONEYBALL
text: blue-card answer. – I think this is a very complicated issue and that is just one part of it. What we must do, always, is make sure that the interests of the child come first.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, honourable Members, Commissioner, the extension of interstate cooperation with regard to the protection of children's rights is imperative. Each society must, with greater care and with a complex of measures, protect the rights of persons who, by virtue of circumstances, physiology or the law, have limited legal capacity (minors).  Therefore, we cannot help but welcome the accession of a number of Member States of the European Union to the 1980 Hague Convention. This is an important step and it will certainly be positively appreciated in the area of international law.  I would like to note that crimes against children unfortunately retain the same high values. One part of the kidnappings is actually an initial stage of the composite crime of "trafficking". It is no secret that thousands of children in Europe are trafficked and criminally exploited. In this sense, I believe that in the future we must respond as an institution to these challenges and put an end to this dirty business.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, I am pleased that 93 countries have already joined the Hague Convention. I regret that only 93 countries have adhered to this convention. I am particularly pleased that all the Member States of the Union have adhered to this Convention and have made the best interests of the child in a central objective. The best interests of the child is a fundamental value of the legal order of the rule of law, of the democratic legal order.  It is necessary that the child reoccupy the center of concerns and not be used as a throwing weapon between disheartuped couples. No anti-legal action can generate rights, it can even generate legitimate legal expectations. That's why I say, finally, that the speed of action in this process is essential... (The speaker agrees to answer a question under the "blue card" procedure in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. "At this late hour, I try very fast, and although I ask this to the previous speaker, I could have asked others. Do you and your group agree that the illegal abduction of children will be retaliated against by much, much stricter criminal law measures?

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – Yes, of course, although I also recognise that it is often not so much the sanction that solves the problem, but it is above all prevention. But that no situation, no anti-legal action, can generate rights or even legitimate expectations. Therefore, the elements that act against the law must be sanctioned, and the first sanction is to remove the effects of its anti-legal action.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Commissioner, with regard to international child protection, in my view, the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is perhaps the most important and comprehensive document. Previous practice shows that when states that adhere to the Convention comply with its provisions, correctly apply its meaning and interpretation, children's problems are relatively successful. Since the statistics show an increasing trend in cases of child abduction abroad without the consent of the other parent, I consider it very important to support the accession of eight other non-EU countries to this document. This will only strengthen the use of this international instrument, to which more than 90 countries have already signed up, for the benefit of children. Their abduction cases are very complicated, emotional and mentally extremely challenging for children and their drivers. I am therefore unequivocal – and in view of the ever closer links between the countries of the Union and the rest of the world – in order to grant the European Parliament's consent to the accession of the eight states to the Hague Convention. And I am also glad that negotiations are already underway on the accession of other States to this Convention. It is our duty to support all actions that will help the next generation.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the ease with which borders are crossed between States today can, in cases of couple crises, be a problem, if not a danger to minors and to the parent who suffers the illegal abduction of his infra-life child. The available statistics, although obsolete, indicate a worrying increase in the phenomenon. Unfortunately, recourse to the national court does not provide adequate guarantees of the settlement of the crisis other than within a framework of judicial cooperation between different States. Outside relations between Eu ropean Union Member States, where the Brussels IIa Regulation applies, only the multilateral mechanisms provided for in the Hague Convention provide the legal instruments necessary for the return of the child. Today we see the opportunity to extend to eight other States the guarantees provided for in the Hague Convention, an instrument which, without wishing to ignore the economic complexities of international judicial procedures, has been significantly successful. However, I believe that we must take advantage of the opportunity offered by this debate to rekindle the spotlight on a phenomenon as dramatic as it is widespread, which can have very serious consequences for the health and safety of the child, but also for the parents involved, and which must always be resolved while safeguarding the supreme interest of the child. That is why I think it is necessary not only to update the statistics but also to take every political and legislative initiative useful to combat this phenomenon both within the Union, by promoting the revision of the Brussels IIIa Regulation and externally, by promoting the accession of other third countries to the Hague Convention.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Madam President, the 1980 Hague Convention is a good treaty, because it has the merit of combating international child abduction. That is why all the Member States of the European Union have ratified it. The accession to this convention of eight additional countries, including Morocco and Russia, is therefore good news. But in my view, the acceptance of their accession is the exclusive competence of the States, not the Union, as the European Court of Justice has said, in an abusive and scandalous manner. The Hague Convention itself reserves this decision for the States. The draft resolution being discussed today is therefore merely a pitiful attempt to make it appear that the Union would be competent to lead accession, while public international law reserves this prerogative for its Member States. The Union must learn to respect the law.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: Sinjura President, huma ftit l-affarijiet li jżibu niket aktar mill-kwistjonijiet relatati mal-ťtif tat-tfal mill-żenituri tagťhom, jiżifieri meta żenitur wieťed jieťu lit-tifel jew ti barrafla mill-pajjiż b'mod illegali. Aktar minn disgťin pajjiż - inklużi l-Istati Members kollha tal-Unjoni Ewropea - iffirmaw il-Konvenzjoni tal-Aja titra l-aspetti σivili ta' σtif ta' tfal tas-sena 1980, li l-gťan tagťha huwa li dawn it-tfal jmorru lura qawwijin u sťať fl-inqas żmien possibbli. U gťalhekk nispera illi gťada aťna nkunu nistgťu nirrikonoxxu b'mod formal l-adeżjoni ta' tmien pajjiżi oťra f'din il-Konvenzjoni, sabiex niżguraw li tingťata protezzjoni xierqa u assoluta lil dawn it-tfal malajr kemm jista' jkun. Gťaldaqstant nixtieq nuri l-appożż ż personali tiegťi gťal dawn ir-rapporti u nispera li gťada ningťaqdu kollha flimkien b'mażżżoranza assoluta sabiex napprovaw dawn ir-rapporti. Dan gťandu jibgťat messażżťʻar lil kulťadd li l-protezzjoni tat-tfal hija prijorità gťalina l-Members tal-Parlament Ewropew.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Madam President! Thanks to Mrs Hautala, but also to the former rapporteur, Eva Lichtenberger, for the work done on child abductions. Seven call signs should be behind it. It is about the best interests of the child. I say this because national vanities should not be in the foreground here, but it happens again and again, and that is, of course, the message to the Member States in this context. That is why the Commission has rightly presented the decision on the accession of the eight countries as the exclusive competence of the European Union. Of course, we now also have the support of the European Court of Justice's argument that matters that clearly fall within the EU are the competence of the European Union in external relations. I would also like to echo Mr Zwiefka's call: the Brussels II regulation is awaiting such innovation. Please take this up!

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: The application of the Hague Convention helps to ensure the immediate return of children wrongfully relocated or detained. The accession of eight more states to the Convention is good news for children, because it means more protection and legal certainty for them. Families where parents come from different countries are increasing, and even these families do not avoid disputes and breakups. These disputes can sometimes include the abduction of a child abroad. However, I know from practice that sometimes it can be a short-circuit procedure in which the parent does not realise that travel without the consent of the other parent may be required for the abduction. I believe that it is precisely these types of situations that we should try to prevent. Where possible, let us focus on preventive and consistent information on the possible consequences of taking children abroad. I believe that we will be able to prevent, at least in part, the abductions and thus to protect the best interests of the child.

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: Madam President, protecting the rights and interests of children must be our priority and the EU has already done a lot, but one thing has just got a lot worse. This is the European hotline for missing children, 116 000, launched by the Commission in 2007, but this January the funding was cut.  The 116 000 number is an essential tool in tackling international child abduction, providing a vital source of practical and emotional support for families and vulnerable children. It allows organisations to work together across country borders to locate missing children and reconnect them with their place of safety. In the UK alone, the charity Missing People received over 50 000 calls, texts and emails last year. Cutting the funding for this service means calls will go unanswered and missing children will be deprived of that vital lifeline. I urge the Commission and Member States to restore this funding for the missing children hotline so it can continue.

name: Petr MACH
text: Commissioner, the convention we are discussing here is intended to ensure the return of children who have been abducted abroad by one of their parents. But what if it's not the parent who kidnapped and detained the child, what if it's the state? I am talking about the case of Eva Michaláková, a Czech citizen whose children were taken away in Norway by the Barnevernet social office and detained for several years, even though the children are Czech citizens and their mother has not committed any crime. For example, I can name Alexandra Hasselström from Sweden or Grażyna Leschinskene from Lithuania. They are desperate mothers to whom the state has taken away their children without mothers blaming them. I believe that in Europe we should respect two fundamental principles: firstly, the principle of the presumption of innocence – when it turns out that the parent did not understand anything, the children should be immediately returned to the family, secondly, the fact that the children do not belong to the state – when the children cannot be cared for by the parent and the grandmother or aunt are willing to take care of them, they should take precedence.  That is why I call on the Commissioner to please discuss the Convention ... (She removed the speaker's word.)

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: One of the biggest social problems facing all the countries of the world, especially the countries of Europe, is the abduction of children. The ability of large numbers of people to travel to different countries of the world, the increase in marriages between people from different countries and the limited custody of parents to children, due to their obligation to work long hours a day and many times in different places, are the main reasons why children are abducted. Children's abductions are usually carried out either to demand a ransom for their release or to make them subject to various forms of exploitation, such as illegal work, drug trafficking, organ removal and even to be used as soldiers by various terrorist organisations in the Middle East and Africa. Remarkable are the abductions of children by their own parents and their transfer to countries other than those of their place of residence. The impact on the mental world of abducted children is many and significant. Most of the time they are forced to live in other countries in a way different from the one they are used to, to try to communicate in a language other than their own and not be able to have dreams about the future. For all these reasons, they feel insecurity, oppression, fear, anguish and lose confidence in the world. Child abductions must be tackled and condemned by all countries. Unfortunately, so far, even in the Hague Convention, the problem is being addressed ... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Emil RADEV
text: Madam President, the need for measures that improve effective cooperation between national judicial authorities is one of the problems we need to work on to make the implementation of the Hague Convention more effective and to minimise problems in its implementation. the enforcement of judgments given in other Member States often proves difficult due to differences between procedural standards, such as those regarding the hearing of the child; cooperation between central authorities of countries also needs to be improved. All these problems manifested itself in a single case, which was presented very recently to the Committee on Petitions. Dear colleagues, we are discussing today the forced removal of one child from one parent without the consent of the other. We condemn these practices. But what do we do when it comes to forcibly taking a child away and giving that child adoption without the consent of his parents. Action carried out not by traffickers but by a court in a Member State of the European Union. Dear colleagues, I assure you, it is possible and becoming common practice in British courts. Two weeks ago, such a case was presented to the Committee on Petitions - Megan's case. In addition to the parental rights being taken away from both parents, they were also denied to the child's grandmother in a clear breach of its procedural rules. Where is the interest of the child we are all talking about in this particular case and until when will we be silent witnesses of this vicious practice of the British courts?

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, children's rights are always our top priority, in this case as in so many others. As all the surveys and statistics, even the most backward ones, show, the phenomenon we are discussing is bound to increase. The mobility between people that spreads leads to many mixed marriages and separation almost always discharges as an element of tension of various kinds and of various configuration on minors. So it is very important that tomorrow we approve the proposal that has been made, woe betide you if that is not the case. But we must acknowledge that the instruments at our disposal are no longer sufficient. I think that the Hague Convention is very fine and has produced important results, and I believe that the Brussels II Regulation must be fully effective, but I also believe that we must start thinking about how to regulate processes of this nature because, if we really want children's rights to prevail, we must also update our instruments.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! Parents from different countries separate and argue for their child. A terrible argument. Parental rights and the best interests of the child are equally affected and must be taken into account. The 1980 Hague Convention on International Child Abduction is an effective tool in resolving similar cases. It has one objective: it is essential to have legal certainty in such disputes, and the Convention contributes to this. That is why it makes perfect sense to extend the Convention to include other countries. It improves legal certainty in a dispute over what is most valuable to parents, even when they separate: their children. It is gratifying that countries such as Russia are also prepared to accede to the agreement. The fact that Russia is involved in the debate on international child abduction and has an interest in acceding to the Hague Convention shows that the problem is important enough to overcome current political differences between Russia and the EU.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Madam President, if you ask children except in cases of severe abuse, children want both parents, children need a father and a mother and if the child's welfare is at heart for parents regardless of divorce they will agree on the care of the child. Parents are simply expected to be parents, and we are aware that this is not always the case and this is evidenced by cases at european union level, which is somewhere around 3 000 cases where one parent took the child to another country without the consent of the other parent. In such circumstances, the child is exposed to quite a mental and physical danger, which is why such abduction can also be characterized as child abuse. The primary international instrument intended to protect children from adverse effects, their illegal removal or detention across the border is the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil-legal aspects of international child abduction. Including Croatia, this multilateral agreement currently has 93 co-signate countries, a number that will surely grow thanks to improved cooperation within international structures and the passage of time.  By establishing a Mediator of the European Parliament who became a member in 2014, we have already shown that the European Parliament contributes greatly to preventing international abductions. However, I believe that the number of abducted children could be further reduced if we increase the number of co-signate states and thus ensure the legal and health well-being of each child.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul The increased mobility in the world has given people very good opportunities to travel and move between national borders, and so we build relationships between each other and families formed. Unfortunately, sometimes these relationships end with a divorce between parents, where a child is also taken out of a country and the child is the subject of an international kidnapping.  Regardless of what has happened between the parents, the best interests of the child must always be taken into account in all decisions concerning children. The wrongful abduction of a child is not just a criminal act – it also constitutes a brutalisation towards the child psychologically, even if the parent considers himself to be committing that act for the good of his child. It is therefore gratifying that more countries want to accede to the 1980 Hague Convention through international cooperation, we can ensure the speeding return of wrongfully abducted children.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: Madam President, the Convention is crucial for at least two reasons. Firstly it involves the well-being and custody of children, which should be our priority, and secondly it touches upon the differences between the legal systems of individual states. It is sad but true that, in instances of the separation of parents originating from different states, very often the lack of cooperation between those states is used as a tool for securing the custody of a child. This Convention aims to resolve this problem by establishing competent courts and applying the law of the state of residence of the said child. I would like to take this opportunity to underline that child abduction is not only the problem of third countries. In the Committee on Petitions we receive plenty of signals from EU citizens regarding cases of forced adoptions and child abductions. In fact this problem touches upon so many cross-cultural families that this has been established as a matter of urgency in our committee. Last but not least I think it is very important to promote the role of the European Parliament Mediator for Parental Child Abduction and join our efforts in protecting the most defenceless EU citizens.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Madam President! I would like to express my support for my colleague, Mr Wasa, in his speech, and I would also like to draw attention to this problem once again in the context of my political work in the Committee on Petitions. Custody, divorce law and adoption law are the responsibility of the Member States and are applied very differently. This leads to grotesque and really creepy situations, especially in divorce cases in interstate marriages. Once again, I would like to call for harmonisation within the European Union. We harmonise the economy, we harmonise money, we harmonise working life. We should also harmonise the rights of children in the European Union. Worse still, there is an opt-out within the framework of these responsibilities of the Member States. For example, Denmark invokes such an opt-out and refuses to apply the Brussels II Agreement. This also hinders the mutual extradition of abducted children. And in the United Kingdom – as a colleague has also mentioned – children are forcibly adopted, against the will of parents or close relatives, which is not possible in other Member States. This is unacceptable to me. What do we need? Firstly, a comprehensive obligation to provide information in the Member States and, secondly, harmonisation!

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Madam President, Commissioner, at a time when travelling is becoming easier and mixed marriages are commonplace, it is important to continue to put pressure on all governments to take up this problem and ratify this convention. Until this is done, many children will continue to endure a life they have not chosen and have their dreams turned into lost illusions or even nightmares. We all know here that when the abducted child is most in need of a family to build, he or she is suffering real trauma, devastating psychological abuse. Not only is he forced into a new country, a new culture and, sometimes, a new language, but he is deprived of one of his parents, part of his family. All of these things are an obvious threat to the well-being of the child, which must be actively combated. That is why I am pleased that countries such as Morocco and Gabon are joining the list of signatories. In these times of extreme tension on the African continent, these two countries are leading the way, and we must support them so that they can lead others in their wake. The scourge of abductions must be fought with greater force because let us not forget that on the African continent... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Madam President, my role in tonight’s debate is really to address the work I do as the Parliament’s International Parental Child Abduction Mediator and it is in that context that I would say the following. The theory behind the Hague Convention is that it is a perfect instrument, but in practice it is not so. The length of time is now much longer for children to be returned than the 42 days that is recommended. Equally with Brussels II – and I would ask the Commission to take on board our request to have this review of its implementation, because Member States differ in interpretation, and indeed in their commitment to this issue. The Committee on Petitions is a good barometer of what is happening across the Member States on this issue. My office receives at least one contact from a distressed parent every single week. We help where we can by mediating, but I believe that this issue is much greater than we understand, and I think that this Parliament has a duty of care to be involved in it and to make things happen.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: Madam President, the main purpose of the Hague Convention is the swift return of a child to his or her habitual residence. In the EU, a court decision is supposed to be taken within six weeks. However, according to Child Focus, it takes an average of one year for an international child abduction case to be resolved. Alongside the legal track of the Hague Convention, I am convinced that mediation between parents is crucial. If successful, mediation is less costly, more durable and can avoid the unnecessary relocation of the child. The Commission should therefore continue to fund projects and the training of mediators who operate in an international context. I would also like to urge the Commission to pay attention to the problem of stateless children. Even though the place of residence is determined by the court decision, the vulnerable situation of these children requires targeted action.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Hague Convention is a fundamental instrument for ensuring the return of children unlawfully transferred or detained abroad by a parent and for ensuring respect for the rights of custody and visitation in all States. My country, Italy, was the only country to support, even before the Court intervened, the Exclusive Competence of the Union in this field, in the knowledge of the need for full regulatory and operational coordination between States in order to avoid approaches aimed at protecting the parent's own citizen to the detriment of the interests of the child. The accession of the new eight States must certainly be welcomed. For good cooperation, however, we need, as a matter of priority, central authorities that can really be used as a reference for administrative cooperation.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the accession of eight states to the 1980 Hague Convention on The Civil Matters of International Child Abduction is an important political and legal development. This multilateral convention raises at an international level the problem of child abduction which very often occurs in the context of separated couples and determines the competent courts and laws of the child's State of residence.  This issue is particularly serious and concerns a significant proportion of citizens in the Member States of the European Union. According to the Cyprus Parliamentary Committee on Human Rights, many Cypriot women, married to third-country nationals, are living their own drama, since more than 2,500 children have been illegally abducted by foreign fathers. So here is a grim example of why the choral extension of this international convention is important.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we welcome Mrs Hautala's report, which is a job well done and on which we will certainly vote in favour. It is clear, as my fellow Members have already pointed out to a large extent, that when we talk about an issue of fundamental importance, such as the abduction of children, we are talking about a priority issue for what the European Union's policies must be. The psychophysical well-being of children must be at the heart of our concerns, and this is clear, especially if we report it with a change that is there in the world with respect to this same case. Because it is clear that globalisation and the ease with which we move leads to new problems and the phenomenon of subtraction is an increasing phenomenon. These are certain data that we have, just as it is certain that trafficking in children has also increased, so we also welcome the enlargement of the Hague Convention and are working towards an urgent revision of the Brussels II Regulation.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Madam President, I welcome the accession of Albania, Andorra, Armenia, the Russian Federation, Singapore, Morocco, Gabon and the Seysela to the Hague Convention on civil-legal aspects of international child abduction.  While the extension of the current system is desirable, I believe that the Union must first and foremost work on its qualitative aspects given the nature of its competences. The courts of the state in which the child was forcibly removed cannot decide on the matter of the proceedings, but only on the return to the home country. It is clear that even in the best faith, such procedures can last several months each, which creates additional traumas in both the child and the injured parent.  Our priority should therefore be to increase efficiency in cooperation with national judicial authorities, because any procrastination, including one behind which there is not disingeliance or insensitivity, but a mere sluggishness of the system, is a kind of form of violence towards children who have already suffered enough.

name: Janusz WOJCIECHOWSKI
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. We are pleased that more countries are acceding to the Hague Convention. This convention must be read together with the Convention on the Rights of the Child (UN Convention of 1989), where beautiful words have been expressed that the child has the right to education in happiness, love and understanding. These are perhaps the only legal acts of international law where the word love has legal meaning. The Hague Convention is important to prevent child abduction, but it is also important to bear in mind its very important Article 13, which states that even in the event of child abduction, if there is a serious risk that the return of a child would expose them to physical or psychological harm or otherwise put them in an unbearable situation, then these provisions must not be applied. These are very important provisions that need to be borne in mind.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, honourable Members, I would like to thank you very much for the discussion and the comments, which we will take into consideration in our work. I would like very briefly to inform you about the latest news and development in this issue. We are now considering an additional six new accessions which are not included in the package of eight proposals. On 21 January, the Commission organised a meeting with the experts from the Member States in order to decide the approach to be adopted. I have to say that the Member States showed a very positive and collaborative attitude and this gives me hope that there will be smooth cooperation in this recurring exercise. The first step will be the gathering of information on the six new acceding countries so as to prepare the ground for the Commission proposals. The Latvian Presidency concluded that a unified EU approach is needed on this file as well as a set of minimum benchmarks to allow for a swift and pragmatic solution concerning the proposal under discussion. The discussions will continue at the next General Affairs Council meeting on 18 March 2015.  I would like to assure you of my determination to work to ensure that children are protected and their rights enforced. I count on your support and engagement in this common aim. I would also like to express my hope that you will support this proposal tomorrow.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Rapporteur. - (FI) Mr President, it is very pleasing to say that we will probably be adopting these eight identical reports almost unanimously tomorrow, and then we expect the Council to take swift action, and we trust Commissioner Jourová that this will actually happen. A couple of comments on the debate: Mr Lebreton indicated that, despite everything, it would be better for these issues to fall within the competence of the Member States in the EU. But let us consider it from the point of view that the Commission is still in a much better position to ensure that the legislation and operational capacity of the new state that acceded to the Convention are actually monitored on behalf of the Member States before accession is adopted. In other hand, I believe that, although these acceding countries may have a capacity gap and may sometimes have little lack of political desire, it is precisely the fact that this issue is undoubtedly a matter for the EU to deal with, that also gives the Commission an obligation to monitor how these other countries operate in this matter. Honeyball is no longer here, but we have just had a discussion with her that it is not so simple that when we here simply give our assent to these accessions on our own behalf, things will then move forward. Indeed, it is the case – as the honourable Members have said here – that Members of this House and Parliament must monitor how, on this important issue, which is often shocking to people's daily lives, namely child abduction, third countries are practically able to do the right thing. Finally, thank You For giving Mr McGuinnes a practical voice to this debate. He told us what the difficulties are, that an agreement is one thing and the other is how it works in practice. Then let's focus on that in the future.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, February 11, 2015 at 12:00 p.m. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – As evidenced by the painful current events with regard to our Lithuanian children in Norway, the Hague Convention on International Child Abduction, which complements the Convention on the Protection of Children, is essential for the protection of the child's interests and rights, since the Convention provides for the immediate return of abducted children to their country of residence. This Hague Convention is important in that it establishes a framework within which participating States can cooperate in order to find solutions in cases of international child abduction. It also provides for the courts competent and what applicable law when deciding on the child's place of residence. Most importantly, it is this Convention that provides for the prompt return of abducted children to their country of residence. In most cases, these problems occur when the couple divorced. If the mother and father come from different countries, there is a desire to take advantage of the lack of cooperation between these states in order to secure custody of the child. In these cases, the national bias of the legal systems of individual countries is the biggest problem. Often, the courts of both states recognise themselves as competent to hear the case and each child is cared for by a parent who is a national of their state. This area falls within the exclusive external competence of the EU. Member States therefore no longer have the right to act on their own initiative. The biggest problem is that the Convention does not provide for the possibility of independent action by international organisations.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. – Preventing child abduction should be an essential part of EU policy to promote the rights of the child. The rights of the child should be a priority. The best interests of the child over parents must be primed. The EU must continue to work internationally to improve the implementation of the 1980 Convention and encourage other States to accede. For this reason, we welcome the news that eight new States (Gabon, Andorra, Seychelles, Russia, Albania, Singapore, Morocco and Armenia) are subject to the common legal framework emanating from this Convention. My position, of course, is in favour of these decisions entering into force and, therefore, extending the scope of this Convention. I hope that the process will be closed as soon as possible within the Council, that it will not be extended over time and that the applicant countries will finally join. A slowdown in this process goes against children's rights, leaving them unsealed. That's why we have to act quickly

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. – Mr President, the report under discussion raises very important issues relating to the civil aspects of international child abduction. This is regulated by the 1980 Hague Convention. Today, the European Parliament is making decisions on the accession of as many as 8 new States to this Convention. I think there should n't even be any doubt. The more countries adopt international standards on this issue, the better it will be for children. After all, family is one of the fundamental values of society, and the institutions should protect it also through legal means, especially in protecting the best interests of children. According to the latest Eurostat data, as many as 140 000 families of different nationalities stand out in the European Union each year. It is increasingly the case that former spouses settle in different countries, including outside the European Union, and children are abducted by a parent. For this reason, the Hague Convention is an important tool for establishing a way of enabling States to cooperate in the resolution of kidnapping. The biggest problem in such cases is the attitude of the state's legal system. It often happens that the courts recognise the custody of a child to the father who holds the nationality of the country in which the court is located. The purpose of this Convention is to remedy such situations. The accession of 8 new countries to the Convention is a reason to be happy, because the point is that children are protected around the world.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. – In the last ten years, there have been more cases where a child is wrongfully transferred or abducted by a second parent to another state. In this situation, a parent seeking the return of a child often encounters a problem with the recognition of a decision of a court of one State in the state where the child was wrongfully transferred. I therefore consider the connection of the other 8 states to the 1980 Hague Convention to be the right step to help clarify these irregularities and thus improve the civil situation in dealing with abducted children. My country often faces the problem of abducted children to the countries of the former Soviet Union, especially Russia. I am therefore very glad that Russia is the signatory to this convention and I believe that this will strengthen its cooperation with the Czech Republic and other EU countries.
